column1: * [http://books.google.com/books?id=ztidaaaambaj&pg=pa59&lpg=pa59&dq=vic+davalillo+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=c37nplqurr&sig=myelndf4_yxlq7_bazfzr8o37py&hl=en&ei=n_bbsu71bsbv8aayzex-ca&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4#v=onepage&q=vic%20davalillo%20baseball%20digest&f=false smoky burgess baseball digest article december 1963]

born in [[caroleen, north carolina|caroleen]], [[north carolina]], burgess was signed as an amateur [[free agent]] by the [[chicago cubs]] in [[1944 chicago cubs season|1944]].<ref name=smoky burgess trades and transactions at baseball almanac>[http://www.baseball-almanac.com/players/trades.php?p=burgesm01 smoky burgess trades and transactions at baseball almanac]</ref> in 1947, he led the [[tri-state league]] with a .387 [[batting average]].<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/minors/leader.cgi?type=bat&id=14341 1947 tri-state league batting leaders at baseball reference]</ref> he followed that by leading the [[southern association]] with a .386 average in 1948.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/minors/leader.cgi?type=bat&id=14022 1948 southern association batting leaders at baseball reference]</ref> he broke into the majors in [[1949 chicago cubs season|1949]] with the cubs.<ref name=smoky burgess at baseball reference/> in october [[1951 chicago cubs season|1951]], he was traded to the cincinnati reds, who promptly traded him to the philadelphia phillies for catcher [[andy seminick]] before the start of the [[1952 philadelphia phillies season|1952]] season.<ref name=smoky burgess trades and transactions at baseball almanac/> with the phillies, he [[platoon system|platooned]] alongside the right-hand hitting [[stan lopata]].<ref name=''catcher with the highest average''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=ztidaaaambaj&pg=pa59&dq=smoky+burgess+baseball+digest&cd=2#v=onepage&q=smoky%20burgess%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''catcher with the highest average'', by ed rumill, baseball digest, december 1963, vol. 10, issn 0005-609x]</ref> he had his best season in [[1954 philadelphia phillies season|1954]], when he had a .368 batting average in 108 games for the phillies, earning his first [[1954 major league baseball all-star game|all-star game]] selection.<ref name=smoky burgess at baseball reference/><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/als/als195407130.shtml 1954 all-star game at baseball reference]</ref>

at the beginning of the [[1955 cincinnati reds season|1955]] season, he was once again traded for [[andy seminick]] and returned to cincinnati, where he finally got the chance to play every day.<ref name=smoky burgess trades and transactions at baseball almanac/><ref name=''catcher with the highest average''/> he rose to the occasion, hitting for a .306 [[batting average]] for the rest of the season along with 20 [[home run]]s and 77 [[runs batted in]], gaining his second consecutive berth on the national league [[1955 major league baseball all-star game|all-star]] team.<ref name=smoky burgess at baseball reference/><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/nls/nls195507120.shtml 1955 all-star game at baseball reference]</ref> on july 29, [[1955 cincinnati reds season|1955]], burgess hit three home runs and had nine runs batted in during a game against the pittsburgh pirates.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/cin/cin195507290.shtml july 29, 1955 pirates-reds box score at baseball reference]</ref> burgess began the [[1956 cincinnati reds season|1956]] season as the reds' starting catcher, but when the team faltered early in the season, reds [[manager (baseball)|manager]] [[birdie tebbetts]] decided to shake things up and replaced burgess in favor of a younger [[ed bailey]].<ref name=''bailey- next catching great?''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=tswdaaaambaj&pg=pa49&dq=ed+bailey+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=9yautpite4gklwfxxpxada&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0ccgq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=ed%20bailey%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''bailey- next catching great?'', by bob pile, baseball digest, august 1956, vol. 15, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref>

over his career, burgess played in 1691 [[games played|games]] hitting for a .295 career [[batting average]] with 126 [[home run]]s, 673 [[runs batted in|rbi]] and a .362 [[on base percentage]]. he accumulated 1318 career [[hit (baseball)|hits]] with 230 [[double (baseball)|doubles]] and 33 [[triple (baseball)|triples]].<ref name=smoky burgess at baseball reference/> his .295 career batting average ranked him 10th among major league catchers as of 2006.<ref>[http://members.tripod.com/bb_catchers/catchers/careerld.htm career batting leaders for catchers at encyclopedia of baseball]</ref> a six-time [[major league baseball all-star game|all-star]], burgess led national league catchers in [[fielding percentage]] three times, in [[1953 philadelphia phillies season|1953]], [[1960 pittsburgh pirates season|1960]] and [[1961 pittsburgh pirates season|1961]].<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa86&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, july 2001, p.86, vol. 60, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref> his major league record of 145 career pinch hits was broken by [[manny mota]] in {{by|1979}}. along with [[curt simmons]], he was the last player to formally retire who had played in the major leagues in the 1940s (not counting [[minnie mioso]], who un-retired twice).

* [http://books.google.com/books?id=my4daaaambaj&pg=pa41&dq=smoky+burgess+baseball+digest&cd=3#v=onepage&q=smoky%20burgess%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''catcher with a belly'', by frank yeutter, baseball digest, may 1953]

* [http://books.google.com/books?id=ztidaaaambaj&pg=pa59&dq=smoky+burgess+baseball+digest&cd=2#v=onepage&q=smoky%20burgess%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''catcher with the highest average'', by ed rumill, baseball digest, december 1963]

* [http://books.google.com/books?id=xdidaaaambaj&pg=pa65&dq=smoky+burgess+baseball+digest&cd=1#v=onepage&q=smoky%20burgess%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''the buddha with the clutch touch'', by francis stan, baseball digest, july 1966]

* [http://books.google.com/books?id=xdidaaaambaj&pg=pa65&dq=smoky+burgess+baseball+digest&cd=1#v=onepage&q=smoky%20burgess%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''the buddha with the clutch touch'', by francis stan, baseball digest, july 1966]

he continued to manage the cubs through the {{by|1940}} season. in 1941 he left to play for, and coach, the [[san francisco giants|new york giants]], hitting .300 in his final year as a player. he ended his 20-year career with a .297 batting average and a .489 slugging percentage; his 236 home runs, 1179 runs batted in, 1912 hits, and 396 doubles were all records for catchers. he also finished among the national league's top ten in [[slugging percentage]] seven times in his career. hartnett led [[national league]] catchers in [[fielding percentage]] six times, including four consecutive seasons from [[1934 chicago cubs season|1934]] to [[1937 chicago cubs season|1937]].<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa86&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, july 2001, vol. 60, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref> he set a national league record with 163 [[double play]]s over his career.<ref>[http://members.tripod.com/bb_catchers/catchers/fielding_misc.htm catchers' fielding records at the encyclopedia of baseball catchers]</ref> hartnett's bat and catcher's mask were the first artifacts sent to the newly constructed [[baseball hall of fame]] in 1938.

hartnett hit 24 home runs in {{by|1925}}, setting a single-season home run record for catchers and, finished second overall in the national league behind the 39 home runs hit by [[rogers hornsby]].<ref name=record for most home runs by a catcher>{{cite web |url=http://www.sabr.org/sabr.cfm?a=cms,c,734,34,0 |title=record for most home runs by a catcher |publisher=sabr.org |accessdate=12 february 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1925-batting-leaders.shtml |title=1925 national league batting leaders |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=12 february 2011 }}</ref> although he led national league catchers in [[error (baseball)|errors]], he also led in [[range factor]] and in [[putout]]s, while his strong throwing arm helped him lead the league in [[assist (baseball)|assists]], and in [[caught stealing]] percentage.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1925-fielding-leaders.shtml |title=1925 national league fielding leaders |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=12 february 2011 }}</ref> [[leo durocher]], who played against hartnett and was a national league manager during johnny bench's career, stated that the two catchers had similarly strong throwing arms.<ref name=baseball's all-time greatest catchers>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ezmdaaaambaj&pg=pa52&dq=gabby+hartnett+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=4cxwtajultoutwfhm42jdq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0ccuq6aewadgk#v=onepage&q=gabby%20hartnett%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=baseball's all-time greatest catchers |author=haag, irv |publisher=books.google.com |date=april 1973 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=12 february 2011 }}</ref> during the major league baseball [[william veeck, sr.|bill veeck, sr.]], squelched the rumors saying that hartnett would not be traded for anybody.<ref>{{cite news |title=many big trades expected at meet |agency=i.n.s. |work=the on september 28, {{by|1938}}, the two teams met for the second game of the series where, hartnett experienced the highlight of his career. with darkness descending on the lightless [[wrigley field]] and the score tied at 5 runs apiece, the umpires ruled that the ninth [[inning (baseball)|inning]] would be the last to be played. the entire game would have to be replayed the following day if the score remained tied. hartnett came to bat with two [[out (baseball)|out]] in the bottom of the ninth inning. with a count of 0 balls and 2 strikes, hartnett connected on a [[mace brown]] pitch, launching the ball into the darkness, before it eventually landed in the left-center field [[bleachers]]. the stadium erupted into pandemonium as players and fans stormed the field to escort hartnett around the bases.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ftqdaaaambaj&pg=pa32&dq=gabby+hartnett+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=fyfbtbjoesibtge619gycw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0ccyq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=gabby%20hartnett%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=when gabby hartnett hit his homer in the gloamin' |author=carmichael, john |publisher=books.google.com |date=october 1978 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=16 february 2011 }}</ref> hartnett's [[walk-off home run]] became immortalized as the ''[[homer in the gloamin']]''.<ref name=homer in the gloamin'/>

hartnett hit 24 home runs in {{by|1925}}, breaking the single-season home run record for catchers set by [[jack clements]] in {{by|1893}}.<ref name=record for most home runs by a catcher>{{cite web |url=http://rockymtn.sabr.org/sabr.cfm?a=cms,c,734,3,158 |title=record for most home runs by a catcher |publisher=sabr.org |accessdate=12 february 2011 }}</ref> he finished second overall in the national league behind the 39 home runs hit by [[rogers hornsby]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1925-batting-leaders.shtml |title=1925 national league batting leaders |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=12 february 2011 }}</ref> although he led national league catchers in [[error (baseball)|errors]], he also led in [[range factor]] and in [[putout]]s, at the time of his retirement, hartnett's 236 home runs, 1,179 runs batted in, 1,912 hits, and 396 doubles were all records for catchers.<ref name=record for most home runs by a catcher/> [[bill dickey]] surpassed his records for most runs batted in and hits in {{by|1943}}, while his career home run record for catchers was broken by [[yogi berra]] in {{by|1956}}.<ref name=record for most home runs by a catcher/> his career mark for doubles stood until {{by|1983}} when it was broken by [[ted simmons]].<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=wssdaaaambaj&pg=pa9&lpg=pa9&dq=ted+simmons+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=z0osofu9-u&sig=4ns_bz40i6l40iiqtbdigespays&hl=en&ei=2x9-ti3hbchflgftv5dscw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0ccsq6aewbzgk#v=onepage&q=ted%20simmons%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=how ted simmons rates with hall of fame catchers |publisher=baseball digest |accessdate=27 june 2012 }}</ref> hartnett also finished among the national league's top ten in slugging percentage seven times in his career.<ref name=gabby hartnett statistics/> a six-time all-star, he was the recipient of one most valuable player award and played on four pennant-winning teams.<ref name=gabby hartnett statistics/> hartnett's .370 career on base percentage was higher than the .342 posted by johnny bench or, the .348 posted by yogi berra.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/b/benchjo01.shtml |title=johnny bench career statistics |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=16 february 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/b/berrayo01.shtml |title=yogi berra career statistics |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=16 february 2011 }}</ref> his bat and catcher's mask were the first artifacts sent to the newly constructed [[baseball hall of fame]] in {{by|1938}}.<ref name=gabby hartnett at the baseball page/>

'''rickey eugene reuschel''' (pronounced rush-el) (born [[may 16]] [[1949]] in [[quincy, illinois]]) is a former [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] [[pitcher]] from the early 1970s into the late 1980s.<ref name=rick reuschel at baseball reference>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/r/reuscri01.shtml?redir rick reuschel at baseball reference]</ref><ref name=rick reuschel at the baseball cube>[http://www.thebaseballcube.com/players/r/rick-reuschel.shtml rick reuschel at the baseball cube]</ref> his nickname was ''big daddy'' because of his portly physique.<ref name=rick reuschel at the baseball page>[http://www.thebaseballpage.com/players/reuscri01.php rick reuschel at the baseball page]</ref> he was known for his deceptive style of pitching, which kept [[hitter]]s off balance by constantly varying the speeds of his pitches.<ref name=''rick reuschel: he lets batter get himself out''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=sjqdaaaambaj&pg=pa77&dq=baseball+digest+rick+reuschel#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20rick%20reuschel&f=false ''rick reuschel: he lets batter get himself out'' by casey tefertiller, baseball digest, december 1988, vol. 47, no. 12, issn 0005-609x]</ref>

reuschel was signed by the [[pittsburgh pirates]] in [[1985 pittsburgh pirates season|1985]] as a [[free agent]],<ref name=rick reuschel trades and transactions at baseball almanac/> and had a 14-8 won-loss record with the last-place pirates,<ref name=rick reuschel at baseball reference/> earning him the national league's [[comeback player of the year]] award.<ref name=the comeback player of the year award at baseball almanac>[http://www.baseball-almanac.com/awards/comeback_player_of_the_year_award.shtml the comeback player of the year award at baseball almanac]</ref><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=qtqdaaaambaj&pg=pa34&dq=baseball+digest+rick+reuschel#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20rick%20reuschel&f=false ''how perseverence paid off for rick reuschel'' by al doyle, baseball digest, may 1986, vol. 45, no. 5, issn 0005-609x]</ref> the pirates traded reuschel to the [[san francisco giants]] in late [[1987 pittsburgh pirates season|1987]] for [[jeff robinson (relief pitcher)|jeff robinson]] and [[scott medvin]].<ref name=rick reuschel trades and transactions at baseball almanac/> reuschel, finally back with a contender, became the ace of the giants' staff and helped them make a late run to the national league western division title, their first division title since [[1971 san francisco giants season|1971]]. he followed that season by winning 19 games for the giants in 1988.<ref name=rick reuschel at baseball reference/><ref name=''rick reuschel: he lets batter get himself out''/> in [[1989 san francisco giants season|1989]], reuschel won 17 games for the giants as he helped lead them to the [[1989 world series|world series]] (their first since [[1962 world series|1962]]).<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1989_ws.shtml 1989 world series at baseball reference]</ref> in the [[1989 world series]], reuschel was the losing pitcher in game 2 with an 11.25 [[earned run average|era]], five earned runs, and five hits given up against the [[oakland athletics]].<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/oak/oak198910150.shtml 1989 world series game 2 box score at baseball reference]</ref> in [[1989 in baseball|1989]] at the age of 40, reuschel was selected as the starting pitcher for the national league in the [[1989 major league baseball all-star game|1989 all-star game]], and gave up a lead off [[home run]] to [[bo jackson]], followed by [[wade boggs]]' home run to start the game.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/als/als198907110.shtml 1989 major league all-star game box score at baseball reference]</ref>

in a 19-year career, reuschel compiled a record of 214-191 in 557 games (529 starts).<ref name=rick reuschel at baseball reference/> he had 102 career [[complete game]]s and 26 of those were [[shutout]]s. he allowed 1330 [[earned run]]s and 2015  [[strike out]]s in 3548 and 1/3 [[innings pitched]].<ref name=rick reuschel at baseball reference/> reuschel was a two-time [[gold glove award]] winner and a three-time all-star.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/gold_glove_nl.shtml#multi national league gold glove award winners at baseball reference]</ref> as of [[2009 in baseball|2009]], reuschel was is in the [[top 100 winning pitchers of all time]]. reuschel won the [[hutch award]] in [[1985 in sports|1985]],<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/hutch_gehrig_ruth_clemente.shtml hutch award winners at baseball reference]</ref> and was also a winner of [[the sporting news comeback player of the year award]].<ref name=the comeback player of the year award at baseball almanac/> reuschel was named to the [[baseball digest]] 1972 rookie all-star team.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=ytqdaaaambaj&pg=pa30&dq=baseball+digest+rick+reuschel#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20rick%20reuschel&f=false baseball digest, december 1989]</ref>

* [http://books.google.com/books?id=qtqdaaaambaj&pg=pa34&dq=baseball+digest+rick+reuschel#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20rick%20reuschel&f=false ''how perseverence paid off for rick reuschel'' by al doyle, baseball digest, may 1986]

* [http://books.google.com/books?id=sjqdaaaambaj&pg=pa77&dq=baseball+digest+rick+reuschel#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20rick%20reuschel&f=false ''rick reuschel: he lets batter get himself out'' by casey tefertiller, baseball digest, december 1988]

'''rickey eugene reuschel''' (pronounced rush-el) (born may 16, 1949 in [[quincy, illinois]]) is a former [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] [[pitcher]] from the early 1970s into the early 1990s.<ref name=rick reuschel at baseball reference>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/r/reuscri01.shtml?redir rick reuschel at baseball reference]</ref><ref name=rick reuschel at the baseball cube>[http://www.thebaseballcube.com/players/r/rick-reuschel.shtml rick reuschel at the baseball cube]</ref> his nickname was ''big daddy'' because of his portly physique.<ref name=rick reuschel at the baseball page>[http://www.thebaseballpage.com/players/reuscri01.php rick reuschel at the baseball page]</ref> he was known for his deceptive style of pitching, which kept [[hitter]]s off balance by constantly varying the speeds of his pitches.<ref name=''rick reuschel: he lets batter get himself out''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=sjqdaaaambaj&pg=pa77&dq=baseball+digest+rick+reuschel#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20rick%20reuschel&f=false ''rick reuschel: he lets batter get himself out'' by casey tefertiller, baseball digest, december 1988, vol. 47, no. 12, issn 0005-609x]</ref>

reuschel was signed by the [[pittsburgh pirates]] in [[1985 pittsburgh pirates season|1985]] as a [[free agent]],<ref name=rick reuschel trades and transactions at baseball almanac/> and had a 14-8 won-loss record with the last-place pirates,<ref name=rick reuschel at baseball reference/> earning him the national league's [[the sporting news comeback player of the year award|comeback player of the year]] award.<ref name=the comeback player of the year award at baseball almanac>[http://www.baseball-almanac.com/awards/comeback_player_of_the_year_award.shtml the comeback player of the year award at baseball almanac]</ref><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=qtqdaaaambaj&pg=pa34&dq=baseball+digest+rick+reuschel#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20rick%20reuschel&f=false ''how perseverence paid off for rick reuschel'' by al doyle, baseball digest, may 1986, vol. 45, no. 5, issn 0005-609x]</ref> the pirates traded reuschel to the [[san francisco giants]] in late [[1987 pittsburgh pirates season|1987]] for [[jeff robinson (relief pitcher)|jeff robinson]] and [[scott medvin]].<ref name=rick reuschel trades and transactions at baseball almanac/> reuschel, finally back with a contender, became the ace of the giants' staff and helped them make a late run to the national league western division title, their first division title since [[1971 san francisco giants season|1971]]. he followed that season by winning 19 games for the giants in 1988.<ref name=rick reuschel at baseball reference/><ref name=''rick reuschel: he lets batter get himself out''/> in [[1989 san francisco giants season|1989]], reuschel won 17 games for the giants as he helped lead them to the [[1989 world series|world series]] (their first since [[1962 world series|1962]]).<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1989_ws.shtml 1989 world series at baseball reference]</ref> in the [[1989 world series]], reuschel was the losing pitcher in game 2 with an 11.25 [[earned run average|era]], five earned runs, and five hits given up against the [[oakland athletics]].<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/oak/oak198910150.shtml 1989 world series game 2 box score at baseball reference]</ref> in [[1989 in baseball|1989]] at the age of 40, reuschel was selected as the starting pitcher for the national league in the [[1989 major league baseball all-star game|1989 all-star game]], and gave up a lead off [[home run]] to [[bo jackson]], followed by [[wade boggs]]' home run to start the game.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/als/als198907110.shtml 1989 major league all-star game box score at baseball reference]</ref>

in a 19-year career, reuschel compiled a record of 214-191 in 557 games (529 starts).<ref name=rick reuschel at baseball reference/> he had 102 career [[complete game]]s and 26 of those were [[shutout]]s. he allowed 1330 [[earned run]]s and 2015  [[strike out]]s in 3548 and 1/3 [[innings pitched]].<ref name=rick reuschel at baseball reference/> reuschel was a two-time [[gold glove award]] winner and a three-time all-star.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/gold_glove_nl.shtml#multi national league gold glove award winners at baseball reference]</ref> as of [[2009 in baseball|2009]], reuschel was is in the [[top 100 winning pitchers of all time]]. reuschel won the [[hutch award]] in [[1985 in sports|1985]],<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/hutch_gehrig_ruth_clemente.shtml hutch award winners at baseball reference]</ref> and was also a winner of [[the sporting news comeback player of the year award]].<ref name=the comeback player of the year award at baseball almanac/> reuschel was named to the [[baseball digest]] 1972 rookie all-star team.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=ytqdaaaambaj&pg=pa30&dq=baseball+digest+rick+reuschel#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20rick%20reuschel&f=false baseball digest, december 1989]</ref>

wilson was one of the most accomplished power hitters in the game during the late 1920s and early 1930s.<ref name=hack wilson belted homers, hecklers with equal gusto>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/?id=3jadaaaambaj&pg=pa78&dq=hack+wilson+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=hack%20wilson%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=hack wilson belted homers, hecklers with equal gusto |author=holway, john |publisher=books.google.com |date=june 1996 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=28 february 2011 }}</ref> his batting talent and propensities for fighting and excessive alcohol consumption made him one of the most colorful sports personalities of his era.<ref name=death overtakes hack wilson of home run fame>{{cite news |title=death overtakes hack wilson of home run fame |agency=associated press |work=the evening independent |page=19 |date=24 november 1948 |accessdate=1 march 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=7abqaaaaibaj&sjid=jludaaaaibaj&pg=6624,4503899&dq=hack+wilson&hl=en}}</ref> his drinking and fighting undoubtedly contributed to a premature end to his athletic career and, ultimately, his premature demise.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=btqdaaaambaj&pg=pa64&dq=hack+wilson+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=2jbstct7e5o6tgegiphhbq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0cc8q6aewag#v=onepage&q=hack%20wilson%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=former teammates recall hack wilson |author=dolgan, bob |publisher=books.google.com |date=march 1978 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=1 march 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=hdidaaaambaj&pg=pa56&dq=hack+wilson+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=2jbstct7e5o6tgegiphhbq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0cdcq6aewba#v=onepage&q=hack%20wilson%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=...but memories of hack wilson fade away |author=drooz, al |publisher=books.google.com |date=october 1974 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=1 march 2011 }}</ref>

in [[1929 chicago cubs season|1929]] wilson hit .345 with 39 home runs and a national league record 159 rbis.<ref name=hack wilson statistics/><ref name=hack wilson belted homers, hecklers with equal gusto/> he and new teammate [[rogers hornsby]] (who also contributed 39 home runs) led the cubs to their first national league pennant in eleven years.  in the [[1929 world series|world series]] against [[connie mack (baseball)|connie mack's]] [[1929 philadelphia athletics season|philadelphia athletics]], wilson's .471 hitting performance was eclipsed by two fielding errors at [[shibe park]].  though trailing the series 2 games to 1, the cubs were leading by a score of 8-0 in game 4 when the athletics mounted a 10-run rally in the seventh inning.  wilson lost two fly balls in the sun; the second, with two runners on base, led to an inside-the-park home run by [[mule haas]] as the athletics won 10-8.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/pha/pha192910120.shtml |title=1929 world series game 4 |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=1 march 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/?id=1zmdaaaambaj&pg=pa94&dq=hack+wilson+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=hack%20wilson%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=hack wilson: he was one of a kind |author1=boone, robert |author2=grunska, gerald |publisher=books.google.com |date=january 1979 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=28 february 2011 }}</ref>  after the game, cubs manager [[joe mccarthy (manager)|joe mccarthy]] reportedly told a boy asking for a souvenir baseball, come back tomorrow and stand behind wilson, and you'll be able to pick up all the balls you want!<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20081016&content_id=3625822&vkey=recap&fext=.jsp&c_id=mlb|title=on cue, drew caps miraculous sox rally|date=2008-10-17|work=ian browne|publisher=mlb.com|accessdate=2009-10-02|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5khjhsbyf|archivedate=2009-10-04|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20081017&content_id=3627098&vkey=ps2008news&fext=.jsp&c_id=mlb|title=comeback among october's best|date=2008-10-17|publisher=mlb.com|accessdate=2009-10-02}}</ref>  the athletics won again the next day to take the series in five games.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1929_ws.shtml |title=1929 world series |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=28 february 2011 }}</ref>

on october 4, 1948 wilson was discovered unconscious after a fall in his home.<ref>{{cite news |title=hack wilson is hospitalized |agency=associated press |work=pittsburgh post-gazette |page=19 |date=5 october 1948 |accessdate=1 march 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=1qgnaaaaibaj&sjid=wmodaaaaibaj&pg=3938,439096&dq=hack+wilson&hl=en}}</ref> the accident didn't appear serious at first, but  pneumonia and other complications developed, and he died of internal hemorrhaging on november 23, 1948 at the age of 48.<ref name=death overtakes hack wilson of home run fame/> wilson died penniless and his son refused to claim his remains. national league president [[ford frick]] finally sent money to cover his funeral expenses.<ref>{{cite news |title=last rites held for hack wilson |agency=associated press |work=the day |page=8 |date=27 november 1948 |accessdate=1 march 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=nh8iaaaaibaj&sjid=thefaaaaibaj&pg=1984,5384665&dq=hack+wilson&hl=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=nc4daaaambaj&pg=pa65&dq=hack+wilson+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=2jbstct7e5o6tgegiphhbq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0cdmq6aewaw#v=onepage&q=hack%20wilson%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=the sad demise of home run king hack wilson |author=steadman, john |publisher=books.google.com |date=february 1990 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=1 march 2011 }}</ref> in marked contrast to [[babe ruth]]'s funeral, which had been attended by thousands just three months earlier, only a few hundred people were present for wilson's services.<ref name=services held for hack wilson>{{cite news |title=services held for hack wilson |agency=united press international |work=the pittsburgh press |page=28 |date=28 november 1948 |accessdate=1 march 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=g2ycaaaaibaj&sjid=jk4eaaaaibaj&pg=3733,4675298&dq=hack+wilson&hl=en}}</ref> he is buried in rosedale cemetery in the town where he made his professional playing debut, martinsburg, west virginia.<ref name=services held for hack wilson/> a martinsburg street is named hack wilson way in his honor.

'''lewis robert hack wilson''' (april 26, 1900  november 23, 1948) was an american [[major league baseball]] player who played 12 seasons for the [[san francisco giants|new york giants]], [[chicago cubs]], [[los angeles dodgers|brooklyn dodgers]] and [[philadelphia phillies]].<ref name=hack wilson statistics>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/w/wilsoha01.shtml |title=hack wilson statistics |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=21 february 2011}}</ref>  despite his diminutive stature, he was one of the most accomplished power hitters in the game during the late 1920s and early 1930s.<ref name=hack wilson belted homers, hecklers with equal gusto>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/?id=3jadaaaambaj&pg=pa78&dq=hack+wilson+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=hack%20wilson%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=hack wilson belted homers, hecklers with equal gusto |author=holway, john |publisher=books.google.com |date=june 1996 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=28 february 2011}}</ref>  his 1930 season with the cubs is widely considered one of the most memorable individual single-season hitting performances in baseball history.  highlights included 56 [[home run]]s, the [[national league]] record for 68 years; and 191 [[runs batted in]], a mark yet to be surpassed.  for a brief span of a few years, wrote a sportswriter of the day, this hammered down little strongman actually rivaled the mighty [babe] ruth.{{sfn|parker|2000|p=195}}

while wilson's combativeness and excessive alcohol consumption made him one of the most colorful sports personalities of his era,<ref name=death overtakes hack wilson of home run fame>{{cite news |title=death overtakes hack wilson of home run fame |agency=associated press |work=the evening independent |page=19 |date=24 november 1948 |accessdate=1 march 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=7abqaaaaibaj&sjid=jludaaaaibaj&pg=6624,4503899&dq=hack+wilson&hl=en}}</ref> his drinking and fighting undoubtedly contributed to a premature end to his athletic career and, ultimately, his premature demise.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=btqdaaaambaj&pg=pa64&dq=hack+wilson+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=2jbstct7e5o6tgegiphhbq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0cc8q6aewag#v=onepage&q=hack%20wilson%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=former teammates recall hack wilson |author=dolgan, bob |publisher=books.google.com |date=march 1978 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=1 march 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=hdidaaaambaj&pg=pa56&dq=hack+wilson+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=2jbstct7e5o6tgegiphhbq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0cdcq6aewba#v=onepage&q=hack%20wilson%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=...but memories of hack wilson fade away |author=drooz, al |publisher=books.google.com |date=october 1974 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=1 march 2011}}</ref>  he was inducted into the [[baseball hall of fame]] in [[baseball hall of fame balloting, 1979|1979]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://baseballhall.org/hof/wilson-hack |title=hack wilson at the baseball hall of fame |publisher=baseballhall.org |accessdate=28 february 2011}}</ref>

in [[1929 chicago cubs season|1929]], wilson hit .345 with 39 home runs and a league-record 159 rbis.<ref name=hack wilson statistics/><ref name=hack wilson belted homers, hecklers with equal gusto/> he and new teammate [[rogers hornsby]] (who also contributed 39 home runs) led the cubs to their first nl pennant in eleven years. in the [[1929 world series|world series]] against [[connie mack (baseball)|connie mack's]] [[1929 philadelphia athletics season|philadelphia athletics]], wilson's .471 hitting performance was eclipsed by two fielding [[error (baseball)|errors]] at [[shibe park]]. though trailing the series two games to one, the cubs were leading by a score of 80 in the fourth game when the athletics mounted a 10-[[run (baseball)|run]] rally in the seventh inning. wilson lost two fly balls in the sun; the second, with two runners on base, led to an [[inside-the-park home run]] by [[mule haas]] as the athletics won 108.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/pha/pha192910120.shtml |title=1929 world series game 4 |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=1 march 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/?id=1zmdaaaambaj&pg=pa94&dq=hack+wilson+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=hack%20wilson%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=hack wilson: he was one of a kind |author1=boone, robert |author2=grunska, gerald |publisher=books.google.com |date=january 1979 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=28 february 2011}}</ref> after the game, cubs manager [[joe mccarthy (manager)|joe mccarthy]] reportedly told a boy asking for a souvenir baseball, come back tomorrow and stand behind wilson, and you'll be able to pick up all the balls you want!<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20081016&content_id=3625822&vkey=recap&fext=.jsp&c_id=mlb|title=on cue, drew caps miraculous sox rally|date=2008-10-17|work=ian browne|publisher=mlb.com|accessdate=2009-10-02|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5khjhsbyf|archivedate=2009-10-04|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20081017&content_id=3627098&vkey=ps2008news&fext=.jsp&c_id=mlb|title=comeback among october's best|date=2008-10-17|publisher=mlb.com|accessdate=2009-10-02}}</ref> the athletics won again the next day to take the series in five games.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1929_ws.shtml |title=1929 world series |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=28 february 2011}}</ref>

on october 4, 1948 wilson was discovered unconscious after a fall in his home.<ref>{{cite news |title=hack wilson is hospitalized |agency=associated press |work=pittsburgh post-gazette |page=19 |date=5 october 1948 |accessdate=1 march 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=1qgnaaaaibaj&sjid=wmodaaaaibaj&pg=3938,439096&dq=hack+wilson&hl=en}}</ref> though the accident did not appear serious at first, [[pneumonia]] and other complications developed and he died of internal [[hemorrhaging]] on november 23, 1948 at the age of 48.<ref name=death overtakes hack wilson of home run fame/> wilson died penniless and his son refused to claim his remains. nl president [[ford frick]] finally sent money to cover his funeral expenses.<ref>{{cite news |title=last rites held for hack wilson |agency=associated press |work=the day |page=8 |date=27 november 1948 |accessdate=1 march 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=nh8iaaaaibaj&sjid=thefaaaaibaj&pg=1984,5384665&dq=hack+wilson&hl=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=nc4daaaambaj&pg=pa65&dq=hack+wilson+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=2jbstct7e5o6tgegiphhbq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0cdmq6aewaw#v=onepage&q=hack%20wilson%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=the sad demise of home run king hack wilson |author=steadman, john |publisher=books.google.com |date=february 1990 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=1 march 2011}}</ref> in marked contrast to [[babe ruth]]'s funeral, which had been attended by thousands just three months earlier, only a few hundred people were present for wilson's services.<ref name=services held for hack wilson>{{cite news |title=services held for hack wilson |agency=united press international |work=the pittsburgh press |page=28 |date=28 november 1948 |accessdate=1 march 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=g2ycaaaaibaj&sjid=jk4eaaaaibaj&pg=3733,4675298&dq=hack+wilson&hl=en}}</ref> he was buried in rosedale cemetery in the town where he made his professional playing debut, martinsburg, west virginia.<ref name=services held for hack wilson/> ten months later joe mccarthy organized a second, more complete memorial service, attended by [[kiki cuyler]], charlie grimm, [[nick altrock]] and other players from the cubs and the martinsburg team (by then renamed the blue sox).  a granite tombstone was unveiled, with the inscription, one of baseball's immortals, lewis r. (hack) wilson, rests here.{{sfn|parker|2000|p=194}}

in [[1929 chicago cubs season|1929]] wilson hit .345 with 39 home runs and a league-record 159 rbis.<ref name=hack wilson statistics/><ref name=hack wilson belted homers, hecklers with equal gusto/> he and new teammate [[rogers hornsby]] (who also contributed 39 home runs) led the cubs to their first nl pennant in eleven years. in the [[1929 world series|world series]] against [[connie mack (baseball)|connie mack's]] [[1929 philadelphia athletics season|philadelphia athletics]], wilson's .471 hitting performance was eclipsed by two fielding [[error (baseball)|errors]] at [[shibe park]]. though trailing the series two games to one, the cubs were leading by a score of 80 in the fourth game when the athletics mounted a 10-[[run (baseball)|run]] rally in the seventh inning. wilson lost two fly balls in the sun; the second, with two runners on base, led to an [[inside-the-park home run]] by [[mule haas]] as the athletics won 108.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/pha/pha192910120.shtml |title=1929 world series game 4 |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=march 1, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/?id=1zmdaaaambaj&pg=pa94&dq=hack+wilson+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=hack%20wilson%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=hack wilson: he was one of a kind |author1=boone, robert |author2=grunska, gerald |publisher=books.google.com |date=january 1979 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=february 28, 2011}}</ref> after the game, mccarthy reportedly told a boy asking for a souvenir baseball, come back tomorrow and stand behind wilson, and you'll be able to pick up all the balls you want!<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20081016&content_id=3625822&vkey=recap&fext=.jsp&c_id=mlb|title=on cue, drew caps miraculous sox rally|date=october 17, 2008|work=ian browne|publisher=mlb.com|accessdate=october 2, 2009|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5khjhsbyf|archivedate=october 4, 2009|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20081017&content_id=3627098&vkey=ps2008news&fext=.jsp&c_id=mlb|title=comeback among october's best|date=october 17, 2008|publisher=mlb.com|accessdate=october 2, 2009}}</ref> the athletics won again the next day to take the series in five games.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1929_ws.shtml |title=1929 world series |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=february 28, 2011}}</ref>

wilson  once the highest-paid player in the national league<ref>berkow, i (september 5, 1998): on baseball; hack wilson's lesson still valid. [http://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/05/sports/on-baseball-hack-wilson-s-lesson-still-valid.html ''new york times'' archive]. retrieved september 23, 2013.</ref>  died penniless; his son, robert, refused to claim his remains. nl president [[ford frick]] finally sent money to cover his funeral expenses.<ref>{{cite news |title=last rites held for hack wilson |agency=associated press |work=the day |page=8 |date=november 27, 1948 |accessdate=march 1, 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=nh8iaaaaibaj&sjid=thefaaaaibaj&pg=1984,5384665&dq=hack+wilson&hl=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=nc4daaaambaj&pg=pa65&dq=hack+wilson+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=2jbstct7e5o6tgegiphhbq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0cdmq6aewaw#v=onepage&q=hack%20wilson%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=the sad demise of home run king hack wilson |author=steadman, john |publisher=books.google.com |date=february 1990 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=march 1, 2011}}</ref>  his gray burial suit was donated by the undertaker.<ref>berkow, i (september 5, 1998): on baseball; hack wilson's lesson still valid. [http://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/05/sports/on-baseball-hack-wilson-s-lesson-still-valid.html ''new york times'' archive]. retrieved september 23, 2013.</ref>  in marked contrast to [[babe ruth]]'s funeral, which had been attended by thousands just three months earlier, only a few hundred people were present for wilson's services.<ref name=services held for hack wilson>{{cite news |title=services held for hack wilson |agency=united press international |work=the pittsburgh press |page=28 |date=november 28, 1948 |accessdate=march 1, 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=g2ycaaaaibaj&sjid=jk4eaaaaibaj&pg=3733,4675298&dq=hack+wilson&hl=en}}</ref> he was buried in rosedale cemetery in the town where he made his professional playing debut, martinsburg, west virginia.<ref name=services held for hack wilson/>

* [http://books.google.com/books?id=uzmdaaaambaj&pg=pa22&lpg=pa22&dq=manny+trillo+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=0t03rgl4xd&sig=kx_keko9bm-i48rxcuvnt9zwve8&hl=en&ei=fy_hspy7edxw8abn6ptica&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5#v=onepage&q=manny%20trillo%20baseball%20digest&f=false manny trillo article in baseball digest, june 1981]

'''jess manuel marcano (manny) trillo''' (born december 25, 1950 in [[caripito]], [[venezuela]]), also nicknamed '''indio''', is a former [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] player who played in the [[major league baseball|major leagues]] from {{by|1973}} to {{by|1989}}.<ref name=manny trillo at baseball reference>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/t/trillma01.shtml manny trillo at baseball reference]</ref> he played most of his career as a [[second baseman]] for the [[oakland athletics]] ([[1973 oakland athletics season|1973]]-[[1974 oakland athletics season|1974]]), [[chicago cubs]] ([[1975 chicago cubs season|1975]]-[[1978 chicago cubs season|1978]], [[1986 chicago cubs season|1986]]-[[1988 chicago cubs season|1988]]), [[philadelphia phillies]] ([[1979 philadelphia phillies season|1979]]-[[1982 philadelphia phillies season|1982]]), [[cleveland indians]] ([[1983 cleveland indians season|1983]]), [[montreal expos]] ([[1983 montreal expos season|1983]]), [[san francisco giants]] ([[1984 san francisco giants season|1984]]-[[1985 san francisco giants season|1985]]) and the [[cincinnati reds]] ([[1989 cincinnati reds season|1989]]).<ref name=manny trillo at baseball reference/> he was known as one of the best fielding second basemen of his era with a strong throwing arm.<ref name=''manny trillo: he's unsung but not under-rated!''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=uzmdaaaambaj&pg=pa22&lpg=pa22&dq=manny+trillo+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=0t03rgl4xd&sig=kx_keko9bm-i48rxcuvnt9zwve8&hl=en&ei=fy_hspy7edxw8abn6ptica&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5#v=onepage&q=manny%20trillo%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''manny trillo: he's unsung but not under-rated!'', by jayson stark, baseball digest, june 1981, vol. 40, no. 6, issn 0005-609x]</ref>

originally signed as a [[catcher]] by the philadelphia phillies in {{by|1968}}, trillo was converted into a [[third baseman]] by his first [[minor league baseball|minor league]] manager, [[dallas green]].<ref name=''manny trillo: he's unsung but not under-rated!''/><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=zdmdaaaambaj&pg=pa84&lpg=pa84&dq=manny+trillo+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=aompdjcel-&sig=feu6fphgbccaavaz1oek5iqivmq&hl=en&ei=agbqtiq3kyob8gbi85hsdq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0cc0q6aewbw#v=onepage&q=manny%20trillo%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''how the phils let trillo get away'', by ritchie ashburn, baseball digest, april 1978, vol. 37, no. 4, issn 0005-609x]</ref> in {{by|1969}}, he was selected by the oakland athletics from the phillies in the [[rule 5 draft]].<ref name=http://armchairgm.wikia.com>[http://armchairgm.wikia.com/manny_trillo http://armchairgm.wikia.com]</ref> trillo was converted into a second baseman in {{by|1973}} while playing for the athletics' [[triple-a (baseball)|triple a]] team, the [[tucson toros]].<ref name=''manny trillo: he's unsung but not under-rated!''/> he made his major league debut with oakland on june 28, [[1973 oakland athletics season|1973]] and stayed with the club as the athletics won the [[american league west|american league western division]] [[pennant (sports)|pennant]] by six games over the [[1973 kansas city royals season|kansas city royals]], then defeated the [[1973 baltimore orioles season|baltimore orioles]] in the [[1973 american league championship series]].<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/al/1973.shtml 1973 american league standings at baseball reference]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1973_alcs.shtml 1973 american league championship series at baseball reference]</ref>

on october 23, {{by|1974}}, trillo was traded along with [[darold knowles]] and [[bob locker]] to the chicago cubs for [[billy williams (left fielder)|billy williams]].<ref name=http://armchairgm.wikia.com>[http://armchairgm.wikia.com/manny_trillo http://armchairgm.wikia.com]</ref><ref name=manny trillo trades and transactions at baseball almanac>[http://www.baseball-almanac.com/players/trades.php?p=trillma01 manny trillo trades and transactions at baseball almanac]</ref> trillo would finish third in the {{by|1975}} [[national league]] [[rookie of the year (award)|rookie of the year]] award balloting.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1975.shtml#nlroy 1975 rookie of the year award voting results at baseball reference]</ref> with the cubs, trillo developed a reputation for being one of the best fielding second basemen in baseball, earning his first [[major league baseball all-star game|all-star]] selection in [[1977 major league baseball all-star game|1977]].<ref name=manny trillo at baseball reference/><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=jtmdaaaambaj&pg=pa30&lpg=pa30&dq=manny+trillo+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=s3zxakhgdo&sig=_isp8kxupnsn-bqclsqvjprcypi&hl=en&ei=1anqtjhzmmoc8gbdtuggaq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0cbcq6aewajge#v=onepage&q=manny%20trillo%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''the cubs' new latin connection, by george vass, baseball digest, august 1977, vol. 36, no. 8, issn 0005-609x]</ref> together with cubs' [[shortstop]] [[ivn dejess]], he formed one of the best [[double play]] combinations in baseball.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=rdqdaaaambaj&pg=pa9&lpg=pa9&dq=manny+trillo+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=4rvatfcqvi&sig=3vm82vju_k3pjnbmcmchaied7e0&hl=en&ei=tajqtpxzdit48aappi2yaq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0cbcq6aewajgk#v=onepage&q&f=false baseball digest, february 1981, vol. 40, no. 2, issn 0005-609x]</ref> he remained with the cubs for four seasons before being traded to the philadelphia phillies on february 23, [[1979 philadelphia phillies season|1979]] as part of an eight-player trade.<ref name=manny trillo trades and transactions at baseball almanac/> later that season, trillo was reunited with his former minor league manager, dallas green, who had replaced [[danny ozark]] as the phillies' manager. trillo would win his first [[gold glove award]] in {{by|1979}}.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/gold_glove_nl.shtml national league gold glove award winners at baseball reference]</ref>

[[1981 philadelphia phillies season|1981]] would be another good year for trillo as he was selected as a reserve for the national league all-star team, and won his second gold glove award and his second consecutive silver slugger award. he was voted to be the starting second baseman for the national league in the [[1982 major league baseball all-star game|1982 all-star game]] and, set a since-broken major league record for consecutive errorless [[total chances|chances]] at second base (479), falling two games short of [[joe morgan]]'s record 91-game errorless streak.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=ei8daaaambaj&pg=pa78&lpg=pa78&dq=manny+trillo+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=y7balggs9f&sig=jhsq-aybr5onju-igq1eguppdqy&hl=en&ei=nebptkeka4t58aap48cvaq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0cdqq6aewcq#v=onepage&q=manny%20trillo%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''the game i'll never forget'', by manny trillo as told to george vass, baseball digest, september 1986, vol. 45, no. 9, issn 0005-609x]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/gold_glove_nl.shtml#1982 1982 gold glove award winners at baseball reference]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseballlibrary.com/ballplayers/player.php?name=ryne_sandberg_1959 www.baseballlibrary.com]</ref>

'''jess manuel marcano (manny) trillo''' (born december 25, 1950 in [[caripito]], [[venezuela]]), also nicknamed '''indio''', is a former [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] player who played in the [[major league baseball|major leagues]] from {{by|1973}} to {{by|1989}}.<ref name=manny trillo at baseball reference>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/t/trillma01.shtml manny trillo at baseball reference]</ref> he played most of his career as a [[second baseman]] for the [[oakland athletics]] ([[1973 oakland athletics season|1973]]-[[1974 oakland athletics season|1974]]), [[chicago cubs]] ([[1975 chicago cubs season|1975]]-[[1978 chicago cubs season|1978]], [[1986 chicago cubs season|1986]]-[[1988 chicago cubs season|1988]]), [[philadelphia phillies]] ([[1979 philadelphia phillies season|1979]]-[[1982 philadelphia phillies season|1982]]), [[cleveland indians]] ([[1983 cleveland indians season|1983]]), [[montreal expos]] ([[1983 montreal expos season|1983]]), [[san francisco giants]] ([[1984 san francisco giants season|1984]]-[[1985 san francisco giants season|1985]]) and the [[cincinnati reds]] ([[1989 cincinnati reds season|1989]]).<ref name=manny trillo at baseball reference/> he was known as one of the best fielding second basemen of his era with a strong throwing arm.<ref name=''manny trillo: he's unsung but not under-rated!''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=uzmdaaaambaj&pg=pa22&lpg=pa22&dq=manny+trillo+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=0t03rgl4xd&sig=kx_keko9bm-i48rxcuvnt9zwve8&hl=en&ei=fy_hspy7edxw8abn6ptica&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5#v=onepage&q=manny%20trillo%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''manny trillo: he's unsung but not under-rated!'', by jayson stark, baseball digest, june 1981, vol. 40, no. 6, issn 0005-609x]</ref>

originally signed as a [[catcher]] by the philadelphia phillies in {{by|1968}}, trillo was converted into a [[third baseman]] by his first [[minor league baseball|minor league]] manager, [[dallas green]].<ref name=''manny trillo: he's unsung but not under-rated!''/><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=zdmdaaaambaj&pg=pa84&lpg=pa84&dq=manny+trillo+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=aompdjcel-&sig=feu6fphgbccaavaz1oek5iqivmq&hl=en&ei=agbqtiq3kyob8gbi85hsdq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0cc0q6aewbw#v=onepage&q=manny%20trillo%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''how the phils let trillo get away'', by ritchie ashburn, baseball digest, april 1978, vol. 37, no. 4, issn 0005-609x]</ref> in {{by|1969}}, he was selected by the oakland athletics from the phillies in the [[rule 5 draft]].<ref name=http://armchairgm.wikia.com>[http://armchairgm.wikia.com/manny_trillo http://armchairgm.wikia.com]</ref> trillo was converted into a second baseman in {{by|1973}} while playing for the athletics' [[triple-a (baseball)|triple a]] team, the [[tucson toros]].<ref name=''manny trillo: he's unsung but not under-rated!''/> he made his major league debut with oakland on june 28, [[1973 oakland athletics season|1973]] and stayed with the club as the athletics won the [[american league west|american league western division]] [[pennant (sports)|pennant]] by six games over the [[1973 kansas city royals season|kansas city royals]], then defeated the [[1973 baltimore orioles season|baltimore orioles]] in the [[1973 american league championship series]].<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/al/1973.shtml 1973 american league standings at baseball reference]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1973_alcs.shtml 1973 american league championship series at baseball reference]</ref>

on october 23, {{by|1974}}, trillo was traded along with [[darold knowles]] and [[bob locker]] to the chicago cubs for [[billy williams (left fielder)|billy williams]].<ref name=http://armchairgm.wikia.com>[http://armchairgm.wikia.com/manny_trillo http://armchairgm.wikia.com]</ref><ref name=manny trillo trades and transactions at baseball almanac>[http://www.baseball-almanac.com/players/trades.php?p=trillma01 manny trillo trades and transactions at baseball almanac]</ref> trillo would finish third in the {{by|1975}} [[national league]] [[rookie of the year (award)|rookie of the year]] award balloting.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1975.shtml#nlroy 1975 rookie of the year award voting results at baseball reference]</ref> with the cubs, trillo developed a reputation for being one of the best fielding second basemen in baseball, earning his first [[major league baseball all-star game|all-star]] selection in [[1977 major league baseball all-star game|1977]].<ref name=manny trillo at baseball reference/><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=jtmdaaaambaj&pg=pa30&lpg=pa30&dq=manny+trillo+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=s3zxakhgdo&sig=_isp8kxupnsn-bqclsqvjprcypi&hl=en&ei=1anqtjhzmmoc8gbdtuggaq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0cbcq6aewajge#v=onepage&q=manny%20trillo%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''the cubs' new latin connection, by george vass, baseball digest, august 1977, vol. 36, no. 8, issn 0005-609x]</ref> together with cubs' [[shortstop]] [[ivn dejess]], he formed one of the best [[double play]] combinations in baseball.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=rdqdaaaambaj&pg=pa9&lpg=pa9&dq=manny+trillo+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=4rvatfcqvi&sig=3vm82vju_k3pjnbmcmchaied7e0&hl=en&ei=tajqtpxzdit48aappi2yaq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0cbcq6aewajgk#v=onepage&q&f=false baseball digest, february 1981, vol. 40, no. 2, issn 0005-609x]</ref> he remained with the cubs for four seasons before being traded to the philadelphia phillies on february 23, [[1979 philadelphia phillies season|1979]] as part of an eight-player trade.<ref name=manny trillo trades and transactions at baseball almanac/> later that season, trillo was reunited with his former minor league manager, dallas green, who had replaced [[danny ozark]] as the phillies' manager. trillo would win his first [[gold glove award]] in {{by|1979}}.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/gold_glove_nl.shtml national league gold glove award winners at baseball reference]</ref>

'''jess manuel marcano manny trillo''' (born december 25, 1950), also nicknamed '''indio''', is a [[venezuela]]n former professional [[baseball]] player who played in [[major league baseball]] from {{by|1973}} to {{by|1989}}.<ref name=manny trillo at baseball reference>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/t/trillma01.shtml manny trillo at baseball reference]</ref> he played most of his career as a [[second baseman]] for the [[oakland athletics]] ([[1973 oakland athletics season|1973]]-[[1974 oakland athletics season|1974]]), [[chicago cubs]] ([[1975 chicago cubs season|1975]]-[[1978 chicago cubs season|1978]], [[1986 chicago cubs season|1986]]-[[1988 chicago cubs season|1988]]), [[philadelphia phillies]] ([[1979 philadelphia phillies season|1979]]-[[1982 philadelphia phillies season|1982]]), [[cleveland indians]] ([[1983 cleveland indians season|1983]]), [[montreal expos]] ([[1983 montreal expos season|1983]]), [[san francisco giants]] ([[1984 san francisco giants season|1984]]-[[1985 san francisco giants season|1985]]) and the [[cincinnati reds]] ([[1989 cincinnati reds season|1989]]).<ref name=manny trillo at baseball reference/> he was known as one of the best fielding second basemen of his era with a strong throwing arm.<ref name=''manny trillo: he's unsung but not under-rated!''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=uzmdaaaambaj&pg=pa22&lpg=pa22&dq=manny+trillo+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=0t03rgl4xd&sig=kx_keko9bm-i48rxcuvnt9zwve8&hl=en&ei=fy_hspy7edxw8abn6ptica&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5#v=onepage&q=manny%20trillo%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''manny trillo: he's unsung but not under-rated!'', by jayson stark, baseball digest, june 1981, vol. 40, no. 6, issn 0005-609x]</ref>

originally signed as a [[catcher]] by the philadelphia phillies in {{by|1968}}, trillo was converted into a [[third baseman]] by his first [[minor league baseball|minor league]] manager, [[dallas green (major league baseball)|dallas green]].<ref name=''manny trillo: he's unsung but not under-rated!''/><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=zdmdaaaambaj&pg=pa84&lpg=pa84&dq=manny+trillo+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=aompdjcel-&sig=feu6fphgbccaavaz1oek5iqivmq&hl=en&ei=agbqtiq3kyob8gbi85hsdq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0cc0q6aewbw#v=onepage&q=manny%20trillo%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''how the phils let trillo get away'', by ritchie ashburn, baseball digest, april 1978, vol. 37, no. 4, issn 0005-609x]</ref> in {{by|1969}}, he was selected by the oakland athletics from the phillies in the [[rule 5 draft]]. trillo was converted into a second baseman in {{by|1973}} while playing for the athletics' [[triple-a (baseball)|triple a]] team, the [[tucson toros]].<ref name=''manny trillo: he's unsung but not under-rated!''/> he made his major league debut with oakland on june 28, [[1973 oakland athletics season|1973]] and stayed with the club as the athletics won the [[american league west|american league western division]] [[pennant (sports)|pennant]] by six games over the [[1973 kansas city royals season|kansas city royals]], then defeated the [[1973 baltimore orioles season|baltimore orioles]] in the [[1973 american league championship series]].<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/al/1973.shtml 1973 american league standings at baseball reference]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1973_alcs.shtml 1973 american league championship series at baseball reference]</ref>

on october 23, {{by|1974}}, trillo was traded along with [[darold knowles]] and [[bob locker]] to the chicago cubs for [[billy williams (left fielder)|billy williams]].<ref name=manny trillo trades and transactions at baseball almanac>[http://www.baseball-almanac.com/players/trades.php?p=trillma01 manny trillo trades and transactions at baseball almanac]</ref> trillo would finish third in the {{by|1975}} [[national league]] [[rookie of the year (award)|rookie of the year]] award balloting.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1975.shtml#nlroy 1975 rookie of the year award voting results at baseball reference]</ref> with the cubs, trillo developed a reputation for being one of the best fielding second basemen in baseball, earning his first [[major league baseball all-star game|all-star]] selection in [[1977 major league baseball all-star game|1977]].<ref name=manny trillo at baseball reference/><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=jtmdaaaambaj&pg=pa30&lpg=pa30&dq=manny+trillo+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=s3zxakhgdo&sig=_isp8kxupnsn-bqclsqvjprcypi&hl=en&ei=1anqtjhzmmoc8gbdtuggaq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0cbcq6aewajge#v=onepage&q=manny%20trillo%20baseball%20digest&f=false the cubs' new latin connection, by george vass, baseball digest, august 1977, vol. 36, no. 8, issn 0005-609x]</ref> together with cubs' [[shortstop]] [[ivn dejess]], he formed one of the best [[double play]] combinations in baseball.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=rdqdaaaambaj&pg=pa9&lpg=pa9&dq=manny+trillo+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=4rvatfcqvi&sig=3vm82vju_k3pjnbmcmchaied7e0&hl=en&ei=tajqtpxzdit48aappi2yaq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0cbcq6aewajgk#v=onepage&q&f=false baseball digest, february 1981, vol. 40, no. 2, issn 0005-609x]</ref> he remained with the cubs for four seasons before being traded to the philadelphia phillies on february 23, [[1979 philadelphia phillies season|1979]] as part of an eight-player trade.<ref name=manny trillo trades and transactions at baseball almanac/> later that season, trillo was reunited with his former minor league manager, dallas green, who had replaced [[danny ozark]] as the phillies' manager. trillo would win his first [[gold glove award]] in {{by|1979}}.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/gold_glove_nl.shtml national league gold glove award winners at baseball reference]</ref>

[[1981 philadelphia phillies season|1981]] would be another good year for trillo as he was selected as a reserve for the national league all-star team, and won his second gold glove award and his second consecutive silver slugger award. he was voted to be the starting second baseman for the national league in the [[1982 major league baseball all-star game|1982 all-star game]] and, set a since-broken major league record for consecutive errorless [[total chances|chances]] at second base (479), falling two games short of [[joe morgan]]'s record 91-game errorless streak.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=ei8daaaambaj&pg=pa78&lpg=pa78&dq=manny+trillo+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=y7balggs9f&sig=jhsq-aybr5onju-igq1eguppdqy&hl=en&ei=nebptkeka4t58aap48cvaq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0cdqq6aewcq#v=onepage&q=manny%20trillo%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''the game i'll never forget'', by manny trillo as told to george vass, baseball digest, september 1986, vol. 45, no. 9, issn 0005-609x]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/gold_glove_nl.shtml#1982 1982 gold glove award winners at baseball reference]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseballlibrary.com/ballplayers/player.php?name=ryne_sandberg_1959 www.baseballlibrary.com]</ref>

'''james edward hegan''' (august 3, 1920  june 17, 1984) was a [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] [[catcher]] and [[coach (baseball)|coach]] who spent almost 40 years in [[major league baseball]].<ref name=jim hegan at baseball reference>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/h/heganji01.shtml |title=jim hegan |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=23 august 2010 }}</ref> while he was light-[[batting (baseball)|hitting]] as an offensive player, he was notable for being one of the best defensive catchers of his era and a capable handler of pitching staffs.<ref name=''former catcher jim hegan: defense was his game''>{{cite web |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=uysdaaaambaj&pg=pa72&dq=jim+hegan+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=jim%20hegan%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=former catcher jim hegan: defense was his game |author=dolgan, bob |publisher=books.google.com |date=february 1999 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=23 august 2010 }}</ref><ref name=sustaining a long career''>{{cite web |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=4i4daaaambaj&pg=pa56&lpg=pa56&dq=sustaining+a+long+career+by+al+doyle&source=bl&ots=rxidgin9sw&sig=oehpmfnqvcwqzgz4b7hriygizkq&hl=en&ei=v2zztns0dowclafz8ow7aq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0ccuq6aewbg#v=onepage&q=sustaining%20a%20long%20career%20by%20al%20doyle&f=false |title=sustaining a long career |author=doyle, al |publisher=books.google.com |date=november 2002 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=24 august 2010 }}</ref>

when his active career ended in july {{by|1960}}, hegan became the [[coach (baseball)|bullpen coach]] for the [[new york yankees]], helping to coach future catching stand outs [[thurmon munson]] and [[rick dempsey]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=9s0daaaambaj&pg=pa26&dq=baseball+digest+defensive+catchers#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20defensive%20catchers&f=false |title=for catchers, the name of the game is defense |author=vass, george |publisher=books.google.com |date=may 2005 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=23 august 2010 }}</ref> he served with the yankees through the [[1973 new york yankees season|1973]] season. he then moved with [[manager (baseball)|manager]] [[ralph houk]] to the [[detroit tigers]] for five years, through {{by|1978}}. he finished his career in uniform back with the yankees as a coach, and was serving as a [[scout (sports)|scout]] for the yankees when he died in [[swampscott, massachusetts]], of a [[myocardial infarction|heart attack]] at the age of 63.<ref name=''former catcher jim hegan: defense was his game''/>

* [http://books.google.com/books?id=uysdaaaambaj&pg=pa72&dq=jim+hegan+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=jim%20hegan%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''former catcher jim hegan: defense was his game'', baseball digest, february 1999]

when his active career ended in july {{by|1960}}, hegan became the [[coach (baseball)|bullpen coach]] for the [[new york yankees]], helping to coach future catching stand outs [[thurmon munson]] and [[rick dempsey]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=9s0daaaambaj&pg=pa26&dq=baseball+digest+defensive+catchers#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20defensive%20catchers&f=false |title=for catchers, the name of the game is defense |author=vass, george |publisher=books.google.com |date=may 2005 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=23 august 2010 }}</ref> he served with the yankees through the [[1973 new york yankees season|1973]] season. he then moved with [[manager (baseball)|manager]] [[ralph houk]] to the [[detroit tigers]] for five years, through {{by|1978}}. he finished his career in uniform back with the yankees as a coach, and was serving as a scout for the yankees when he died in [[swampscott, massachusetts]], of a [[myocardial infarction|heart attack]] at the age of 63.<ref name=''former catcher jim hegan: defense was his game''/>

'''vctor jos davalillo romero''' [da-va-lee-yo] (july 31, 1936 in [[cabimas]], [[zulia state|zulia]]), is a former [[venezuela]]n [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] player.<ref name=vic davalillo statistics>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/d/davalvi01.shtml |title=vic davalillo statistics |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=8 february 2011 }}</ref> he played in [[major league baseball]] as an [[outfielder]] for the [[cleveland indians]] (196368), [[los angeles angels of anaheim|california angels]] ([[1968 california angels season|1968]]-[[1969 california angels season|69]]), [[st. louis cardinals]] ([[1969 st. louis cardinals season|1969]]-[[1970 st. louis cardinals season|70]]), [[pittsburgh pirates]] ([[1971 pittsburgh pirates season|1971]]-[[1973 pittsburgh pirates season|73]]), [[oakland athletics]] ([[1973 oakland athletics season|1973]]-[[1974 oakland athletics season|74]]) and [[los angeles dodgers]] ([[1977 los angeles dodgers season|1977]]-[[1980 los angeles dodgers season|80]]).<ref name=vic davalillo statistics/> davalillo batted and threw left-handed. he was a [[leadoff hitter]] known for his speedy [[baserunner|baserunning]] and capable defensive ability.<ref name=vic davalillo may prove he was '63's top rookie in '64>{{cite book '''oswaldo jos guilln barrios''' (born january 20, 1964), well known as '''ozzie guilln''' ({{ipa-es|ien}}), is a former [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] player and, current [[manager (baseball)|manager]] of the [[chicago white sox]].<ref name=ozzie guillen at baseball reference>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/g/guilloz01.shtml |title=ozzie guilln |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=21 august 2010 }}</ref> born in [[ocumare del tuy]], [[venezuela]], he played in [[major league baseball]] as a [[shortstop]] for the white sox (198597), [[baltimore orioles]] ([[1998 baltimore orioles season|1998]]), [[atlanta braves]] ([[1998 atlanta braves season|1998]][[1999 atlanta braves season|1999]]) and [[tampa bay devil rays]] ([[2000 tampa bay devil rays season|2000]]).<ref name=ozzie guillen at baseball reference/> he batted left-handed and threw right-handed. as a player, guilln was regarded for his passion, speed, hustle, intensity and defensive abilities and his ebullient love for the game.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ry4daaaambaj&pg=pa18&lpg=pa18&dq=ozzie+guillen+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=gpqjclmdoa&sig=a_gcutoy5pw0jgyhrmfxuqflqsk&hl=en&ei=e-xftn7elytglqeuxpwxcg&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0cbcq6aewajgu#v=onepage&q=ozzie%20guillen%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=early season success of guillen and fielder cheered sox-tigers fans |author=kuenster, john |publisher=books.google.com |date=september 1990 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=21 august 2010 }}</ref><ref name=''ozzie guillen still retains defensive edge at short''>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=acwdaaaambaj&pg=pa44&lpg=pa44&dq=ozzie+guillen+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=zlto-fqztl&sig=83biwbprf8pa5av1lex30-ao010&hl=en&ei=hopftol2bigclafd56szca&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0ccoq6aewbw#v=onepage&q=ozzie%20guillen%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=ozzie guillen still retains defensive edge at short |author=sullivan, paul |publisher=books.google.com |date=july 1996 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=21 august 2010 }}</ref> he is the first [[latin americans|latin american]] manager in major league history to have won a [[world series]].

guilln was a light-[[batting (baseball)|hitting]], quick-handed shortstop, emerging from a line of venezuelan shortstops that included; [[chico carrasquel]], [[luis aparicio]] (both white sox players), [[dave concepcin]], and [[omar vizquel]] (who now plays for guillen as a [[utility player]] for the white sox).<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ajqdaaaambaj&pg=pa74&lpg=pa74&dq=ozzie+guillen+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=4mrlosc50q&sig=rdf_ta5pxfeqd5kwgrhgvr6w1io&hl=en&ei=bu5ftpsllcwclge3pycuca&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0cbeq6aewadgk#v=onepage&q=ozzie%20guillen%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=ozzie guillen: he's another concepcion in the making |author=krasnick, jerry |publisher=books.google.com |date=august 1988 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=21 august 2010 }}</ref> he was originally signed as a [[free agent]] by the [[san diego padres]] in {{by|1980}}.<ref name=ozzie guillen trades and transactions at baseball almanac>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-almanac.com/players/trades.php?p=guilloz01 |title=ozzie guillen trades and transactions |publisher=baseball almanac |accessdate=21 august 2010 }}</ref> in december {{by|1984}}, he was traded to the chicago white sox as part of an eight-player trade.<ref name=ozzie guillen trades and transactions at baseball almanac/>
