'''edward frederick joseph yost''' (born october 13, 1926 in [[brooklyn]], [[new york city]], [[new york]]) is a former [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] player and [[coach (baseball)|coach]].<ref name=eddie yost at baseball reference>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/y/yosted01.shtml |title=eddie yost |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=24 october 2010 }}</ref> he played the majority of his [[major league baseball]] career as a [[third baseman]] for the [[minnesota twins|washington senators]], before ending his career with the [[detroit tigers]] and the [[los angeles angels]].<ref name=eddie yost at baseball reference/> yost batted and threw right-handed.<ref name=eddie yost at baseball reference/> he was nicknamed the walking man for the numerous [[bases on balls]] he drew.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=qc4daaaambaj&pg=pa49&dq=eddie+yost+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=sljftm_dd5uh4gawj7c5aw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0cckq6aewadgk#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=washington's yost becomes majors' new walking man |author=heft, herb |publisher=books.google.com |date=october 1950 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=25 october 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=my4daaaambaj&pg=pa33&dq=eddie+yost+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=adzftpgzjswclgfy1eqc&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0cdiq6aewag#v=onepage&q=eddie%20yost%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=walking man starts swinging |author=povich, shirley |publisher=books.google.com |date=may 1953 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=25 october 2010 }}</ref> yost was considered one of the best [[batting order (baseball)|lead off]] men and third basemen of his era.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=7jidaaaambaj&pg=pa33&dq=eddie+yost+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=91zftnb4msvx4gb_4-m5aw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0cduq6aewazgu#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=oh, where are the lead off men? |author=dexter charles |publisher=books.google.com |date=june 1958 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=25 october 2010 }}</ref><ref name=major league coaches labor in obscurity>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=odmdaaaambaj&pg=pa44&dq=eddie+yost+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=adzftpgzjswclgfy1eqc&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0cdyq6aewaw#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=major league coaches labor in obscurity |author=gapay, les |publisher=books.google.com |date=december 1971 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=25 october 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=zcodaaaambaj&pg=pa44&dq=eddie+yost+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=eh3gtouch4lhbqs36dsp&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0cdiq6aewajgk#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=20th century all-overlooked stars |author=vass, george |publisher=books.google.com |date=august 1999 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=25 october 2010 }}</ref><ref name=the baseball biography project: eddie yost>{{cite web|url=http://bioproj.sabr.org/bioproj.cfm?a=v&v=l&bid=2155&pid=15639|title=the baseball biography project: eddie yost|author=schiff, andrew |author2=silverman, mathew |publisher=society for american baseball research|accessdate=31 october 2010}}</ref>

yost was signed by the washington senators as an amateur [[free agent]] in {{by|1944}}.<ref name=eddie yost at baseball reference/> he made his major league debut with the senators at the age of 17 on august 16, [[1944 washington senators season|1944]], having never played in the [[minor league baseball|minor leagues]].<ref name=eddie yost at baseball reference/><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=my4daaaambaj&pg=pa69&dq=eddie+yost+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=sljftm_dd5uh4gawj7c5aw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0cdkq6aewbdgk#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=yost bypasses all farms |author=richman, milton |publisher=books.google.com |date=february 1949 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=25 october 2010 }}</ref> yost spent the {{by|1945}} season in the [[united states navy]] before returning to the senators in [[1946 washington senators season|1946]].<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=47cdaaaambaj&pg=pa8&dq=eddie+yost+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=sljftm_dd5uh4gawj7c5aw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0cd0q6aewbtgk#v=onepage&q=eddie%20yost%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=yost-senator from new york |author=dexter, charles |publisher=books.google.com |date=march 1951 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=25 october 2010 }}</ref>

in [[1950 washington senators season|1950]], yost posted career-highs with a .295 [[batting average]] and a .440 [[on base percentage]].<ref name=eddie yost at baseball reference/> in [[1951 washington senators season|1951]] he led the american league with 36 [[double (baseball)|doubles]] and produced a career-high 65 [[runs batted in]].<ref name=eddie yost at baseball reference/> he earned a place as a reserve player for the american league team in the [[1952 major league baseball all-star game|1952 all-star game]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/nls/nls195207080.shtml |title=1952 all-star game |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=25 october 2010 }}</ref> between august 30, [[1949 washington senators season|1949]] and may 11, [[1955 washington senators season|1955]], yost played in 829 consecutive games for the senators, the ninth longest [[major league baseball consecutive games played streaks|consecutive game streak]] in major league history.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-almanac.com/feats/feats2.shtml |title=consecutive games played |publisher=baseball almanac |accessdate=25 october 2010 }}</ref> yost's [[home run]] totals were diminished by having to play his home games in washington's cavernous [[griffith stadium]].<ref name=12 years in the wrong park!>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=os4daaaambaj&pg=pa67&dq=eddie+yost+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=kdbftmecemt6lwfnuc0d&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0cc8q6aewaq#v=onepage&q=eddie%20yost%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=12 years in the wrong park! |author=middlesworth, hal |publisher=books.google.com |date=december 1960 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=25 october 2010 }}</ref> between 1944 and [[1953 washington senators season|1953]], he hit only 3 home runs at [[home (sports)|home]] while hitting 52 home runs on the [[road (sports)|road]].<ref name=the bill james historical baseball abstract>{{cite book |author=james, bill |title=[[the bill james historical baseball abstract]] |publisher=free press |location=new york |year=2001 |pages= 558 |isbn=0-684-80697-5}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/event_hr.cgi?n1=yosted01&t=b |title=eddie yost home run log |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=25 october 2010 }}</ref>

yost led american league third basemen eight times in [[putout]]s, seven times in [[double play]]s, three times in [[assist (baseball)|assists]] and twice in fielding percentage.<ref name=the baseball biography project: eddie yost/> he set american league career records with 2,356 putouts, 3,659 assists, and 6,285 [[total chances]].<ref name=the baseball biography project: eddie yost/> his 2,356 putouts ranks him third all-time among third basemen behind [[brooks robinson]] and [[jimmy collins]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leaders/po_3b_career.shtml |title=career leaders & records for putouts as third baseman |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=1 november 2010 }}</ref> in {{by|1960}}, he surpassed [[pie traynor]]'s major league record for most games played as a third baseman with 1,865 games.<ref name=17 years at third base!>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=gy0daaaambaj&pg=pa61&dq=eddie+yost+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=zyhfto-ol4aglaeg5eeg&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0ccsq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=eddie%20yost%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=17 years at third base! |author=middlesworth, hal |publisher=books.google.com |date=october 1960 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=25 october 2010 }}</ref> yost was the first third baseman in history to appear in more than 2,000 games.<ref name=the baseball biography project: eddie yost/> baseball historian [[bill james]] ranked yost 24th all-time among third baseman in his [[the bill james historical baseball abstract|historical baseball abstract]].<ref name=the bill james historical baseball abstract/>

yost was signed by the washington senators as an amateur [[free agent]] in 1944.<ref name=eddie yost at baseball reference/> he made his major league debut with the senators at the age of 17 on august 16, 1944, having never played in the [[minor league baseball|minor leagues]].<ref name=eddie yost at baseball reference/><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=my4daaaambaj&pg=pa69&dq=eddie+yost+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=sljftm_dd5uh4gawj7c5aw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0cdkq6aewbdgk#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=yost bypasses all farms |author=richman, milton |publisher=books.google.com |date=february 1949 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=25 october 2010 }}</ref> yost spent the 1945 season in the [[united states navy]] before returning to the senators in 1946.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=47cdaaaambaj&pg=pa8&dq=eddie+yost+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=sljftm_dd5uh4gawj7c5aw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0cd0q6aewbtgk#v=onepage&q=eddie%20yost%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=yost-senator from new york |author=dexter, charles |publisher=books.google.com |date=march 1951 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=25 october 2010 }}</ref>

in 1950, yost posted career-highs with a .295 [[batting average]] and a .440 [[on base percentage]].<ref name=eddie yost at baseball reference/> in 1951 he led the american league with 36 [[double (baseball)|doubles]] and produced a career-high 65 [[runs batted in]].<ref name=eddie yost at baseball reference/> he earned a place as a reserve player for the american league team in the [[1952 major league baseball all-star game|1952 all-star game]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/nls/nls195207080.shtml |title=1952 all-star game |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=25 october 2010 }}</ref> between august 30, 1949 and may 11, 1955, yost played in 829 consecutive games for the senators, the ninth longest [[major league baseball consecutive games played streaks|consecutive game streak]] in major league history.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-almanac.com/feats/feats2.shtml |title=consecutive games played |publisher=baseball almanac |accessdate=25 october 2010 }}</ref> yost's [[home run]] totals were diminished by having to play his home games in washington's cavernous [[griffith stadium]].<ref name=12 years in the wrong park!>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=os4daaaambaj&pg=pa67&dq=eddie+yost+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=kdbftmecemt6lwfnuc0d&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0cc8q6aewaq#v=onepage&q=eddie%20yost%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=12 years in the wrong park! |author=middlesworth, hal |publisher=books.google.com |date=december 1960 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=25 october 2010 }}</ref> between 1944 and [[1953 washington senators season|1953]], he hit only 3 home runs at [[home (sports)|home]] while hitting 52 home runs on the [[road (sports)|road]].<ref name=the bill james historical baseball abstract>{{cite book |author=james, bill |title=[[the bill james historical baseball abstract]] |publisher=free press |location=new york |year=2001 |pages= 558 |isbn=0-684-80697-5}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/event_hr.cgi?n1=yosted01&t=b |title=eddie yost home run log |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=25 october 2010 }}</ref>

yost led american league third basemen eight times in [[putout]]s, seven times in [[double play]]s, three times in [[assist (baseball)|assists]] and twice in fielding percentage.<ref name=the baseball biography project: eddie yost/> he set american league career records with 2,356 putouts, 3,659 assists, and 6,285 [[total chances]].<ref name=the baseball biography project: eddie yost/> his 2,356 putouts ranks him third all-time among third basemen behind [[brooks robinson]] and [[jimmy collins]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leaders/po_3b_career.shtml |title=career leaders & records for putouts as third baseman |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=1 november 2010 }}</ref> in 1960, he surpassed [[pie traynor]]'s major league record for most games played as a third baseman with 1,865 games.<ref name=17 years at third base!>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=gy0daaaambaj&pg=pa61&dq=eddie+yost+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=zyhfto-ol4aglaeg5eeg&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0ccsq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=eddie%20yost%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=17 years at third base! |author=middlesworth, hal |publisher=books.google.com |date=october 1960 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=25 october 2010 }}</ref> yost was the first third baseman in history to appear in more than 2,000 games.<ref name=the baseball biography project: eddie yost/> baseball historian [[bill james]] ranked yost 24th all-time among third baseman in his [[the bill james historical baseball abstract|historical baseball abstract]].<ref name=the bill james historical baseball abstract/>

'''edward frederick joseph eddie yost''' (october 13, 1926  october 16, 2012<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hardballtalk.nbcsports.com/2012/10/16/eddie-yost-dubbed-the-walking-man-passes-away-at-age-86/|title=eddie yost, dubbed the walking man, passes away at age 86|work=nbc sports|date=2012-10-16}}</ref>) was a [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] player and [[coach (baseball)|coach]].<ref name=eddie yost at baseball reference>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/y/yosted01.shtml |title=eddie yost |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=24 october 2010 }}</ref> he played the majority of his [[major league baseball]] career as a [[third baseman]] for the [[minnesota twins|washington senators]], then played 2 seasons each with the [[detroit tigers]] and the [[los angeles angels]] before retiring in 1962.<ref name=eddie yost at baseball reference/> yost batted and threw right-handed.<ref name=eddie yost at baseball reference/> he was nicknamed the walking man for the numerous [[bases on balls]] |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=qc4daaaambaj&pg=pa49&dq=eddie+yost+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=sljftm_dd5uh4gawj7c5aw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0cckq6aewadgk#v=onepage&q&f=false yost led american league third basemen eight times in [[putout]]s, seven times in [[double play]]s, three times in [[assist (baseball)|assists]] and twice in fielding percentage.<ref name=sabrbio/> he set american league career records with 2,356 putouts, 3,659 assists, and 6,285 [[total chances]].<ref name=sabrbio/> his 2,356 putouts ranks him third all-time among third basemen behind [[brooks robinson]] and [[jimmy collins]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leaders/po_3b_career.shtml |title=career leaders & records for putouts as third baseman |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=1 november 2010 }}</ref> in 1960, he surpassed [[pie traynor]]'s major league record for most games played as a third baseman with 1,865 games.<ref name=17 years at third base!>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=gy0daaaambaj&pg=pa61&dq=eddie+yost+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=zyhfto-ol4aglaeg5eeg&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0ccsq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=eddie%20yost%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=17 years at third base! |author=middlesworth, hal |publisher=books.google.com |date=october 1960 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=25 october 2010 }}</ref> yost was the first third baseman in history to appear in more than 2,000 games.<ref name=sabrbio/> baseball historian [[bill james]] ranked yost 24th all-time among third baseman in his [[the bill james historical baseball abstract|historical baseball abstract]].<ref name=the bill james historical baseball abstract/>

bench had another strong year in [[1972 cincinnati reds season|1972]], again winning the most valuable player award and leading the national league in home runs (40) and rbis (125), to help propel the reds to another national league west division title, and a five game victory over the [[1972 pittsburgh pirates season|pittsburgh pirates]] in the [[1972 national league championship series]].<ref name=johnny bench career statistics at baseball reference/><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1972.shtml#nlmvp 1972 national league most valuable player award voting results at baseball reference]</ref> one of his most dramatic home runs{{citation needed|date=april 2009}} was likely his ninth-[[inning]], [[lead off]], [[opposite field]] home run in the final game of the 1972 national league championship series.<ref name=''johnny bench: number 1 home run hitter of all catchers''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=7jmdaaaambaj&pg=pa60&dq=baseball+digest+johnny+bench#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20johnny%20bench&f=false ''johnny bench: number 1 home run hitter of all catchers'', by hal mccoy, baseball digest, december 1980, vol. 39, no. 12, issn 0005-609x]</ref> the solo shot tied the game 3-3, in a game the reds went on to win later in the inning on a wild pitch, 4-3.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/cin/cin197210110.shtml 1972 nlcs game 5 box score at baseball reference]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1972_nlcs.shtml 1972 nlcs at baseball reference]</ref> it was hailed after the game as one of the great [[clutch hitter|clutch]] home runs of all time.{{citation needed|date=april 2009}} however, the reds would lose in the [[1972 world series|world series]] to a strong [[1972 oakland athletics season|oakland athletics]] team in seven games.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1972_ws.shtml 1972 world series at baseball reference]</ref>

* [http://books.google.com/books?id=7jmdaaaambaj&pg=pa60&dq=baseball+digest+johnny+bench#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20johnny%20bench&f=false ''johnny bench: number 1 home run hitter of all catchers'', baseball digest, december 1980]

* [http://books.google.com/books?id=kssdaaaambaj&pg=pa64&dq=baseball+digest+johnny+bench#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20johnny%20bench&f=false ''johnny bench: from binger to cooperstown'', baseball digest, february 2000]

bench had another strong year in [[1972 cincinnati reds season|1972]], again winning the most valuable player award and leading the national league in home runs (40) and rbis (125), to help propel the reds to another national league west division title, and a five game victory over the [[1972 pittsburgh pirates season|pittsburgh pirates]] in the [[1972 national league championship series]].<ref name=johnny bench career statistics at baseball reference/><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1972.shtml#nlmvp 1972 national league most valuable player award voting results at baseball reference]</ref> one of his most dramatic home runs{{citation needed|date=april 2009}} was likely his ninth-[[inning]], [[lead off]], [[opposite field]] home run in the final game of the 1972 national league championship series.<ref name=''johnny bench: number 1 home run hitter of all catchers''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=7jmdaaaambaj&pg=pa60&dq=baseball+digest+johnny+bench#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20johnny%20bench&f=false ''johnny bench: number 1 home run hitter of all catchers'', by hal mccoy, baseball digest, december 1980, vol. 39, no. 12, issn 0005-609x]</ref> the solo shot tied the game 3-3, in a game the reds went on to win later in the inning on a wild pitch, 4-3.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/cin/cin197210110.shtml 1972 nlcs game 5 box score at baseball reference]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1972_nlcs.shtml 1972 nlcs at baseball reference]</ref> it was hailed after the game as one of the great [[clutch hitter|clutch]] home runs of all time.{{citation needed|date=april 2009}} however, the reds would lose in the [[1972 world series|world series]] to a strong [[1972 oakland athletics season|oakland athletics]] team in seven games.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1972_ws.shtml 1972 world series at baseball reference]</ref>

bench popularized the hinged [[baseball_glove#varieties|catcher's mitt]], first introduced by [[randy hundley]] of the [[chicago cubs]].<ref name=johnny bench at the baseball library/><ref>[http://www.baseballlibrary.com/ballplayers/player.php?name=randy_hundley_1942 randy hundley at the baseball library]</ref><ref name=''are catchers today as good defensively as in the past?''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=ucsdaaaambaj&pg=pa58&dq=baseball+digest+catchers#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20catchers&f=false ''are catchers today as good defensively as in the past?'', by rick van blair, baseball digest, march 1994, vol. 53, no. 3, issn 0005-609x]</ref> he began using the mitt after a stint on the disabled list in [[1966 cincinnati reds season|1966]] for a thumb injury on his throwing hand. the mitt allowed bench to tuck his throwing arm safely to the side when receiving the pitch.<ref name=http://entertainment.howstuffworks.com/> by the turn of the decade, the hinged mitt became standard catchers' equipment. having huge hands (a famous photograph features him holding seven baseballs in his right hand<ref>[http://www.uc.edu/news/view.asp?infoid=1915&photo=image3 http://www.uc.edu]</ref>), bench also tended to block breaking balls in the dirt by scooping them with one hand instead of the more common and fundamentally proper way: dropping to both knees and blocking the ball using the chest protector to keep the ball in front.<ref name=''are catchers today as good defensively as in the past?''/>

* [http://books.google.com/books?id=7jmdaaaambaj&pg=pa60&dq=baseball+digest+johnny+bench#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20johnny%20bench&f=false ''johnny bench: number 1 home run hitter of all catchers'', baseball digest, december 1980]

* [http://books.google.com/books?id=kssdaaaambaj&pg=pa64&dq=baseball+digest+johnny+bench#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20johnny%20bench&f=false ''johnny bench: from binger to cooperstown'', baseball digest, february 2000]

bench popularized the hinged [[baseball_glove#varieties|catcher's mitt]], first introduced by [[randy hundley]] of the [[chicago cubs]].<ref name=johnny bench at the baseball library/><ref>[http://www.baseballlibrary.com/ballplayers/player.php?name=randy_hundley_1942 randy hundley at the baseball library]</ref><ref name=''are catchers today as good defensively as in the past?''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=ucsdaaaambaj&pg=pa58&dq=baseball+digest+catchers#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20catchers&f=false ''are catchers today as good defensively as in the past?'', by rick van blair, baseball digest, march 1994, vol. 53, no. 3, issn 0005-609x]</ref> he began using the mitt after a stint on the disabled list in [[1966 cincinnati reds season|1966]] for a thumb injury on his throwing hand. the mitt allowed bench to tuck his throwing arm safely to the side when receiving the pitch.<ref name=http://entertainment.howstuffworks.com/> by the turn of the decade, the hinged mitt became standard catchers' equipment. having huge hands (a famous photograph features him holding seven baseballs in his right hand<ref>[http://www.uc.edu/news/view.asp?infoid=1915&photo=image3 http://www.uc.edu]</ref>), bench also tended to block breaking balls in the dirt by scooping them with one hand instead of the more common and fundamentally proper way: dropping to both knees and blocking the ball using the chest protector to keep the ball in front.<ref name=''are catchers today as good defensively as in the past?''/>

* [http://books.google.com/books?id=7jmdaaaambaj&pg=pa60&dq=baseball+digest+johnny+bench#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20johnny%20bench&f=false ''johnny bench: number 1 home run hitter of all catchers'', baseball digest, december 1980]

* [http://books.google.com/books?id=kssdaaaambaj&pg=pa64&dq=baseball+digest+johnny+bench#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20johnny%20bench&f=false ''johnny bench: from binger to cooperstown'', baseball digest, february 2000]

bench had another strong year in [[1972 cincinnati reds season|1972]], again winning the most valuable player award and leading the national league in home runs (40) and rbi (125), to help propel the reds to another national league west division title, and a five-game victory over the [[1972 pittsburgh pirates season|pittsburgh pirates]] in the [[1972 national league championship series]].<ref name=johnny bench career statistics at baseball reference/><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1972.shtml#nlmvp 1972 national league most valuable player award voting results at baseball reference]</ref> one of his most dramatic home runs<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/mlb/history/postseason/mlb_lcs.jsp?feature=this_day |title=league championship series overview | mlb.com: history |publisher=mlb.mlb.com |date=2013-05-24 |accessdate=2013-09-24}}</ref> was likely his ninth-[[inning]], [[lead off]], [[opposite field]] home run in the final game of the 1972 national league championship series.<ref name=''johnny bench: number 1 home run hitter of all catchers''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=7jmdaaaambaj&pg=pa60&dq=baseball+digest+johnny+bench#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20johnny%20bench&f=false ''johnny bench: number 1 home run hitter of all catchers'', by hal mccoy, baseball digest, december 1980, vol. 39, no. 12, issn 0005-609x]</ref> the solo shot tied the game 33, in a game the reds went on to win later in the inning on a wild pitch, 43.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/cin/cin197210110.shtml 1972 nlcs game 5 box score at baseball reference]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1972_nlcs.shtml 1972 nlcs at baseball reference]</ref> it was hailed after the game as one of the great [[clutch hitter|clutch]] home runs of all time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.geocaching.com/seek/cache_details.aspx?guid=c61a5e96-6143-48a2-9557-575f50fabea9 |title=gc1gqab fp series #226 - johnny bench (traditional cache) in texas, united states created by drives |publisher=geocaching.com |date= |accessdate=2013-09-24}}</ref> however, the reds would lose in the [[1972 world series|world series]] to a strong [[1972 oakland athletics season|oakland athletics]] team in seven games.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1972_ws.shtml 1972 world series at baseball reference]</ref>

* [http://books.google.com/books?id=7jmdaaaambaj&pg=pa60&dq=baseball+digest+johnny+bench#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20johnny%20bench&f=false ''johnny bench: number 1 home run hitter of all catchers'', baseball digest, december 1980]

* [http://books.google.com/books?id=kssdaaaambaj&pg=pa64&dq=baseball+digest+johnny+bench#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20johnny%20bench&f=false ''johnny bench: from binger to cooperstown'', baseball digest, february 2000]

'''james howard sundberg''' (born may 18, 1951 in [[galesburg, illinois]]) is a former [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] [[catcher]] known for being one of the best defensive catchers of his era.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=szmdaaaambaj&pg=pa54&dq=jim+sundberg+baseball+digest&cd=3#v=onepage&q=jim%20sundberg%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''jim sundberg adds hitting to his skills on defense'', by randy harvey, baseball digest, december 1977, vol. 36, no. 12, issn 0005-609x]</ref><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=1jmdaaaambaj&pg=pa86&dq=jim+sundberg+baseball+digest&cd=2#v=onepage&q=jim%20sundberg%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''jim sundberg: does he rate as the number 1 catcher?'', by phil elderkin, baseball digest, november 1978, vol. 37, no. 11, issn 0005-609x]</ref> he played for a number of [[major league baseball|major league]] teams, most significantly the [[texas rangers (baseball)|texas rangers]] and [[kansas city royals]], with whom we won a world championship. he batted and threw right-handed.

sundberg established himself as one of the top defensive catchers in the [[american league]] by winning six consecutive [[gold glove awards]] from [[1976 texas rangers season|1976]] to [[1981 texas rangers season|1981]].<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/gold_glove_al.shtml#1981 american league gold glove award winners at baseball reference]</ref> in december 1983, after ten years with the rangers, he was traded to the [[1984 milwaukee brewers season|milwaukee brewers]].<ref name=jim sundberg trades and transactions at baseball almanac>[http://www.baseball-almanac.com/players/trades.php?p=sundbji01 jim sundberg trades and transactions at baseball almanac]</ref> after playing one season with the brewers, he was traded to the kansas city royals. sundberg's veteran experience helped bolster the [[1985 kansas city royals season|royals']] young pitching staff, and the team's combined [[earned run average]] improved to second best in the american league.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=sjqdaaaambaj&pg=pa80&dq=jim+sundberg+baseball+digest&cd=1#v=onepage&q=jim%20sundberg%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''jim sundberg: forgotten man in the catching derby'', by bob nightengale, baseball digest, december 1988, vol. 47, no. 12, issn 0005-609x]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/al/1985.shtml 1985 american league team statistics and standings at baseball reference]</ref> the royals went on to win the [[1985 world series|1985 world championship]]. in game six of that series, sundberg scored the dramatic ninth [[inning]] winning [[run (baseball)|run]] by sliding into [[home plate]], skillfully avoiding the [[tag out|tag]] of st. louis cardinals catcher [[darrell porter]].<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/kca/kca198510260.shtml 1985 world series game 6 box score at baseball reference]</ref> in [[1986 kansas city royals season|1986]], sundberg helped the royals pitching staff lead the league in earned run average, however they fell to third place in the american league's western division.

sundberg ended his career with 1493 [[hit (baseball)|hits]] in 6021 [[at bat]]s, for a .248 [[batting average]] along with 95 [[home run]]s and 624 [[runs batted in|rbis]] in 1962 [[games played|games]].<ref name=jim sundberg at baseball reference/> sundberg was the first catcher to win 6 american league gold gloves, although [[bob boone]] won 5 in the american league and two more in the national league. his 1976 gold glove was the first by any ranger player. he led american league catchers in [[fielding percentage]] six times, ending his career with a .993 average.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa86&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, july 2001, vol. 60, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref> he completed 145 [[double play]]s in 1962 games in his career, and holds the major league record for the best ratio of double plays to [[error (baseball)|errors]] of any catcher in major league history behind the plate for at least 1000 games.<ref name=jim sundberg at baseball reference/><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=9s0daaaambaj&pg=pa26&dq=baseball+digest+defensive+catchers#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20defensive%20catchers&f=false ''for catchers, the name of the game is defense'', by george vass, baseball digest, may 2005, vol. 64, no. 3, issn 0005-609x]</ref> sundberg played more games as a catcher than any other player in rangers history (1512).<ref>[http://members.tripod.com/bb_catchers/catchers/mostgame.htm most games caught for team at the encyclopedia of catchers]</ref> at the time of his retirement, sundberg had caught more major league games than any man in history except his contemporary [[bob boone]].<ref>[http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=950de4d81630f931a2575ac0a96f948260 sports people: baseball; sundberg to retire - new york times<!-- bot generated title -->]</ref> he still ranks fifth today.<ref>[http://bb_catchers.tripod.com/catchers/8clistgc.htm encyclopedia of baseball catchers 800 games caught - list by games caught table<!-- bot generated title -->]</ref> richard kendall of the [[society for american baseball research]] devised an unscientific study that ranked sundberg as the third most dominating fielding catcher in major league history.<ref>[http://members.tripod.com/bb_catchers/catchers/dominate.htm dominating fielding catchers at the encyclopedia of baseball catchers]</ref>

'''ted lyle simmons''' (born august 9, 1949, in [[highland park, michigan]]) is an [[united states|american]] former [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] player and [[coach (baseball)|coach]].<ref name=ted simmons at baseball reference>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/s/simmote01.shtml |title=ted simmons |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=1 september 2010 }}</ref> a [[switch-hitter]], simmons was a [[catcher]] for most of his [[major league baseball]] career with the [[st. louis cardinals]] (1968-80), the [[milwaukee brewers]] (1981-85) and the [[atlanta braves]] (1986-88).<ref name=ted simmons at baseball reference/> although he was often overshadowed by his contemporary, [[johnny bench]], simmons is considered one of the best [[batting (baseball)|hitting]] catchers in major league baseball history.<ref name=how ted simmons rates with hall of fame catchers>{{cite web |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=wssdaaaambaj&pg=pa9&lpg=pa9&dq=ted+simmons+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=z0osofu9-u&sig=4ns_bz40i6l40iiqtbdigespays&hl=en&ei=2x9-ti3hbchflgftv5dscw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0ccsq6aewbzgk#v=onepage&q=ted%20simmons%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=how ted simmons rates with hall of fame catchers |publisher=baseball digest |accessdate=31 august 2010 }}</ref> while he didn't possess bench's power hitting ability, he hit for a higher [[batting average]].<ref name=ted simmons: the national league's other catcher>{{cite web |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ctmdaaaambaj&pg=pa28&lpg=pa28&dq=ted+simmons+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=mranxcjhby&sig=ytuk2szzrsrgukuyrxkh3grb67a&hl=en&ei=qe99tiudbsgblgfcujzscw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0ccqq6aewbq#v=onepage&q=ted%20simmons%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=ted simmons: the national league's other catcher |author=murray, jim |publisher=books.google.com |date=october 1977 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=1 september 2010 }}</ref> a volatile competitor with an intense desire to win, simmons once fought with team-mate [[john denny]] during a game at [[busch memorial stadium]], in the runway between the club house and the [[dugout (baseball)|dugout]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=pdqdaaaambaj&pg=pa75&lpg=pa75&dq=ted+simmons+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=f3dmkukesa&sig=2nrzw1h-phe2suweybyq0pfo_08&hl=en&ei=ssv-tk2egcwqlafcyvtrcw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0ccaq6aewaw#v=onepage&q=ted%20simmons%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=ted simmons talks about the challenges of hitting |author=koster, rich |publisher=books.google.com |date=march 1983 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=1 september 2010 }}</ref>

simmons refused to sign a contract for the amount of salary offered by the cardinals in [[1972 st. louis cardinals season|1972]], electing to play without a contract.<ref name=ted simmons: losing drives me crazy>{{cite web |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=4dedaaaambaj&pg=pa21&lpg=pa21&dq=ted+simmons+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=pnctesvfox&sig=vbpt2y__xrccszh8_mhn0sevd5g&hl=en&ei=yff9tppbaol6lwfvyshscw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0cbgq6aewatgk#v=onepage&q=ted%20simmons%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=ted simmons: losing drives me crazy! |author=broeg, bob |publisher=books.google.com |date=june 1973 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=1 september 2010 }}</ref> he ultimately signed a contract well into the season during which he was recognized as one of the top catchers in the league by earning a spot as a reserve on the {{by|1972}} [[1972 major league baseball all-star game|national league all-star]] team.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/nls/nls197207250.shtml |title=1972 all-star game |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=1 september 2010 }}</ref> he finished the year with a .303 batting average with 16 home runs and 96 runs batted in, breaking [[walker cooper]]'s team record for rbis by a catcher and, set the team record for home runs by a catcher, previously held jointly by [[gene oliver]] and [[tim mccarver]].<ref name=ted simmons at baseball reference/><ref name=ted simmons: losing drives me crazy/> his defense began to improve as well, posting a .991 [[fielding percentage]] and leading national league catchers in [[assist (baseball)|assists]] and in [[putout]]s.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1972-fielding-leaders.shtml |title=1972 national league fielding leaders |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=1 september 2010 }}</ref> despite the cardinals finishing the season in fourth place, simmons would finish in 10th place in the national league most valuable player award balloting.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1972.shtml#nlmvp |title=1972 national league most valuable player award balloting results |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=1 september 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1972.shtml |title=1972 national league final standings |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=1 september 2010 }}</ref> simmons continued to produce offensively in [[1973 st. louis cardinals season|1973]] with a .310 batting average, along with 13 home runs and 91 runs batted in.<ref name=ted simmons at baseball reference/> he also led the league's catchers in putouts and finished second in assists, earning his second all-star berth as the cardinals again finished the season in second place.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1973-fielding-leaders.shtml |title=1973 national league fielding leaders |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=1 september 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/als/als197307240.shtml |title=1973 all-star game |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=1 september 2010 }}</ref>

[[batting average]].<ref name=ted simmons: the national league's other catcher>{{cite web |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ctmdaaaambaj&pg=pa28&lpg=pa28&dq=ted+simmons+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=mranxcjhby&sig=ytuk2szzrsrgukuyrxkh3grb67a&hl=en&ei=qe99tiudbsgblgfcujzscw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0ccqq6aewbq#v=onepage&q=ted%20simmons%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=ted simmons: the national league's other catcher |author=murray, jim |publisher=books.google.com |date=october 1977 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=1 september 2010 }}</ref> a volatile competitor with an intense desire to win, simmons once fought with team-mate [[john denny]] during a game at [[busch memorial stadium]], in the runway between the club house and the [[dugout (baseball)|dugout]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=pdqdaaaambaj&pg=pa75&lpg=pa75&dq=ted+simmons+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=f3dmkukesa&sig=2nrzw1h-phe2suweybyq0pfo_08&hl=en&ei=ssv-tk2egcwqlafcyvtrcw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0ccaq6aewaw#v=onepage&q=ted%20simmons%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=ted simmons talks about the challenges of hitting |author=koster, rich |publisher=books.google.com |date=march 1983 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=1 september 2010 }}</ref>

simmons refused to sign a contract for the amount of salary offered by the cardinals in [[1972 st. louis cardinals season|1972]], electing to play without a contract.<ref name=ted simmons: losing drives me crazy>{{cite web |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=4dedaaaambaj&pg=pa21&lpg=pa21&dq=ted+simmons+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=pnctesvfox&sig=vbpt2y__xrccszh8_mhn0sevd5g&hl=en&ei=yff9tppbaol6lwfvyshscw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0cbgq6aewatgk#v=onepage&q=ted%20simmons%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=ted simmons: losing drives me crazy! |author=broeg, bob |publisher=books.google.com |date=june 1973 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=1 september 2010 }}</ref> he ultimately signed a contract well into the season during which he was recognized as one of the top catchers in the league by earning a spot as a reserve on the {{by|1972}} [[1972 major league baseball all-star game|national league all-star]] team.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/nls/nls197207250.shtml |title=1972 all-star game |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=1 september 2010 }}</ref> he finished the year with a .303 batting average with 16 home runs and 96 runs batted in, breaking [[walker cooper]]'s team record for rbis by a catcher and, set the team record for home runs by a catcher, previously held jointly by [[gene oliver]] and [[tim mccarver]].<ref name=ted simmons at baseball reference/><ref name=ted simmons: losing drives me crazy/> his defense began to improve as well, posting a .991 [[fielding percentage]] and leading national league catchers in [[assist (baseball)|assists]] and in [[putout]]s.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1972-fielding-leaders.shtml |title=1972 national league fielding leaders |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=1 september 2010 }}</ref> despite the cardinals finishing the season in fourth place, simmons would finish in 10th place in the national league most valuable player award balloting.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1972.shtml#nlmvp |title=1972 national league most valuable player award balloting results |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=1 september 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1972.shtml |title=1972 national league final standings |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=1 september 2010 }}</ref> simmons continued to produce offensively in [[1973 st. louis cardinals season|1973]] with a .310 batting average, along with 13 home runs and 91 runs batted in.<ref name=ted simmons at baseball reference/> he also led the league's catchers in putouts and finished second in assists, earning his second all-star berth as the cardinals again finished the season in second place.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1973-fielding-leaders.shtml |title=1973 national league fielding leaders |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=1 september 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/als/als197307240.shtml |title=1973 all-star game |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=1 september 2010 }}</ref>

* [http://books.google.com/books?id=wssdaaaambaj&pg=pa9&lpg=pa9&dq=ted+simmons+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=z0osofu9-u&sig=4ns_bz40i6l40iiqtbdigespays&hl=en&ei=2x9-ti3hbchflgftv5dscw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0ccsq6aewbzgk#v=onepage&q=ted%20simmons%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''how ted simmons compares with hall of fame catchers''], baseball digest, august 2002

'''harold joseph pie traynor''' (november 11, 1899 - march 16, 1972) was an [[united states|american]] [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] player.<ref name=pie traynor>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/t/traynpi01.shtml |title=pie traynor |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=27 october 2010 }}</ref> he played his entire [[major league baseball]] career as a [[third baseman]] with the [[pittsburgh pirates]] (1920-37).<ref name=pie traynor/> he batted and threw right-handed.<ref name=pie traynor/> following world war ii, traynor was often cited as the greatest third baseman in major league baseball history.<ref name=pie traynor greatest of the third basemen>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=7didaaaambaj&pg=pa87&dq=pie+traynor+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=twbitnxobaoj4gbxpcnvca&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0ccgq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=pie%20traynor%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=pie traynor greatest of the third basemen |author=kaese, harold |publisher=books.google.com |date=june, 1972 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=27 october 2010 }}</ref><ref name=the bill james historical baseball abstract>{{cite book |author=james, bill |title=[[the bill james historical baseball abstract]] |publisher=free press |location=new york |year=2001 |pages= 554 |isbn=0-684-80697-5}}</ref><ref name=pie traynor best of all third basemen>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=5dedaaaambaj&pg=pa70&dq=pie+traynor+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=j8jltminiikglaei7tdqca&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0cc4q6aewaq#v=onepage&q=pie%20traynor%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=pie traynor best of all third basemen |author=birtwell, roger |publisher=books.google.com |date=september, 1969 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=30 october 2010 }}</ref> he was inducted into the [[baseball hall of fame]] in [[baseball hall of fame balloting, 1948|1948]].<ref name=pie traynor at the baseball hall of fame>{{cite web |url=http://baseballhall.org/hof/traynor-pie |title=pie traynor at the baseball hall of fame |publisher=baseballhall.org |accessdate=27 october 2010 }}</ref>

traynor was born in [[framingham, massachusetts]] to parents who had emigrated from canada.<ref name=the baseball biography project: pie traynor>{{cite web|url=http://bioproj.sabr.org/bioproj.cfm?a=v&v=l&bid=2124&pid=3515|title=the baseball biography project: pie traynor|last=forr|first=james|publisher=society for american baseball research|accessdate=30 october 2010}}</ref> he received his nickname as a child in [[somerville, massachusetts]] because he frequented a grocery store and often asked for pie.  the store owner called him ''pie face'', which was later shortened to pie by his friends.<ref name=pie traynor greatest of the third basemen/> traynor began his playing career in {{by|1920}} as a [[shortstop]] for the [[portsmouth truckers]] of the [[virginia league]].<ref name=pie traynor minor league statistics>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/minors/player.cgi?id=trayno001har |title=pie traynor minor league statistics |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=27 october 2010 }}</ref> he was asked by a [[atlanta braves|boston braves]] [[scout (sports)|scout]] to work out with the team at [[braves field]] but, the scout forgot to tell the braves manager [[george stallings]].<ref name=on seeing pie traynor again>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=5tidaaaambaj&pg=pa79&dq=pie+traynor+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=sf_htiwnj8_44aals-tlbg&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0cdqq6aewbdgk#v=onepage&q=pie%20traynor%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=on seeing pie traynor again |author=graham, frank |publisher=books.google.com |date=october, 1954 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=27 october 2010 }}</ref> stallings proceeded to run traynor off the field, telling him not to return.<ref name=on seeing pie traynor again/> traynor made his major league debut with the pittsburgh pirates at the age of 21 on september 15, [[1920 pittsburgh pirates season|1920]], appearing in 17 games that season.<ref name=pie traynor/> he appeared in 10 games for the pirates in [[1921 pittsburgh pirates season|1921]], but spent the majority of the season playing for the [[birmingham barons]].<ref name=pie traynor minor league statistics/> he posted a .336 [[batting average]] in 131 games for the barons but, his defense was still a problem as he committed 64 [[error (baseball)|errors]] as a shortstop.<ref name=the baseball biography project: pie traynor/><ref name=pie traynor minor league statistics/>

in a 17 year major league career, traynor played in 1941 [[games played|games]], accumulating 2,416 [[hit (baseball)|hits]] in 7,559 [[at bats]] for a .320 career batting average along with 58 home runs, 1,273 runs batted in and an [[on base percentage]] of .362.<ref name=pie traynor/> he retired with a .946 [[fielding percentage]].<ref name=pie traynor/> traynor was not a home run hitter - he reached a high of 12 in 1923 - but had high numbers of doubles and triples, hitting 371 doubles and 164 triples lifetime and leading the league in triples in 1923, with 19.<ref name=pie traynor/> he hit over .300 ten times and, had over 100 runs batted in (rbi) in a season seven times.<ref name=pie traynor/> among major league third basemen, his seven seasons with more than 100 runs batted in is second only to the nine seasons by [[mike schmidt]].<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=yn5azomxalwc&pg=pa13&dq=pie+traynor+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=-otltorfooa0lqfpnz3uca&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0cckq6aewadgk#v=onepage&q=pie%20traynor%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=third basemen with most 100 rbi seasons |publisher=books.google.com |date=january 2009 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=30 october 2010 }}</ref> [[chipper jones]] is the only other third baseman in history to match traynor's five consecutive seasons with more than 100 runs batted in.<ref name=the baseball biography project: pie traynor/> he had 208 hits in 1923, and was the last pirate infielder with 200 or more hits until shortstop [[jack wilson (shortstop)|jack wilson]], who had 201 hits in 2004. he [[strikeout|struck out]] only 278 times in his career.<ref name=pie traynor/>

traynor was considered the best fielding third baseman of his era, leading the national league in [[fielding percentage]] once, [[assist (baseball)|assists]] and [[double play]]s three times and [[putout]]s seven times.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ncsdaaaambaj&pg=pa35&dq=pie+traynor+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=t_3htnupozsa4qbc__tlbg&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0ceiq6aewbg#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=all-time best third basemen starred as hitters, fielders |author=kuenster, bob |publisher=books.google.com |date=september 1994 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=27 october 2010 }}</ref> his 2,289 putouts ranks him fifth all-time among third basemen.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leaders/po_3b_career.shtml |title=career leaders & records for putouts as third baseman |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=31 october 2010 }}</ref> his 1,863 games played at third base was a major league record that would stand until {{by|1960}} when it was surpassed by [[eddie yost]].<ref name=17 years at third base!>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=gy0daaaambaj&pg=pa61&dq=eddie+yost+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=zyhfto-ol4aglaeg5eeg&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0ccsq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=eddie%20yost%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=17 years at third base! |author=middlesworth, hal |publisher=books.google.com |date=october 1960 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=25 october 2010 }}</ref> traynor is also the only major league baseball player ever to steal [[home plate]] in an all-star game.<ref name=the baseball biography project: pie traynor/> traynor finished in the top ten in voting for the national league's most valuable player award six times during his career.<ref name=pie traynor/>

traynor's reputation as possibly the greatest third baseman of all time has been diminished in recent years, with the modern-era careers of third basemen such as [[eddie mathews]], [[brooks robinson]], [[mike schmidt]] and [[george brett (baseball)|george brett]] moving to the forefront in the memories of baseball fans. baseball historian [[bill james]] ranked traynor only 15th all-time among third baseman in his [[the bill james historical baseball abstract|historical baseball abstract]].<ref name=the bill james historical baseball abstract/> one notable difference between modern players and players from traynor's era, was the difference in [[baseball glove]]s.<ref name=how modern gloves trim batting averages>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ndmdaaaambaj&pg=pa64&dq=pie+traynor+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=-mnlto39gikclae9rdtmca&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0cd0q6aewbtgk#v=onepage&q=pie%20traynor%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=how modern gloves trim batting averages |author=nason, jerry |publisher=books.google.com |date=january 1970 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=30 october 2010 }}</ref> while modern players use webbed gloves, players during traynor's era used gloves whose primary function was protection of the hands.<ref name=how modern gloves trim batting averages/> instead of using his glove to backhand balls hit to his right, traynor often snared them with his bare throwing hand.<ref name=pie traynor greatest of the third basemen/>

[[scout (sports)|scout]] and [[color commentator|radio broadcaster]].<ref name=pie traynor>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/t/traynpi01.shtml |title=pie traynor |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=27 october 2010 }}</ref> he played his entire [[major league baseball]] career as a [[third baseman]] with the [[pittsburgh pirates]] (192037).<ref name=pie traynor/> he batted and threw right-handed.<ref name=pie traynor/> following the second world war, traynor was often cited as the greatest third baseman in major league baseball history.<ref name=pie traynor greatest of the third basemen>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=7didaaaambaj&pg=pa87&dq=pie+traynor+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=pie%20traynor%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=pie traynor greatest of the third basemen |author=kaese, harold |publisher=|date=june, 1972 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=27 october 2010 }}</ref><ref name=the bill james historical baseball hall of fame |publisher=baseballhall.org |accessdate=27 october 2010 }}</ref>

traynor was considered the best fielding third baseman of his era, leading the national league in [[fielding percentage]] once, [[assist (baseball)|assists]] and [[double play]]s three times and [[putout]]s seven times.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ncsdaaaambaj&pg=pa35&dq=pie+traynor+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=all-time best third basemen starred as hitters, fielders |author=kuenster, bob |publisher=|date=september 1994 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=27 october 2010 }}</ref> his 2,289 putouts ranks him fifth all-time among third basemen.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leaders/po_3b_career.shtml |title=career leaders & records for putouts as third baseman |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=31 october 2010 }}</ref> his 1,863 games played at third base was a major league record that would stand until {{by|1960}} when it was surpassed by [[eddie yost]].<ref name=17 years at third base!>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=gy0daaaambaj&pg=pa61&dq=eddie+yost+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=eddie%20yost%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=17 years at third base! |author=middlesworth, hal |publisher=|date=october 1960 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=25 october 2010 }}</ref> traynor is also the only major league baseball player ever to steal [[home plate]] in an all-star game.<ref name=the baseball biography project: pie traynor/> traynor finished in the top ten in voting for the national league's most valuable player award six times during his career.<ref name=pie traynor/>

traynor's reputation as one of the greatest third basemen of all time has been diminished in recent years, with the modern-era careers of third basemen such as [[eddie mathews]], [[brooks robinson]], [[mike schmidt]] and [[george brett (baseball)|george brett]] moving to the forefront in the memories of baseball fans. baseball historian [[bill james]] ranked traynor only 15th all-time among third baseman in his [[the bill james historical baseball abstract|historical baseball abstract]].<ref name=the bill james historical baseball abstract/> one notable difference between modern players and players from traynor's era, was the difference in [[baseball glove]]s.<ref name=how modern gloves trim batting averages>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ndmdaaaambaj&pg=pa64&dq=pie+traynor+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=pie%20traynor%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=how modern gloves trim batting averages |author=nason, jerry |publisher=|date=january 1970 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=30 october 2010 }}</ref> while modern players use webbed gloves, players during traynor's era used gloves whose primary function was protection of the hands.<ref name=how modern gloves trim batting averages/> instead of using his glove to backhand balls hit to his right, traynor often snared them with his bare throwing hand.<ref name=pie traynor greatest of the third basemen/>

following the second world war, traynor was often cited as the greatest third baseman in major league baseball history. in recent years his reputation has diminished, with the modern-era careers of third basemen such as [[eddie mathews]], [[brooks robinson]], [[mike schmidt]] and [[george brett (baseball)|george brett]] moving to the forefront in the memories of baseball fans.<ref name=pie traynor greatest of the third basemen>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=7didaaaambaj&pg=pa87&dq=pie+traynor+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=pie%20traynor%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=pie traynor greatest of the third basemen |author=kaese, harold |publisher=|date=june, 1972 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=27 october 2010 }}</ref><ref name=the bill james historical baseball abstract>{{cite book |author=james, bill |title=[[the bill james historical baseball abstract]] |publisher=free press |location=new york |year=2001 |pages= 554 |isbn=0-684-80697-5}}</ref><ref name=pie traynor best of all third basemen>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=5dedaaaambaj&pg=pa70&dq=pie+traynor+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=pie%20traynor%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=pie traynor best of all third basemen |author=birtwell, roger |publisher=|date=september, 1969 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=30 october 2010 }}</ref>

traynor was born in [[framingham, massachusetts]], to parents who had emigrated from canada.<ref name=the baseball biography project: pie traynor>{{cite web|url=http://bioproj.sabr.org/bioproj.cfm?a=v&v=l&bid=1101&pid=14330|title=the baseball biography project: pie traynor|last=forr|first=james|publisher=society for american baseball research|accessdate=30 october 2010}}</ref> he received his nickname as a child in [[somerville, massachusetts]], because he frequented a grocery store and often asked for pie.  the store owner called him ''pie face'', which was later shortened to pie by his friends.<ref name=pie traynor greatest of the third basemen/> traynor began his playing career in {{by|1920}} as a [[shortstop]] for the [[portsmouth truckers]] of the [[virginia league]].<ref name=pie traynor minor league statistics>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/minors/player.cgi?id=trayno001har |title=pie traynor minor league statistics |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=27 october 2010 }}</ref> he was asked by a [[atlanta braves|boston braves]] [[scout (sports)|scout]] to work out with the team at [[braves field]] but, the scout forgot to tell the braves manager [[george stallings]].<ref name=on seeing pie traynor again>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=5tidaaaambaj&pg=pa79&dq=pie+traynor+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=pie%20traynor%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=on seeing pie traynor again |author=graham, frank |publisher=|date=october, 1954 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=27 october 2010 }}</ref> stallings proceeded to run traynor off the field, telling him not to return.<ref name=on seeing pie traynor again/> traynor made his major league debut with the pittsburgh pirates at the age of 21 on september 15, [[1920 pittsburgh pirates season|1920]], appearing in 17 games that season.<ref name=pie traynor/> he appeared in 10 games for the pirates in [[1921 pittsburgh pirates season|1921]], but spent the majority of the season playing for the [[birmingham barons]].<ref name=pie traynor minor league statistics/> he posted a .336 [[batting average]] in 131 games for the barons, but his defense was still a problem as he committed 64 [[error (baseball)|errors]] as a shortstop.<ref name=the baseball biography project: pie traynor/><ref name=pie traynor minor league statistics/>

in a 17 year major league career, traynor played in 1941 [[games played|games]], accumulating 2,416 [[hit (baseball)|hits]] in 7,559 [[at bats]] for a .320 career batting average along with 58 home runs, 1,273 runs batted in and an [[on base percentage]] of .362.<ref name=pie traynor/> he retired with a .946 [[fielding percentage]].<ref name=pie traynor/> traynor was not a home run hitter - he reached a high of 12 in 1923 - but had high numbers of doubles and triples, hitting 371 doubles and 164 triples lifetime and leading the league in triples in 1923, with 19.<ref name=pie traynor/> he hit over .300 ten times and, had over 100 runs batted in (rbi) in a season seven times.<ref name=pie traynor/> among major league third basemen, his seven seasons with more than 100 runs batted in is second only to the nine seasons by [[mike schmidt]].<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=yn5azomxalwc&pg=pa13&dq=pie+traynor+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=pie%20traynor%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=third basemen with most 100 rbi seasons |publisher=|date=january 2009 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=30 october 2010 }}</ref> [[chipper jones]] is the only other third baseman in history to match traynor's five consecutive seasons with more than 100 runs batted in.<ref name=the baseball biography project: pie traynor/> he had 208 hits in 1923, and was the last pirate infielder with 200 or more hits until shortstop [[jack wilson (shortstop)|jack wilson]], who had 201 hits in 2004. he [[strikeout|struck out]] only 278 times in his career.<ref name=pie traynor/>

traynor was considered the best fielding third baseman of his era, leading the national league in [[fielding percentage]] once, [[assist (baseball)|assists]] and [[double play]]s three times and [[putout]]s seven times.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ncsdaaaambaj&pg=pa35&dq=pie+traynor+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=all-time best third basemen starred as hitters, fielders |author=kuenster, bob |publisher=|date=september 1994 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=27 october 2010 }}</ref> his 2,289 putouts ranks him fifth all-time among third basemen.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leaders/po_3b_career.shtml |title=career leaders & records for putouts as third baseman |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=31 october 2010 }}</ref> his 1,863 games played at third base was a major league record that would stand until {{by|1960}} when it was surpassed by [[eddie yost]].<ref name=17 years at third base!>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=gy0daaaambaj&pg=pa61&dq=eddie+yost+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=eddie%20yost%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=17 years at third base! |author=middlesworth, hal |publisher=|date=october 1960 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=25 october 2010 }}</ref> traynor is also the only major league baseball player ever to steal [[home plate]] in an all-star game.<ref name=the baseball biography project: pie traynor/> traynor finished in the top ten in voting for the national league's most valuable player award six times during his career.<ref name=pie traynor/>

in {{by|1999}}, he ranked number 70 on ''[[the sporting news]]''' list of the 100 greatest baseball players, and was nominated as a finalist for the [[major league baseball all-century team]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://archive.sportingnews.com/baseball/100/ |title=100 greatest baseball players |publisher=sportingnews.com |accessdate=27 october 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://mlb.mlb.com/mlb/history/mlb_history_moreinfo.jsp |title=the major league baseball all-century team |publisher=mlb.com |accessdate=27 october 2010 }}</ref> baseball historian [[bill james]] ranked traynor 15th all-time among third baseman in his [[the bill james historical baseball abstract|historical baseball abstract]].<ref name=the bill james historical baseball abstract/> one notable difference between modern players and players from traynor's era, was the difference in [[baseball glove]]s.<ref name=how modern gloves trim batting averages>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ndmdaaaambaj&pg=pa64&dq=pie+traynor+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=pie%20traynor%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=how modern gloves trim batting averages |author=nason, jerry |publisher=|date=january 1970 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=30 october 2010 }}</ref> while modern players use webbed gloves, players during traynor's era used gloves whose primary function was protection of the hands.<ref name=how modern gloves trim batting averages/> instead of using his glove to backhand balls hit to his right, traynor often snared them with his bare throwing hand.<ref name=pie traynor greatest of the third basemen/>

'''herold dominic muddy ruel''' (february 20, 1896 - november 13, 1963) was an [[united states|american]] [[catcher]], [[coach (baseball)|coach]], [[manager (baseball)|manager]] and [[general manager (baseball)|general manager]] in [[major league baseball]]. he played for 19 seasons with the [[baltimore orioles|st. louis browns]], [[new york yankees]], [[minnesota twins|washington senators]], [[boston red sox]], [[detroit tigers]], and the [[chicago white sox]].<ref name=muddy ruel at baseball reference>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/r/ruelmu01.shtml muddy ruel at baseball reference]</ref> ruel was one of the top defensive catchers of his era, and is best remembered for scoring the winning run for the washington senators in game 7 of the [[1924 world series]] and, for being the [[battery (baseball)|battery]]-mate of [[baseball hall of fame]] [[pitcher]], [[walter johnson]].<ref name=''how senators' strategy won for johnson''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=zzidaaaambaj&pg=pa37&dq=muddy+ruel+baseball+digest&cd=1#v=onepage&q=muddy%20ruel%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''how senators' strategy won for johnson'', by muddy ruel, baseball digest, october 1964, vol. 23, no. 9, issn 0005-609x]</ref><ref name=muddy ruel new york times obituary at www.thedeadballera.com>[http://www.thedeadballera.com/obits/obits_r/ruel.muddy.obit.html muddy ruel new york times obituary at www.thedeadballera.com]</ref><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=dc0daaaambaj&pg=pa57&lpg=pa57&dq=muddy+ruel+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=ylmzbz7b_q&sig=ldkxgzcpnsbpnaa5sevk1qwzlqq&hl=en&ei=4gfvtilocyh58abdqisvba&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0cckq6aewbw#v=onepage&q&f=false ''muddy - but stylish'', by francis stann, baseball digest, february 1964, issn 0005-609x]</ref>

in a 19 year career, ruel played in 1468 [[games played|games]], accumulating 1242 [[hit (baseball)|hits]] in 4514 [[at bats]] for a .275 career batting average along with 4 home runs, 534 [[runs batted in]] and a .365 [[on base percentage]].<ref name=muddy ruel at baseball reference/> he possessed strong defensive skills, leading american league catchers in [[fielding percentage]] three consecutive years (1926-1928), finishing with a .982 career fielding percentage.<ref name=muddy ruel at baseball reference/><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa86&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, july 2001, vol. 60, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref> ruel also led american league catchers three times in putouts and assists and twice in [[range factor]] and in baserunners caught stealing.<ref name=muddy ruel at baseball reference/> he made 23 [[double play]]s in [[1924 washington senators season|1924]], the seventh highest season total for catchers in major league history.<ref>[http://members.tripod.com/bb_catchers/catchers/fieldsea.htm catchers fielding records at the encyclopedia of catchers]</ref> his reputation as a defensive stand out is enhanced because of the era in which he played. in the [[deadball era]], catchers played a huge defensive role, given the large number of [[bunt (baseball)|bunt]]s and [[stolen base]] attempts, as well as the difficulty of handling the [[spitball]] pitchers who dominated pitching staffs.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=9s0daaaambaj&pg=pa26&dq=baseball+digest+defensive+catchers#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20defensive%20catchers&f=false ''for catchers, the name of the game is defense'', by george vass, baseball digest, may 2005, vol. 64, no. 3, issn 0005-609x]</ref> richard kendall of the [[society for american baseball research]] devised an unscientific study that ranked ruel as the fifth most dominating fielding catcher in major league history.<ref>[http://members.tripod.com/bb_catchers/catchers/dominate.htm dominating fielding catchers at the encyclopedia of baseball catchers]</ref>

* [http://books.google.com/books?id=zzidaaaambaj&pg=pa37&dq=muddy+ruel+baseball+digest&cd=1#v=onepage&q=muddy%20ruel%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''how senators' strategy won for johnson'', by muddy ruel, baseball digest, october 1964]

'''herold dominic muddy ruel''' (february 20, 1896  november 13, 1963) was an [[united states|american]] [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] player, [[coach (baseball)|coach]], [[manager (baseball)|manager]] and [[general manager (baseball)|general manager]]. he played as a [[catcher]] in [[major league baseball]] for 19 seasons with the [[baltimore orioles|st. louis browns]], [[new york yankees]], [[minnesota twins|washington senators]], [[boston red sox]], [[detroit tigers]], and the [[chicago white sox]].<ref name=muddy ruel at baseball reference>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/r/ruelmu01.shtml muddy ruel at baseball reference]</ref> ruel was one of the top defensive catchers of his era, and is best remembered for scoring the winning run for the washington senators in game 7 of the [[1924 world series]] and, for being the [[battery (baseball)|battery]]-mate of [[baseball hall of fame]] [[pitcher]], [[walter johnson]].<ref name=''how senators' strategy won for johnson''>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=zzidaaaambaj&pg=pa37&dq=muddy+ruel+baseball+digest&cd=1#v=onepage&q=muddy%20ruel%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=how senators' strategy won for johnson |author=ruel, muddy |publisher=|date=october 1964 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=29 april 2012 }}</ref><ref name=muddy ruel new york times obituary at www.thedeadballera.com>[http://www.thedeadballera.com/obits/obits_r/ruel.muddy.obit.html muddy ruel new york times obituary at www.thedeadballera.com]</ref><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=dc0daaaambaj&pg=pa57&lpg=pa57&dq=muddy+ruel+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=ylmzbz7b_q&sig=ldkxgzcpnsbpnaa5sevk1qwzlqq&hl=en&ei=4gfvtilocyh58abdqisvba&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0cckq6aewbw#v=onepage&q&f=false ''muddy - but stylish'', by francis stann, baseball digest, february 1964, issn 0005-609x]</ref>

in a 19-year career, ruel played in 1468 [[games played|games]], accumulating 1242 [[hit (baseball)|hits]] in 4514 [[at bats]] for a .275 career batting average along with 4 home runs, 534 [[runs batted in]] and a .365 [[on base percentage]].<ref name=muddy ruel at baseball reference/> he possessed strong defensive skills, leading american league catchers in [[fielding percentage]] three consecutive years (19261928), finishing with a .982 career fielding percentage.<ref name=muddy ruel at baseball reference/><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa86&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, july 2001, vol. 60, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref> ruel also led american league catchers three times in putouts and assists and twice in [[range factor]] and in baserunners caught stealing.<ref name=muddy ruel at baseball reference/> he made 23 [[double play]]s in [[1924 washington senators season|1924]], the seventh highest season total for catchers in major league history.<ref>[http://members.tripod.com/bb_catchers/catchers/fieldsea.htm catchers fielding records at the encyclopedia of catchers]</ref> his reputation as a defensive stand out is enhanced because of the era in which he played. in the [[deadball era]], catchers played a huge defensive role, given the large number of [[bunt (baseball)|bunt]]s and [[stolen base]] attempts, as well as the difficulty of handling the [[spitball]] pitchers who dominated pitching staffs.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=9s0daaaambaj&pg=pa26&dq=baseball+digest+defensive+catchers#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20defensive%20catchers&f=false ''for catchers, the name of the game is defense'', by george vass, baseball digest, may 2005, vol. 64, no. 3, issn 0005-609x]</ref> richard kendall of the [[society for american baseball research]] devised an unscientific study that ranked ruel as the fifth most dominating fielding catcher in major league history.<ref>[http://members.tripod.com/bb_catchers/catchers/dominate.htm dominating fielding catchers at the encyclopedia of baseball catchers]</ref>

* [http://books.google.com/books?id=zzidaaaambaj&pg=pa37&dq=muddy+ruel+baseball+digest&cd=1#v=onepage&q=muddy%20ruel%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''how senators' strategy won for johnson'', by muddy ruel, baseball digest, october 1964]

'''delmar wesley crandall''' (born march 5, 1930 in [[ontario, california]]<ref name=del crandall at baseball reference>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/c/crandde01.shtml del crandall at baseball reference]</ref>) is a former [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] [[catcher]] and [[manager (baseball)|manager]] in [[major league baseball]] who played most of his career with the [[atlanta braves|boston & milwaukee braves]].<ref name=del crandall at baseball reference/><ref>[http://www.baseball-almanac.com/players/player.php?p=crandde01 del crandall at baseball almanac]</ref> considered one of the [[national league]]'s top catchers during the 1950s and early 1960s, he led the league in [[assist (baseball)|assists]] a record-tying six times, in [[fielding percentage]] four times and in [[putout]]s three times.<ref name=del crandall at baseball reference/><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa86&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''fielding leaders'', baseball digest, july 2001, vol. 60, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=zcodaaaambaj&pg=pa7&dq=del+crandall+baseball+digest&cd=1#v=onepage&q=del%20crandall%20baseball%20digest&f=false del crandal in baseball digest, august 1999, vol. 58, no. 8, issn 0005-609x]</ref>

crandall was signed as an amateur [[free agent]] by the braves in [[1948 boston braves season|1948]].<ref name=del crandall trades and transactions at baseball almanac>[http://www.baseball-almanac.com/players/trades.php?p=crandde01 del crandall trades and transactions at baseball almanac]</ref> he was only 19 when he first played in a major league game with the [[1949 boston braves season|1949 boston braves]].<ref name=del crandall at baseball reference/> he appeared in 146 games for boston in 1949-[[1950 boston braves season|1950]] before entering military service during the [[korean war]]. when his two-year hitch was over in march [[1953 milwaukee braves season|1953]], the braves departed boston for milwaukee, where – benefitting from a powerful offense featuring [[hank aaron]], [[eddie mathews]] and [[joe adcock]] – they soon became both successful on the field and phenomenally popular off it. crandall seized the regular catcher's job from veteran [[walker cooper]] in 1953 and held it for eight years, handling star braves [[pitcher]]s such as left-hander [[warren spahn]] and right-handers [[lew burdette]] and [[bob buhl]].<ref name=del crandall at baseball reference/><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=ac4daaaambaj&pg=pa43&dq=del+crandall+baseball+digest&cd=2#v=onepage&q=&f=false ''orange-topped catcher'', by charles dexter, baseball digest, august 1953, vol. 12, no. 8, issn 0005-609x]</ref> as a testament to crandall's pitch calling skills, between 1953 and [[1959 milwaukee braves season|1959]], the braves' pitching staff finished either first or second in the national league in team [[earned run average]] every year except 1955. burdette credited crandall for some of his success saying, i never- well hardly ever- have to shake him off. he knows the job like no one else, and you can have faith in his judgment.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=2zidaaaambaj&pg=pa5&dq=lew+burdette+baseball+digest&cd=2#v=onepage&q=lew%20burdette%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''the nitro-glistenin' kid'' by al jonas, baseball digest, pp 9, may 1954, vol. 13, no. 4, issn 0005-609x]</ref> on september 11, [[1955 milwaukee braves season|1955]], with the braves trailing the [[1955 philadelphia phillies season|philadelphia phillies]] 4-1 with two [[out (baseball)|outs]] in the ninth [[inning]], crandall hit a dramatic [[grand slam (baseball)|grand slam]] home run to win the game.<ref>[http://www.retrosheet.org/boxesetc/1955/b09111mln1955.htm september 11, 1955 phillies-braves box score at retrosheet]</ref> the braves won national league [[pennant (sports)|pennants]] in [[1957 milwaukee braves season|1957]] and [[1958 milwaukee braves season|1958]],<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1957.shtml 1957 national league team statistics and standings at baseball reference]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1958.shtml 1958 national league team statistics and standings at baseball reference]</ref> also finishing in second place five times between 1953 and [[1960 milwaukee braves season|1960]], and captured the [[1957 world series]] championship – the franchise's first title since [[1914 boston braves season|1914]].<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1957_ws.shtml 1957 world series at baseball reference]</ref> although he only [[batting average|batted]] .211 in the 1957 series against the [[1957 new york yankees season|new york yankees]], crandall had a solo home run for the braves' last tally in a 5-0 win in the deciding game 7.<ref name=del crandall post-season statistics at baseball reference>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/c/crandde01.shtml#batting_postseason del crandall post-season statistics at baseball reference]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/nya/nya195710100.shtml 1957 world series game 7 box score at baseball reference]</ref>
