'''delmar wesley crandall''' (born march 5, 1930 in [[ontario, california]]<ref name=del crandall at baseball reference>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/c/crandde01.shtml del crandall at baseball reference]</ref>) is a former [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] [[catcher]] and [[manager (baseball)|manager]] in [[major league baseball]] who played most of his career with the [[atlanta braves|boston & milwaukee braves]].<ref name=del crandall at baseball reference/><ref>[http://www.baseball-almanac.com/players/player.php?p=crandde01 del crandall at baseball almanac]</ref> considered one of the [[national league]]'s top catchers during the 1950s and early 1960s, he led the league in [[assist (baseball)|assists]] a record-tying six times, in [[fielding percentage]] four times and in [[putout]]s three times.<ref name=del crandall at baseball reference/><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa86&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''fielding leaders'', baseball digest, july 2001, vol. 60, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=zcodaaaambaj&pg=pa7&dq=del+crandall+baseball+digest&cd=1#v=onepage&q=del%20crandall%20baseball%20digest&f=false del crandal in baseball digest, august 1999, vol. 58, no. 8, issn 0005-609x]</ref>

crandall was signed as an amateur [[free agent]] by the braves in [[1948 boston braves season|1948]].<ref name=del crandall trades and transactions at baseball almanac>[http://www.baseball-almanac.com/players/trades.php?p=crandde01 del crandall trades and transactions at baseball almanac]</ref> he was only 19 when he first played in a major league game with the [[1949 boston braves season|1949 boston braves]].<ref name=del crandall at baseball reference/> he appeared in 146 games for boston in 1949-[[1950 boston braves season|1950]] before entering military service during the [[korean war]]. when his two-year hitch was over in march [[1953 milwaukee braves season|1953]], the braves departed boston for milwaukee, where – benefitting from a powerful offense featuring [[hank aaron]], [[eddie mathews]] and [[joe adcock]] – they soon became both successful on the field and phenomenally popular off it. crandall seized the regular catcher's job from veteran [[walker cooper]] in 1953 and held it for eight years, handling star braves [[pitcher]]s such as left-hander [[warren spahn]] and right-handers [[lew burdette]] and [[bob buhl]].<ref name=del crandall at baseball reference/><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=ac4daaaambaj&pg=pa43&dq=del+crandall+baseball+digest&cd=2#v=onepage&q=&f=false ''orange-topped catcher'', by charles dexter, baseball digest, august 1953, vol. 12, no. 8, issn 0005-609x]</ref> as a testament to crandall's pitch calling skills, between 1953 and [[1959 milwaukee braves season|1959]], the braves' pitching staff finished either first or second in the national league in team [[earned run average]] every year except 1955. burdette credited crandall for some of his success saying, i never- well hardly ever- have to shake him off. he knows the job like no one else, and you can have faith in his judgment.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=2zidaaaambaj&pg=pa5&dq=lew+burdette+baseball+digest&cd=2#v=onepage&q=lew%20burdette%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''the nitro-glistenin' kid'' by al jonas, baseball digest, pp 9, may 1954, vol. 13, no. 4, issn 0005-609x]</ref> on september 11, [[1955 milwaukee braves season|1955]], with the braves trailing the [[1955 philadelphia phillies season|philadelphia phillies]] 4-1 with two [[out (baseball)|outs]] in the ninth [[inning]], crandall hit a dramatic [[grand slam (baseball)|grand slam]] home run to win the game.<ref>[http://www.retrosheet.org/boxesetc/1955/b09111mln1955.htm september 11, 1955 phillies-braves box score at retrosheet]</ref> the braves won national league [[pennant (sports)|pennants]] in [[1957 milwaukee braves season|1957]] and [[1958 milwaukee braves season|1958]],<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1957.shtml 1957 national league team statistics and standings at baseball reference]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1958.shtml 1958 national league team statistics and standings at baseball reference]</ref> also finishing in second place five times between 1953 and [[1960 milwaukee braves season|1960]], and captured the [[1957 world series]] championship – the franchise's first title since [[1914 boston braves season|1914]].<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1957_ws.shtml 1957 world series at baseball reference]</ref> although he only [[batting average|batted]] .211 in the 1957 series against the [[1957 new york yankees season|new york yankees]], crandall had a solo home run for the braves' last tally in a 5-0 win in the deciding game 7.<ref name=del crandall post-season statistics at baseball reference>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/c/crandde01.shtml#batting_postseason del crandall post-season statistics at baseball reference]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/nya/nya195710100.shtml 1957 world series game 7 box score at baseball reference]</ref>

kamm was considered a master of the [[hidden ball trick]].<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=iswdaaaambaj&pg=pa49&lpg=pa49&dq=willie+kamm+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=-2tzpi_gmu&sig=opo2usn7fu4szo-dw5ks1yj_5sk&hl=en&ei=n51wtlflomt58aabrytgba&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0ccqq6aewbjgk#v=onepage&q&f=false ''kamm-ouflage!'', by edgar munzel, baseball digest, november 1956, vol. 15, no. 10, issn 0005-609x]</ref> on april 30, {{by|1929}}, in a game against the [[1929 cleveland indians season|cleveland indians]], kamm was involved in a rare [[triple play]] that involved a hidden ball trick.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=xiwdaaaambaj&pg=pa63&lpg=pa63&dq=willie+kamm+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=sy5uc929nr&sig=wejx2b57fiikf9zksyzsscramgw&hl=en&ei=n51wtlflomt58aabrytgba&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0cbsq6aewazgk#v=onepage&q&f=false ''the old kamm-ouflage'', by gordon cobbledick, baseball digest, november 1949, vol. 8, no. 11, issn 0005-609x]</ref> the indians had [[baserunner]]s on second and third bases when [[carl lind]] [[ground out|grounded out]] to the [[shortstop]], who then threw to first base to retire the batter. [[johnny hodapp]], who had been the [[baserunner]] on second base, erroneously thought the runner on third base, [[charlie jamieson]] had scored, so he advanced to third base on the ground out. kamm retrieved the ball from the first baseman and [[tag out|tagged]] both runners at third base, whereupon the umpire ruled hodapp [[out (baseball)|out]]. kamm then hid the ball under his arm and waited for jamieson to step off the base. when he did so, kamm tagged him out to complete the triple play.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=2zadaaaambaj&pg=pa14&lpg=pa14&dq=willie+kamm+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=v8glti5xtv&sig=ekqm4u925c6r-egeiwc5ywolvqs&hl=en&ei=ozhwtoelb4k78gb8zshaba&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0ccaq6aewba#v=onepage&q=willie%20kamm%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, june 2005, vol. 64, no. 4, issn 0005-609x]</ref>

in a 13 year career, kamm played in 1693 [[games played|games]], accumulating 1643 [[hit (baseball)|hits]] in 5851 [[at bats]] for a .281 career batting average along with 29 [[home run]]s and 826 runs batted in.<ref name=willie kamm at baseball reference/> at the time of his retirement, only [[heinie groh]] had a higher career fielding percentage among retired major league third basemen, and as of {{by|2010}}, his .967 career fielding percentage is the 15th highest by a third baseman in major league baseball history.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leaders/fielding_perc_3b_career.shtml career leaders in fielding percentage by third basemen at baseball reference]</ref> kamm led the league in [[fielding average]] eight times, including six times in a row, and in [[putout]]s seven times.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=wssdaaaambaj&pg=pa6&lpg=pa6&dq=willie+kamm+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=z0opshwf0w&sig=gmevc9bum155ti-gaz_rkiqnyh0&hl=en&ei=iafwtjilcok88gbxpkmsba&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0cboq6aewag#v=onepage&q=willie%20kamm%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, august 2002, vol. 61, no. 8, issn 0005-609x]</ref> kamm still holds the american league single-season record for putouts by a third baseman with 243 set in {{by|1928}}, and ranks eighth overall in putouts by third basemen.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leaders/po_3b_season.shtml single-season records for putouts by third basemen at baseball reference]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leaders/po_3b_career.shtml career leaders for putouts by third basemen at baseball reference]</ref> he also led american league third basemen four times in [[assist (baseball)|assists]] and twice in [[range factor]].<ref name=willie kamm at baseball reference/>

kamm is one of only 18 players in major league baseball history to have more than 60 runs batted in during a season, without hitting a home run.<ref name=baseball digest>[http://books.google.com/books?id=2y0daaaambaj&pg=pa7&lpg=pa7&dq=willie+kamm+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=uzl9iteuo6&sig=t7zzsh7y7wphmpgfncxn5vfcpyu&hl=en&ei=n51wtlflomt58aabrytgba&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0cbeq6aewadgk#v=onepage&q=willie%20kamm%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, may 2006, vol. 65, no. 3, issn 0005-609x]</ref> he is the only player to have ever accomplished the feat twice, with 62 runs batted in during the [[1926 chicago white sox season|1926]] season, and 75 runs batted in during the [[1931 chicago white sox season|1931]] season.<ref name=baseball digest/>

kamm was considered a master of the [[hidden ball trick]].<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=iswdaaaambaj&pg=pa49&lpg=pa49&dq=willie+kamm+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=-2tzpi_gmu&sig=opo2usn7fu4szo-dw5ks1yj_5sk&hl=en&ei=n51wtlflomt58aabrytgba&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0ccqq6aewbjgk#v=onepage&q&f=false ''kamm-ouflage!'', by edgar munzel, baseball digest, november 1956, vol. 15, no. 10, issn 0005-609x]</ref> on april 30, {{by|1929}}, in a game against the [[1929 cleveland indians season|cleveland indians]], kamm was involved in a rare [[triple play]] that involved a hidden ball trick.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=xiwdaaaambaj&pg=pa63&lpg=pa63&dq=willie+kamm+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=sy5uc929nr&sig=wejx2b57fiikf9zksyzsscramgw&hl=en&ei=n51wtlflomt58aabrytgba&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0cbsq6aewazgk#v=onepage&q&f=false ''the old kamm-ouflage'', by gordon cobbledick, baseball digest, november 1949, vol. 8, no. 11, issn 0005-609x]</ref> the indians had [[baserunner]]s on second and third bases when [[carl lind (baseball)|carl lind]] [[batted ball|grounded out]] to the [[shortstop]], who then threw to first base to retire the batter. [[johnny hodapp]], who had been the [[baserunner]] on second base, erroneously thought the runner on third base, [[charlie jamieson]] had scored, so he advanced to third base on the ground out. kamm retrieved the ball from the first baseman and [[tag out|tagged]] both runners at third base, whereupon the umpire ruled hodapp [[out (baseball)|out]]. kamm then hid the ball under his arm and waited for jamieson to step off the base. when he did so, kamm tagged him out to complete the triple play.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=2zadaaaambaj&pg=pa14&lpg=pa14&dq=willie+kamm+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=v8glti5xtv&sig=ekqm4u925c6r-egeiwc5ywolvqs&hl=en&ei=ozhwtoelb4k78gb8zshaba&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0ccaq6aewba#v=onepage&q=willie%20kamm%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, june 2005, vol. 64, no. 4, issn 0005-609x]</ref>

in a 13 year career, kamm played in 1693 [[games played|games]], accumulating 1643 [[hit (baseball)|hits]] in 5851 [[at bats]] for a .281 career batting average along with 29 [[home run]]s and 826 runs batted in.<ref name=willie kamm at baseball reference/> at the time of his retirement, only [[heinie groh]] had a higher career fielding percentage among retired major league third basemen, and as of {{by|2010}}, his .967 career fielding percentage is the 15th highest by a third baseman in major league baseball history.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leaders/fielding_perc_3b_career.shtml career leaders in fielding percentage by third basemen at baseball reference]</ref> kamm led the league in [[fielding average]] eight times, including six times in a row, and in [[putout]]s seven times.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=wssdaaaambaj&pg=pa6&lpg=pa6&dq=willie+kamm+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=z0opshwf0w&sig=gmevc9bum155ti-gaz_rkiqnyh0&hl=en&ei=iafwtjilcok88gbxpkmsba&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0cboq6aewag#v=onepage&q=willie%20kamm%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, august 2002, vol. 61, no. 8, issn 0005-609x]</ref> kamm still holds the american league single-season record for putouts by a third baseman with 243 set in {{by|1928}}, and ranks eighth overall in putouts by third basemen.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leaders/po_3b_season.shtml single-season records for putouts by third basemen at baseball reference]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leaders/po_3b_career.shtml career leaders for putouts by third basemen at baseball reference]</ref> he also led american league third basemen four times in [[assist (baseball)|assists]] and twice in [[range factor]].<ref name=willie kamm at baseball reference/>

kamm is one of only 18 players in major league baseball history to have more than 60 runs batted in during a season, without hitting a home run.<ref name=baseball digest>[http://books.google.com/books?id=2y0daaaambaj&pg=pa7&lpg=pa7&dq=willie+kamm+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=uzl9iteuo6&sig=t7zzsh7y7wphmpgfncxn5vfcpyu&hl=en&ei=n51wtlflomt58aabrytgba&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0cbeq6aewadgk#v=onepage&q=willie%20kamm%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, may 2006, vol. 65, no. 3, issn 0005-609x]</ref> he is the only player to have ever accomplished the feat twice, with 62 runs batted in during the [[1926 chicago white sox season|1926]] season, and 75 runs batted in during the [[1931 chicago white sox season|1931]] season.<ref name=baseball digest/>

aparicio regained his form in baltimore and continued to lead the league in stolen bases and in fielding percentage, producing a career-high .983 fielding percentage in [[1963 baltimore orioles |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=gs4daaaambaj&pg=pa19&lpg=pa19&dq=luis+aparicio+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=4fxw_rxjx9&sig=acw2brlwopedutnffnhbxii-htk&hl=en&ei=myr7tov6f4o0lqfck9jscw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0cbeq6aewadgu#v=onepage&q&f=false aparicio posted a .278 batting average with 178 [[hit (baseball)|hits]] in [[1966 baltimore orioles season|1966]], second-most hits in the league behind [[tony oliva]] and, won a seventh gold glove award as the orioles would clinch the american league pennant.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/al/1966-batting-leaders.shtml |title=1966 american league batting leaders |accessdate=30 august 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1966.shtml#almvp |title=1966 american league most valuable player award voting results |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=30 august 2010 }}</ref>

in [[1995 florida marlins season|1995]], johnson's reputation as a skilled defensive player was solidified when he became the fourth catcher in major league history to win a gold glove award in his [[rookie]] season, joining [[johnny bench]], [[carlton fisk]] and [[sandy alomar, jr.]]<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=kssdaaaambaj&pg=pa26&dq=charles+johnson+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=m2ugtoq8f4lglqejpnhycg&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0ccuq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=charles%20johnson%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''charles johnson: marlins' biggest catch'', by gordon edes, baseball digest, february 1998, vol. 57, no. 2, issn 0005-609x]</ref> although his offensive statistics weren't impressive, he made up for those shortcomings by helping his team with his superior defensive skills.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=9s0daaaambaj&pg=pa26&dq=baseball+digest+defensive+catchers#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20defensive%20catchers&f=false ''for catchers, the name of the game is defense'', by george vass, baseball digest, may 2005, vol. 64, no. 3, issn 0005-609x]</ref> in [[1996 florida marlins season|1996]], johnson was the marlins catcher when [[al leiter]] threw a [[no-hitter]] against the [[colorado rockies]].<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/flo/flo199605110.shtml may 11, 1996 rockies-marlins box score at baseball reference]</ref> johnson set a major league record in [[1997 florida marlins season|1997]] by playing in 123 [[games played|games]] without committing a single [[error (baseball)|error]], earning him his first [[1997 major league baseball all-star game|all-star]] selection, and helping the marlins win the [[1997 world series]] against the [[1997 cleveland indians season|cleveland indians]].<ref>[http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/mag1010922/index.htm ''somebody's perfect'', by tom verducci, sports illustrated, september 22, 1997]</ref><ref>[http://members.tripod.com/bb_catchers/catchers/fielding_misc.htm catcher fielding records at the encyclopedia of baseball catchers]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/als/als199707080.shtml 1997 all-star game at baseball reference]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1997_ws.shtml 1997 world series at baseball reference]</ref> johnson led the marlins in the series with 10 [[hit (baseball)|hits]], batting .357 including one [[home run]].<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/j/johnsch04.shtml#batting_postseason charles johnson post-season batting statistics at baseball reference]</ref> along with winning his third consecutive gold glove award in 1997, he also caught his second no hitter when [[kevin brown (right-handed pitcher)|kevin brown]] no hit the giants on june 10th.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/sfn/sfn199706100.shtml june 10, 1997 marlins-giants box score at baseball reference]</ref>

in a 12-season career covering 1,188 [[games played|games]], johnson had a .245 batting average along with 167 [[home run]]s, 570 [[runs batted in]] and a .993 [[fielding percentage]].<ref name=charles johnson at baseball reference/> his .993 fielding percentage ranks 16th all-time among major league catchers.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leaders/fielding_perc_c_career.shtml career fielding leaders at catcher]</ref> along with his four gold glove awards, johnson twice led national league catchers in fielding percentage, and once each in baserunners [[caught stealing]] and [[assist (baseball)|assists]].<ref name=charles johnson at baseball reference/> during his playing career, he ranked second only to [[ivn rodrguez]] in throwing out baserunners, with a 39% average.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa24&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''catching'', by john lowe, baseball digest, july 2001, vol. 60, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref> he earned two all-star berths as well as winning a [[world series]] during his career. his three no hitters caught ties him with several other players for second place on the all-time list behind the four no hitters caught by [[jason varitek]].<ref>[http://members.tripod.com/bb_catchers/catchers/catchno8.htm no hitters caught at the encyclopedia of baseball catchers]</ref> johnson played more games as a catcher than any other player in marlins history (582).<ref>[http://members.tripod.com/bb_catchers/catchers/mostgame.htm most games caught for team at the encyclopedia of baseball catchers]</ref>

web|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=kssdaaaambaj&pg=pa26&dq=charles+johnson+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=m2ugtoq8f4lglqejpnhycg&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0ccuq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=charles%20johnson%20baseball%20digest&f=false although his offensive statistics weren't impressive, he made up for those shortcomings by helping his team with his superior defensive skills.<ref>{{cite in a 12-season career covering 1,188 [[games played|games]], johnson had a .245 batting average along with 167 [[home run]]s, 570 [[runs batted in]] and a .993 [[fielding percentage]].<ref name=charles johnson at baseball reference/> his .993 fielding percentage ranks 16th all-time among major league catchers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leaders/fielding_perc_c_career.shtml |title=career fielding leaders at catcher |publisher=baseball-reference.com |accessdate=november 20, 2011}}</ref> along with his four gold glove awards, johnson twice led national league catchers in fielding percentage, and once each in baserunners [[caught stealing]] and [[assist (baseball)|assists]].<ref name=charles johnson at baseball reference/> during his playing career, he ranked second only to [[ivn rodrguez]] in throwing out baserunners, with a 39% average.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa24&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=''catching'', by john lowe, baseball digest, july 2001, vol. 60, no. 7, issn 0005-609x |publisher=google books |accessdate=november 20, 2011}}</ref> he earned two all-star berths as well as winning a [[world series]] during his career. his three no hitters caught ties him with several other players for second place on the all-time list behind the four no hitters caught by [[jason varitek]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://members.tripod.com/bb_catchers/catchers/catchno8.htm |title=no hitters caught at the encyclopedia of baseball catchers |publisher=members.tripod.com |accessdate=november 20, 2011}}</ref> johnson played more games as a catcher than any other player in marlins history (582).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://members.tripod.com/bb_catchers/catchers/mostgame.htm |title=most games caught for team at the encyclopedia of baseball catchers |publisher=members.tripod.com |accessdate=november 20, 2011}}</ref>

although he was often overshadowed by his contemporary, [[johnny bench]], sanguilln was considered one of the best catchers in major league baseball in the early 1970s.<ref name=''two catchers cut from royal cloth''>[http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/mag1086236/index.htm ''two catchers cut from royal cloth'', by ron fimrite, sports illustrated, june 26, 1972]</ref><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=4zedaaaambaj&pg=pa4&lpg=pa5&dq=manny+sanguillen+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=cyx-9cnbrb&sig=zmjjun_zwjd1o5tddo47_dedd4e&hl=en&ei=jngptn-gj8oqlaffwqmpaw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0ccmq6aewbtge#v=onepage&q&f=false ''warm up tosses'', by john kuenster, baseball digest, march 1973, vol. 32, no. 3, issn 0005-609x]</ref> while he didn't possess bench's power hitting ability, sanguillen hit for a higher batting average.<ref name=''two catchers cut from royal cloth''/><ref name=''warm up tosses''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=jzidaaaambaj&pg=pa4&lpg=pa4&dq=manny+sanguillen+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=wo1i6coe06&sig=oiucbn9cv813aliteji4jivuvd8&hl=en&ei=p9kptjuujcgqlaebo-muaw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0cbgq6aewajgu#v=onepage&q&f=false ''warm up tosses'', by john kuenster, baseball digest, september 1972, vol. 31, no. 9, issn 0005-609x]</ref> he was an integral member of the pirates teams that won three consecutive [[national league eastern division]] [[pennant (sports)|pennants]] between [[1970 pittsburgh pirates season|1970]] and [[1972 pittsburgh pirates season|1972]], and a [[world series]] victory in [[1971 world series|1971]].<ref name=''warm up tosses''/> sanguillen was also a fast baserunner for a catcher and was a good defensive player with a strong throwing arm.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=dzidaaaambaj&pg=pa42&lpg=pa42&dq=manny+sanguillen+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=jvkozujjwq&sig=rl5v-r841yyjayplzaoldzp-nz8&hl=en&ei=xcyqtiggmsb_lgeis9sqba&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0ccuq6aewbq#v=onepage&q=manny%20sanguillen%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''superstardom ahead for sanguillen?'', by al abrams, baseball digest, june 1970, vol. 29, no. 6, issn 0005-609x]</ref>

after the tragic death of roberto clemente in [[1973 pittsburgh pirates season|1973]], the pirates slated sanguillen to take clemente's place in [[right field]].<ref>[http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/mag1087148/index.htm ''now playing right: manny sanguillen'', by roy blount jr., sports illustrated, march 19, 1973]</ref><ref name=''sanguillen...out from clemente's shadow''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=gzidaaaambaj&pg=pa46&lpg=pa46&dq=manny+sanguillen+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=mixudhuscp&sig=n1ze2syrzsmj69lafamrjblnr74&hl=en&ei=tdqqtlcze8sqlaebk4iaaw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0cbiq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=manny%20sanguillen%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''sanguillen...out from clemente's shadow'', by bob lenoir, baseball digest, july 1975, vol. 34, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref> by mid-june, it was apparent that sanguillen couldn't adapt to playing the [[outfield]] and he was moved back to the catcher's position.<ref name=''sanguillen...out from clemente's shadow''/> sanguillen had another strong year in [[1975 pittsburgh pirates season|1975]], when he posted a .328 batting average, third in the national league batting championship behind [[bill madlock]] and [[ted simmons]].<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1975-batting-leaders.shtml 1975 national league batting leaders at baseball reference]</ref> in [[1977 oakland athletics season|1977]], sanguillen was traded by the pirates to the [[oakland athletics]] for the services of then-a's manager [[chuck tanner]] and $100,000 as a settlement of tanner's contract with the a's.<ref name=manny sanguillen trades and transactions at baseball almanac>[http://www.baseball-almanac.com/players/trades.php?p=sanguma01 manny sanguillen trades and transactions at baseball almanac]</ref>

although he was often overshadowed by his contemporary, [[johnny bench]], sanguilln was considered one of the best catchers in major league baseball in the early 1970s.<ref name=''two catchers cut from royal cloth''>[http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/mag1086236/index.htm ''two catchers cut from royal cloth'', by ron fimrite, sports illustrated, june 26, 1972]</ref><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=4zedaaaambaj&pg=pa4&lpg=pa5&dq=manny+sanguillen+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=cyx-9cnbrb&sig=zmjjun_zwjd1o5tddo47_dedd4e&hl=en&ei=jngptn-gj8oqlaffwqmpaw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0ccmq6aewbtge#v=onepage&q&f=false warm up tosses, by john kuenster, ''baseball digest'', march 1973, vol. 32, no. 3, issn 0005-609x]</ref> while he didn't possess bench's power hitting ability, sanguillen hit for a higher batting average.<ref name=''two catchers cut from royal cloth''/><ref name=''warm up tosses''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=jzidaaaambaj&pg=pa4&lpg=pa4&dq=manny+sanguillen+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=wo1i6coe06&sig=oiucbn9cv813aliteji4jivuvd8&hl=en&ei=p9kptjuujcgqlaebo-muaw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0cbgq6aewajgu#v=onepage&q&f=false warm up tosses, by john kuenster, ''baseball digest'', september 1972, vol. 31, no. 9, issn 0005-609x]</ref> he was an integral member of the pirates teams that won three consecutive [[national league eastern division]] [[pennant (sports)|pennants]] between [[1970 pittsburgh pirates season|1970]] and [[1972 pittsburgh pirates season|1972]], and a [[world series]] victory in [[1971 world series|1971]].<ref name=''warm up tosses''/> sanguillen was also a fast baserunner for a catcher and was a good defensive player with a strong throwing arm.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=dzidaaaambaj&pg=pa42&lpg=pa42&dq=manny+sanguillen+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=jvkozujjwq&sig=rl5v-r841yyjayplzaoldzp-nz8&hl=en&ei=xcyqtiggmsb_lgeis9sqba&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0ccuq6aewbq#v=onepage&q=manny%20sanguillen%20baseball%20digest&f=false * [http://books.google.com/books?id=dzidaaaambaj&pg=pa42&dq=manny+sanguillen+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=g9qptlxroya8lqegvtzdaw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0cduq6aewag#v=onepage&q=manny%20sanguillen%20baseball%20digest&f=false superstardom ahead for sanguillen?, by al abrams, ''baseball digest'', june 1970]

in a 18 year career, lollar played in 1752 [[games played|games]], accumulating 1,415 [[hit (baseball)|hits]] in 5,351 [[at bats]] for a .264 career batting average along with 155 home runs, 808 [[runs batted in]] and a .357 [[on base percentage]].<ref name=sherm lollar/> a nine-time [[major league baseball all-star game|all-star]], lollar led american league catchers in [[fielding percentage]] four times over his career.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa86&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=fielding leaders |publisher=books.google.com |date=july 2001 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=14 november 2010 }}</ref> in [[1961 chicago white sox season|1961]], he committed only one [[error (baseball)|error]] over the entire season.<ref name=sherm lollar/> at the time of his retirement in [[1963 chicago white sox season|1963]], lollar's .992 career fielding percentage was the highest for a catcher in major league history.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://members.tripod.com/bb_catchers/catchers/8cfldfld.htm |title=catchers career fielding percentages |publisher=the encyclopedia of baseball catchers |accessdate=14 november 2010 }}</ref> during his career, lollar threw out 46.18% of the [[baserunning|base runners]] who tried [[stolen base|steal]] a base on him, ranking him 5th on the all-time list.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://members.tripod.com/bb_catchers/catchers/100bestcscar.pdf |title=100 best catcher cs% totals |publisher=the encyclopedia of baseball catchers |accessdate=14 november 2010 }}</ref> at the time of his retirement, he ranked 9th all-time in home runs by catchers.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ctmdaaaambaj&pg=pa13&dq=baseball+digest+sherm+lollar&lr=#v=onepage&q=&f=false |title=most home runs by catchers |publisher=books.google.com |date=october 1977 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=14 november 2010 }}</ref>

* american league leader in fielding percentage for catcher (1951, 1953, 1956, 1960, 1961).<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa86&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=fielding leaders |publisher=|date=july 2001 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=14 november 2010 }}</ref>

the braves performed one of the most memorable reversals in major league history when, they went from last place to first place in two months, becoming the first team to win a pennant after being in last place on the fourth of july.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=as0daaaambaj&pg=pa84&dq=hank+gowdy+baseball+digest&cd=3#v=onepage&q=hank%20gowdy%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''how losing an exhibition sparked miracle braves'', by joseph m. overfield, baseball digest, may 1961, vol. 20, no. 4, issn 0005-609x]</ref> after finishing in fifth place in {{by|1913}} with a record of 69 wins and 82 losses, the braves hadn't been expected to pose a threat. they spent the first part of the season in last place, posting a record of 26 wins and 40 losses in early july.<ref>[http://www.thisgreatgame.com/1914.html the 1914 boston braves at www.thisgreatgame.com]</ref> led by three pitchers, [[dick rudolph]], [[bill james (pitcher, born 1892)|seattle bill james]], and [[lefty tyler]], the team began to win games, taking over first place for good on september 8.<ref name=''down to the wire; six greatest stretch runs for the pennant''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=2c4daaaambaj&pg=pa30&lpg=pa30&dq=1914+boston+braves+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=nygtwm4v81&sig=elgkgxnpkd-omqyqvyosk_54sku&hl=en&ei=z9lltjumcyp58aah6luy&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0ccuq6aewbq#v=onepage&q&f=false ''down to the wire; six greatest stretch runs for the pennant'' by george vass, baseball digest, sep 2001, vol. 60, no. 9, issn 0005-609x]</ref> their record over their final 89 games was 70-19 for a winning percentage of .787.<ref name=''down to the wire; six greatest stretch runs for the pennant''/> infielders [[johnny evers]] and [[rabbit maranville]] led the league in [[double plays]]. the braves went on to sweep [[connie mack]]'s heavily-favored athletics in four games in the [[1914 world series]].<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1914_ws.shtml 1914 world series at baseball-reference]</ref> the team became known as the miracle braves and remain one of the most storied comeback teams in baseball history.

the braves performed one of the most memorable reversals in major league history, going from last place to first place in two months, becoming the first team to win a pennant after being in last place on the [[fourth of july]].<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=as0daaaambaj&pg=pa84&dq=hank+gowdy+baseball+digest&cd=3#v=onepage&q=hank%20gowdy%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''how losing an exhibition sparked miracle braves'', by joseph m. overfield, baseball digest, may 1961, vol. 20, no. 4, issn 0005-609x]</ref> after finishing in fifth place in 1913 with a record of 69 wins and 82 losses, the braves were not expected to be contenders. they spent the first part of the season in last place, posting a record of 26 wins and 40 losses in early july.<ref>[http://www.thisgreatgame.com/1914.html the 1914 boston braves at www.thisgreatgame.com]</ref> led by three pitchers, [[dick rudolph]], [[bill james (pitcher, born 1892)|seattle bill james]], and [[lefty tyler]], the team began to win games, taking over first place for good on september 8.<ref name=''down to the wire; six greatest stretch runs for the pennant''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=2c4daaaambaj&pg=pa30&lpg=pa30&dq=1914+boston+braves+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=nygtwm4v81&sig=elgkgxnpkd-omqyqvyosk_54sku&hl=en&ei=z9lltjumcyp58aah6luy&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0ccuq6aewbq#v=onepage&q&f=false ''down to the wire; six greatest stretch runs for the pennant'' by george vass, baseball digest, sep 2001, vol. 60, no. 9, issn 0005-609x]</ref> their record over their final 89 games was 70-19 for a winning percentage of .787.<ref name=''down to the wire; six greatest stretch runs for the pennant''/> infielders [[johnny evers]] and [[rabbit maranville]] led the league in [[double plays]]. the braves went on to sweep [[connie mack]]'s heavily favored athletics in four games in the [[1914 world series]].<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1914_ws.shtml 1914 world series at baseball-reference]</ref> the team became known as the miracle braves and remain one of the most storied comeback teams in baseball history.

'''john rikard dempsey''' (born september 13, 1949 in [[fayetteville, tennessee]]) is a former [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] player who was a [[catcher]] in the [[major league baseball|major leagues]] from {{by|1969}} to {{by|1992}}.<ref name=rick dempsey at baseball reference>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/d/dempsri01.shtml#batting_postseason rick dempsey at baseball reference]</ref> he was best known for his years with the [[baltimore orioles]]. he also played for the [[minnesota twins]], [[new york yankees]], [[cleveland indians]], [[los angeles dodgers]], and [[milwaukee brewers]].<ref name=rick dempsey at baseball reference/> dempsey was known for being one of the best defensive catchers of his era.<ref name=''for catchers, the name of the game is defense''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=9s0daaaambaj&pg=pa26&dq=baseball+digest+defensive+catchers#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20defensive%20catchers&f=false ''for catchers, the name of the game is defense'', by george vass, baseball digest, may 2005, vol. 64, no. 3, issn 0005-609x]</ref>

for the next ten and a half seasons, dempsey would remain as the orioles' starting catcher.<ref name=''rick dempsey looks back on his 24 seasons as a big league catcher''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=2y0daaaambaj&pg=pa76&dq=baseball+digest+may+2006&hl=en&ei=flk4tidbnmsqlae9onxsbw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0ccsq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20may%202006&f=false ''rick dempsey looks back on his 24 seasons as a big league catcher'', by ed lucas and paul post, baseball digest may 2006, vol. 65, no. 3, issn 0005-609x]</ref> he became known for his exceptional ability to handle pitching staffs, his strong throwing arm, and for his agility behind [[home plate]].<ref name=''for catchers, the name of the game is defense''/> in [[1979 baltimore orioles season|1979]], the orioles defeated the [[1979 california angels season|california angels]] in the [[1979 american league championship series]] to reach the world series.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1979_alcs.shtml 1979 american league championship series at baseball reference]</ref> in the [[1979 world series]], the orioles won three of the first four games against the [[1979 pittsburgh pirates season|pittsburgh pirates]] and seemed to be on the verge of winning the championship, when the pirates, led by [[willie stargell]], rebounded to win the final three games.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1979_ws.shtml 1979 world series at baseball reference]</ref> it was one of dempsey's greatest disappointments of his playing career.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=vzqdaaaambaj&pg=pa71&lpg=pa71&dq=rick+dempsey+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=vacm2ad2js&sig=sfquwfgbatesic99o8vnqnsdlpg&hl=en&ei=jgo4tkogccgclgejtohvbw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0cb4q6aewaw#v=onepage&q=rick%20dempsey%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''the game i'll never forget'', by rick dempsey, baseball digest, november 1987, vol. 46, no. 11, issn 0005-609x]</ref>

'''frederick cy williams''' (december 21, 1887  april 23, 1974) was an american [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] player.<ref name=cy williams statistics>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/w/willicy01.shtml |title=cy williams statistics |publisher=baseball-reference.com |accessdate=24 april 2012}}</ref> he played in [[major league baseball]] as an [[outfielder]] for the [[chicago cubs]] (191217) and [[philadelphia phillies]] (191830).<ref name=cy williams statistics/> as major league baseball emerged from the [[dead ball era]], williams became one of the most prominent [[home run]] hitters in the national league.<ref name=the baseball biography project: cy williams>{{cite web|url=http://sabr.org/bioproj/person/da11d4a5|title=the baseball biography project: cy williams|last=gagnon|first=cappy|publisher=society for american baseball research|accessdate=24 april 2012}}</ref><ref name=20th century all-overlooked stars>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=zcodaaaambaj&pg=pa41&dq=eddie+yost+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=eh3gtouch4lhbqs36dsp&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0cdiq6aewajgk#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=20th century all-overlooked stars |author=vass, george |publisher=books.google.com |date=august 1999 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=24 april 2012 }}</ref><ref name=baseball's forgotten stars>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=4i0daaaambaj&pg=pa30&dq=ken+williams+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=i8lgtjnfbjyg4qa7zododw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0ceiq6aewbg#v=onepage&q=ken%20williams%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=baseball's forgotten stars |author=vass, george |publisher=books.google.com |date=july 2004 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=24 april 2012 }}</ref>

'''frederick cy williams''' (december 21, 1887  april 23, 1974) was an american [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] player.<ref name=cy williams statistics>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/w/willicy01.shtml |title=cy williams statistics |publisher=baseball-reference.com |accessdate=24 april 2012}}</ref> he played in [[major league baseball]] as an [[outfielder]] for the [[chicago cubs]] (191217) and [[philadelphia phillies]] (191830).<ref name=cy williams statistics/> as major league baseball emerged from the [[dead ball era]], williams became one of the most prominent [[home run]] hitters in the national league.<ref name=sabrbio>{{sabrbio|da11d4a5|cappy gagnon|24 april 2012}}</ref><ref name=20th century all-overlooked stars>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=zcodaaaambaj&pg=pa41&dq=eddie+yost+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=eh3gtouch4lhbqs36dsp&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0cdiq6aewajgk#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=20th century all-overlooked stars |author=vass, george |publisher=books.google.com |date=august 1999 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=24 april 2012 }}</ref><ref name=baseball's forgotten stars>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=4i0daaaambaj&pg=pa30&dq=ken+williams+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=i8lgtjnfbjyg4qa7zododw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0ceiq6aewbg#v=onepage&q=ken%20williams%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=baseball's forgotten stars |author=vass, george |publisher=books.google.com |date=july 2004 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=24 april 2012 }}</ref>

'''johnny leonard roosevelt pepper martin''' (february 29, 1904 – march 5, 1965) was an [[united states|american]] [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] player and minor league [[manager (baseball)|manager]].<ref name=pepper martin statistics>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/m/martipe01.shtml |title=pepper martin statistics |publisher=baseball-reference |accessdate=15 march 2011}}</ref> he was known as the ''wild horse of the osage'' because of his daring, aggressive [[baserunning]] abilities. martin played in [[major league baseball]] as a [[third baseman]] and an [[outfielder]] for the [[st. louis cardinals]] during the 1930s and early 1940s. he was best known for his heroics during the [[1931 world series]], in which he was the catalyst in a cardinals' upset victory over the [[oakland athletics|philadelphia athletics]].<ref name=the peppering of philly>{{cite web |url=http://www.thisgreatgame.com/1931.html |title=the peppering of philly |publisher=thisgreatgame.com |accessdate=15 march 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ozidaaaambaj&pg=pa24&dq=pepper+martin+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=akd_tdegdoxitwe1u4hfca&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0cd8q6aewbtgk#v=onepage&q=pepper%20martin%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=all-time world series team |author=vass, george |publisher=books.google.com |date=october 1971 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=15 march 2011}}</ref>

martin, along with cardinals teammates such as [[leo durocher]], [[dizzy dean]] and [[joe medwick]] among others, became known as the [[gashouse gang]] due to their boisterous activities on and off the field.<ref name=dizzy, dazzy and ducky>{{cite web |url=http://www.thisgreatgame.com/1934.html |title=dizzy, dazzy and ducky |publisher=thisgreatgame.com |accessdate=15 march 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=dbcdaaaambaj&pg=pa29&dq=gas+house+gang+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=ak9_temoay6atwfg2entca&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0ccwq6aewaa#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=the gashouse gang- laughing gas, that is |author=lyall, smith |publisher=books.google.com |date=july 1960 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=15 march 2011 }}</ref> he played the guitar in a [[old-time music|hillbilly]] band composed of cardinals players named ''the mudcat band''.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=otmdaaaambaj&pg=pa70&dq=pepper+martin+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=akd_tdegdoxitwe1u4hfca&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0cdmq6aewajgk#v=onepage&q=pepper%20martin%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=baseball's all-time team of 'screwballs' |author=vass, george |publisher=books.google.com |date=june 1971 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=15 march 2011 }}</ref>

'''johnny leonard roosevelt pepper martin''' (february 29, 1904 – march 5, 1965) was an [[united states|american]] professional [[baseball]] player and minor league [[manager (baseball)|manager]].<ref name=pepper martin statistics>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/m/martipe01.shtml |title=pepper martin statistics |publisher=baseball-reference |accessdate=15 march 2011}}</ref> he was known as the ''wild horse of the osage'' because of his daring, aggressive [[baserunning]] abilities. martin played in [[major league baseball]] as a [[third baseman]] and an [[outfielder]] for the [[st. louis cardinals]] during the 1930s and early 1940s. he was best known for his heroics during the [[1931 world series]], in which he was the catalyst in a cardinals' upset victory over the [[oakland athletics|philadelphia athletics]].<ref name=the peppering of philly>{{cite web |url=http://www.thisgreatgame.com/1931.html |title=the peppering of philly |publisher=thisgreatgame.com |accessdate=15 march 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ozidaaaambaj&pg=pa24&dq=pepper+martin+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=akd_tdegdoxitwe1u4hfca&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0cd8q6aewbtgk#v=onepage&q=pepper%20martin%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=all-time world series team |author=vass, george |publisher=books.google.com |date=october 1971 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=15 march 2011}}</ref>

martin's batting average dropped to .289 in [[1934 st. louis cardinals season|1934]], but he once again led the league in stolen bases as the cardinals rallied from seven games behind the [[1934 new york giants (mlb) season|new york giants]] in early september to win the national league pennant on the last day of the season.<ref name=pepper martin statistics/><ref name=dizzy, dazzy and ducky/> he made an appearance as a [[relief pitcher]] on august 19, allowing one hit in two innings pitched.<ref>{{cite news |title=cards split bargain bill with braves |agency=associated press |work=the milwaukee sentinel |page=10 |date=20 august 1934 |accessdate=15 march 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=otwaaaaaibaj&sjid=pg4eaaaaibaj&pg=6610,3178962&dq=pepper+martin&hl=en}}</ref> in a memorable [[1934 world series]] against the [[1934 detroit tigers season|detroit tigers]], the cardinals were down 3 games to 2, before rebounding to win the final two games.<ref name=the game i'll never forget/> the series was highlighted by several rough plays on the base paths that culminated in game 7, when joe medwick made a rough slide into tigers' third baseman [[marv owen]].<ref name=cardinals rule baseball third time in nine years>{{cite news |title=cardinals rule baseball third time in nine years |agency=associated press |work=the meriden daily journal |page=4 |date=9 october 1934 |accessdate=15 march 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=-wpjaaaaibaj&sjid=qwinaaaaibaj&dq=pepper%20martin&pg=3307%2c273499}}</ref> the following inning, outraged detroit fans pelted medwick with debris when he assumed his defensive position in the outfield.<ref name=cardinals rule baseball third time in nine years/> the disturbance wasn't quelled until the umpires appealed to baseball commissioner [[kenesaw mountain landis]], who had medwick removed from the game.<ref name=cardinals rule baseball third time in nine years/> martin ended the series with 11 hits for a .355 average, stole two bases and scored eight runs in the series.<ref name=pepper martin post-season batting statistics/> he experienced difficulties in the field, committing 3 [[error (baseball)|errors]] in game 4 and setting a world series record with four errors overall.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/sln/sln193410060.shtml |title=1934 world series game 4 |publisher=baseball-reference |accessdate=16 march 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=seven all-time records for world series set this year |agency=associated press |work=the meriden daily journal |page=4 |date=9 october 1934 |accessdate=19 march 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=-wpjaaaaibaj&sjid=qwinaaaaibaj&dq=pepper%20martin&pg=5905%2c271501}}</ref> while in a st. louis hospital in december 1934, for a minor operation on his left arm, martin insisted that he be entertained by a [[western music (north america)|cowboy]] musical group that he had hired. he created such a disturbance among the other patients that the hospital staff moved him to an isolated wing.<ref>{{cite news |title='pepper' martin big buddies; both met in missouri hospital |agency=united press international |work=the telegraph-herald and times-journal |page=12 |date=21 december 1934 |accessdate=15 march 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=cn9baaaaibaj&sjid=-qkmaaaaibaj&pg=2566,1680649&dq=pepper+martin&hl=en}}</ref> martin, along with cardinals teammates such as [[leo durocher]], [[dizzy dean]] and [[joe medwick]] among others, became known as the 1934 [[gashouse gang]] due to their boisterous activities on and off the field.<ref name=dizzy, dazzy and ducky/><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=dbcdaaaambaj&pg=pa29&dq=gas+house+gang+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=ak9_temoay6atwfg2entca&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0ccwq6aewaa#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=the gashouse gang- laughing gas, that is |author=lyall, smith |publisher=books.google.com |date=july 1960 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=15 march 2011 }}</ref> he played the guitar in a [[old-time music|hillbilly]] band composed of cardinals players named ''the mudcat band''.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=otmdaaaambaj&pg=pa70&dq=pepper+martin+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=akd_tdegdoxitwe1u4hfca&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0cdmq6aewajgk#v=onepage&q=pepper%20martin%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=baseball's all-time team of 'screwballs' |author=vass, george |publisher=books.google.com |date=june 1971 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=15 march 2011 }}</ref>

'''johnny leonard roosevelt pepper martin''' (february 29, 1904 – march 5, 1965) was an [[united states|american]] professional [[baseball]] player and minor league [[manager (baseball)|manager]].<ref name=pepper martin statistics>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/m/martipe01.shtml |title=pepper martin statistics |publisher=baseball-reference |accessdate=15 march 2011}}</ref> he was known as the ''wild horse of the osage'' because of his daring, aggressive [[baserunning]] abilities. martin played in [[major league baseball]] as a [[third baseman]] and an [[outfielder]] for the [[st. louis cardinals]] during the 1930s and early 1940s. he was best known for his heroics during the [[1931 world series]], in which he was the catalyst in a cardinals' upset victory over the [[oakland athletics|philadelphia athletics]].<ref name=the peppering of philly>{{cite web |url=http://www.thisgreatgame.com/1931.html |title=the peppering of philly |publisher=thisgreatgame.com |accessdate=15 march 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ozidaaaambaj&pg=pa24&dq=pepper+martin+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=akd_tdegdoxitwe1u4hfca&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0cd8q6aewbtgk#v=onepage&q=pepper%20martin%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=all-time world series team |author=vass, george |publisher=books.google.com |date=october 1971 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=15 march 2011}}</ref>

martin's batting average dropped to .289 in [[1934 st. louis cardinals season|1934]], but he once again led the league in stolen bases as the cardinals rallied from seven games behind the [[1934 new york giants (mlb) season|new york giants]] in early september to win the national league pennant on the last day of the season.<ref name=pepper martin statistics/><ref name=dizzy, dazzy and ducky/> he made an appearance as a [[relief pitcher]] on august 19, allowing one hit in two innings pitched.<ref>{{cite news |title=cards split bargain bill with braves |agency=associated press |work=the milwaukee sentinel |page=10 |date=20 august 1934 |accessdate=15 march 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=otwaaaaaibaj&sjid=pg4eaaaaibaj&pg=6610,3178962&dq=pepper+martin&hl=en}}</ref> in a memorable [[1934 world series]] against the [[1934 detroit tigers season|detroit tigers]], the cardinals were down 3 games to 2, before rebounding to win the final two games.<ref name=the game i'll never forget/> the series was highlighted by several rough plays on the base paths that culminated in game 7, when joe medwick made a rough slide into tigers' third baseman [[marv owen]].<ref name=cardinals rule baseball third time in nine years>{{cite news |title=cardinals rule baseball third time in nine years |agency=associated press |work=the meriden daily journal |page=4 |date=9 october 1934 |accessdate=15 march 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=-wpjaaaaibaj&sjid=qwinaaaaibaj&dq=pepper%20martin&pg=3307%2c273499}}</ref> the following inning, outraged detroit fans pelted medwick with debris when he assumed his defensive position in the outfield.<ref name=cardinals rule baseball third time in nine years/> the disturbance wasn't quelled until the umpires appealed to baseball commissioner [[kenesaw mountain landis]], who had medwick removed from the game.<ref name=cardinals rule baseball third time in nine years/> martin ended the series with 11 hits for a .355 average, stole two bases and scored eight runs in the series.<ref name=pepper martin post-season batting statistics/> he experienced difficulties in the field, committing 3 [[error (baseball)|errors]] in game 4 and setting a world series record with four errors overall.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/sln/sln193410060.shtml |title=1934 world series game 4 |publisher=baseball-reference |accessdate=16 march 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=seven all-time records for world series set this year |agency=associated press |work=the meriden daily journal |page=4 |date=9 october 1934 |accessdate=19 march 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=-wpjaaaaibaj&sjid=qwinaaaaibaj&dq=pepper%20martin&pg=5905%2c271501}}</ref> while in a st. louis hospital in december 1934, for a minor operation on his left arm, martin insisted that he be entertained by a [[western music (north america)|cowboy]] musical group that he had hired. he created such a disturbance among the other patients that the hospital staff moved him to an isolated wing.<ref>{{cite news |title='pepper' martin big buddies; both met in missouri hospital |agency=united press international |work=the telegraph-herald and times-journal |page=12 |date=21 december 1934 |accessdate=15 march 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=cn9baaaaibaj&sjid=-qkmaaaaibaj&pg=2566,1680649&dq=pepper+martin&hl=en}}</ref> martin, along with cardinals teammates such as [[leo durocher]], [[dizzy dean]] and [[joe medwick]] among others, became known as the 1934 [[gashouse gang]] due to their boisterous activities on and off the field.<ref name=dizzy, dazzy and ducky/><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=dbcdaaaambaj&pg=pa29&dq=gas+house+gang+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=ak9_temoay6atwfg2entca&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0ccwq6aewaa#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=the gashouse gang- laughing gas, that is |author=lyall, smith |publisher=books.google.com |date=july 1960 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=15 march 2011 }}</ref> he played the guitar in a [[old-time music|hillbilly]] band composed of cardinals players named ''the mudcat band''.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=otmdaaaambaj&pg=pa70&dq=pepper+martin+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=akd_tdegdoxitwe1u4hfca&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0cdmq6aewajgk#v=onepage&q=pepper%20martin%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=baseball's all-time team of 'screwballs' |author=vass, george |publisher=books.google.com |date=june 1971 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=15 march 2011 }}</ref>

dalrymple began his professional baseball career with the [[sacramento solons]] of the [[pacific coast league]] in [[1956 in baseball|1956]], and was obtained by the [[milwaukee braves]] before the [[1959 milwaukee braves season|1959]] season.<ref name=clay dalrymple trades and transactions at baseball almanac>[http://www.baseball-almanac.com/players/trades.php?p=dalrycl01 clay dalrymple trades and transactions at baseball almanac]</ref> the braves invited him to their 1959 [[spring training]] camp where he received catching tips from veteran catchers [[del crandall]] and [[del rice]].<ref name=man he's got a gun!>[http://books.google.com/books?id=lrydaaaambaj&pg=pa55&dq=clay+dalrymple+baseball+digest&cd=2#v=onepage&q=clay%20dalrymple%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''man he's got a gun!'', by edgar williams, baseball digest, september 1962, issn 0005-609x]</ref>  in november 1959 he was drafted by the philadelphia phillies from the braves in the [[rule 5 draft]].<ref name=clay dalrymple trades and transactions at baseball almanac/><ref>[http://www.retrosheet.org/boxesetc/1959/11301959.htm november 30, 1959 rule 5 draft results at retrosheet]</ref>

dalrymple spent the [[1960 philadelphia phillies season|1960]] season backing up [[jimmie coker]], before taking over the starting catcher position for the phillies in [[1961 philadelphia phillies season|1961]].<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/phi/1960.shtml 1960 philadelphia phillies batting, pitching, & fielding statistics at baseball reference]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/phi/1961.shtml 1961 philadelphia phillies batting, pitching, & fielding statistics at baseball reference]</ref> although his offensive output peaked in [[1962 philadelphia phillies season|1962]], he remained in the phillies lineup due to his strong defensive skills.<ref name=clay dalrymple at the baseball biography project/><ref name=man he's got a gun!/> he was instrumental in helping the phillies transform from perennial losers to [[pennant (sports)|pennant]] contenders by the [[1964 philadelphia phillies season|1964]] season.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=azidaaaambaj&pg=pa15&dq=clay+dalrymple+baseball+digest&cd=1#v=onepage&q=clay%20dalrymple%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''the catcher who was brainwashed'', by ron smith, baseball digest, july 1965, vol. 24, no. 6, issn 0005-609x]</ref> with dalrymple's guidance, the phillies' [[pitch (baseball)|pitching]] staff posted a 3.36 [[earned run average]], and the team was in first place in the [[national league]] with 12 games left in the season.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1964.shtml 1964 national league team statistics and standings at baseball reference]</ref> unfortunately, the team suffered a 10 game losing streak in the final two weeks of the season, being overtaken by the [[1964 st. louis cardinals season|st. louis cardinals]] and the [[1964 cincinnati reds season|cincinnati reds]], and ending the season in a second-place tie with cincinnati.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/phi/1964-schedule-scores.shtml 1964 philadelphia phillies schedule, box scores and splits at baseball reference]</ref><ref>[http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/mag1076958/index.htm ''the rise and fall of the fabulous phillies'', by william leggett, sports illustrated, march 1, 1965]</ref>

'''gerald wayne grote''' (born [[october 6]], [[1942]] in [[san antonio, texas]]) was a [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] [[catcher]] who played in the [[major league baseball|major leagues]] for the [[houston astros|houston colt .45s]], [[new york mets]], [[los angeles dodgers]] and [[kansas city royals]] between {{by|1963}} and {{by|1981}}.<ref name=jerry grote at baseball reference>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/g/groteje01.shtml jerry grote at baseball reference]</ref><ref>[http://www.thebaseballcube.com/players/g/jerry-grote.shtml jerry grote at the baseball cube]</ref> grote was considered one of the finest defensive catchers of his era.<ref name=''jerry grote: he caught some of the greats in his career''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=2yodaaaambaj&pg=pa63&dq=baseball+digest+jerry+grote#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20jerry%20grote&f=false ''jerry grote: he caught some of the greats in his career'', baseball digest, may 1992, vol. 51, no. 5, issn 0005-609x]</ref>

during the [[miracle mets#1969: the miracle mets|1969 ''miracle mets'']] season, he was considered one of the most valuable players on the team because of his work in handling the pitching staff and for his defensive skills.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=kdmdaaaambaj&pg=pa33&dq=baseball+digest+jerry+grote#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20jerry%20grote&f=false ''jerry grote: mets most valuable?'', baseball digest, feb 1970, vol. 29, no. 2, issn 0005-609x]</ref> prior to the [[1969 new york mets season|1969]] season, the mets had been perennial losers, never finishing higher than ninth place in the national league.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/bullpen/new_york_mets the new york mets at baseball reference]</ref> the [[1969 chicago cubs season|chicago cubs]], had been in first place in the [[national league east]] for 156 days of the season, and seemed likely to win the division, when they slumped to a 9-17 record in their final 25 games, while the mets went 37-11 in their final 48 games and clinched the [[pennant (sports)|pennant]].<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1969-standings.shtml 1969 national league east standings at baseball reference]</ref><ref name=''pennant races don't really begin until month of july''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=acwdaaaambaj&pg=pa29&dq=baseball+digest+miracle+mets#v=onepage&q=&f=false ''pennant races don't really begin until month of july'', baseball digest, july 1996, vol. 55, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref> the mets went on to sweep the [[1969 atlanta braves season|atlanta braves]] in the [[1969 national league championship series]], and then [[upset]] the favored [[1969 baltimore orioles season|baltimore orioles]] to win the [[1969 world series|world series]], four games to one.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1969_ws.shtml 1969 world series at baseball reference]</ref>

'''gerald wayne grote''' (born october 6, 1942) is a former [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] [[catcher]] who played the majority of his [[major league baseball|major league]] career with the [[new york mets]].<ref name=jerry grote>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/g/groteje01.shtml |title=jerry grote |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=2 november 2010 }}</ref> he was considered one of the finest defensive catchers of his era.<ref name=jerry grote: he caught some of the greats in his career>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=2yodaaaambaj&pg=pa63&dq=baseball+digest+jerry+grote#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20jerry%20grote&f=false |title=jerry grote: he caught some of the greats in his career |author=winkworth, bruce |publisher=books.google.com |date=may 1992 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=2 november 2010 }}</ref>

grote finished the season with a .252 average and produced career-highs with 6 home runs and 40 runs batted in but, it was his defensive skills that proved most valuable for the mets.<ref name=jerry grote/><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=kdmdaaaambaj&pg=pa33&dq=baseball+digest+jerry+grote#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20jerry%20grote&f=false |title=jerry grote: mets most valuable? |author=elderkin, phil |publisher=books.google.com |date=february 1970 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=2 november 2010 }}</ref> grote posted a .991 [[fielding percentage]] and his 56.3% [[caught stealing]] percentage was second-best among national league catchers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1969-fielding-leaders.shtml |title=1969 national league fielding leaders |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=3 november 2010 }}</ref> he was also given credit for guiding the mets young pitching staff which, led the league in victories and [[shutout (baseball)|shutouts]] and, finished second in team [[earned run average]].<ref name=the baseball biography project: jerry grote/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1969.shtml#teams_standard_pitching::none |title=1969 national league team statistics and standings |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=3 november 2010 }}</ref>

grote and the 1969 mets became an improbable part of baseball history. in their previous seven seasons, the mets had finished in last place five times. their sudden turn of fortune in 1969 and their subsequent upset victory in the world series stunned the sports world and, became one of the more storied events in baseball lore.<ref name=when the miracle mets shocked the baseball world>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=vybawtlkgmwc&pg=pa48&dq=miracle+mets+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=rojqtivjgogub5q-0a8m&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0ccwq6aewaq#v=onepage&q=miracle%20mets%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=when the miracle mets shocked the baseball world |author=schultz, randy |publisher=books.google.com |date=june 2009 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=3 november 2010 }}</ref> the team became known as the ''miracle mets''.<ref name=when the miracle mets shocked the baseball world/>

in may [[1973 new york mets season|1973]], grote broke a bone in his right arm when he was hit by a pitch and went on the [[disabled list]] for two months.<ref name=the baseball biography project: jerry grote/> when he returned in mid-july, the mets began winning, climbing from last place on august 30 to win the national league eastern division pennant.<ref name=''pennant races don't really begin until month of july''/><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ui4daaaambaj&pg=pa20&dq=pennant+races+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=w_lqtniffysclgfx4ocbdq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0cc0q6aewaq#v=onepage&q=pennant%20races%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=six greatest pennant races of the last 50 years |author=vass, george |publisher=books.google.com |date=september 1991 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=3 november 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/nym/1973.shtml |title=1973 new york mets batting, pitching, & fielding statistics |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=2 november 2010 }}</ref> they then proceeded to defeat the heavily-favored [[1973 cincinnati reds season|cincinnati reds]] in the [[1973 national league championship series]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1973_nlcs.shtml |title=1973 national league championship series |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=2 november 2010 }}</ref> in the [[1973 world series|world series]], the mets took the [[1973 oakland athletics season|oakland athletics]] to the seventh and final game, before they were defeated.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1973_ws.shtml |title=1973 world series |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=2 november 2010 }}</ref> as he had in 1969, grote caught every [[inning]] of every post-season game for the mets in {{by|1973}}.<ref name=the baseball biography project: jerry grote/> looking back on his two pennant-winning seasons with the mets, grote said, it was no miracle, grote said of his 1969 season with the mets. now, '73 was a miracle.<ref name=grote/>

in a 16 year career, grote played in 1421 [[games played|games]], accumulating 1,092 [[hit (baseball)|hits]] in 4,339 [[at bats]] for a .252 career batting average along with 39 home runs and 404 [[runs batted in]].<ref name=jerry grote/> he ended his career with a .991 fielding percentage.<ref name=jerry grote/> at the time of his retirement in 1981, his .991 career fielding percentage was eighth highest all-time among catchers. on april 22, {{by|1970}}, grote set a major league record with 20 [[putout]]s in a game when, tom seaver threw 19 [[strikeout]]s against the [[1970 san diego padres season|san diego padres]].<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ry4daaaambaj&pg=pa15&dq=bob+schmidt+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=d_qdtopneswblgfytemjdq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0cdiq6aewag#v=onepage&q=bob%20schmidt%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=letters to the editor |publisher=books.google.com |date=september 1990 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=3 november 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/nyn/nyn197004220.shtml |title=april 22, 1970 padres-mets box score |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=3 november 2010 }}</ref> he is the mets all-time leader in games played as a catcher (1,176).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://bb_catchers.tripod.com/catchers/mostgame.htm |title=most games caught for team |publisher=the encyclopedia of baseball catchers |accessdate=3 november 2010 }}</ref>

grote finished the season with a .252 average and produced career-highs with 6 home runs and 40 runs batted in, but it was his defensive skills that proved most valuable for the mets.<ref name=jerry grote/><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=kdmdaaaambaj&pg=pa33&dq=baseball+digest+jerry+grote#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20jerry%20grote&f=false |title=jerry grote: mets most valuable? |author=elderkin, phil |publisher=|date=february 1970 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=2 november 2010 }}</ref> grote posted a .991 [[fielding percentage]] and his 56.3% [[caught stealing]] percentage was second-best among national league catchers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1969-fielding-leaders.shtml |title=1969 national league fielding leaders |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=3 november 2010 }}</ref> he was also given credit for guiding the mets young pitching staff that led the league in victories and [[shutout (baseball)|shutouts]] and finished second in team [[earned run average]].<ref name=sabrbio/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1969.shtml#teams_standard_pitching::none |title=1969 national league team statistics and standings |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=3 november 2010 }}</ref>

grote and the 1969 mets became an improbable part of baseball history. in their previous seven seasons the mets had finished in last place five times. their sudden turn of fortune in 1969 and their subsequent upset victory in the world series stunned the sports world and became one of the more storied events in baseball lore.<ref name=when the miracle mets shocked the baseball world>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=vybawtlkgmwc&pg=pa48&dq=miracle+mets+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=miracle%20mets%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=when the miracle mets shocked the baseball world |author=schultz, randy |publisher=|date=june 2009 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=3 november 2010 }}</ref> the team became known as the ''miracle mets''.<ref name=when the miracle mets shocked the baseball world/>

in may [[1973 new york mets season|1973]], grote broke a bone in his right arm when he was hit by a pitch and went on the [[disabled list]] for two months.<ref name=sabrbio/> when he returned in mid-july, the mets began winning, climbing from last place on august 30 to win the national league eastern division pennant.<ref name=''pennant races don't really begin until month of july''/><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ui4daaaambaj&pg=pa20&dq=pennant+races+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=pennant%20races%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=six greatest pennant races of the last 50 years |author=vass, george |publisher=|date=september 1991 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=3 november 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/nym/1973.shtml |title=1973 new york mets batting, pitching, & fielding statistics |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=2 november 2010 }}</ref> they then proceeded to defeat the heavily favored [[1973 cincinnati reds season|cincinnati reds]] in the [[1973 national league championship series]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1973_nlcs.shtml |title=1973 national league championship series |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=2 november 2010 }}</ref> in the [[1973 world series|world series]], the mets took the [[1973 oakland athletics season|oakland athletics]] to the seventh and final game, before they were defeated.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1973_ws.shtml |title=1973 world series |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=2 november 2010 }}</ref> as he had in 1969, grote caught every [[inning]] of every post-season game for the mets in {{by|1973}}.<ref name=sabrbio/> looking back on his two pennant-winning seasons with the mets, grote said, it (the 1969 season) was no miracle. now, '73 was a miracle.<ref name=grote/>

in a 16-year career, grote played in 1,421 [[games played|games]], accumulating 1,092 [[hit (baseball)|hits]] in 4,339 [[at bats]] for a .252 career batting average along with 39 home runs and 404 [[runs batted in]].<ref name=jerry grote/> he ended his career with a .991 fielding percentage,<ref name=jerry grote/> which at the time of his retirement was eighth highest all-time among catchers. on april 22, {{by|1970}}, grote set a major league record with 20 [[putout]]s in a game when tom seaver threw 19 [[strikeout]]s against the [[1970 san diego padres season|san diego padres]].<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ry4daaaambaj&pg=pa15&dq=bob+schmidt+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=bob%20schmidt%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=letters to the editor |publisher=|date=september 1990 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=3 november 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/nyn/nyn197004220.shtml |title=april 22, 1970 padres-mets box score |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=3 november 2010 }}</ref> he is the mets all-time leader in games played as a catcher (1,176).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://bb_catchers.tripod.com/catchers/mostgame.htm |title=most games caught for team |publisher=the encyclopedia of baseball catchers |accessdate=3 november 2010 }}</ref> grote caught 116 [[shutouts in baseball|shutouts]] in his career, ranking him 15th all-time among catchers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://bb_catchers.tripod.com/catchers/tmonth1.htm |title=career shutouts caught |publisher=the encyclopedia of baseball catchers |accessdate=1 february 2011 }}</ref>

in a 16 year career, davis played in 1,458 [[games played|games]], accumulating 1,312 [[hit (baseball)|hits]] in 4,255 [[at bats]] for a .308 career batting average along with 77 home runs, 647 runs batted in and a .369 on base percentage.<ref name=spud davis/> he ended his career with a .984 fielding percentage.<ref name=spud davis/> davis hit over .300 ten times in sixteen years.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=rdqdaaaambaj&pg=pa48&dq=spud+davis+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=gzratmrvlswalafezzz1ca&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0ccwq6aewajgk#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=13 most forgotten stars in baseball history! |author=grosshandler, stan |publisher=books.google.com |date=february 1981 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=10 november 2010 }}</ref><ref name=baseball's forgotten stars>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=4i0daaaambaj&pg=pa38&dq=ken+williams+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=i8lgtjnfbjyg4qa7zododw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0ceiq6aewbg#v=onepage&q=ken%20williams%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=baseball's forgotten stars |author=vass, george |publisher=books.google.com |date=july 2004 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=25 october 2010 }}</ref> at the time of his retirement, davis' .308 career batting average was second only to [[mickey cochrane]] all-time among major league catchers.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=qzqdaaaambaj&pg=pa12&dq=spud+davis+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=xzfatitsjih7lwflp9jfca&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0cckq6aewaq#v=onepage&q=spud%20davis%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=all-time best hitting catchers |publisher=books.google.com |date=october 1979 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=10 november 2010 }}</ref> as of {{by|2010}}, he ranks fourth all-time among career batting averages for catchers behind [[joe mauer]], mickey cochrane and [[bill dickey]].<ref name=catcher batting average leaders/>
