because the position requires a comprehensive understanding of the game's strategies, the pool of former catchers yields a disproportionate number of major and minor-league managers, including such prominent examples as [[connie mack (baseball)|connie mack]], [[steve o'neill]], [[al lopez]], [[yogi berra]], [[mike scioscia]] and [[joe torre]].<ref name=''catchers are baseball's least appreciated players''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=pc0daaaambaj&pg=pa24&lpg=pa24&dq=catchers+least+appreciated+players+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=7ystjq1cp3&sig=f1gb-phynyvh9lvzehbgnvye9lk&hl=en&ei=raq7tjx2h4p7lwfy-ojsbw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0cciq6aewba#v=onepage&q=catchers%20least%20appreciated%20players%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''catchers are baseball's least appreciated players'', by david andriesen, baseball digest, november 2003, vol. 62, no. 11, issn 0005-609x]</ref> the physical and mental strain of being involved on every defensive play can wear catchers down over a long season, and can have a negative effect on their offensive output.<ref name=never underestimate a good defensive catcher>[http://books.google.com/books?id=vssdaaaambaj&pg=pa38&dq=baseball+digest+defensive+catchers&cd=1#v=onepage&q=&f=false ''never underestimate a good defensive catcher'', by al doyle, baseball digest, june 1997, vol. 56, no. 6, issn 0005-609x]</ref><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa24&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''catching'', by john lowe, baseball digest, july 2001, vol. 60, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref> due to catching's strategic defensive importance, if a catcher has exceptional defensive skills, teams are often willing to overlook their relative offensive weaknesses.<ref name=never underestimate a good defensive catcher/> a knowledgeable catcher's ability to work with the pitcher, via pitch selection and location, can diminish the effectiveness of the opposing team's offense.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=9s0daaaambaj&pg=pa26&dq=baseball+digest+defensive+catchers#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20defensive%20catchers&f=false ''for catchers, the name of the game is defense'', by george vass, baseball digest, may 2005, vol. 64, no. 3, issn 0005-609x]</ref> many great defensive catchers toiled in relative anonymity, because they didn't produce large offensive numbers. notable examples of light-[[batting (baseball)|hitting]], defensive specialists were; [[ray schalk]], [[jim hegan]], [[jim sundberg]] and [[brad ausmus]]. schalk's career [[batting average]] of .253 is the lowest of any position player in the [[baseball hall of fame]].<ref name=howstuffworks.com>[http://entertainment.howstuffworks.com/ray-schalk-hof.htm howstuffworks.com]</ref> that he was selected for enshrinement in [[baseball hall of fame balloting, 1955|1955]] was largely a tribute to his outstanding defensive skills.<ref name=howstuffworks.com/> catchers are often able to play [[first base]] and less commonly [[third base]].

because the position requires a comprehensive understanding of the game's strategies, the pool of former catchers yields a disproportionate number of major and minor-league [[manager (baseball)|manager]]s, including such prominent examples as [[connie mack]], [[steve o'neill]], [[al lopez]], [[yogi berra]], [[mike scioscia]], and [[joe torre]].<ref name=''catchers are baseball's least appreciated players''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=pc0daaaambaj&pg=pa24&lpg=pa24&dq=catchers+least+appreciated+players+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=7ystjq1cp3&sig=f1gb-phynyvh9lvzehbgnvye9lk&hl=en&ei=raq7tjx2h4p7lwfy-ojsbw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0cciq6aewba#v=onepage&q=catchers%20least%20appreciated%20players%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''catchers are baseball's least appreciated players'', by david andriesen, ''baseball digest'', november 2003, vol. 62, no. 11, issn 0005-609x]</ref> the physical and mental strain of being involved on every defensive play can wear catchers down over a long season, and can have a negative effect on their offensive output.<ref name=never underestimate a good defensive catcher>[http://books.google.com/books?id=vssdaaaambaj&pg=pa38&dq=baseball+digest+defensive+catchers&cd=1#v=onepage&q=&f=false ''never underestimate a good defensive catcher'', by al doyle, baseball digest, june 1997, vol. 56, no. 6, issn 0005-609x]</ref><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa24&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''catching'', by john lowe, baseball digest, july 2001, vol. 60, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref>

due to catching's strategic defensive importance, if a catcher has exceptional defensive skills, teams are often willing to overlook their relative offensive weaknesses.<ref name=never underestimate a good defensive catcher/> a knowledgeable catcher's ability to work with the pitcher, via pitch selection and location, can diminish the effectiveness of the opposing team's offense.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=9s0daaaambaj&pg=pa26&dq=baseball+digest+defensive+catchers#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20defensive%20catchers&f=false ''for catchers, the name of the game is defense'', by george vass, ''baseball digest'', may 2005, vol. 64, no. 3, issn 0005-609x]</ref> many great defensive catchers toiled in relative anonymity, because they did not produce large offensive numbers. notable examples of light-[[batting (baseball)|hitting]], defensive specialists were; [[ray schalk]], [[jim hegan]], [[jim sundberg]] and [[brad ausmus]]. schalk's career [[batting average]] of .253 is the lowest of any position player in the [[baseball hall of fame]].<ref name=howstuffworks.com>[http://entertainment.howstuffworks.com/ray-schalk-hof.htm howstuffworks.com]</ref> that he was selected for enshrinement in [[baseball hall of fame balloting, 1955|1955]] was largely a tribute to his outstanding defensive skills.<ref name=howstuffworks.com/> catchers are often able to play [[first base]] and less commonly [[third base]].

because the position requires a comprehensive understanding of the game's strategies, the pool of former catchers yields a disproportionate number of major and minor-league [[manager (baseball)|managers]], including such prominent examples as [[connie mack]], [[steve o'neill]], [[al lopez]], [[yogi berra]], [[mike scioscia]], [[bruce bochy]], [[joe torre]], and [[mike matheny]].<ref name=''catchers are baseball's least appreciated players''>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=pc0daaaambaj&pg=pa24&lpg=pa24&dq=catchers+least+appreciated+players+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=7ystjq1cp3&sig=f1gb-phynyvh9lvzehbgnvye9lk&hl=en&ei=raq7tjx2h4p7lwfy-ojsbw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0cciq6aewba#v=onepage&q=catchers%20least%20appreciated%20players%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=catchers are baseball's least appreciated players |author=andriesen, david |publisher=books.google.com |date=november 2003 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=9 march 2012 }}</ref> the physical and mental strain of being involved on every defensive play can wear catchers down over a long season, and can have a negative effect on their offensive output.<ref name=never underestimate a good defensive catcher>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=vssdaaaambaj&pg=pa38&dq=baseball+digest+defensive+catchers&cd=1#v=onepage&q=&f=false |title=never underestimate a good defensive catcher |author=doyle, al |publisher=books.google.com |date=june 1997 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=9 march 2012 }}</ref>

due to catching's strategic defensive importance, if a catcher has exceptional defensive skills, teams are often willing to overlook their relative offensive weaknesses.<ref name=never underestimate a good defensive catcher/> a knowledgeable catcher's ability to work with the pitcher, via pitch selection and location, can diminish the effectiveness of the opposing team's offense.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=9s0daaaambaj&pg=pa26&dq=baseball+digest+defensive+catchers#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20defensive%20catchers&f=false |title=for catchers, the name of the game is defense |author=vass, george |publisher=books.google.com |date=may 2005 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=9 march 2012 }}</ref> many great defensive catchers toiled in relative anonymity, because they did not produce large offensive numbers. notable examples of light-[[batting (baseball)|hitting]], defensive specialists were; [[ray schalk]], [[jim hegan]], [[jim sundberg]] and [[brad ausmus]]. schalk's career [[batting average]] of .253 is the lowest of any position player in the [[baseball hall of fame]].<ref name=howstuffworks.com>{{cite web|url=http://entertainment.howstuffworks.com/ray-schalk-hof.htm |title=howstuffworks.com |publisher=entertainment.howstuffworks.com |date= |accessdate=2013-09-21}}</ref> that he was selected for enshrinement in [[baseball hall of fame balloting, 1955|1955]] was largely a tribute to his outstanding defensive skills.<ref name=howstuffworks.com/> catchers are often able to play [[first base]] and less commonly [[third base]].

'''john alban edwards''' (born june 10, 1938 in [[columbus, ohio]]<ref name=johnny edwards at baseball reference>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/e/edwarjo01.shtml johnny edwards at baseball reference]</ref>) was a former [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] [[catcher]] known for his excellent defensive skills.<ref name=at times it's smart to be dumb, says cincy's edwards>[http://books.google.com/books?id=ftidaaaambaj&pg=pa57&dq=johnny+edwards+baseball+digest&cd=1#v=onepage&q=johnny%20edwards%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''at times it's smart to be dumb, says cincy's edwards'', by ritter collett, baseball digest, june 1965, vol. 24, no. 5, issn 0005-609x]</ref> he played in the [[major league baseball|major leagues]] for the [[cincinnati reds]] (196167), [[st. louis cardinals]] (1968) and [[houston astros]] (196974).<ref name=johnny edwards at baseball reference/>

in 14 seasons edwards played in 1,470 [[games played|games]], producing 1,106 [[hit (baseball)|hits]] in 4,577 [[at bats]] for a .242 [[batting average]] along with 81 [[home run]]s and 524 [[runs batted in]].<ref name=johnny edwards at baseball reference/> he was voted to three [[national league]] [[major league baseball all-star game|all-star]] teams in [[1963 major league baseball all-star game|1963]], [[1964 major league baseball all-star game|1964]] and [[1965 major league baseball all-star game|1965]].<ref name=johnny edwards at baseball reference/> a solid defensive player, he won the [[national league]] [[gold glove award]] for catchers in [[1963 cincinnati reds season|1963]] and [[1964 cincinnati reds season|1964]], and led national league catchers in [[fielding percentage]] four times in 1963, 1969, [[1970 houston astros season|1970]] and [[1971 houston astros season|1971]].<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/gold_glove_nl.shtml#1964 national league gold glove award winners at baseball reference]</ref><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa86&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, july 2001, vol. 60, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref> he also led the league four times in [[assist (baseball)|assists]] and three times in [[putout]]s.<ref name=johnny edwards at baseball reference/> in 1969, edwards set single season records for catchers with 1135 putouts and 1221 [[total chances]].<ref>[http://members.tripod.com/bb_catchers/catchers/fieldcar.htm fielding records at the encyclopedia of catchers]</ref> richard kendall of the [[society for american baseball research]] devised an unscientific study that ranked edwards as the second most dominating fielding catcher in major league history.<ref>[http://members.tripod.com/bb_catchers/catchers/dominate.htm dominating fielding catchers at the encyclopedia of baseball catchers]</ref> as of the end of the 2009 [[major league baseball]] season he ranked 79th on the all-time [[intentional walk]]s list.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leaders/ibb_career.shtml career intentional walks at baseball reference]</ref>
* [http://books.google.com/books?id=ftidaaaambaj&pg=pa57&dq=johnny+edwards+baseball+digest&cd=1#v=onepage&q=johnny%20edwards%20baseball%20digest&f=false johnny edwards in baseball digest, june 1965]

'''andrew wasal seminick''' (september 12, 1920  february 22, 2004) was an [[united states|american]] [[major league baseball]] [[catcher]] and right-handed batter.<ref name=andy seminick at baseball reference>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/s/seminan01.shtml andy seminick at baseball reference]</ref> he played for the [[philadelphia phillies]] between [[1943 philadelphia phillies season|1943]] and [[1951 philadelphia phillies season|1951]], and the [[cincinnati reds|cincinnati reds/redlegs]] from [[1952 cincinnati reds season|1952]] through part of [[1955 cincinnati reds season|1955]], when he rejoined the phillies for the rest of the year until his release at the end of the [[1957 philadelphia phillies season|1957]] season. seminick was an integral part of the [[1950 philadelphia phillies season|1950]] [[whiz kids (baseball)|whiz kids]] phillies team that won their first [[pennant (sports)|pennant]] since {{by|1915}}.<ref name=''seminick-key man of phils''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=njmdaaaambaj&pg=pa21&dq=andy+seminick+baseball+digest&cd=1#v=onepage&q=andy%20seminick%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''seminick-key man of phils'', by charles dexter, baseball digest november 1950, vol. 9, no. 11, issn 0005-609x]</ref><ref name=andy seminick obituary at the new york times>[http://www.nytimes.com/2004/02/24/sports/andy-seminick-83-catcher-for-whiz-kids.html?pagewanted=1 andy seminick obituary at the new york times]</ref>

in [[1951 philadelphia phillies season|1951]], seminick was [[beanball|beaned]] by a [[max lanier]] fastball, diminishing his ability to play.<ref name=andy seminick biography at the baseball biography project/> he was traded to the cincinnati reds for catcher [[smoky burgess]], playing there from [[1952 cincinnati reds season|1952]] until the early part of the [[1955 cincinnati reds season|1955]] season.<ref name=andy seminick trades and transactions at baseball almanac/> in [[1955 philadelphia phillies season|1955]], he was once again traded for burgess, returning to the phillies where he led national league catchers with a .994 [[fielding percentage]].<ref name=andy seminick trades and transactions at baseball almanac/><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa86&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, july 2001, p.86, vol. 60, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref> he played a couple of more years before ending his playing career after the [[1957 philadelphia phillies season|1957]] season.

* [http://books.google.com/books?id=4i4daaaambaj&pg=pa66&dq=baseball+digest+november+2002&cd=2#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20november%202002&f=false ''1950: when philadelphia's whiz kids won the n.l. pennant'', baseball digest, november 2002]

* [http://books.google.com/books?id=njmdaaaambaj&pg=pa21&dq=andy+seminick+baseball+digest&cd=1#v=onepage&q=andy%20seminick%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''seminick-key man of phils'', by charles dexter, baseball digest november 1950]

'''andrew wasal seminick''' (september 12, 1920  february 22, 2004) was an [[united states|american]] [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] player.<ref name=andy seminick at baseball reference>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/s/seminan01.shtml andy seminick at baseball reference]</ref> he played in [[major league baseball]] as a [[catcher]] for the [[philadelphia phillies]] between [[1943 philadelphia phillies season|1943]] and [[1951 philadelphia phillies season|1951]], and the [[cincinnati reds|cincinnati reds/redlegs]] from [[1952 cincinnati reds season|1952]] through part of [[1955 cincinnati reds season|1955]], when he rejoined the phillies for the rest of his career until his release at the end of the [[1957 philadelphia phillies season|1957]] season. seminick was an integral part of the [[1950 philadelphia phillies season|1950]] [[whiz kids (baseball)|whiz kids]] phillies team that won their first [[pennant (sports)|pennant]] since {{by|1915}}.<ref name=''seminick-key man of phils''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=njmdaaaambaj&pg=pa21&dq=andy+seminick+baseball+digest&cd=1#v=onepage&q=andy%20seminick%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''seminick-key man of phils'', by charles dexter, baseball digest november 1950, vol. 9, no. 11, issn 0005-609x]</ref><ref name=andy seminick obituary at the new york times>[http://www.nytimes.com/2004/02/24/sports/andy-seminick-83-catcher-for-whiz-kids.html?pagewanted=1 andy seminick obituary at the new york times]</ref>

in [[1951 philadelphia phillies season|1951]], seminick was [[beanball|beaned]] by a [[max lanier]] fastball, diminishing his ability to play.<ref name=sabrbio/> he was traded to the cincinnati reds for catcher [[smoky burgess]], playing there from [[1952 cincinnati reds season|1952]] until the early part of the [[1955 cincinnati reds season|1955]] season.<ref name=andy seminick trades and transactions at baseball almanac/> in [[1955 philadelphia phillies season|1955]], he was once again traded for burgess, returning to the phillies, where he led national league catchers with a .994 [[fielding percentage]].<ref name=andy seminick trades and transactions at baseball almanac/><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa86&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, july 2001, p.86, vol. 60, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref> he played a couple of more years before ending his playing career after the [[1957 philadelphia phillies season|1957]] season.

* [http://books.google.com/books?id=4i4daaaambaj&pg=pa66&dq=baseball+digest+november+2002&cd=2#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20november%202002&f=false ''1950: when philadelphia's whiz kids won the n.l. pennant'', baseball digest, november 2002]

* [http://books.google.com/books?id=njmdaaaambaj&pg=pa21&dq=andy+seminick+baseball+digest&cd=1#v=onepage&q=andy%20seminick%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''seminick-key man of phils'', by charles dexter, baseball digest november 1950]

in a 16 year career, snyder played in 1392 [[games played|games]], accumulating 1122 [[hit (baseball)|hits]] in 4229 [[at bats]] for a .265 career batting average along with 44 [[triple (baseball)|triples]], 47 [[home run]]s and 525 [[runs batted in]].<ref name=frank snyder at baseball reference/> he ended his career with a .981 fielding percentage.<ref name=frank snyder at baseball reference/> snyder led [[national league]] catchers in [[fielding percentage]] three times in [[1914 st. louis cardinals season|1914]], [[1923 new york giants season|1923]] and [[1925 new york giants (mlb) season|1925]].<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa86&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, july 2001, vol. 60, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref> he also led the league twice in [[putout]]s and [[caught stealing]] percentage and, once in [[assist (baseball)|assists]] and in baserunners caught stealing.<ref name=frank snyder at baseball reference/> his 204 assists as a catcher in {{by|1915}} is the seventh highest single-season total in major league baseball history.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leaders/a_c_season.shtml single-season leaders & records for assists as catcher at baseball reference]</ref>

richard kendall of the [[society for american baseball research]] devised an unscientific study that ranked snyder as the ninth most dominating fielding catcher in major league history.<ref>[http://members.tripod.com/bb_catchers/catchers/dominate.htm dominating fielding catchers at the encyclopedia of baseball catchers]</ref> his reputation as a defensive stand out is enhanced because of the era in which he played. in the [[deadball era]], catchers played a huge defensive role, given the large number of [[bunt (baseball)|bunt]]s and [[stolen base]] attempts, as well as the difficulty of handling the [[spitball]] pitchers who dominated pitching staffs.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=9s0daaaambaj&pg=pa26&dq=baseball+digest+defensive+catchers#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20defensive%20catchers&f=false ''for catchers, the name of the game is defense'', by george vass, baseball digest, may 2005, vol. 64, no. 3, issn 0005-609x]</ref>

in a 16 year career, snyder played in 1392 [[games played|games]], accumulating 1122 [[hit (baseball)|hits]] in 4229 [[at bat]]s for a .265 career batting average along with 44 [[triple (baseball)|triples]], 47 [[home run]]s and 525 [[runs batted in]].<ref name=frank snyder at baseball reference/> a good defensive player, his .981 career [[fielding average]] was 8 points higher than the league average over the span of his playing career.<ref name=frank snyder at baseball reference/> snyder led [[national league]] catchers in [[fielding percentage]] three times: in [[1914 st. louis cardinals season|1914]], [[1923 new york giants season|1923]] and [[1925 new york giants (mlb) season|1925]].<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa86&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, july 2001, vol. 60, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref> he also led the league twice in [[putout]]s and [[caught stealing]] percentage and, once in [[assist (baseball)|assists]] and in baserunners caught stealing.<ref name=frank snyder at baseball reference/> his 204 assists as a catcher in {{by|1915}} is the seventh highest single-season total in major league baseball history.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leaders/a_c_season.shtml |title=single-season leaders & records for assists as catcher |publisher=baseball-reference.com |accessdate=11 november 2011}}</ref> his 1,332 career assists rank him 17th all-time among major league catchers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leaders/a_c_career.shtml |title=career leaders & records for assists as catcher |publisher=baseball-reference.com |accessdate=11 november 2011}}</ref>

on september 22, [[1968 minnesota twins season|1968]], tovar became the second player to play every position in a game, joining [[bert campaneris]] ([[oakland athletics|kansas city athletics]], [[1965 kansas city athletics season|1965]]), [[scott sheldon]] (texas rangers, [[2000 texas rangers season|2000]]) and [[shane halter]] ([[detroit tigers]], [[2000 detroit tigers season|2000]]) as the only players to have accomplished the feat.<ref>[http://www.baseball-almanac.com/box-scores/boxscore.php?boxid=196809220min september 22, 1968 athletics-twins box score at baseball almanac]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/min/min196809220.shtml september 22, 1968 athletics-twins box score at baseball reference]</ref><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=2tedaaaambaj&pg=pa50&lpg=pa50&dq=cesar+tovar+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=dnd4valbrw&sig=sumvkbbzauzjy50iginbfd7vlqg&hl=en&ei=80plstbpfz2ltgfr1pdkaq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5#v=onepage&q=cesar%20tovar%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''the day csar tovar played all 9 positions'', by emil rothe, baseball digest, february 1973, vol. 32, no. 2, issn 0005-609x]</ref><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=bywdaaaambaj&pg=pa86&dq=cesar+tovar#v=onepage&q=cesar%20tovar&f=false ''when csar tovar played all nine positions in one game'' by bruce markusen, baseball digest, december 1998, vol. 57, no. 12, issn 0005-609x]</ref> tovar started the game on the mound against oakland and [[pitcher|pitched]] one scoreless inning in which he struck out [[reggie jackson]]; the first batter he faced was campaneris. along with campaneris, tovar is one of only four players to have played in all of the baseball positions, including one pitching appearance and being a [[designated hitter]].<ref name=csar tovar at the baseball page>[http://www.thebaseballpage.com/players/tovarce01.php csar tovar at the baseball page]</ref> no [[national league]] player has ever played all nine positions in one game.

* [http://books.google.com/books?id=2tedaaaambaj&pg=pa50&lpg=pa50&dq=cesar+tovar+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=dnd4valbrw&sig=sumvkbbzauzjy50iginbfd7vlqg&hl=en&ei=80plstbpfz2ltgfr1pdkaq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5#v=onepage&q=cesar%20tovar%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''the day csar tovar played all 9 positions'', baseball digest, february 1973]

'''csar leonardo tovar''' (july 3, 1940 - july 14, 1994), nicknamed '''pepito''' and '''mr. versatility''', was a [[venezuela]]n [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] player. he played in [[major league baseball]]  for the [[minnesota twins]] (1965-72), [[philadelphia phillies]] ([[1973 philadelphia phillies season|1973]]), [[texas rangers (baseball)|texas rangers]] ([[1974 texas rangers season|1974]]-[[1975 texas rangers season|1975]]), [[oakland athletics]] ([[1975 oakland athletics season|1975]]-[[1976 oakland athletics season|1976]]) and [[new york yankees]] ([[1976 new york yankees season|1976]]).<ref name=csar tovar at baseball reference>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/t/tovarce01.shtml csar tovar at baseball reference]</ref> tovar was a right-handed batter capable of playing various defensive [[baseball positions|positions]] on the field. he was one of the few players in major league history to play all nine positions during a single game.<ref name=''the day csar tovar played all 9 positions''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=2tedaaaambaj&pg=pa50&lpg=pa50&dq=cesar+tovar+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=dnd4valbrw&sig=sumvkbbzauzjy50iginbfd7vlqg&hl=en&ei=80plstbpfz2ltgfr1pdkaq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5#v=onepage&q=cesar%20tovar%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''the day csar tovar played all 9 positions'', by emil rothe, baseball digest, february 1973, vol. 32, no. 2, issn 0005-609x]</ref>

* [http://books.google.com/books?id=2tedaaaambaj&pg=pa50&lpg=pa50&dq=cesar+tovar+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=dnd4valbrw&sig=sumvkbbzauzjy50iginbfd7vlqg&hl=en&ei=80plstbpfz2ltgfr1pdkaq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5#v=onepage&q=cesar%20tovar%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''the day csar tovar played all 9 positions'', baseball digest, february 1973]

'''brooks calbert robinson, jr.''' (born may 18, 1937<ref name=brooks robinson at baseball reference>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/r/robinbr01.shtml brooks robinson]. - [[baseball-reference]].</ref>) is a former [[united states|american]] [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] player.<ref name=brooks robinson at baseball reference/><ref>[http://www.baseball-almanac.com/players/player.php?p=robinbr01 brooks robinson]. - baseball almanac.</ref> he played his entire 23-year [[major league baseball|major league]] career for the [[baltimore orioles]] (1955–1977).<ref name=brooks robinson at baseball reference/> nicknamed '''the human vacuum cleaner'''<ref name=br-nbhoff />, he is generally acclaimed as one of the greatest defensive third-basemen of all time.<ref>{{cite journal |author=kuenster, bob |date=september 1994 |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ncsdaaaambaj&pg=pa32&dq=baseball+digest+third+basemen#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20third%20basemen&f=false |title=all-time best third basemen starred as hitters, fielders |journal=baseball digest |volume=53 - no. 9 |issn=0005-609x }}</ref> he won 16 consecutive [[gold glove award]]s during his career,<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/gold_glove_al.shtml#multi list of gold glove award winners]. - [[baseball-reference]].</ref> tied with pitcher [[jim kaat]] for the second most all-time for any player at any position. robinson was elected to the [[baseball hall of fame]] in [[baseball hall of fame balloting, 1983|1983]].<ref name=br-nbhoff>[http://baseballhall.org/hof/robinson-brooks brooks robinson]. - [[national baseball hall of fame and museum|national baseball hall of fame]].</ref>

in the [[1970 baltimore orioles season|1970]] post-season, robinson hit for a .583 [[batting average]] in the [[1970 american league championship series]] against the [[1970 minnesota twins season|minnesota twins]].<ref name=brooks robinson post-season statistics at baseball reference>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/r/robinbr01.shtml#batting_postseason brooks robinson post-season statistics]. - [[baseball-reference]].</ref>  in the [[1970 world series]] against the [[1970 cincinnati reds season|cincinnati reds]], robinson had a .429 batting average with 2 home runs,<ref name=brooks robinson post-season statistics at baseball reference/> however, it was his defensive prowess at third base that stood out, making several impressive plays during the series that robbed the reds of apparent base hits.<ref name=espn: top 10 plays of all time>{{cite web |author=jayson, stark |url=http://static.espn.go.com/mlb/columns/stark_jayson/1191205.html |title=top 10 plays of all time |publisher=[[espn]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=condon, david |date=january 1971  |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=wjmdaaaambaj&pg=pa22&dq=brooks+robinson+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=brooks%20robinson%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=the incomparable brooks robinson |journal=baseball digest |volume=30| issue =  1 |issn=0005-609x. }}</ref> his performance won him the [[world series mvp award]] presented by [[sport (magazine)|''sport'']],<ref name=post-season awards at baseball reference/> as well as the [[hickok belt]] as top professional athlete of the year.<ref>[http://www.hickoksports.com/biograph/robinsonbrooks.shtml brooks robinson at hickok sports]</ref> after the 1970 world series, [[cincinnati reds]] [[manager (baseball)|manager]] [[sparky anderson]] quipped, i'm beginning to see brooks in my sleep. if i dropped this paper plate, he'd pick it up on one hop and throw me out at first.<ref>[http://www.baseball-almanac.com/quotes/quobrob.shtml quotes about brooks robinson]. - baseball almanac.</ref>

in his playing career, robinson was selected for the all-star team in 15 consecutive years ({{by|1960}}-[[1974 in baseball|74]]), and played in four [[world series]].<ref name=brooks robinson at baseball reference/> he compiled a .267 career batting average with 2,848 [[hit (baseball)|hits]], 268 home runs and 1357 runs batted in.<ref name=brooks robinson at baseball reference/> robinson led the american league in [[fielding percentage]] a record 11 times, and at the time of his retirement, his .971 career fielding average was the highest ever for a third baseman.<ref name=osheit-bd-1995>{{cite journal |author=o'shei, tim |date=june 1995 |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=pcsdaaaambaj&pg=pa54&dq=brooks+robinson+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=brooks%20robinson%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=tips on third base defense shared by brooks robinson |journal=[[baseball digest]] |volume=54| issue =  6 |issn=0005-609x }}</ref> his totals of 2870 [[games played]] at third base, 2697 career [[putout]]s, 6205 career [[assist (baseball)|assists]], 8902 career [[total chances]] and 618 [[double play]]s, were records for third basemen at the time of his retirement.<ref name=osheit-bd-1995 /> robinson's 23 seasons with one team set a new major league record, since tied by [[carl yastrzemski]]. only yastrzemski (3308), [[hank aaron]] (3076) and [[stan musial]] (3026) played more games for one franchise.<ref name=osheit-bd-1995 /> robinson also hit into four [[triple plays]] during his career, a major league record. he commented, i wouldn't mind seeing someone erase my record of hitting into four triple plays.<ref>[http://www.baseball-almanac.com/quotes/quobrob.shtml brooks robinson quotes]. - baseball almanac.</ref>

'''brooks calbert robinson, jr.''' (born may 18, 1937) is an american former professional [[baseball]] player.<ref name=brooks robinson at baseball reference>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/r/robinbr01.shtml brooks robinson]. - [[baseball-reference.com]].</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-almanac.com/players/player.php?p=robinbr01 brooks robinson]. - baseball almanac.</ref> he played his entire 23-year [[major league baseball|major league]] career for the [[baltimore orioles]] (1955–1977).<ref name=brooks robinson at baseball reference/> he batted and threw right-handed, in spite of the fact he was a natural left-hander.<ref>[http://bluebattinghelmet.wordpress.com/2012/08/13/a-left-handed-story/]</ref> nicknamed '''the human vacuum cleaner''',<ref name=br-nbhoff /> he is generally acclaimed as the greatest defensive third-baseman in major league history.<ref>{{cite journal |author=kuenster, bob |date=september 1994 |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ncsdaaaambaj&pg=pa32&dq=baseball+digest+third+basemen#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20third%20basemen&f=false |title=all-time best third basemen starred as hitters, fielders |journal=baseball digest |volume=53 - no. 9 |issn=0005-609x }}</ref> he won 16 consecutive [[gold glove award]]s during his career,<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/gold_glove_al.shtml#multi list of gold glove award winners]. - [[baseball-reference.com]].</ref> tied with pitcher [[jim kaat]] for the second most all-time for any player at any position. robinson was elected to the [[baseball hall of fame]] in [[baseball hall of fame balloting, 1983|1983]].<ref name=br-nbhoff>[http://baseballhall.org/hof/robinson-brooks brooks robinson]. - [[national baseball hall of fame and museum|national baseball hall of fame]].</ref>

[[baseball-reference.com]].</ref>  in the [[1970 world series]] against the [[1970 cincinnati reds season|cincinnati reds]], robinson had a .429 batting average with 2 home runs;<ref name=brooks robinson post-season statistics at baseball reference/> however, it was his defensive prowess at third base that stood out, making several impressive plays during the series that robbed the reds of apparent base hits.<ref name=espn: top 10 plays of all time>{{cite web |author=jayson, stark |url=http://static.espn.go.com/mlb/columns/stark_jayson/1191205.html |title=top 10 plays of all time |publisher=[[espn]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=condon, david |date=january 1971  |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=wjmdaaaambaj&pg=pa22&dq=brooks+robinson+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=brooks%20robinson%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=the incomparable brooks robinson |journal=baseball digest |volume=30| issue =  1 |issn=0005-609x }}</ref> his performance won him the [[world series mvp award]] presented by [[sport (magazine)|''sport'']],<ref name=post-season awards at baseball reference/> as well as the [[hickok belt]] as top professional athlete of the year.<ref>[http://www.hickoksports.com/biograph/robinsonbrooks.shtml brooks robinson at hickok sports]</ref> after the 1970 world series, [[cincinnati reds]] [[manager (baseball)|manager]] [[sparky anderson]] quipped, i'm beginning to see brooks in my sleep. if i dropped this paper plate, he'd pick it up on one hop and throw me out at first.<ref>[http://www.baseball-almanac.com/quotes/quobrob.shtml quotes about brooks robinson]. - [[willie kamm]] was considered another master of the hidden ball trick.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=iswdaaaambaj&pg=pa49&lpg=pa49&dq=willie+kamm+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=-2tzpi_gmu&sig=opo2usn7fu4szo-dw5ks1yj_5sk&hl=en&ei=n51wtlflomt58aabrytgba&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0ccqq6aewbjgk#v=onepage&q&f=false ''kamm-ouflage!'', by edgar munzel, baseball digest, november 1956, vol. 15, no. 10, issn 0005-609x]</ref> on april 30, {{by|1929}}, in a game against the [[1929 cleveland indians season|cleveland indians]], kamm was involved in a rare [[triple play]] involving a hidden ball trick.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=xiwdaaaambaj&pg=pa63&lpg=pa63&dq=willie+kamm+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=sy5uc929nr&sig=wejx2b57fiikf9zksyzsscramgw&hl=en&ei=n51wtlflomt58aabrytgba&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0cbsq6aewazgk#v=onepage&q&f=false ''the old kamm-aflouge'', by gordon cobbledick, baseball digest, november 1949, vol. 8, no. 11, issn 0005-609x]</ref> the indians had [[baserunner]]s on second and third bases when [[carl lind]] [[ground out|grounded out]] to the [[shortstop]]. [[johnny hodapp]], who had been on second base, erroneously thought the runner on third base, [[charlie jamieson]] had scored, so he advanced to third base on the ground out. kamm retrieved the ball and [[tag out|tagged]] both runners, whereupon the umpire ruled hodapp [[out (baseball)|out]]. kamm then hid the ball under his arm and waited for jamieson to step off the base. when he did so, kamm tagged him out to complete the triple play.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=2zadaaaambaj&pg=pa14&lpg=pa14&dq=willie+kamm+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=v8glti5xtv&sig=ekqm4u925c6r-egeiwc5ywolvqs&hl=en&ei=ozhwtoelb4k78gb8zshaba&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0ccaq6aewba#v=onepage&q=willie%20kamm%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, june 2005, vol. 64, no. 4, issn 0005-609x]</ref>

[[willie kamm]] was considered another master of the hidden ball trick.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=iswdaaaambaj&pg=pa49&lpg=pa49&dq=willie+kamm+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=-2tzpi_gmu&sig=opo2usn7fu4szo-dw5ks1yj_5sk&hl=en&ei=n51wtlflomt58aabrytgba&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0ccqq6aewbjgk#v=onepage&q&f=false ''kamm-ouflage!'', by edgar munzel, baseball digest, november 1956, vol. 15, no. 10, issn 0005-609x]</ref> on april 30, {{by|1929}}, in a game against the [[1929 cleveland indians season|cleveland indians]], kamm was involved in a rare [[triple play]] involving a hidden ball trick.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=xiwdaaaambaj&pg=pa63&lpg=pa63&dq=willie+kamm+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=sy5uc929nr&sig=wejx2b57fiikf9zksyzsscramgw&hl=en&ei=n51wtlflomt58aabrytgba&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0cbsq6aewazgk#v=onepage&q&f=false ''the old kamm-aflouge'', by gordon cobbledick, baseball digest, november 1949, vol. 8, no. 11, issn 0005-609x]</ref> the indians had [[baserunner]]s on second and third bases when [[carl lind (baseball)|carl lind]] [[batted ball|grounded out]] to the [[shortstop]]. [[johnny hodapp]], who had been on second base, erroneously thought the runner on third base, [[charlie jamieson]] had scored, so he advanced to third base on the ground out. kamm retrieved the ball and [[tag out|tagged]] both runners, whereupon the umpire ruled hodapp [[out (baseball)|out]]. kamm then hid the ball under his arm and waited for jamieson to step off the base. when he did so, kamm tagged him out to complete the triple play.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=2zadaaaambaj&pg=pa14&lpg=pa14&dq=willie+kamm+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=v8glti5xtv&sig=ekqm4u925c6r-egeiwc5ywolvqs&hl=en&ei=ozhwtoelb4k78gb8zshaba&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0ccaq6aewba#v=onepage&q=willie%20kamm%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, june 2005, vol. 64, no. 4, issn 0005-609x]</ref>

hundley was signed by the san francisco giants as an amateur [[free agent]] in [[1960 san francisco giants season|1960]].<ref name=randy hundley trades and transactions at baseball almanac>[http://www.baseball-almanac.com/players/trades.php?p=hundlra01 randy hundley trades and transactions at baseball almanac]</ref> in [[1965 chicago cubs season|1965]], he was traded to the cubs along with future 20-game winner [[bill hands]] in exchange for [[lindy mcdaniel]] and [[don landrum]].<ref name=randy hundley trades and transactions at baseball almanac/><ref name=randy hundley at the baseball library>[http://www.baseballlibrary.com/ballplayers/player.php?name=randy_hundley_1942 randy hundley at the baseball library]</ref> he finished in fourth place in the {{by|1966}} [[national league]] [[major league baseball rookie of the year award|rookie of the year]] voting.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1966.shtml#nlroy 1966 national league rookie of the year voting results at baseball reference]</ref> hundley was recognized as one of the best defensive catchers in the league, winning the {{by|1967}} [[list of nl gold glove winners at catcher|gold glove award]] for catchers, and setting a national league record by committing just four errors.<ref name=randy hundley at the baseball library/><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/gold_glove_nl.shtml#1967 1967 national league gold glove award winners at baseball reference]</ref> hundley popularized a new hinged [[baseball_glove#varieties|catcher's mitt]] that permitted a one-handed catching style, protecting his throwing hand.<ref name=randy hundley at the baseball library/> he became a stalwart for the cubs, setting a record in [[1968 chicago cubs season|1968]] with 160 games behind the plate (147 complete).<ref name=randy hundley at baseball reference/><ref name=randy hundley at the baseball library/><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=cdqdaaaambaj&pg=pa10&dq=randy+hundley+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=randy%20hundley%20baseball%20digest&f=false randy hundley in baseball digest, august 1978]</ref> he also became the first player to catch 150 games for three consecutive years (1967-1969).<ref name=randy hundley at baseball reference/><ref name=randy hundley at the baseball library/> during the cubs unsuccessful run for the [[pennant (sports)|pennant]] in [[1969 chicago cubs season|1969]], hundley's fielding and 18 [[home run]]s were key contributions, earning him a spot on the [[1969 major league baseball all-star game|1969 national league all-star team]]<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/chc/1969.shtml 1969 chicago cubs batting, pitching, & fielding statistics at baseball reference]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/als/als196907230.shtml 1969 all-star game at baseball reference]</ref>.

name=randy hundley at the baseball library>[http://www.baseballlibrary.com/ballplayers/player.php?name=randy_hundley_1942 randy hundley at the baseball library]</ref> on august 11, [[1966 chicago cubs after a few more years, his hard work began to wear on him.<ref name=randy hundley at the baseball library/> his iron-man streak ended on april 21, [[1970 chicago cubs season|1970]], when his left knee was seriously injured when the cardinals' [[carl taylor (baseball)|carl taylor]] collided with him, putting him out of action for several weeks.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/chn/chn197004210.shtml april 21, 1970 cardinals-cubs box score at baseball reference]</ref> he missed most of the [[1971 chicago cubs season|1971]] season when he badly injured his right knee, and was never the same afterwards, although he bounced back to lead national league catchers with a .995 [[fielding percentage]] in [[1972 chicago cubs season|1972]].<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa86&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, july 2001, p.86, vol. 60, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref> while hundley was a light hitter, he was valued for his defensive skills and for the way he handled the pitching staff. cubs' [[relief pitcher]] [[phil regan (baseball)|phil regan]] said of hundley in [[1972 chicago cubs season|1972]],he's not only our catcher, he's our leader.<ref name=sports illustrated, april 10, 1972/> after being traded by the cubs, he played for the twins, padres, and then finally back to the cubs where he ended his career on september 25, 1977.<ref name=randy hundley trades and transactions at baseball almanac/>

hundley was signed by the san francisco giants as an amateur [[free agent]] in [[1960 san francisco giants season|1960]] for the sum of $140,000.<ref name=randy hundley trades and transactions at baseball almanac>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-almanac.com/players/trades.php?p=hundlra01 |title=randy hundley trades and transactions |publisher=baseball almanac |accessdate=30 january 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=czidaaaambaj&pg=pa59&dq=randy+hundley+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=randy%20hundley%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=$140,000 for one single |author=mcgee, james |publisher=books.google.com |date=september 1967 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=31 january 2011 }}</ref> while playing for the [[minor league baseball|double-a]] el paso sun kings in {{by|1963}}, he posted a .325 [[batting average]] with 23 [[home run]]s and 81 [[runs batted in]].<ref name=randy hundley minor league statistics>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/minors/player.cgi?id=hundle001cec |title=randy hundley minor league statistics |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=30 january 2011 }}</ref> hundley made his major league debut with the giants on september 27, [[1964 san francisco giants season|1964]]. he returned to the minor leagues in [[1965 san francisco giants season|1965]], playing for the [[tacoma rainiers|tacoma giants]] of the [[pacific coast league]] although, he was called back to the major leagues briefly in june when regular giants catcher [[tom haller]] was injured.<ref name=randy hundley minor league statistics/><ref>{{cite news |title=phils stop marichal in big victory |agency=associated press |work=gettysburg times |page=5 |date=25 june 1965 |accessdate=30 january 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=oewmaaaaibaj&sjid=mv4faaaaibaj&pg=2232,448308&dq=randy+hundley&hl=en}}</ref> in december {{by|1965}}, he was traded to the chicago cubs along with future 20-game winner [[bill hands]] in exchange for [[lindy mcdaniel]] and [[don landrum]], as part of first-year [[manager (baseball)|manager]] [[leo durocher]]'s rebuilding effort.<ref name=randy hundley trades and transactions at baseball almanac/><ref name=randy hundley at the baseball library>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseballlibrary.com/ballplayers/player.php?name=randy_hundley_1942 |title=randy hundley at the baseball library |publisher=baseballlibrary.com |accessdate=30 january 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=bragan surprised cincy willing to trade robinson |agency=associated press |work=reading eagle |page=3 |date=3 december 1965 |accessdate=30 january 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=yzehaaaaibaj&sjid=d5gfaaaaibaj&pg=4789,1727666&dq=randy+hundley&hl=en}}</ref>

hundley continued to shoulder a heavy workload in [[1967 chicago cubs season|1967]], playing in 152games and committing just four errors to set a national league record for fewest errors in a season.<ref name=randy hundley at the baseball library/> he led national league catchers in [[putout]]s and won the {{by|1967}} national league [[gold glove award]] for catchers as the cubs improved from a last place finish in {{by|1966}} to finish in third place.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1967-fielding-leaders.shtml |title=1967 national league fielding leaders |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=31 january 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/gold_glove_nl.shtml#1967 |title=1967 national league gold glove award winners |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=30 january 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1967.shtml |title=1967 national league standings |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=31 january 2011 }}</ref> hundley was the first catcher to begin using a new hinged [[baseball_glove#varieties|catcher's mitt]] that permitted a one-handed catching style, protecting his throwing hand.<ref name=randy hundley at the baseball library/><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ucsdaaaambaj&pg=pa58&dq=baseball+digest+catchers#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20catchers&f=false |title=are catchers today as good defensively as in the past? |author=van blair, rick |publisher=books.google.com |date=march 1994 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=31 january 2011 }}</ref> he became a stalwart for the cubs, setting a record in [[1968 chicago cubs season|1968]] with 160 games behind the plate (147 complete) as the cubs again finished the season in third place.<ref name=randy hundley at baseball reference/><ref name=randy hundley at the baseball library/><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=cdqdaaaambaj&pg=pa10&dq=randy+hundley+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=randy%20hundley%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=the fans speak out |author= |publisher=books.google.com |date=august 1978 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=31 january 2011 }}</ref>

the cubs began the [[1969 chicago cubs season|1969]] season by winning 11 of their first 12 games and held first place from the first day of the season.<ref name=1969 chicago cubs schedule>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/chc/1969-schedule-scores.shtml |title=1969 chicago cubs schedule |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=31 january 2011 }}</ref> by late june, hundley's batting average was above .300 along with 11 home runs earning him a spot as a reserve for the national league team in the [[1969 major league baseball all-star game|1969 all-star game]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/gl.cgi?id=hundlra01&t=b&year=1969 |title=1969 randy hundley batting log |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=31 january 2011 }}</ref><ref name=1969 all-star game>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/als/als196907230.shtml |title=1969 all-star game |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=31 january 2011 }}</ref> the entire chicago cubs [[infield]] joined hundley on the national league team with [[third baseman]] [[ron santo]] and [[shortstop]] [[don kessinger]] making the team as starting players.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=uysdaaaambaj&pg=pa71&dq=baseball+digest+1969+chicago+cubs#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%201969%20chicago%20cubs&f=false |title=fans still carry the torch for also-ran '69 cubs |author=castle, george |publisher=books.google.com |date=june 1993 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=31 january 2011 }}</ref>

30, 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=oewmaaaaibaj&sjid=mv4faaaaibaj&pg=2232,448308&dq=randy+hundley&hl=en}}</ref> in december 1965, he was traded to the chicago cubs along with future 20-game winner [[bill hands]] in exchange for [[lindy mcdaniel]] and [[don landrum]], as part of first-year [[manager (baseball)|manager]] [[leo durocher]]'s rebuilding effort.<ref name=randy hundley hundley at the baseball library |publisher=baseballlibrary.com |accessdate=january 30, 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=bragan surprised cincy willing to trade robinson |agency=associated press hundley continued to shoulder a heavy workload in [[1967 chicago cubs season|1967]], playing in 152games and committing just four errors to set a national league record for fewest errors by a catcher in a season.<ref name=randy hundley at the baseball library/> he led national league catchers in [[putout]]s and won the 1967 national league [[gold glove award]] for catchers as the cubs improved from a last place finish in 1966 to finish in third place.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1967-fielding-leaders.shtml |title=1967 national league fielding leaders |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=january 31, 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/gold_glove_nl.shtml#1967 |title=1967 national league gold glove award winners |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=january 30, 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1967.shtml |title=1967 national league standings |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=january 31, 2011 }}</ref> hundley was the first catcher to begin using a new hinged [[baseball_glove#varieties|catcher's mitt]] that permitted a one-handed catching style, protecting his throwing hand.<ref name=randy hundley at the baseball library/><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ucsdaaaambaj&pg=pa58&dq=baseball+digest+catchers#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20catchers&f=false |title=are catchers today as good defensively as in the past? |author=van blair, rick |publisher=books.google.com |date=march 1994 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=january 31, 2011 }}</ref> he became a stalwart for the cubs, setting a record in [[1968 chicago cubs season|1968]] with 160 games behind the plate (147 complete) as the cubs again finished the season in third place.<ref name=randy hundley at baseball reference/><ref name=randy hundley at the baseball library/><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=cdqdaaaambaj&pg=pa10&dq=randy+hundley+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=randy%20hundley%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=the fans speak out |author= |publisher=books.google.com |date=august 1978 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=january 31, 2011 }}</ref>

the cubs began the [[1969 chicago cubs season|1969]] season by winning 11 of their first 12 games and held first place from the first day of the season.<ref name=1969 chicago cubs schedule>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/chc/1969-schedule-scores.shtml |title=1969 chicago cubs schedule |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=january 31, 2011 }}</ref> by late june, hundley's batting average was above .300 along with 11 home runs earning him a spot as a reserve for the national league team in the [[1969 major league baseball all-star game|1969 all-star game]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/gl.cgi?id=hundlra01&t=b&year=1969 |title=1969 randy hundley batting log |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=january 31, 2011 }}</ref><ref name=1969 all-star game>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/als/als196907230.shtml |title=1969 all-star game |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=january 31, 2011 }}</ref> the entire chicago cubs [[infield]] joined hundley on the national league team with [[third baseman]] [[ron santo]] and [[shortstop]] [[don kessinger]] making the team as starting players.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=uysdaaaambaj&pg=pa71&dq=baseball+digest+1969+chicago+cubs#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%201969%20chicago%20cubs&f=false |title=fans still carry the torch for also-ran '69 cubs |author=castle, george |publisher=books.google.com |date=june 1993 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=january 31, 2011 }}</ref>

o'farrell experienced the highlight of his career in [[1926 st. louis cardinals season|1926]] when he hit for a .293 average with a career-high 30 [[double (baseball)|doubles]], 7 home runs and 68 runs batted in as he helped the cardinals clinch the national league [[pennant (sports)|pennant]].<ref name=bob o'farrell statistics/><ref>{{cite news |title=hornsby likes bob o'farrell |agency=associated press |work=the meriden journal |page=4 |date=28 september 1926 |accessdate=21 february 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=rtxiaaaaibaj&sjid=8genaaaaibaj&pg=4106,7534052&dq=bob+o-farrell&hl=en}}</ref> he also led national league catchers in games caught and in putouts.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1926-fielding-leaders.shtml |title=1926 national league fielding leaders |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=21 february 2011 }}</ref> in the [[1926 world series]] against the [[1926 new york yankees season|new york yankees]], o'farrell produced a .301 batting average but, is remembered for throwing out [[babe ruth]] trying to steal second base for the last [[out (baseball)|out]] of the seven-game series as the cardinals claimed their first-ever world championship.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=fzmdaaaambaj&pg=pa89&dq=bob+o'farrell+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=rzpityphlmybtgfpitgrda&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0ccoq6aewaq#v=onepage&q=bob%20o'farrell%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=bob o'farrell recalls the 'good old days' |author=ahrens, arthur |publisher=books.google.com |date=april 1975 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=21 february 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1926_ws.shtml |title=1926 world series |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=21 february 2011 }}</ref> in november, he was voted the winner of the {{by|1926}} national league [[major league baseball most valuable player award|most valuable player award]] with 79 out of the possible 80 votes.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1926.shtml#nlmvp |title=1926 national league most valuable player award |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=21 february 2011 }}</ref><ref name=bob o'farrell nat. league's most valuable>{{cite news |title=bob o'farrell nat. league's most valuable |agency= |work=the grape belt |page=29 |date=7 december 1926 |accessdate=21 february 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=mrxcaaaaibaj&sjid=pbkmaaaaibaj&pg=3817,3467783&dq=bob+o-farrell&hl=en}}</ref> he was the first catcher to win a most valuable player award.<ref name=bob o'farrell nat. league's most valuable/>

on october 1, [[1949 new york yankees season|1949]], during a late-season [[pennant race]], he hit an eighth-inning, game-winning, [[home run]] against the [[1949 boston red sox season|boston red sox]], putting the yankees one game ahead of their boston arch-rivals with one game left to play.<ref>[http://www.retrosheet.org/boxesetc/1949/b10010nya1949.htm october 1, 1949 red sox-yankees box score at retrosheet]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/nyy/1949-schedule-scores.shtml 1949 new york yankees schedule and standings at baseball reference]</ref> the yankees went on to win the final game and clinched the american league [[pennant (sports)|pennant]].<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=ec8daaaambaj&pg=pa38&dq=bob+schmidt+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=d_qdtopneswblgfytemjdq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0cc0q6aewaq#v=onepage&q=bob%20schmidt%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''stumbling down the stretch'', by al stump, baseball digest, october 1959, vol. 18, no. 9, issn 0005-609x]</ref>

during spring training in [[1949 new york yankees season|1949]], lindell developed a [[knuckleball]] and new yankees manager [[casey stengel]] experimented with using him as a relief pitcher.<ref name=johnny lindell may become hurler again/> on october 1, {{by|1949}}, during a late-season [[pennant race]], he hit an eighth-inning, game-winning, [[home run]] against the [[1949 boston red sox season|boston red sox]], putting the yankees into a tie their boston arch-rivals with one game left to play.<ref>{{cite news |title=yanks, sox settle title in new york |agency=associated press |work=the victoria advocate |page=8 |date=29 september 1949 |accessdate=11 april 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ttucaaaaibaj&sjid=dloeaaaaibaj&pg=6368,2208137&dq=johnny+lindell&hl=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.retrosheet.org/boxesetc/1949/b10010nya1949.htm |title=october 1, 1949 red sox-yankees box score |publisher=retrosheet.org |accessdate=11 april 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/nyy/1949-schedule-scores.shtml |title=1949 new york yankees schedule and standings |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=11 april 2011 }}</ref> the yankees went on to win the final game to clinch the american league [[pennant (sports)|pennant]] then defeated the brooklyn dodgers in the [[1949 world series]].<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ec8daaaambaj&pg=pa38&dq=bob+schmidt+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=d_qdtopneswblgfytemjdq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0cc0q6aewaq#v=onepage&q=bob%20schmidt%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=stumbling down the stretch |author=stump, al |publisher=books.google.com |date=october 1959 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=11 april 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1949_ws.shtml |title=1949 world series |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=17 april 2011 }}</ref>

the washington senators [[baseball]] team were one of the [[american league|american league's]] eight charter franchises. the club was founded in [[washington, d.c.]] in {{by|1901}} as the washington senators. in 1905 the team changed its official name to the washington nationals.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/min/ |title=minnesota twins team history & encyclopedia | work=baseball-reference.com |accessdate=2008-09-24}}</ref> the name nationals would appear on the uniforms for only two seasons, and would then be replaced with the w logo for the next 52 years. for a time, from 1911 to 1933, the senators were one of the more successful franchises in [[major league baseball]]. the team's rosters included hall of famers [[goose goslin]], [[sam rice]], [[joe cronin]], [[bucky harris]], [[heinie manush]] and one of the greatest pitchers of all time, [[walter johnson]]. but the senators are remembered more for their many years of mediocrity and futility, including six last-place finishes in the 1940s and 1950s. [[joe judge]], [[cecil travis]], [[buddy myer]], [[roy sievers]] and [[eddie yost]] were other notable senators players whose careers were spent in obscurity due to the team's lack of success.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com.sa/books?id=rdqdaaaambaj&lpg=pa48&dq=spud%20davis%20baseball%20digest&pg=pa46#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=13 most forgotten stars in major league history |author=grosshandler, stan |publisher=books.google.com |date=february 1981 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=3 may 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=zcodaaaambaj&pg=pa44&dq=eddie+yost+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=eh3gtouch4lhbqs36dsp&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0cdiq6aewajgk#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=20th century all-overlooked stars |author=vass, george |publisher=books.google.com |date=august 1999 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=3 may 2012 }}</ref>

the senators faced [[john mcgraw]]'s heavily-favored [[1924 new york giants season|new york giants]] in the [[1924 world series]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1924_ws.shtml |title=1924 world series |publisher=baseball-reference.com |accessdate=29 april 2012}}</ref> despite johnson losing both his two starts, the senators kept pace to tie the series at three games apiece and force game 7. the senators trailed the giants 3 to 1 in the eighth inning of game 7, when bucky harris hit a routine ground ball to third which hit a pebble and took a bad hop over giants third baseman [[freddie lindstrom]]. two runners scored on the play, tying the score at three.<ref name=1924 world series game 7 box score at baseball reference>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/ws1/ws1192410100.shtml |title=1924 world series game 7 box score |publisher=baseball-reference.com |accessdate=29 april 2012}}</ref> in the ninth inning with the game tied 3-3, harris brought in an aging johnson to pitch on just one day of rest  he had been the losing pitcher in game 5. johnson held the giants scoreless into extra innings. in the bottom of the twelfth inning, [[muddy ruel]] hit a high [[foul ball]] directly over [[home plate]].<ref name=how senators' strategy won for johnson>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=zzidaaaambaj&pg=pa37&dq=muddy+ruel+baseball+digest&cd=1#v=onepage&q=muddy%20ruel%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=how senators' strategy won for johnson |author=ruel, muddy |publisher=|date=october 1964 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=29 april 2012 }}</ref> the giants' catcher, [[hank gowdy]], dropped his protective mask to field the ball but, failing to toss the mask aside, stumbled over it and dropped the ball, thus giving ruel another chance to bat.<ref name=how senators' strategy won for johnson/> on the next [[pitch (baseball)|pitch]], ruel hit a [[double (baseball)|double]] and, then proceeded to score the winning [[run (baseball)|run]] when [[earl mcneely]] hit a [[ground ball]] that took another bad hop over lindstrom's head.<ref name=1924 world series game 7 box score at baseball reference/><ref name=how senators' strategy won for johnson/> it would mark the only [[world series]] triumph for the franchise during their sixty-year tenure in washington.

the following september, richards resigned as manager of the orioles to become general manager of the new [[houston astros|houston colt .45s]] [[national league]] club.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=gs8daaaambaj&pg=pa29&lpg=pa29&dq=paul+richards+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=viw1qx3oje&sig=pxgsz1iyzp9-eap3rp5srbtytde&hl=en&ei=tw9rtiv2hckb8ga645xtba&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0cbiq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=paul%20richards%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''paul richards takes a desk'', by barney kremenko, baseball digest, march 1962, vol. 21, no. 2, issn 0005-609x]</ref> richards stocked the houston club (soon renamed the [[houston astros|astros]]) with young players – including [[joe morgan]], [[jimmy wynn]], [[don wilson (baseball)|don wilson]] and [[rusty staub]] – but he was fired after the [[1965 houston astros season|1965]] season when the on-field results did not match ownership's expectations. the following year, richards was hired as director of player personnel by the [[atlanta braves]] – returning to the city where he excelled as a minor league catcher and player-manager for the [[southern association]]'s [[atlanta crackers]] from 1938-42. by the end of the {{by|1966}} season, richards was given the title of general manager of the braves.

richards was credited in helping [[sherm lollar]] become one of the best catchers in the major leagues and, he also helped [[gus triandos]] become a respectable catcher.<ref>{{cite book |author=james, bill |title=the new bill james historical baseball abstract |publisher=free press |location=new york |year=2001 |pages= 407 |isbn=0-684-80697-5}}</ref> he is known for designing the oversized [[baseball_glove#varieties|catcher's mitt]] first used by triandos to catch [[knuckleball]] [[pitcher]]s.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=vssdaaaambaj&pg=pa82&dq=gus+triandos+baseball+digest&cd=1#v=onepage&q=gus%20triandos%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''gus triandos looks back on his catching career'', baseball digest, june 1997, vol. 56, no. 6, issn 0005-609x]</ref> despite his skills as a motivator, mentor and strategist of the game, richards never was able to lead a team to a [[pennant (sports)|pennant]].

the following september, richards resigned as manager of the orioles to become general manager of the new [[houston astros|houston colt .45s]] [[national league]] club.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=gs8daaaambaj&pg=pa29&lpg=pa29&dq=paul+richards+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=viw1qx3oje&sig=pxgsz1iyzp9-eap3rp5srbtytde&hl=en&ei=tw9rtiv2hckb8ga645xtba&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0cbiq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=paul%20richards%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''paul richards takes a desk'', by barney kremenko, baseball digest, march 1962, vol. 21, no. 2, issn 0005-609x]</ref> richards stocked the houston club (soon renamed the [[houston astros|astros]]) with young players – including [[joe morgan]], [[jimmy wynn]], [[mike cuellar]], [[don wilson (baseball)|don wilson]] and [[rusty staub]] – but he was fired after the [[1965 houston astros season|1965]] season when the on-field results did not match owner [[roy hofheinz]]' expectations.<ref name=the baseball biography project: paul richards/>

in the tigers [[1968 detroit tigers season|1968]] world championship season, mcauliffe played a key role.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=rjidaaaambaj&pg=pa80&dq=baseball+digest+dick+mcauliffe#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20dick%20mcauliffe&f=false ''mcauliffe, despite '67 nightmare, is dream player now'' by joe falls, baseball digest, oct 1968, issn 0005-609x]</ref> he had a .344 on base percentage, led the american league with 95 runs scored, and showed power with 50 extra base hits.<ref name=dick mcauliffe at baseball reference/><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/al/1968-batting-leaders.shtml 1968 american league batting leaders at baseball reference]</ref> he also tied a [[major league baseball|major league]] record by going the entire 1968 season without grounding into a [[double play]].<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=ltidaaaambaj&pg=pa53&dq=baseball+digest+dick+mcauliffe#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20dick%20mcauliffe&f=false baseball digest, may 1977]</ref> mcauliffe also improved defensively in 1968, reducing his [[error (baseball)|error]] total from 28 in 1967 to nine in 1968.<ref name=dick mcauliffe at baseball reference/> he finished seventh in the 1968 american league [[major league baseball most valuable player award|most valuable player award]] voting, behind teammates [[denny mclain]], [[bill freehan]], and [[willie horton (baseball)|willie horton]].<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1968.shtml#almvp 1968 american league most valuable player award voting results at baseball reference]</ref>

in the tigers [[1968 detroit tigers season|1968]] world championship season, mcauliffe played a key role.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=rjidaaaambaj&pg=pa80&dq=baseball+digest+dick+mcauliffe#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20dick%20mcauliffe&f=false |title=''mcauliffe, despite '67 nightmare, is dream player now'' |author=falls, joe |publisher=books.google.com |date=october 1968 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=20 october 2010 }}</ref> he had a .344 on base percentage, led the american league with 95 [[run (baseball)|runs]] scored, and showed power with 50 extra base hits.<ref name=dick mcauliffe at baseball reference/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/al/1968-batting-leaders.shtml |title=1968 american league batting leaders |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=20 october 2010 }}</ref> he also tied a [[major league baseball|major league]] record by going the entire 1968 season without grounding into a [[double play]].<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ltidaaaambaj&pg=pa53&dq=baseball+digest+dick+mcauliffe#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20dick%20mcauliffe&f=false |title=letters to the editor |author=baseball digest|publisher=books.google.com |date=may 1977 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=20 october 2010 }}</ref> mcauliffe also improved defensively in 1968, reducing his [[error (baseball)|error]] total from 28 in 1967 to nine in 1968 and, finished second among american league second basemen in [[fielding percentage]].<ref name=the baseball biography project: dick mcauliffe/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/al/1968-fielding-leaders.shtml |title=1968 american league fielding leaders |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=20 october 2010 }}</ref> he finished seventh in the 1968 american league [[major league baseball most valuable player award|most valuable player award]] voting, behind teammates [[denny mclain]], [[bill freehan]], and [[willie horton (baseball)|willie horton]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1968.shtml#almvp |title=1968 american league most valuable player award |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=20 october 2010 }}</ref>

he made his major league debut for [[john mcgraw]]'s new york giants in [[1910 new york giants season|1910]], before being traded to the boston the next year.<ref name=hank gowdy at baseball reference/> he didn't have much playing time, and spent the majority of the [[1913 in baseball|1913 season]] with the [[buffalo bisons]] in the [[international league]]. in [[1914 boston braves season|1914]], gowdy became the braves regular catcher in a year that saw them go from last to first in two months, becoming the first team to win a pennant after being in last place on the fourth of july.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=as0daaaambaj&pg=pa84&dq=hank+gowdy+baseball+digest&cd=3#v=onepage&q=hank%20gowdy%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''how losing an exhibition sparked miracle braves'', by joseph m. overfield, baseball digest, may 1961, vol. 20, no. 4, issn 0005-609x]</ref> in the [[1914 world series]], he had a .545 [[batting average]], including the only [[home run]] of the series, in the historic upset of [[connie mack (baseball)|connie mack's]] [[1914 philadelphia athletics season|philadelphia athletics]].<ref name=the baseball biography project: hank gowdy/><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=zzidaaaambaj&pg=pa35&dq=hank+gowdy+baseball+digest&cd=1#v=onepage&q=hank%20gowdy%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''1914: hank gowdy's big, big day'', by francis powers, baseball digest, october 1964, vol. 23, no. 9, issn 0005-609x]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/g/gowdyha01.shtml#batting_postseason hank gowdy post-season batting statistics at baseball reference]</ref>

gowdy saw more playing time in subsequent seasons, but when [[world war i]] broke out, he became the first major league player to sign up.<ref name=the baseball biography project: hank gowdy/> he saw considerable action in [[france]] with the 166th infantry regiment of the [[ohio national guard]], including some of the worst trench fighting in the war.<ref name=the baseball biography project: hank gowdy/> when he returned in {{by|1919}}, he got his old job as a catcher back, but not before going on a speaking tour of the united states, detailing his war experiences.<ref name=the baseball biography project: hank gowdy/> four years later, he was traded back to the giants, where he played in the [[1923 world series|1923]] and [[1924 world series]], but his heroics weren't repeated, as he committed a costly error which led to the game-winning run in game 7 against the [[1924 washington senators season|washington senators]].<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=zzidaaaambaj&pg=pa37&dq=muddy+ruel+baseball+digest&cd=1#v=onepage&q=muddy%20ruel%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''how senators' strategy won for johnson'', by muddy ruel, baseball digest, october 1964, vol. 23, no. 9, issn 0005-609x]</ref> in {{by|1925}}, the giants released him. four years later, he made a comeback with braves, albeit with very limited playing time. he then became a coach with the giants, braves, and the [[cincinnati reds|reds]].<ref name=the baseball biography project: hank gowdy/>

'''harry danning''', nicknamed '''harry the horse''' (september 6, 1911, [[los angeles, california]]  november 29, 2004) was a [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] player who was a [[catcher]] in the [[major league baseball|major leagues]].<ref name=harry danning at baseball reference>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/d/danniha01.shtml harry danning at baseball reference]</ref> he played his entire career with the [[san francisco giants|new york giants]], and was considered one of the top defensive catchers of his era.<ref name=harry danning at baseball reference/><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=pssdaaaambaj&pg=pa63&dq=harry+danning+baseball+digest&cd=2#v=onepage&q=harry%20danning%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''harry danning: catching star of another era'', by rick van blair, baseball digest, october 1994, vol. 53, no. 10, issn 0005-609x]</ref> he batted and threw [[right-handed]]. danning, who was [[jewish]], was nicknamed harry the horse for [[damon runyon]]'s broadway character.<ref name=harry danning obituary at the new york times>[http://www.nytimes.com/2004/12/05/sports/baseball/05danning.html harry danning obituary at the new york times]</ref> he attended [[john h. francis polytechnic high school|polytechnic high school]] in [[los angeles]].

from [[1938 new york giants (mlb) season|1938]] to [[1940 new york giants (mlb) season|1940]] danning hit .306, .313, and .300, and finished in the top 10 in [[mlb most valuable player award|national league mvp]] voting in [[1939 new york giants (mlb) season|1939]] (9th) and 1940 (7th).<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1939.shtml#nlmvp 1939 national league most valuable player award voting results at baseball reference]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1940.shtml#nlmvp 1940 national league most valuable player award voting results at baseball reference]</ref> he collected career highs in home runs (16) in 1939, and in rbis (91) in 1940.<ref name=harry danning at baseball reference/> he led all national league catchers with a .991 [[fielding average]] in 1939.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa86&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, july 2001, p.86, vol. 60, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref>

*[http://books.google.com/books?id=pssdaaaambaj&pg=pa63&dq=harry+danning+baseball+digest&cd=2#v=onepage&q=harry%20danning%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''harry danning: catching star of another era'', by rick van blair, baseball digest, october 1994]

'''harry danning''', nicknamed '''harry the horse''' (september 6, 1911, [[los angeles, california]]  november 29, 2004) was a [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] player.<ref name=harry danning at baseball reference>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/d/danniha01.shtml |title=harry danning at baseball reference |publisher=baseball-reference.com |date= |accessdate=january 22, 2011}}</ref> he played his entire [[major league baseball]] career as a [[catcher]] for the [[san francisco giants|new york giants]], and was considered one of the top defensive catchers of his era.<ref name=harry danning at baseball reference/><ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=pssdaaaambaj&pg=pa63&dq=harry+danning+baseball+digest&cd=2#v=onepage&q=harry%20danning%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=''harry danning: catching star of another era'', by rick van blair, baseball digest, october 1994, vol. 53, no. 10, issn 0005-609x |publisher=books.google.com |date= |accessdate=january 22, 2011}}</ref> he batted and threw [[right-handed]]. danning, who was [[jewish]], was nicknamed harry the horse for [[damon runyon]]'s broadway character.<ref name=harry danning obituary at the new york times>[http://www.nytimes.com/2004/12/05/sports/baseball/05danning.html harry danning obituary at the new york times]</ref> he attended [[john h. francis polytechnic high school|polytechnic high school]] in los angeles. his brother, [[ike danning]], played for the [[baltimore orioles|st. louis browns]] in {{by|1928}}.
