'''harry danning''' (september 6, 1911  november 29, 2004), nicknamed harry the horse, was a [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] player.<ref name=harry danning at baseball reference>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/d/danniha01.shtml |title=harry danning at baseball reference |publisher=baseball-reference.com |date= |accessdate=january 22, 2011}}</ref> he played his entire [[major league baseball]] career as a [[catcher]] for the [[san francisco giants|new york giants]], and was considered to be both a good hitter and one of the top defensive catchers of his era.<ref name=harry danning at baseball reference/><ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=pssdaaaambaj&pg=pa63&dq=harry+danning+baseball+digest&cd=2#v=onepage&q=harry%20danning%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=''harry danning: catching star of another era'', by rick van blair, baseball digest, october 1994, vol. 53, no. 10, issn 0005-609x |publisher=books.google.com |date= |accessdate=january 22, 2011}}</ref> he batted and threw [[right-handed]] and was a member of the national league all-star team in 1938, 1939, 1940, and 1941. danning, who was [[jewish]], was nicknamed harry the horse for [[damon runyon]]'s broadway character.<ref name=harry danning obituary at the new york times>[http://www.nytimes.com/2004/12/05/sports/baseball/05danning.html harry danning obituary at the new york times]</ref> he attended los angeles high school in los angeles. his brother, [[ike danning]], played for the [[baltimore orioles|st. louis browns]] in {{by|1928}}.

from [[1938 new york giants (mlb) season|1938]] through [[1940 new york giants (mlb) season|1940]] danning hit .306, .313, and .300, and finished in the top 10 in [[mlb most valuable player award|national league mvp]] voting in [[1939 new york giants (mlb) season|1939]] (9th) and 1940 (7th).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1939.shtml#nlmvp |title=1939 national league most valuable player award voting results at baseball reference |publisher=baseball-reference.com |date= |accessdate=january 22, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1940.shtml#nlmvp |title=1940 national league most valuable player award voting results at baseball reference |publisher=baseball-reference.com |date= |accessdate=january 22, 2011}}</ref> he collected career highs in home runs (16) in 1939, and in rbis (91) in 1940.<ref name=harry danning at baseball reference/> he led all national league catchers with a .991 [[fielding average]] in 1939.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa86&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=baseball digest, july 2001, p.86, vol. 60, no. 7, issn 0005-609x |publisher=books.google.com |date= |accessdate=january 22, 2011}}</ref>

*[http://books.google.com/books?id=pssdaaaambaj&pg=pa63&dq=harry+danning+baseball+digest&cd=2#v=onepage&q=harry%20danning%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''harry danning: catching star of another era'', by rick van blair, baseball digest, october 1994]

williams had the best season of his career in [[1922 st. louis browns season|1922]], leading the [[american league]] with 39 home runs and 155 runs batted in as, the browns finished the season one game behind the [[pennant (sports)|pennant]]-winning [[1922 new york yankees season|new york yankees]].<ref name=ken williams at baseball reference/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/al/1922.shtml |title=1922 american league team statistics and standings |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=26 october 2010 }}</ref> 32 of his 39 home runs were hit at [[home (sports)|home]] in [[sportsman's park]].<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=0ysdaaaambaj&pg=pa12&dq=ken+williams+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=s83gtofjjykb4qbmypqe&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0cc0q6aewatgk#v=onepage&q=ken%20williams%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=most home runs hit at home, one season |publisher=books.google.com |date=september 1992 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=26 october 2010 }}</ref> on august 7, 1922, during a game against the [[1922 washington senators season|washington senators]], he became the first player in american league history to hit two home runs in one [[inning]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://mlb.mlb.com/mlb/history/rare_feats/index.jsp?feature=two_homers_inning |title=two home runs in one inning |publisher=mlb.com |accessdate=27 october 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.retrosheet.org/boxesetc/1922/b08070sla1922.htm |title=august 7, 1922 senators-browns box score |publisher=retrosheet.org |accessdate=26 october 2010 }}</ref> his 39 home runs topped [[babe ruth]], who had led the league the previous four seasons although, ruth had been suspended well into the {{by|1922}} season by [[commissioner of baseball (mlb)|baseball commissioner]] [[kenesaw mountain landis]] for violating a curb on [[barnstorm (sports)|barnstorming]].<ref name=20th century all-overlooked stars/><ref name=baseball's forgotten stars>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=4i0daaaambaj&pg=pa30&dq=ken+williams+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=i8lgtjnfbjyg4qa7zododw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0ceiq6aewbg#v=onepage&q=ken%20williams%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=baseball's forgotten stars |author=vass, george |publisher=books.google.com |date=july 2004 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=25 october 2010 }}</ref> he was one of only two players to break babe ruth's twelve-year string in which he led the american league in home runs (the other being [[bob meusel]]).<ref name=baseball's forgotten stars/> also in {{by|1922}}, williams also became the first player in history to have 30 home runs and 30-plus [[stolen base]]s in the same season, which would not be achieved again until [[willie mays]] accomplished the feat with the [[san francisco giants|new york giants]] in {{by|1956}}.<ref name=baseball's forgotten stars/>

in an 8 year career, robinson played in 610 [[games played|games]], accumulating 478 [[hit (baseball)|hits]] in 1839 [[at bats]] for a .260 career batting average along with 61 home runs and 272 [[runs batted in]].<ref name=aaron robinson at baseball reference/> robinson was a fine defensive catcher, ending his career with a .990 [[fielding percentage]].<ref name=aaron robinson at baseball reference/> in {{by|1953}} only, the 'aaron robinson, macgregor g176' [[baseball_glove#varieties|catcher's mitt]] was produced.<ref name=aaron robinson at www.29seven20.com/> the {{by|1948}} trade between the detroit tigers and the chicago white sox involving robinson and pierce has been cited as one of the more lopsided trades in baseball history, as robinson had retired from baseball by 1951, whereas pierce had a lengthy, productive career with the white sox.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=scsdaaaambaj&pg=pa31&lpg=pa31&dq=aaron+robinson+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=ofyvcfjeku&sig=vlq3rkbyyzgxwsmwva3lwq_wt5i&hl=en&ei=j4notncug8x6lwer4mnfba&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0cc4q6aewbg#v=onepage&q=aaron%20robinson%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''these were the ten most lopsided player trades'', by eddie gold, baseball digest, august 1996, vol. 55, no. 8, issn 0005-609x]</ref><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=sc4daaaambaj&pg=pa59&lpg=pa59&dq=aaron+robinson+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=qgp5vjbraa&sig=rpa05bucmpn6rjcxqpnslofheyi&hl=en&ei=-irotir-e8h7lwfw-lj7aw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0cdyq6aewctgu#v=onepage&q&f=false ''they dealt themselves out'' by joe mcguff, baseball digest, december 1957, vol. 16, no. 10, issn 0005-609x]</ref>

after the {{by|1917}} season, in one of the most lopsided trades in major league history, the financially-strapped phillies sent killefer and alexander to the chicago cubs for two players and $55,000 in cash.<ref name=bill killefer at the baseball biography project/><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=6tmdaaaambaj&pg=pa16&dq=bill+killefer+baseball+digest&lr=&cd=3#v=onepage&q=bill%20killefer%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, october 1987, vol. 46, no. 10, issn 0005-609x]</ref> with the [[1918 chicago cubs season|cubs]], killefer was credited with strengthening their pitching staff.<ref name=''babe ruth and the 1918 red sox''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=ma-dazlduzkc&pg=pa241&dq=bill+killefer&lr=&cd=27#v=onepage&q=bill%20killefer&f=false ''babe ruth and the 1918 red sox'', allan wood, iuniverse, 2000, isbn 0595148263, 9780595148264]</ref> the cubs won the {{by|1918}} national league [[pennant (sports)|pennant]] before losing to the [[1918 boston red sox season|boston red sox]] in the [[1918 world series|world series]].<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1918_ws.shtml 1918 world series at baseball reference]</ref> killefer had another strong season in [[1919 chicago cubs season|1919]], hitting a career-high .286 batting average and leading national league catchers in fielding percentage, putouts and assists.<ref name=bill killefer at baseball reference/><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1919-fielding-leaders.shtml 1919 national league fielding leaders at baseball reference]</ref> he served as [[player-manager]] for the cubs in [[1921 chicago cubs season|1921]] before retiring as a player at age 33.

in a 13 year career, killefer played in 1035 [[games played|games]], accumulating 751 [[hit (baseball)|hits]] in 3150 [[at bats]] for a .238 career batting average along with 4 [[home run]]s and 240 [[runs batted in]].<ref name=bill killefer at baseball reference/> he had a career fielding percentage of .977.<ref name=bill killefer at baseball reference/> while he wasn't a powerful [[batting (baseball)|hitter]], he possessed a strong throwing arm and a talent for working with pitchers.<ref name=''babe ruth and the 1918 red sox''/> killefer led [[national league]] catchers in [[fielding percentage]] four consecutive seasons from [[1916 philadelphia phillies season|1916]] to [[1919 chicago cubs season|1919]].<ref name=bill killefer at baseball reference/><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa86&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, july 2001, vol. 60, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref> he also led the league three times in putouts, assists and in baserunners caught stealing.<ref name=bill killefer at baseball reference/> his reputation as a defensive stand out is enhanced because of the era in which he played. in the [[deadball era]], catchers played a huge defensive role, given the large number of [[bunt (baseball)|bunt]]s and [[stolen base]] attempts, as well as the difficulty of handling the [[spitball]] pitchers who dominated pitching staffs.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=9s0daaaambaj&pg=pa26&dq=baseball+digest+defensive+catchers#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20defensive%20catchers&f=false ''for catchers, the name of the game is defense'', by george vass, baseball digest, may 2005, vol. 64, no. 3, issn 0005-609x]</ref> richard kendall of the [[society for american baseball research]] devised an unscientific study that ranked killefer as the most dominating fielding catcher in major league history.<ref>[http://members.tripod.com/bb_catchers/catchers/dominate.htm dominating fielding catchers at the encyclopedia of baseball catchers]</ref>

after the 1917 season, in one of the most lopsided trades in major league history, the financially-strapped phillies sent killefer and alexander to the chicago cubs for two players and $55,000 in cash.<ref name=bill killefer at the baseball biography project/><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=6tmdaaaambaj&pg=pa16&dq=bill+killefer+baseball+digest&lr=&cd=3#v=onepage&q=bill%20killefer%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, october 1987, vol. 46, no. 10, issn 0005-609x]</ref> with the [[1918 chicago cubs season|cubs]], killefer was credited with strengthening their pitching staff.<ref name=''babe ruth and the 1918 red sox''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=ma-dazlduzkc&pg=pa241&dq=bill+killefer&lr=&cd=27#v=onepage&q=bill%20killefer&f=false ''babe ruth and the 1918 red sox'', allan wood, iuniverse, 2000, isbn 0595148263, 9780595148264]</ref> the cubs won the 1918 [[national league pennant]] before losing to the [[boston red sox]] in the [[1918 world series]].<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1918_ws.shtml 1918 world series at baseball reference]</ref> killefer had another strong season in 1919, hitting a career-high .286 batting average and leading national league catchers in fielding percentage, putouts and assists.<ref name=bill killefer at baseball reference/><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1919-fielding-leaders.shtml 1919 national league fielding leaders at baseball reference]</ref> he served as [[player-manager]] for the cubs in 1921 before retiring as a player at age 33.

in a 13 year career, killefer played in 1035 [[games played|games]], accumulating 751 [[hit (baseball)|hits]] in 3150 [[at bats]] for a .238 career batting average along with 4 [[home run]]s and 240 [[runs batted in]].<ref name=bill killefer at baseball reference/> he had a career fielding percentage of .977.<ref name=bill killefer at baseball reference/> while he was not a powerful [[batting (baseball)|hitter]], he possessed a strong throwing arm and a talent for working with pitchers.<ref name=''babe ruth and the 1918 red sox''/> killefer led [[national league]] catchers in [[fielding percentage]] four consecutive seasons from 1916 to 1919.<ref name=bill killefer at baseball reference/><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa86&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, july 2001, vol. 60, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref> he also led the league three times in putouts, assists and in baserunners caught stealing.<ref name=bill killefer at baseball reference/>

killefer's reputation as a defensive standout is enhanced because of the era in which he played. in the [[deadball era]], catchers played a huge defensive role, given the large number of [[bunt (baseball)|bunt]]s and [[stolen base]] attempts, as well as the difficulty of handling the [[spitball]] pitchers who dominated pitching staffs.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=9s0daaaambaj&pg=pa26&dq=baseball+digest+defensive+catchers#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20defensive%20catchers&f=false ''for catchers, the name of the game is defense'', by george vass, baseball digest, may 2005, vol. 64, no. 3, issn 0005-609x]</ref> richard kendall of the [[society for american baseball research]] devised an unscientific study that ranked killefer as the most dominating fielding catcher in major league history.<ref>[http://members.tripod.com/bb_catchers/catchers/dominate.htm dominating fielding catchers at the encyclopedia of baseball catchers]</ref>

triandos was signed by the new york yankees as an amateur [[free agent]] in [[1948 new york yankees season|1948]].<ref name=gus triandos trades and transactions at baseball almanac>[http://www.baseball-almanac.com/players/trades.php?p=triangu01 gus triandos trades and transactions at baseball almanac]</ref> he joined the yankees' major league roster briefly in [[1953 new york yankees season|1953]], but was sent back to the [[minor league baseball|minor leagues]] in [[1954 new york yankees season|1954]]. triandos was traded to the baltimore orioles in [[1955 baltimore orioles season|1955]] where he played mostly as a first baseman for his first two years with the team, before becoming the orioles' regular catcher in [[1957 baltimore orioles season|1957]]. as the orioles' catcher, he used an outsized [[baseball_glove#varieties|catcher's mitt]] designed by manager [[paul richards (baseball)|paul richards]] to handle the dancing [[knuckleball]] of [[hoyt wilhelm]].<ref name=''gus triandos looks back on his catching career''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=vssdaaaambaj&pg=pa82&dq=gus+triandos+baseball+digest&cd=1#v=onepage&q=gus%20triandos%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''gus triandos looks back on his catching career'', baseball digest, june 1997, vol. 56, no. 6, issn 0005-609x]</ref> triandos was behind the plate when wilhelm threw a [[no hitter]] against the [[1958 new york yankees season|new york yankees]] on september 20, [[1958 baltimore orioles season|1958]], and also scored the only run of the game, when he hit a home run in the eighth [[inning]].<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/bal/bal195809200.shtml september 20, 1958 yankees-orioles box score at baseball reference]</ref>

in [[1962 baltimore orioles season|1962]], he hit only .169 in 63 games and was traded to the detroit tigers at the end of the year.<ref name=gus triandos trades and transactions at baseball almanac/> with the tigers in [[1963 detroit tigers season|1963]], he shared catching duties with [[bill freehan]] and led american league catchers with a .996 [[fielding percentage]].<ref name=''gus triandos looks back on his catching career''/><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa86&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, july 2001, p.86, vol. 60, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref> the following winter, he was traded along with [[jim bunning]] to the philadelphia phillies, where he again shared catching duties, this time with [[clay dalrymple]]. as the phillies' catcher, triandos caught bunning's [[perfect game]] against the [[new york mets]] on june 21, [[1964 philadelphia phillies season|1964]], thus becoming the first catcher in major league history to catch no hitters in both the american and national leagues.<ref name=''gus triandos looks back on his catching career''/>

* [http://books.google.com/books?id=vssdaaaambaj&pg=pa82&dq=gus+triandos+baseball+digest&cd=1#v=onepage&q=gus%20triandos%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''gus triandos looks back on his catching career'', baseball digest, june 1997]

triandos was signed by the new york yankees as an amateur [[free agent]] in [[1948 new york yankees season|1948]].<ref name=gus triandos trades and transactions at baseball almanac>[http://www.baseball-almanac.com/players/trades.php?p=triangu01 gus triandos trades and transactions at baseball almanac]</ref> he joined the yankees' major league roster briefly in [[1953 new york yankees season|1953]], but was sent back to the [[minor league baseball|minor leagues]] in [[1954 new york yankees season|1954]]. triandos was traded to the baltimore orioles in [[1955 baltimore orioles season|1955]] where he played mostly as a first baseman for his first two years with the team, before becoming the orioles' regular catcher in [[1957 baltimore orioles season|1957]]. as the orioles' catcher, he used an outsized [[baseball_glove#varieties|catcher's mitt]] designed by manager [[paul richards (baseball)|paul richards]] to handle the unpredictable [[knuckleball]] of [[hoyt wilhelm]].<ref name=''gus triandos looks back on his catching career''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=vssdaaaambaj&pg=pa82&dq=gus+triandos+baseball+digest&cd=1#v=onepage&q=gus%20triandos%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''gus triandos looks back on his catching career'', baseball digest, june 1997, vol. 56, no. 6, issn 0005-609x]</ref> triandos was behind the plate when wilhelm threw a [[no hitter]] against the [[1958 new york yankees season|new york yankees]] on september 20, [[1958 baltimore orioles season|1958]], and also scored the only run of the game when he hit a home run in the eighth [[inning]].<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/bal/bal195809200.shtml september 20, 1958 yankees-orioles box score at baseball reference]</ref>

triandos was signed by the new york yankees as an amateur [[free agent]] in [[1948 new york yankees season|1948]].<ref name=gus triandos trades and transactions at baseball almanac>[http://www.baseball-almanac.com/players/trades.php?p=triangu01 gus triandos trades and transactions] at ''baseball almanac''</ref> he joined the yankees' major league roster briefly in [[1953 new york yankees season|1953]], but was sent back to the [[minor league baseball|minor leagues]] in [[1954 new york yankees season|1954]]. triandos was traded to the baltimore orioles in [[1955 baltimore orioles season|1955]] where he played mostly as a first baseman for his first two years with the team, before becoming the orioles' regular catcher in [[1957 baltimore orioles season|1957]]. as the orioles' catcher, he used an outsized [[baseball_glove#varieties|catcher's mitt]] designed by manager [[paul richards (baseball)|paul richards]] to handle the unpredictable [[knuckleball]] of [[hoyt wilhelm]].<ref name=gus triandos looks back on his catching career>[http://books.google.com/books?id=vssdaaaambaj&pg=pa82&dq=gus+triandos+baseball+digest&cd=1#v=onepage&q=gus%20triandos%20baseball%20digest&f=false gus triandos looks back on his catching career], ''baseball digest'', june 1997, vol. 56, no. 6, issn 0005-609x</ref> triandos was behind the plate when wilhelm threw a [[no hitter]] against the [[1958 new york yankees season|new york yankees]] on september 20, [[1958 baltimore orioles season|1958]], and also scored the only run of the game when he hit a home run in the eighth [[inning]].<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/bal/bal195809200.shtml september 20, 1958 yankees-orioles box score] at baseball-reference</ref> triandos said catching for wilhelm was incredibly taxing, telling a reporter, wilhelm nearly ruined me.

* [http://books.google.com/books?id=vssdaaaambaj&pg=pa82&dq=gus+triandos+baseball+digest&cd=1#v=onepage&q=gus%20triandos%20baseball%20digest&f=false gus triandos looks back on his catching career], ''baseball digest'', june 1997

the game of september 28, [[1938 chicago cubs season|1938]], reached the bottom of the ninth [[inning (baseball)|inning]] with the score tied at 5 runs apiece.<ref name=homer in the gloamin'/> with darkness descending on the lightless [[wrigley field]], the umpires ruled that the ninth [[inning (baseball)|inning]] would be the last to be played.<ref name=homer in the gloamin'/> at the time, [[suspended game]] rules did not provide for suspending games due to darkness. the game would have to have been replayed in its entirety the following day, prior to the scheduled third game of the series. hartnett came to bat with two [[out (baseball)|out]] in the bottom of the ninth inning.<ref name=homer in the gloamin'/> with a count of 0 balls and 2 strikes, hartnett connected on a [[mace brown]] pitch, launching the ball into the darkness, before it eventually landed in the left-center field [[bleachers]] for a game-winning home run. the stadium erupted into pandemonium as players and fans stormed the field to escort hartnett around the bases.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ftqdaaaambaj&pg=pa32&dq=gabby+hartnett+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=fyfbtbjoesibtge619gycw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0ccyq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=gabby%20hartnett%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=when gabby hartnett hit his homer in the gloamin' |author=carmichael, john |publisher=books.google.com |date=october 1978 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=16 february 2011 }}</ref>

the game of september 28, [[1938 chicago cubs season|1938]], reached the bottom of the ninth [[inning (baseball)|inning]] with the score tied at 5 runs apiece.<ref name=homer in the gloamin'/> with darkness descending on the lightless [[wrigley field]], the umpires ruled that the ninth [[inning (baseball)|inning]] would be the last to be played.<ref name=homer in the gloamin'/> at the time, [[suspended game]] rules did not provide for suspending games due to darkness. the game would have to have been replayed in its entirety the following day, prior to the scheduled third game of the series. hartnett came to bat with two [[out (baseball)|out]] in the bottom of the ninth inning.<ref name=homer in the gloamin'/> with a count of 0 balls and 2 strikes, hartnett connected on a [[mace brown]] pitch, launching the ball into the darkness, before it eventually landed in the left-center field [[bleachers]] for a game-winning home run. the stadium erupted into pandemonium as players and fans stormed the field to escort hartnett around the bases.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ftqdaaaambaj&pg=pa32&dq=gabby+hartnett+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=fyfbtbjoesibtge619gycw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0ccyq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=gabby%20hartnett%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=when gabby hartnett hit his homer in the gloamin' |author=carmichael, john |publisher=books.google.com |date=october 1978 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=16 february 2011 }}</ref>

the game of september 28, [[1938 chicago cubs season|1938]], reached the bottom of the ninth [[inning (baseball)|inning]] with the score tied at 5 runs apiece.<ref name=homer in the gloamin'/> with darkness descending on a [[wrigley field]] which did not yet have artificial lighting, the umpires ruled that the ninth [[inning (baseball)|inning]] would be the last to be played.<ref name=homer in the gloamin'/> at the time, [[suspended game]] rules did not provide for suspending games due to darkness. the game would have to have been replayed in its entirety the following day, prior to the scheduled third game of the series. hartnett came to bat with two [[out (baseball)|out]] in the bottom of the ninth inning.<ref name=homer in the gloamin'/> with a count of 0 balls and 2 strikes, hartnett connected on a [[mace brown]] pitch, launching the ball into the darkness, before it eventually landed in the left-center field [[bleachers]] for a game-winning home run. the stadium erupted into pandemonium as players and fans stormed the field to escort hartnett around the bases.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ftqdaaaambaj&pg=pa32&dq=gabby+hartnett+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=fyfbtbjoesibtge619gycw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0ccyq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=gabby%20hartnett%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=when gabby hartnett hit his homer in the gloamin' |author=carmichael, john |publisher=books.google.com |date=october 1978 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=16 february 2011 }}</ref>

pierce was sent back to buffalo for the 1946 season, now with [[gabby hartnett]] as his manager (harris having moved to the team's front office), but missed most of the year with a back injury which was attributed to overwork.<ref name=james/neyer/> after the 1947 season in buffalo, where richards was now his manager, he returned to detroit in 1948, spending most of the season in the bullpen but making five starts and posting a 3–0 record; he had yet added very little weight since his high school days, being still at 148 pounds.<ref>{{cite book |last=hilligan |first=earl j., ed. |title=the 1948 american league red book |page=13 }}</ref> he made his first start, and earned his first major league victory, on august 8 against the [[minnesota twins|washington senators]], pitching 7 innings and striking out six in a 6–5 victory in which he also [[run batted in|drove in]] a run with a [[triple (baseball)|triple]] and scored.<ref>{{cite news |title=american league scores |work=the sporting news |page=16 |date=1948-08-18 }}</ref> however, pierce also issued 51 [[base on balls|walks]] in 55 innings that year, and concerns about his pitching control led the tigers to trade him to the white sox on november 10 for catcher [[aaron robinson]] and $10,000, in what most baseball historians consider to be one of the most one-sided trades in baseball history.<ref>bill james selected it as the most lopsided trade of the 1940s. {{cite book |last=james |first=bill |title=[[the bill james historical baseball abstract]] |year=1985 |publisher=villard books |location=new york |isbn=0-394-53713-0 |chapter=the 1940s |page=188 }}</ref><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=scsdaaaambaj&pg=pa31&lpg=pa31&dq=aaron+robinson+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=ofyvcfjeku&sig=vlq3rkbyyzgxwsmwva3lwq_wt5i&hl=en&ei=j4notncug8x6lwer4mnfba&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0cc4q6aewbg#v=onepage&q=aaron%20robinson%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''these were the ten most lopsided player trades'', by eddie gold, baseball digest, august 1996, vol. 55, no. 8, issn 0005-609x]</ref><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=sc4daaaambaj&pg=pa59&lpg=pa59&dq=aaron+robinson+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=qgp5vjbraa&sig=rpa05bucmpn6rjcxqpnslofheyi&hl=en&ei=-irotir-e8h7lwfw-lj7aw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0cdyq6aewctgu#v=onepage&q&f=false ''they dealt themselves out'' by joe mcguff, baseball digest, december 1957, vol. 16, no. 10, issn 0005-609x]</ref> talks had initially centered on chicago acquiring pierce's high school teammate ted gray, although sources differ as to whether it was white sox [[general manager (baseball)|general manager]] [[frank lane]] or his detroit counterpart [[billy evans]] who switched the focus to pierce<ref name=vanderberg/><ref>condon, p. 135.</ref>; the tigers tried to call off the deal one day after it was completed upon fully realizing what they had given up, even offering $50,000 to get pierce back, but lane had no intention of giving up the steal he had accomplished in his first trade as general manager.<ref name=vanderberg/><ref>{{cite news |first=john c. |last=hoffman |title=hats off...! |work=the sporting news |page=21 |date=1956-06-06 }}</ref><ref name=si>{{cite journal | last = terrell | first = roy | date = may 13, 1957 | title = the go-sox go again | journal = [[sports illustrated]] | volume = 6 | issue = 19 | pages = p. 40 | issn = }}</ref>

1948 american league red book |page=13 }}</ref> he made his first start, and earned his first major league victory, on august 8 against the [[minnesota twins|washington senators]], pitching 7 innings and striking out six in a 6–5 victory in which he also [[run batted in|drove in]] a run with a [[triple (baseball)|triple]] and scored.<ref>{{cite news |title=american league scores |work=the sporting news |page=16 |date=1948-08-18 }}</ref> however, pierce also issued 51 [[base on balls|walks]] in 55 innings that year, and concerns about his pitching control led the tigers to trade him to the white sox on november 10 for catcher [[aaron robinson]] and $10,000, in what most baseball historians consider to be one of the most one-sided trades in baseball history.<ref>bill james selected it as the most lopsided trade of the 1940s. {{cite book |last=james |first=bill |title=[[the bill james historical baseball abstract]] |year=1985 |publisher=villard books |location=new york |isbn=0-394-53713-0 |chapter=the 1940s |page=188 }}</ref><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=scsdaaaambaj&pg=pa31&lpg=pa31&dq=aaron+robinson+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=ofyvcfjeku&sig=vlq3rkbyyzgxwsmwva3lwq_wt5i&hl=en&ei=j4notncug8x6lwer4mnfba&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0cc4q6aewbg#v=onepage&q=aaron%20robinson%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''these were the ten most lopsided player trades'', by eddie gold, baseball digest, august 1996, vol. 55, no. 8, issn 0005-609x]</ref><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=sc4daaaambaj&pg=pa59&lpg=pa59&dq=aaron+robinson+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=qgp5vjbraa&sig=rpa05bucmpn6rjcxqpnslofheyi&hl=en&ei=-irotir-e8h7lwfw-lj7aw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0cdyq6aewctgu#v=onepage&q&f=false ''they dealt themselves out'' by joe mcguff, baseball digest, december 1957, vol. 16, no. 10, issn 0005-609x]</ref> talks had initially centered on chicago acquiring pierce's high school teammate ted gray, although sources differ as to whether it was white sox [[general manager (baseball)|general manager]] [[frank lane]] or his detroit counterpart [[billy evans]] who switched the focus to pierce;<ref name=vanderberg/><ref>condon, p. 135.</ref> the tigers tried to call off the deal one day after it was completed upon fully realizing what they had given up, even offering $50,000 to get pierce back, but lane had no intention of giving up the steal he had accomplished in his first trade as general manager.<ref name=vanderberg/><ref>{{cite news |first=john c. |last=hoffman |title=hats off...! |work=the sporting news |page=21 |date=1956-06-06 }}</ref><ref name=si>{{cite journal | last = terrell | first = roy | date = may 13, 1957 | title = the go-sox go again | journal = [[sports illustrated]] | volume = 6 | issue = 19 | pages = p. 40 }}</ref>

'''donald eulon kessinger''' (born july 17, 1942 in [[forrest city, arkansas|forrest city]], [[arkansas]]) is a former [[united states|american]] [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] player and [[manager (baseball)|manager]].<ref name=don kessinger statistics>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/k/kessido01.shtml |title=don kessinger statistics |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=11 january 2011 }}</ref> he played in [[major league baseball]] as a [[shortstop]] from {{by|1964}} to {{by|1979}} for the [[chicago cubs]], [[st. louis cardinals]] and the [[chicago white sox]].<ref name=don kessinger statistics/> a six-time [[major league baseball all-star game|all-star]], he was a light-[[batting (baseball)|hitting]], defensive specialist who spent the majority of his career as the chicago cubs starting shortstop.<ref name=don kessinger statistics/> in the late 1960s and early 1970s, he was considered one of the best shortstops in baseball.<ref name=don kessinger- is he best shortstop in the majors?>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=9tedaaaambaj&pg=pa29&dq=don+kessinger+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=w_crtb-2e4wclafw8dj0cw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0ccmq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=don%20kessinger%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=don kessinger- is he best shortstop in the majors? |author=furlong, william |publisher=books.google.com |date=october 1969 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=11 january 2011 }}</ref>

* [http://books.google.com/books?id=uysdaaaambaj&pg=pa71&dq=baseball+digest+1969+chicago+cubs#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%201969%20chicago%20cubs&f=false ''fans still carry the torch for also-ran '69 cubs'', baseball digest, june 1993]

'''donald eulon kessinger''' (born july 17, 1942 in [[forrest city, arkansas]]) is an [[united states|american]] former [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] player and [[manager (baseball)|manager]].<ref name=don kessinger statistics>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/k/kessido01.shtml |title=don kessinger statistics |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=11 january 2011 }}</ref> he played in [[major league baseball]] as a [[shortstop]] from {{by|1964}} to {{by|1979}} for the [[chicago cubs]], [[st. louis cardinals]] and the [[chicago white sox]].<ref name=don kessinger statistics/> a six-time [[major league baseball all-star game|all-star]], he was a light-[[batting (baseball)|hitting]], defensive specialist who spent the majority of his career as the chicago cubs starting shortstop.<ref name=don kessinger statistics/> in the late 1960s and early 1970s, he was considered one of the best shortstops in baseball.<ref name=don kessinger- is he best shortstop in the majors?>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=9tedaaaambaj&pg=pa29&dq=don+kessinger+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=w_crtb-2e4wclafw8dj0cw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0ccmq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=don%20kessinger%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=don kessinger- is he best shortstop in the majors? |author=furlong, william |publisher=books.google.com |date=october 1969 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=11 january 2011 }}</ref>

the 33 year old kessinger still played well in st. louis, ending the season with a .320 [[on base percentage]] and was second in the league in range factor.<ref name=don kessinger statistics/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1976-fielding-leaders.shtml |title=1976 national league fielding leaders |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=11 january 2011 }}</ref> in august [[1977 chicago white sox season|1977]], he was traded to the chicago white soxfor pitcher steve stanilandwho were seeking to bolster their infield strength.<ref>{{cite news |title=don kessinger to white sox |agency=associated press |work=the montreal gazette |page=12 |date=22 august 1977 |accessdate=11 january 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=masyaaaaibaj&sjid=1qefaaaaibaj&pg=2389,4329694&dq=don+kessinger&hl=en}}</ref> the white sox held a don kessinger night on september 8, 1978, where 31,000 chicago baseball fans (said to consist, in baseball digest, of nearly equal numbers of sox and cubs fans) thanked #11 for his years of service at shortstop.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=1zmdaaaambaj&pg=pa50&dq=%22don+kessinger%22'+%22baseball+digest%22&hl=en&sa=x&ei=ydvwt8rgcuw30ghq8pwocg&ved=0cecq6aewaq#v=onepage&q=%22don%20kessinger%22'%20%22baseball%20digest%22&f=false |title=don kessinger: baseball's newest player-manager |author=dozer, richard |publisher=|date=january 1979 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=2 april 2012 }}</ref> on october 19, [[1978 chicago white sox season|1978]], white sox president [[bill veeck]] named kessinger to be the team's [[player-manager]] (the last in al history).<ref>{{cite news |title=white sox name don kessinger player-manager |agency=associated press |work=wilmington morning star |page=1 |date=20 october 1978 |accessdate=11 january 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=s-syaaaaibaj&sjid=lhmeaaaaibaj&pg=2364,3972020&dq=don+kessinger&hl=en}}</ref> he was managing at comiskey park on july 12, 1979 when the infamous [[disco demolition night]] took place, and wisely locked his players in the locker room between games, avoiding the near-riot.<ref>{{cite news |title=kessinger recalls `unbelievable' disco night |agency= |work=the chicago tribune |page= |date=13 july 2006 |accessdate=2 april 2012 |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2006-07-13/sports/0607130294_1_disco-steve-dahl-don-kessinger}}</ref> with the white sox languishing in 5th place in the standings, kessinger resigned on august 2, [[1979 chicago white sox season|1979]] and was replaced by [[tony larussa]].<ref>{{cite news |title=larussa takes over from don kessinger |agency=united press international |work=the telegraph-herald |page=14 |date=3 august 1979 |accessdate=11 january 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=0-9baaaaibaj&sjid=xkomaaaaibaj&pg=5825,325798&dq=don+kessinger&hl=en}}</ref>

* [http://books.google.com/books?id=uysdaaaambaj&pg=pa71&dq=baseball+digest+1969+chicago+cubs#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%201969%20chicago%20cubs&f=false ''fans still carry the torch for also-ran '69 cubs'', baseball digest, june 1993]

born in [[harvel, illinois|harvel]], [[illinois]]<ref name=ray schalk at baseball reference/>, schalk played for the [[milwaukee brewers (minor league baseball team)|milwaukee brewers]] of the [[american association (20th century)|american association]] before being sold to the [[chicago white sox]].<ref>[http://www.baseball-almanac.com/players/trades.php?p=schalra01 ray schalk trades and transactions at baseball almanac]</ref> he made his major league debut in [[1912 chicago white sox season|1912]], playing 23 games behind the plate.<ref name=ray schalk at baseball reference/> he assumed the everyday role of catcher the following year, playing in 129 games, [[batting average|batting]] .244 and [[stolen base|stealing]] 14 bases.<ref name=ray schalk at baseball reference/> schalk played on the [[1917 chicago white sox season|1917 world champion white sox]] team and was one of the honest players in the [[black sox scandal]] of the [[1919 world series]], hitting .304 for the series.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=ijmdaaaambaj&pg=pa4&dq=ray+schalk+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=ray%20schalk%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''warm up tosses'', by john kuenster, baseball digest, september 1970, vol. 29, no. 9, issn 0005-609x]</ref>

schalk's reputation as a defensive stand out is enhanced because of the era in which he played. in the [[deadball era]], catchers played a huge defensive role, given the large number of [[bunt (baseball)|bunt]]s and stolen base attempts, as well as the difficulty of handling the [[spitball]] pitchers who dominated pitching staffs.<ref name=ray schalk at br bullpen/> he caught every type of [[pitch (baseball)|pitch]] imaginable, such as shine balls, spitballs, [[knuckleball]]s, and emory balls from some of the greatest pitchers of his day,<ref name=''for catchers, the name of the game is defense''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=9s0daaaambaj&pg=pa26&dq=baseball+digest+defensive+catchers#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20defensive%20catchers&f=false ''for catchers, the name of the game is defense'', by george vass, baseball digest, may 2005, vol. 64, no. 3, issn 0005-609x]</ref> including [[ed walsh]], [[eddie cicotte]], [[dickie kerr]], [[urban faber]], and [[ted lyons]].<ref name=''for catchers, the name of the game is defense''/> no catcher has approached schalk's record for career double plays, and none has led the league in fielding percentage eight times.<ref name=''for catchers, the name of the game is defense''/> schalk held the record for most [[no-hitter]]s caught, with four, until a rules change in the early 1990s disallowed one of the games.<ref name=ray schalk at br bullpen/>
* [http://books.google.com/books?id=ijmdaaaambaj&pg=pa4&dq=ray+schalk+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=ray%20schalk%20baseball%20digest&f=false ray schalk in baseball digest, september 1970]

the white sox rebounded in [[1919 chicago white sox season|1919]] to recapture the american league pennant with schalk hitting for a career-high .282 average and, leading the league in putouts for a seventh consecutive season.<ref name=ray schalk at baseball reference/> the [[1919 world series]] against the [[1919 cincinnati reds season|cincinnati reds]] was shrouded in a controversy which became known as the [[black sox scandal]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.1919blacksox.com/story.htm |title=the black sox |publisher=1919blacksox.com |accessdate=12 january 2011 }}</ref> several white sox players were accused of intentionally trying to lose games.<ref name=the baseball biography project: ray schalk/> schalk played to win during the series, hitting for a .304 batting average and was later absolved from any wrongdoing.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ijmdaaaambaj&pg=pa4&dq=ray+schalk+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=ray%20schalk%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=warm up tosses |author=kuenster, john |publisher=books.google.com |date=september 1970 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=12 january 2011 }}</ref> he stated that he knew something was wrong when pitchers eddie cicotte and [[lefty williams]] failed to throw the pitches schalk had called for.<ref name=the baseball biography project: ray schalk/> the white sox eventually lost the series, and eight of the white sox players were banned for life from major league baseball for taking part in the scandal.<ref name=the baseball biography project: ray schalk/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1919_ws.shtml |title=1919 world series |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=12 january 2011 }}</ref>

schalk helped revolutionize the way the catcher's position was played.<ref name=slim catchers replace big men in majors/> he is credited with being the first catcher to back up infield throws to [[first base]] and [[outfield]] throws to [[third base]].<ref name=the baseball biography project: ray schalk/> schalk claimed to be the only major league catcher to make a putout at every base and, he once made three assists in one [[inning (baseball)|inning]].<ref name=the baseball biography project: ray schalk/><ref name=chisox great ray schalk dead at 78>{{cite news |title=chisox great ray schalk dead at 78 |agency=associated press |work=the spokesman-review |page=15 |date=20 may 1970 |accessdate=15 january 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ipapaaaaibaj&sjid=busdaaaaibaj&pg=6753,1747684&dq=ray+schalk&hl=en}}</ref> he also became known for his handling of the white sox pitching staff and his pitch-calling skills.<ref name=the baseball biography project: ray schalk/> schalk's reputation as a defensive stand out is enhanced because of the era in which he played. in the [[deadball era]], catchers played a huge defensive role, given the large number of [[bunt (baseball)|bunt]]s and stolen base attempts, as well as the difficulty of handling the [[spitball]] pitchers who dominated pitching staffs.<ref name=for catchers, the name of the game is defense/><ref name=ray schalk at br bullpen>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/bullpen/ray_schalk |title=ray schalk at br bullpen |publisher=baseball-reference.com |accessdate=12 january 2011 }}</ref> he had to catch every type of [[pitch (baseball)|pitch]] imaginable, such as shine balls, spitballs, [[knuckleball]]s, and emory balls from pitchers such as, [[ed walsh]], [[eddie cicotte]], [[dickie kerr]], [[urban faber]], and [[ted lyons]].<ref name=for catchers, the name of the game is defense>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=9s0daaaambaj&pg=pa26&dq=baseball+digest+defensive+catchers#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20defensive%20catchers&f=false |title=for catchers, the name of the game is defense |author=vass, george |publisher=books.google.com |date=may 2005 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=12 january 2011 }}</ref>
* [http://books.google.com/books?id=ijmdaaaambaj&pg=pa4&dq=ray+schalk+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=ray%20schalk%20baseball%20digest&f=false ray schalk in baseball digest, september 1970]

they rebounded in [[1919 chicago white sox season|1919]] to recapture the american league pennant, with schalk hitting a career-high .282 and led the league in putouts for a seventh consecutive season.<ref name=ray schalk at baseball reference/> the [[1919 world series]], which the white sox lost to the [[1919 cincinnati reds season|cincinnati reds]], was shrouded in a controversy which became known as the [[black sox scandal]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.1919blacksox.com/story.htm |title=the black sox |publisher=1919blacksox.com |accessdate=12 january 2011 }}</ref> several white sox players were accused of intentionally throwing games<ref name=the baseball biography project: ray schalk/>in contrast to schalk, who played to win, hit for a series .304 batting average and was later absolved from any wrongdoing.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ijmdaaaambaj&pg=pa4&dq=ray+schalk+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=ray%20schalk%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=warm up tosses |author=kuenster, john |publisher=books.google.com |date=september 1970 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=12 january 2011 }}</ref> he told investigators he knew something was wrong when pitchers eddie cicotte and [[lefty williams]] didn't throw the pitches he had called for.<ref name=the baseball biography project: ray schalk/> the white sox lost the series five games to three, and eight of their players were banned for life from major league baseball as complicit in the scandal but not schalk.<ref name=the baseball biography project: ray schalk/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1919_ws.shtml |title=1919 world series |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=12 january 2011 }}</ref>

the name of the game is defense |author=vass, george |publisher=books.google.com |date=may 2005 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=12 january 2011 }}</ref>
* [http://books.google.com/books?id=ijmdaaaambaj&pg=pa4&dq=ray+schalk+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=ray%20schalk%20baseball%20digest&f=false ray schalk in baseball digest, september 1970]

they rebounded in [[1919 chicago white sox season|1919]] to recapture the american league pennant, with schalk hitting a career-high .282 and led the league in putouts for a seventh consecutive season.<ref name=ray schalk at baseball reference/> the [[1919 world series]], which the white sox lost to the [[1919 cincinnati reds season|cincinnati reds]], was shrouded in a controversy which became known as the [[black sox scandal]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.1919blacksox.com/story.htm |title=the black sox |publisher=1919blacksox.com |accessdate=12 january 2011 }}</ref> several white sox players were accused of intentionally throwing games<ref name=the baseball biography project: ray schalk/> in contrast to schalk, who played to win, hit for a series .304 batting average and was later absolved from any wrongdoing.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ijmdaaaambaj&pg=pa4&dq=ray+schalk+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=ray%20schalk%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=warm up tosses |author=kuenster, john |publisher=books.google.com |date=september 1970 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=12 january 2011 }}</ref> he told investigators he knew something was wrong when pitchers eddie cicotte and [[lefty williams]] didn't throw the pitches he had called for.<ref name=the baseball biography project: ray schalk/> the white sox lost the series five games to three, and eight of their players were banned for life from major league baseball as complicit in the scandal but not schalk.<ref name=the baseball biography project: ray schalk/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1919_ws.shtml |title=1919 world series |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=12 january 2011 }}</ref>

schalk helped revolutionize the way the catcher's position was played.<ref name=slim catchers replace big men in majors/> he is credited with being the first catcher to back up infield throws to [[first base]] and [[outfield]] throws to [[third base]].<ref name=the baseball biography project: ray schalk/> he claimed to be the only major league catcher to have made a putout at every base, and once made three assists in one [[inning (baseball)|inning]].<ref name=the baseball biography project: ray schalk/><ref name=chisox great ray schalk dead at 78>{{cite news |title=chisox great ray schalk dead at 78 |agency=associated press |work=the spokesman-review |page=15 |date=20 may 1970 |accessdate=15 january 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ipapaaaaibaj&sjid=busdaaaaibaj&pg=6753,1747684&dq=ray+schalk&hl=en}}</ref> he also became known for his handling of the white sox pitching staff and his pitch-calling skills.<ref name=the baseball biography project: ray schalk/> his reputation as a defensive standout is enhanced due to the era in which he played: in the [[deadball era]], catchers played a much greater defensive role than subsequently, given the large number of [[bunt (baseball)|bunt]]s and stolen base attempts, as well as the difficulty of handling the [[spitball]] pitchers who dominated pitching staffs.<ref name=for catchers, the name of the game is defense/><ref name=ray schalk at br bullpen>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/bullpen/ray_schalk |title=ray schalk at br bullpen |publisher=baseball-reference.com |accessdate=12 january 2011 }}</ref> he had to catch every type of [[pitch (baseball)|pitch]] imaginable, including shine balls, spitballs, [[knuckleball]]s and emory balls from pitchers such as, [[ed walsh]], [[eddie cicotte]], [[dickie kerr]], [[urban faber]] and [[ted lyons]].<ref name=for catchers, the name of the game is defense>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=9s0daaaambaj&pg=pa26&dq=baseball+digest+defensive+catchers#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20defensive%20catchers&f=false |title=for catchers, the name of the game is defense |author=vass, george |publisher=books.google.com |date=may 2005 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=12 january 2011 }}</ref>
* [http://books.google.com/books?id=ijmdaaaambaj&pg=pa4&dq=ray+schalk+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=ray%20schalk%20baseball%20digest&f=false ray schalk in baseball digest, september 1970]

'''william walker cooper''' (january 8, 1915 - april 11, 1991) was an [[united states|american]] [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] player.<ref name=walker cooper at baseball reference>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/c/coopewa01.shtml?redir walker cooper at baseball reference]</ref> he was a [[catcher]] in [[major league baseball]] who played for six [[national league]] teams from 1940 to 1957.<ref name=walker cooper at baseball reference/> he was known as one of the top catchers in baseball during the 1940s and early 1950s.<ref name=walker cooper looks back on an all-star career>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=y7edaaaambaj&pg=pa69&dq=walker+cooper+baseball+digest&cd=1#v=onepage&q=walker%20cooper%20baseball%20digest&f=false|title=walker cooper looks back on an all-star career|last=harris|first=don|date=june 1990|publisher=baseball digest|pages=6972|accessdate=2010-02-17}}</ref>

*[http://books.google.com/books?id=y7edaaaambaj&pg=pa69&dq=walker+cooper+baseball+digest&cd=1#v=onepage&q=walker%20cooper%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''walker cooper looks back on an all-star career'', baseball digest, june 1990]

'''antonio francisco pea padilla''' ({{ipa-es|toni pea}}; born june 4, 1957, in [[provinces of the dominican republic|monte cristi]], [[dominican republic]]) is a former [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] player, [[manager (baseball)|manager]] and current [[coach (baseball)|coach]].<ref name=tony pena statistics>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/p/penato01.shtml |title=tony pena statistics |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=5 january 2011 }}</ref> he played as a [[catcher]] in [[major league baseball]] for the [[pittsburgh pirates|pirates]], [[st. louis cardinals|cardinals]], [[boston red sox|red sox]], [[cleveland indians|indians]], [[chicago white sox|white sox]], and [[houston astros|astros]].<ref name=tony pena statistics/> pea was the manager of the [[kansas city royals]] between [[2002 kansas city royals season|2002]] and [[2005 kansas city royals season|2005]]. he currently is the bench coach for the [[new york yankees]]. as a player, pea was known for his defensive abilities as well as his unorthodox squat behind [[home plate]].<ref name=these are best defensive players in big leagues>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=5zmdaaaambaj&lpg=pa64&dq=tony%20pena%20baseball%20digest&pg=pa62#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=these are best defensive players in big leagues |author=wilner, barry |publisher=books.google.com |date=april 1985 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=5 january 2011 }}</ref>

after the 1983 season, the pirates went into a period of decline, finishing in last place for three consecutive years between [[1984 pittsburgh pirates season|1984]] and [[1986 pittsburgh pirates season|1986]]. although his offensive statistics tapered off, pea continued to be productive defensively during this period, leading national league catchers in assists, putouts and baserunners caught stealing in {{by|1984}} and, again leading the league in assists and baserunners caught stealing in {{by|1985}}, winning two more gold glove awards and two more all-star selections in the process.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1984-fielding-leaders.shtml |title=1984 national league fielding leaders |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=5 january 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1985-fielding-leaders.shtml |title=1985 national league fielding leaders |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=5 january 2011 }}</ref> when pea broke the 100 assists barrier in {{by|1985}}, he joined [[johnny bench]], [[jim sundberg]] and gary carter as the only catchers to have more than 100 assists in a season since the end of the second world war.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leaders/a_c_leagues.shtml |title=yearly league leaders & records for assists as catchers |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=5 january 2011 }}</ref> in a {{by|1986}} poll of major league managers, pea was selected as the best throwing catcher in the major leagues.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=lzqdaaaambaj&pg=pa43&dq=tony+pena+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=uzgktcc1e4gclafw182taq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0cdiq6aewbdgk#v=onepage&q=tony%20pena%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=1985 best of everything major league poll |author=maccarl, neil |publisher=books.google.com |date=february 1986 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=5 january 2011 }}</ref>

in november 1989, pea was granted free agency and signed a contract to play for the boston red sox.<ref name=tony pena statistics/> with the red sox in [[1990 boston red sox season|1990]], he led [[american league]] catchers in [[games played]], [[range factor]], putouts and finished second in assists and in fielding percentage.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/al/1990-fielding-leaders.shtml |title=1990 american league fielding leaders |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=5 january 2011 }}</ref> his performance earned him the gold glove award, making him only the second catcher after [[bob boone]] to earn a gold glove in both the american and national leagues.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=pcsdaaaambaj&lpg=pa18&dq=tony%20pena%20baseball%20digest&pg=pa18#v=onepage&q=tony%20pena%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=letters to the editor |author= |publisher=books.google.com |date=february 2001 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=5 january 2011 }}</ref> the red sox won the [[american league east|american league eastern division]] pennant before eventually losing to the [[1990 oakland athletics season|oakland athletics]] in the [[1990 american league championship series]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1990_alcs.shtml |title=1990 american league championship series |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=5 january 2011 }}</ref>

in october 1993, pea again filed for free agency and signed to play for the cleveland indians.<ref name=tony pena statistics/> although his batting statistics weren't as strong as his earlier career, pea was still valued for his strong defensive skills as a catcher.<ref name=these are the majors' top comeback players of '94>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=eysdaaaambaj&lpg=pa24&dq=tony%20pena%20baseball%20digest&pg=pa24#v=onepage&q=tony%20pena%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=these are the majors' top comeback players of '94 |author=vass, george |publisher=books.google.com |date=november 1994 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=5 january 2011 }}</ref> he proved invaluable for the indians in [[1994 cleveland indians season|1994]] as a substitute for the injury-prone starting catcher, [[sandy alomar, jr.]], while posting a .296 batting average with a .341 [[on base percentage]].<ref name=these are the majors' top comeback players of '94/> he caught the majority of the indians' games in [[1995 cleveland indians season|1995]] as they made it all the way to the [[1995 world series]] before losing to the [[1995 atlanta braves season|atlanta braves]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/cle/1995.shtml |title=1995 cleveland indians |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=5 january 2011 }}</ref> pea's batting average dropped to .195 in [[1995 cleveland indians season|1995]] and, he once again filed for free agency at the end of the season, signing a contract with the chicago white sox.<ref name=tony pena statistics/> he played with the white sox until august [[1997 chicago white sox season|1997]] when he was traded to the houston astros. at the end of the year, he retired as a player at the age of 40.<ref name=tony pena statistics/>

after the 1983 season, the pirates went into a period of decline, finishing in last place for three consecutive years between [[1984 pittsburgh pirates season|1984]] and [[1986 pittsburgh pirates season|1986]]. although his offensive statistics tapered off, pea continued to be productive defensively during this period, leading national league catchers in assists, putouts and baserunners caught stealing in {{by|1984}} and, again leading the league in assists and baserunners caught stealing in {{by|1985}}, winning two more gold glove awards and two more all-star selections in the process.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1984-fielding-leaders.shtml |title=1984 national league fielding leaders |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=5 january 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1985-fielding-leaders.shtml |title=1985 national league fielding leaders |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=5 january 2011 }}</ref> when pea broke the 100 assists barrier in {{by|1985}}, he joined [[johnny bench]], [[jim sundberg]] and gary carter as the only catchers to have more than 100 assists in a season since the end of the second world war.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leaders/a_c_leagues.shtml |title=yearly league leaders & records for assists as catchers |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=5 january 2011 }}</ref> in a {{by|1986}} poll of major league managers, pea was selected as the best throwing catcher in the major leagues.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=lzqdaaaambaj&pg=pa43&dq=tony+pena+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=uzgktcc1e4gclafw182taq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0cdiq6aewbdgk#v=onepage&q=tony%20pena%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=1985 best of everything major league poll |author=maccarl, neil |date=february 1986 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=5 january 2011 }}</ref>

in november 1989, pea was granted free agency and signed a contract to play for the boston red sox.<ref name=tony pena statistics/> with the red sox in [[1990 boston red sox season|1990]], he led [[american league]] catchers in [[games played]], [[range factor]], putouts and finished second in assists and in fielding percentage.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/al/1990-fielding-leaders.shtml |title=1990 american league fielding leaders |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=5 january 2011 }}</ref> his performance earned him the gold glove award, making him only the second catcher after [[bob boone]] to earn a gold glove in both the american and national leagues.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=pcsdaaaambaj&lpg=pa18&dq=tony%20pena%20baseball%20digest&pg=pa18#v=onepage&q=tony%20pena%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=letters to the editor |work=baseball digest|date=february 2001 |accessdate=5 january 2011 }}</ref> the red sox won the [[american league east|american league eastern division]] pennant before eventually losing to the [[1990 oakland athletics season|oakland athletics]] in the [[1990 american league championship series]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1990_alcs.shtml |title=1990 american league championship series |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=5 january 2011 }}</ref>

in october 1993, pea again filed for free agency and signed to play for the cleveland indians.<ref name=tony pena statistics/> although his batting statistics weren't as strong as his earlier career, pea was still valued for his strong defensive skills as a catcher.<ref name=these are the majors' top comeback players of '94>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=eysdaaaambaj&lpg=pa24&dq=tony%20pena%20baseball%20digest&pg=pa24#v=onepage&q=tony%20pena%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=these are the majors' top comeback players of '94 |author=vass, george|date=november 1994 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=5 january 2011 }}</ref> he proved invaluable for the indians in [[1994 cleveland indians season|1994]] as a substitute for the injury-prone starting catcher, [[sandy alomar, jr.]], while posting a .296 batting average with a .341 [[on base percentage]].<ref name=these are the majors' top comeback players of '94/> he caught the majority of the indians' games in [[1995 cleveland indians season|1995]] as they made it all the way to the [[1995 world series]] before losing to the [[1995 atlanta braves season|atlanta braves]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/cle/1995.shtml |title=1995 cleveland indians |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=5 january 2011 }}</ref> pea's batting average dropped to .195 in [[1995 cleveland indians season|1995]] and, he once again filed for free agency at the end of the season, signing a contract with the chicago white sox.<ref name=tony pena statistics/> he played with the white sox until august [[1997 chicago white sox season|1997]] when he was traded to the houston astros. at the end of the year, he retired as a player at the age of 40.<ref name=tony pena statistics/>

'''carl william mays''' (november 12, 1891 – april 4, 1971) was a right-handed [[pitcher]] in [[major league baseball]] from 1915 to 1929.<ref name=carl mays at baseball reference>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/m/maysca01.shtml carl mays at baseball reference]</ref> he is remembered for throwing a [[beanball]] on august 16, 1920, that struck and killed [[ray chapman]] of the [[cleveland indians]], making chapman only the second person to die from an injury sustained while playing major league baseball.<ref name=''carl mays: my pitch that killed chapman was a strike!''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=miwdaaaambaj&pg=pa9&lpg=pa9&dq=chapman+mays+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=n_rjrvpk_q&sig=xks6butxlmmuhyw5wnoo6slgrk4&hl=en&ei=hrrvs4hsks2ptgeild2ebg&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0cagq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=chapman%20mays%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''carl mays: my pitch that killed chapman was a strike!'' by phyllis propert, baseball digest, july 1957, vol. 16, no. 6, issn 0005-609x]</ref><ref>[http://www.nytimes.com/packages/html/sports/year_in_sports/08.17.html ''the death of ray chapman'', the new york times, august 17, 1920]</ref>

[[image:carl-mays.jpg|thumb|left|mays as a batter]]mays enjoyed his best season in [[1921 in baseball|1921]], when he led the [[american league]] in [[win (baseball)|win]]s (27), [[innings pitched]] (336.2), [[games pitched]] (49), and [[win (baseball)|winning percentage]] (.750). however that same season mays, pitching then for the [[1921 new york yankees season|yankees]], played in a [[1921 world series|world series]] that others later would accuse him of helping to throw, bringing back still-lingering memories of the [[black sox scandal]] from just two years prior. these rumors were never proven, but they persisted long enough that, combined with an already negative reputation among other players both from the chapman incident and from having a personality that few found agreeable, he was never elected to the [[national baseball hall of fame and museum|baseball hall of fame]] despite having lifetime statistics comparable to some other pitchers who were.<ref name=''tragic pitch recalled by carl mays''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=9rydaaaambaj&pg=pa38&dq=carl+mays+baseball+digest&cd=2#v=onepage&q=carl%20mays%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''tragic pitch recalled by carl mays'', by jack murphy, baseball digest, may 1971, vol. 30, no. 5, issn 0005-609x]</ref>

mays enjoyed his best season in [[1921 in baseball|1921]], when he led the [[american league]] in [[win (baseball)|win]]s (27), [[innings pitched]] (336.2), [[games pitched]] (49), and [[win (baseball)|winning percentage]] (.750). however that same season mays, pitching then for the [[1921 new york yankees season|yankees]], played in a [[1921 world series|world series]] that others later would accuse him of helping to throw, bringing back still-lingering memories of the [[black sox scandal]] from just two years prior. these rumors were never proven, but they persisted long enough that, combined with an already negative reputation among other players both from the chapman incident and from having a personality that few found agreeable, he was never elected to the [[national baseball hall of fame and museum|baseball hall of fame]] despite having lifetime statistics comparable to some other pitchers who were.<ref name=''tragic pitch recalled by carl mays''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=9rydaaaambaj&pg=pa38&dq=carl+mays+baseball+digest&cd=2#v=onepage&q=carl%20mays%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''tragic pitch recalled by carl mays'', by jack murphy, baseball digest, may 1971, vol. 30, no. 5, issn 0005-609x]</ref>
