mays enjoyed his best season in [[1921 in baseball|1921]], when he led the [[american league]] in [[win (baseball)|win]]s (27), [[innings pitched]] (336.2), [[games pitched]] (49), and [[win (baseball)|winning percentage]] (.750). however, that same season mays, pitching then for the [[1921 new york yankees season|yankees]], played in a [[1921 world series|world series]] that others later accused him of helping to throw, bringing back memories of the [[black sox scandal]] from just two years prior. these rumors were never proven, but they persisted long enough that, combined with an already negative reputation among other players both from the chapman incident and from having a personality that few found agreeable, he was never elected to the [[national baseball hall of fame and museum|baseball hall of fame]] despite having lifetime statistics comparable to some other pitchers who were.<ref name=''tragic pitch recalled by carl mays''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=9rydaaaambaj&pg=pa38&dq=carl+mays+baseball+digest&cd=2#v=onepage&q=carl%20mays%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''tragic pitch recalled by carl mays'', by jack murphy, baseball digest, may 1971, vol. 30, no. 5, issn 0005-609x]</ref>

'''louis clark lou brock''' (born june 18, 1939) is an american former [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] player.<ref name=lou brock statistics>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/b/brocklo01.shtml |title=lou brock statistics |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=19 april 2011 }}</ref> he began his [[major league baseball]] career with the [[chicago cubs]] but, spent the majority of his career as the [[left fielder]] for the [[st. louis cardinals]]. brock was best known for breaking [[ty cobb]]'s all-time major league [[stolen base]] record.<ref name=success story: lou brock's climb to the hall of fame>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=jzqdaaaambaj&pg=pa39&dq=lou+brock+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=8rqttbnkjmbngqeeo-x1cw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0ccsq6aewaq#v=onepage&q=lou%20brock%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=success story: lou brock's climb to the hall of fame |author=fortus, bob |publisher=books.google.com |date=november 1985 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=19 april 2011 }}</ref> he is currently a special instructor [[coach (baseball)|coach]] for the st. louis cardinals. brock was inducted into the [[baseball hall of fame]] in [[baseball hall of fame balloting, 1985|1985]].<ref name=lou brock at the baseball hall of fame>{{cite web |url=http://baseballhall.org/hof/brock-lou |title=lou brock at the baseball hall of fame |publisher=baseballhall.org |accessdate=18 april 2011 }}</ref>

brock was born in [[el dorado, arkansas]] to a family of [[sharecropping|sharecroppers]].<ref name=lou brock looks back on his 19-year hall of fame career>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=1ysdaaaambaj&pg=pa66&dq=lou+brock+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=pzktte_gn8psgqfxkqt7cw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0cc8q6aewag#v=onepage&q=lou%20brock%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=lou brock looks back on his 19-year hall of fame career |author=eisenbath, mike |publisher=books.google.com |date=december 1984 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=19 april 2011 }}</ref> his family moved to [[collinston, louisiana]] when he was two years old.<ref name=success story: lou brock's climb to the hall of fame/> while his family didn't have much money, he said that he never felt poor because,if you don't have something, you don't miss it.<ref name=lou brock looks back on his 19-year hall of fame career/> brock grew up as a fan of the [[los angeles dodgers|brooklyn dodgers]], the team that included [[jackie robinson]], [[don newcombe]] and [[roy campanella]].<ref name=lou brock looks back on his 19-year hall of fame career/> although he didn't play in organized baseball until he reached the 11th grade, he learned much about the sport from listening to cardinals radio broadcaster [[harry caray]] describe the way major league hitters stood at the plate.<ref name=lou brock looks back on his 19-year hall of fame career/> after attending high school in [[mer rouge, louisiana]], he received academic assistance to attend [[southern university]] in [[baton rouge, louisiana|baton rouge]] but, when a low grade in his first semester meant the possibility of losing his scholarship, he decided to try out for the school's baseball team in order to secure an athletic scholarship.<ref name=success story: lou brock's climb to the hall of fame/>

after brock was traded to the cardinals, his career turned around significantly. he moved to left field and batted .348 and stole 38 bases for the remainder of the [[1964 st. louis cardinals season|1964]] season.<ref name=lou brock statistics/> at the time of the trade, the cardinals were 2831, in eighth place in the [[national league]], trailing even the cubs, who were 2727 and in sixth place. brock helped the cardinals storm from behind to capture the national league [[pennant (sports)|pennant]] on the last day of the season.<ref name=success story: lou brock's climb to the hall of fame/> four months to the day after brock's trade, the cardinals would win the [[1964 world series]] in seven games over the favored [[1964 new york yankees season|new york yankees]], who were appearing in their fourteenth world series in sixteen years (and their last until a dozen years later). brock's contributions to the cardinals' championship season were recognized when he finished in tenth place in voting for the {{by|1964}} national league [[major league baseball most valuable player award|most valuable player award]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1964.shtml#nlmvp |title=1964 national league most valuable player award voting results |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=19 april 2011 }}</ref> meanwhile, broglio won only seven games for the chicago cubs before retiring from baseball after the {{by|1966}} season. to this day, the trade of [[brock for broglio]] is considered one of the most lopsided deals in baseball history.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=scsdaaaambaj&lpg=pa31&ots=ofyvcfjeku&dq=aaron%20robinson%20baseball%20digest&pg=pa32#v=onepage&q=aaron%20robinson%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=these were the ten most lopsided player trades |author=gold, eddie |publisher=books.google.com |date=august 1996 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=19 april 2011 }}</ref>

in [[1966 st. louis cardinals season|1966]], brock ended [[maury wills]]' six-year reign as the national league's stolen base champion with 76 steals.<ref>{{cite news |title=national loop hitting crown won by alou |agency=associated press |work=gadsden times |page=15 |date=11 december 1966 |accessdate=19 april 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=drapaaaaibaj&sjid=dtceaaaaibaj&pg=874,1465586&dq=lou+brock&hl=en}}</ref> in [[david halberstam]]'s book, ''october 1964'', the author states that manager johnny keane asked brock to forgo hitting home runs in favor of the stealing bases.<ref name=lou brock: base stealing demands mental discipline>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ry4daaaambaj&pg=pa35&dq=lou+brock+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=pzktte_gn8psgqfxkqt7cw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0cccq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=lou%20brock%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=lou brock: base stealing demands mental discipline |author=stone, george |publisher=books.google.com |date=september 1990 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=19 april 2011 }}</ref> brock went on to lead the national league in stolen bases eight times within a nine year span between {{by|1966}} and {{by|1974}} (former teammate [[bobby tolan]] led the league in steals in {{by|1970}}).<ref name=success story: lou brock's climb to the hall of fame/> brock began the [[1967 st. louis cardinals season|1967]] season by hitting 5 home runs in the first four games of the season, becoming the first player to do so.<ref>{{cite news |title=lou brock slowed to trot by power |agency=united press international |work=the pittsburgh press |page= |date=17 april 1967 |accessdate=19 april 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=2kgqaaaaibaj&sjid=yk8eaaaaibaj&pg=3738,1394989&dq=lou+brock&hl=en}}</ref> he was hitting for a .328 average by mid-june to earn the role as the starting left fielder for the national league in the [[1967 major league baseball all-star game|1967 all-star game]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/gl.cgi?id=brocklo01&t=b&year=1967 |title=1967 lou brock batting log |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=19 april 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/als/als196707110.shtml |title=1967 all-star game |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=19 april 2011 }}</ref> after suffering through a mid-season slump, he recovered to finish the season with a career-high 206 [[hit (baseball)|hits]] and a .299 batting average while leading the league in stolen bases and [[run (baseball)|runs]] scored as the cardinals won the national league pennant by ten and a half games. brock became the first player to steal 50 bases and hit 20 home runs in the same season.<ref name=success story: lou brock's climb to the hall of fame/> in the [[1967 world series]], brock hit for a .414 average and set a world series record with seven stolen bases as the cardinals defeated the [[1967 boston red sox season|boston red sox]] in seven games.<ref>{{cite news |title=gibson gets his car, says brock real hero |agency=associated press |work=daytona beach morning journal |page=7 |date=17 october 1967 |accessdate=19 april 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=e24eaaaaibaj&sjid=nmkeaaaaibaj&pg=1875,3617083&dq=lou+brock&hl=en}}</ref>

'''louis clark lou brock''' (born june 18, 1939) is an american former professional baseball player.<ref name=lou brock statistics>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/b/brocklo01.shtml |title=lou brock statistics |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=april 19, 2011 }}</ref> he began his [[major league baseball]] career with the [[chicago cubs]], but spent the majority of his career as the [[left fielder]] for the [[st. louis cardinals]]. brock was best known for breaking [[ty cobb]]'s all-time major league [[stolen base]] record.<ref name=success story: lou brock's climb to the hall of fame>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=jzqdaaaambaj&pg=pa39&dq=lou+brock+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=8rqttbnkjmbngqeeo-x1cw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0ccsq6aewaq#v=onepage&q=lou%20brock%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=success story: lou brock's climb to the hall of fame |author=fortus, bob |publisher=google books |date=november 1985 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=april 19, 2011 }}</ref> he is currently a special instructor [[coach (baseball)|coach]] for the st. louis cardinals. brock was inducted into the [[baseball hall of fame]] in [[baseball hall of fame balloting, 1985|1985]].<ref name=lou brock at the baseball hall of fame>{{cite web |url=http://baseballhall.org/hof/brock-lou |title=lou brock at the baseball hall of fame |publisher=baseballhall.org |accessdate=april 18, 2011 }}</ref>

brock was born in [[el dorado, arkansas]] to a family of [[sharecropping|sharecroppers]].<ref name=lou brock looks back on his 19-year hall of fame career>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=1ysdaaaambaj&pg=pa66&dq=lou+brock+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=pzktte_gn8psgqfxkqt7cw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0cc8q6aewag#v=onepage&q=lou%20brock%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=lou brock looks back on his 19-year hall of fame career |author=eisenbath, mike |publisher=google books |date=december 1984 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=april 19, 2011 }}</ref> his family moved to [[collinston, louisiana]] when he was two years old.<ref name=success story: lou brock's climb to the hall of fame/> while his family didn't have much money, he said that he never felt poor because,if you don't have something, you don't miss it.<ref name=lou brock looks back on his 19-year hall of fame career/> brock grew up as a fan of the [[los angeles dodgers|brooklyn dodgers]], the team that included [[jackie robinson]], [[don newcombe]] and [[roy campanella]].<ref name=lou brock looks back on his 19-year hall of fame career/> although he didn't play in organized baseball until he reached the 11th grade, he learned much about the sport from listening to cardinals radio broadcaster [[harry caray]] describe the way major league hitters stood at the plate.<ref name=lou brock looks back on his 19-year hall of fame career/> after attending high school in [[mer rouge, louisiana]], he received academic assistance to attend [[southern university]] in [[baton rouge, louisiana|baton rouge]], but when a low grade in his first semester meant the possibility of losing his scholarship, he decided to try out for the school's baseball team in order to secure an athletic scholarship.<ref name=success story: lou brock's climb to the hall of fame/>

after brock was traded to the cardinals, his career turned around significantly. he moved to left field and batted .348 and stole 38 bases for the remainder of the [[1964 st. louis cardinals season|1964]] season.<ref name=lou brock statistics/> at the time of the trade, the cardinals were 2831, in eighth place in the [[national league]], trailing even the cubs, who were 2727 and in sixth place. brock helped the cardinals storm from behind to capture the national league [[pennant (sports)|pennant]] on the last day of the season.<ref name=success story: lou brock's climb to the hall of fame/> four months to the day after brock's trade, the cardinals would win the [[1964 world series]] in seven games over the favored [[1964 new york yankees season|new york yankees]], who were appearing in their fourteenth world series in sixteen years (and their last until a dozen years later). brock's contributions to the cardinals' championship season were recognized when he finished in tenth place in voting for the 1964 national league [[major league baseball most valuable player award|most valuable player award]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1964.shtml#nlmvp |title=1964 national league most valuable player award voting results |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=april 19, 2011 }}</ref> meanwhile, broglio won only seven games for the chicago cubs before retiring from baseball after the 1966 season. to this day, the trade of [[brock for broglio]] is considered one of the most lopsided deals in baseball history.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=scsdaaaambaj&lpg=pa31&ots=ofyvcfjeku&dq=aaron%20robinson%20baseball%20digest&pg=pa32#v=onepage&q=aaron%20robinson%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=these were the ten most lopsided player trades |author=gold, eddie |publisher=google books |date=august 1996 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=april 19, 2011 }}</ref>

in [[1966 st. louis cardinals season|1966]], brock ended [[maury wills]]' six-year reign as the national league's stolen base champion with 76 steals.<ref>{{cite news |title=national loop hitting crown won by alou |agency=associated press |work=gadsden times |page=15 |date=december 11, 1966 |accessdate=april 19, 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=drapaaaaibaj&sjid=dtceaaaaibaj&pg=874,1465586&dq=lou+brock&hl=en}}</ref> in [[david halberstam]]'s book, ''october 1964'', the author states that manager johnny keane asked brock to forgo hitting home runs in favor of the stealing bases.<ref name=lou brock: base stealing demands mental discipline>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ry4daaaambaj&pg=pa35&dq=lou+brock+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=pzktte_gn8psgqfxkqt7cw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0cccq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=lou%20brock%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=lou brock: base stealing demands mental discipline |author=stone, george |publisher=google books |date=september 1990 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=april 19, 2011 }}</ref> brock went on to lead the national league in stolen bases eight times within a nine year span between 1966 and 1974 (former teammate [[bobby tolan]] led the league in steals in 1970).<ref name=success story: lou brock's climb to the hall of fame/> brock began the [[1967 st. louis cardinals season|1967]] season by hitting 5 home runs in the first four games of the season, becoming the first player to do so.<ref>{{cite news |title=lou brock slowed to trot by power |agency=united press international |work=the pittsburgh press |date=april 17, 1967 |accessdate=april 19, 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=2kgqaaaaibaj&sjid=yk8eaaaaibaj&pg=3738,1394989&dq=lou+brock&hl=en}}</ref> he was hitting for a .328 average by mid-june to earn the role as the starting left fielder for the national league in the [[1967 major league baseball all-star game|1967 all-star game]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/gl.cgi?id=brocklo01&t=b&year=1967 |title=1967 lou brock batting log |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=april 19, 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/als/als196707110.shtml |title=1967 all-star game |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=april 19, 2011 }}</ref> after suffering through a mid-season slump, he recovered to finish the season with a career-high 206 [[hit (baseball)|hits]] and a .299 batting average while leading the league in stolen bases and [[run (baseball)|runs]] scored as the cardinals won the national league pennant by ten and a half games. brock became the first player to steal 50 bases and hit 20 home runs in the same season.<ref name=success story: lou brock's climb to the hall of fame/> in the [[1967 world series]], brock hit for a .414 average, scored 8 runs and set a world series record with seven stolen bases as the cardinals defeated the [[1967 boston red sox season|boston red sox]] in seven games.<ref>{{cite news |title=gibson gets his car, says brock real hero |agency=associated press |work=daytona beach morning journal |page=7 |date=october 17, 1967 |accessdate=april 19, 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=e24eaaaaibaj&sjid=nmkeaaaaibaj&pg=1875,3617083&dq=lou+brock&hl=en}}</ref>

'''ricardo adolfo jacobo carty''' (born september 1, 1939 [[san pedro de macoris]], [[dominican republic]]) is a former [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] player.<ref name=rico carty at baseball reference>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/c/cartyri01.shtml rico carty at baseball reference]</ref> nicknamed ''beeg boy'', he played mostly as an [[outfielder]] in [[major league baseball]] from {{by|1963}} to {{by|1979}}.<ref name=rico carty at baseball reference/> carty played for the [[atlanta braves|milwaukee braves]], [[atlanta braves]] and [[chicago cubs]] of the [[national league]] and the [[oakland a's]], [[cleveland indians]], [[toronto blue jays]] and [[texas rangers (baseball)|texas rangers]] of the [[american league]].<ref name=rico carty at baseball reference/> a charismatic, gifted [[batter (baseball)|hitter]], carty's career was marked by battles with injuries, illnesses and with team mates.<ref name=''rico carty: he's no longer the 'beeg boy''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=2tedaaaambaj&pg=pa74&lpg=pa74&dq=rico+carty+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=dng1vchjks&sig=zklqkir0nk6vvwjg8myiobkgztu&hl=en&ei=cyjntnvilswqlafzznwebq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0cbuq6aewaq#v=onepage&q=rico%20carty%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''rico carty: he's no longer the 'beeg boy'', by ron hudspeth, baseball digest, february 1973, vol. 32, no. 2, issn 0005-609x]</ref>

carty signed a contract with the [[milwaukee braves]] as a [[free agent]] in [[1959 milwaukee braves season|1959]].<ref name=rico carty trades and transactions at baseball almanac>[http://www.baseball-almanac.com/players/trades.php?p=cartyri01 rico carty trades and transactions at baseball almanac]</ref> while he was an excellent hitter, he had poor defensive skills.<ref name=''rico carty - the beeg boy finally makes it big''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=vdmdaaaambaj&pg=pa68&lpg=pa68&dq=rico+carty+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=1xmjf3myus&sig=bqaeyxmsahtxv5uvmcpj4wo3868&hl=en&ei=0zjntjfxlmoqlaeg9fgebq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0ccqq6aewbq#v=onepage&q=rico%20carty%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''rico carty - the beeg boy finally makes it big'', by priit vesilind, baseball digest, august 1970, vol. 29, no. 8, issn 0005-609x]</ref> originally a [[catcher]], carty was converted into an outfielder in order to lessen his defensive liabilities and to get his bat into the everday roster.<ref name=''rico carty - the beeg boy finally makes it big''/> after four years in the [[minor league baseball|minor leagues]], carty made an impressive major league debut in [[1964 milwaukee braves season|1964]], finishing second to [[roberto clemente]] in the national league batting championship with a .330 [[batting average]] and, finishing the season as runner-up to [[dick allen]] in the {{by|1964}} [[national league]] [[major league baseball rookie of the year award|rookie of the year award]] ballot.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1964-batting-leaders.shtml 1964 national league batting leaders at baseball reference]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1964.shtml#nlroy 1964 national league rookie of the year award ballot results at baseball reference]</ref>

carty had his best season in [[1970 atlanta braves season|1970]] when he hit 25 [[home run]]s with 101 [[runs batted in]] and, won the national league [[list of major league baseball batting champions|batting championship]] with a .366 batting average, the highest average in the major leagues since [[ted williams]] recorded a .388 batting average in {{by|1957}}.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1970-batting-leaders.shtml 1970 national league batting leaders at baseball reference]</ref> despite not appearing on the [[major league baseball all-star game|all-star]] ballot, he was voted to be a starting outfielder for the national league as a write-in candidate in the [[1970 major league baseball all-star game|1970 all-star game]], playing alongside [[hank aaron]] and [[willie mays]] in the outfield.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=di8daaaambaj&pg=pa10&lpg=pa10&dq=rico+carty+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=13xbmw2ugs&sig=bbo-zfw22yv9fiui8ciufc63ula&hl=en&ei=c8lntigrmoh7lwedmoihbq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0cdiq6aewcdgu#v=onepage&q=rico%20carty%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, july 1986, vol. 45, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/nls/nls197007140.shtml 1970 all-star game at baseball reference]</ref> carty also compiled a 31-game [[hitting streak]] in {{by|1970}} and, finished 10th in the 1970 national league most valuable player award voting.<ref name=''rico carty - the beeg boy finally makes it big''/><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1970.shtml#nlmvp 1970 national league most valuable player award voting results at baseball reference]</ref>

a crushed knee injury suffered during the [[dominican winter baseball league|dominican winter baseball]] season meant that carty would miss another entire season in [[1971 atlanta braves season|1971]].<ref name=''rico carty: he's no longer the 'beeg boy''/> he returned in [[1972 atlanta braves season|1972]], but only managed a .277 batting average. by then, carty had worn out his welcome with the braves management as well as his teammates, having been involved in fights with hank aaron and [[ron reed]].<ref name=''rico carty: he's no longer the 'beeg boy''/> in october {{by|1972}}, he was traded to the [[1973 texas rangers season|texas rangers]] to fill the role of the newly-adopted [[designated hitter]].<ref name=rico carty trades and transactions at baseball almanac/> carty had difficulty adjusting to the hitting-only position, hitting for only a .232 average before being traded in mid-season to the [[1973 chicago cubs season|chicago cubs]].<ref name=''designated hitter born 25 years ago''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=ui0daaaambaj&pg=pa80&lpg=pa80&dq=rico+carty+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=wu8g5j_yry&sig=n2bxo5ijweqs7icb7znj9vtx8zu&hl=en&ei=hdtntjnze4kklwfsvdwebq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0cbwq6aewazgu#v=onepage&q=rico%20carty%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''designated hitter born 25 years ago'', by bruce markusen, baseball digest, july 1998, vol. 57, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref> while with the cubs, he had a personality clash with their star third baseman, [[ron santo]], forcing the team to trade carty to the [[1973 oakland athletics season|oakland athletics]] one month later.<ref name=rico carty trades and transactions at baseball almanac/><ref name=''designated hitter born 25 years ago''/> with a combined .229 batting average for the three teams, carty was released by the athletics in december {{by|1973}} and, it seemed as if his career might be over.<ref name=rico carty at baseball reference/>

'''ricardo adolfo jacobo carty''' (born september 1, 1939 [[san pedro de macoris]], [[dominican republic]]) is a former [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] player.<ref name=rico carty at baseball reference>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/c/cartyri01.shtml rico carty at baseball reference]</ref> nicknamed ''beeg boy'', he played mostly as an [[outfielder]] in [[major league baseball]] from {{by|1963}} to {{by|1979}}.<ref name=rico carty at baseball reference/> carty played for the [[atlanta braves|milwaukee braves]], [[atlanta braves]] and [[chicago cubs]] of the [[national league]] and the [[oakland a's]], [[cleveland indians]], [[toronto blue jays]] and [[texas rangers (baseball)|texas rangers]] of the [[american league]].<ref name=rico carty at baseball reference/> a charismatic, gifted [[batter (baseball)|hitter]], carty's career was marked by battles with injuries, illnesses and with team mates.<ref name=''rico carty: he's no longer the 'beeg boy''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=2tedaaaambaj&pg=pa74&lpg=pa74&dq=rico+carty+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=dng1vchjks&sig=zklqkir0nk6vvwjg8myiobkgztu&hl=en&ei=cyjntnvilswqlafzznwebq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0cbuq6aewaq#v=onepage&q=rico%20carty%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''rico carty: he's no longer the 'beeg boy'', by ron hudspeth, baseball digest, february 1973, vol. 32, no. 2, issn 0005-609x]</ref>

carty signed a contract with the [[milwaukee braves]] as a [[free agent]] in [[1959 milwaukee braves season|1959]].<ref name=rico carty trades and transactions at baseball almanac>[http://www.baseball-almanac.com/players/trades.php?p=cartyri01 rico carty trades and transactions at baseball almanac]</ref> while he was an excellent hitter, he had poor defensive skills.<ref name=''rico carty - the beeg boy finally makes it big''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=vdmdaaaambaj&pg=pa68&lpg=pa68&dq=rico+carty+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=1xmjf3myus&sig=bqaeyxmsahtxv5uvmcpj4wo3868&hl=en&ei=0zjntjfxlmoqlaeg9fgebq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0ccqq6aewbq#v=onepage&q=rico%20carty%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''rico carty - the beeg boy finally makes it big'', by priit vesilind, baseball digest, august 1970, vol. 29, no. 8, issn 0005-609x]</ref> originally a [[catcher]], carty was converted into an outfielder in order to lessen his defensive liabilities and to get his bat into the everday lineup.<ref name=''rico carty - the beeg boy finally makes it big''/> after four years in the [[minor league baseball|minor leagues]], carty made an impressive major league debut in [[1964 milwaukee braves season|1964]], finishing second to [[roberto clemente]] in the national league batting championship with a .330 [[batting average]] and, finishing the season as runner-up to [[dick allen]] in the {{by|1964}} [[national league]] [[major league baseball rookie of the year award|rookie of the year award]] ballot.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1964-batting-leaders.shtml 1964 national league batting leaders at baseball reference]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1964.shtml#nlroy 1964 national league rookie of the year award ballot results at baseball reference]</ref>

carty had his best season in [[1970 atlanta braves season|1970]] when he hit 25 [[home run]]s with 101 [[runs batted in]] and, won the national league [[list of major league baseball batting champions|batting championship]] with a .366 batting average, the highest average in the major leagues since [[ted williams]] recorded a .388 batting average in {{by|1957}}.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1970-batting-leaders.shtml 1970 national league batting leaders at baseball reference]</ref> despite not appearing on the [[major league baseball all-star game|all-star]] ballot, he was voted to be a starting outfielder for the national league as a write-in candidate in the [[1970 major league baseball all-star game|1970 all-star game]], playing alongside [[hank aaron]] and [[willie mays]] in the outfield.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=di8daaaambaj&pg=pa10&lpg=pa10&dq=rico+carty+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=13xbmw2ugs&sig=bbo-zfw22yv9fiui8ciufc63ula&hl=en&ei=c8lntigrmoh7lwedmoihbq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0cdiq6aewcdgu#v=onepage&q=rico%20carty%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, july 1986, vol. 45, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/nls/nls197007140.shtml 1970 all-star game at baseball reference]</ref> carty also compiled a 31-game [[hitting streak]] in {{by|1970}} (the longest by a brave in the franchise's atlanta history until it was surpassed by [[dan uggla]]'s 33-game streak in {{by|2011}}) and, finished 10th in the 1970 national league most valuable player award voting.<ref name=''rico carty - the beeg boy finally makes it big''/><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1970.shtml#nlmvp 1970 national league most valuable player award voting results at baseball reference]</ref>

a crushed knee injury suffered during the [[dominican winter baseball league|dominican winter baseball]] season meant that carty would miss another entire season in [[1971 atlanta braves season|1971]].<ref name=''rico carty: he's no longer the 'beeg boy''/> he returned in [[1972 atlanta braves season|1972]], but only managed a .277 batting average. by then, carty had worn out his welcome with the braves management as well as his teammates, having been involved in fights with hank aaron and [[ron reed]].<ref name=''rico carty: he's no longer the 'beeg boy''/> in october {{by|1972}}, he was traded to the [[1973 texas rangers season|texas rangers]] to fill the role of the newly-adopted [[designated hitter]].<ref name=rico carty trades and transactions at baseball almanac/> carty had difficulty adjusting to the hitting-only position, hitting for only a .232 average before being traded in mid-season to the [[1973 chicago cubs season|chicago cubs]].<ref name=''designated hitter born 25 years ago''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=ui0daaaambaj&pg=pa80&lpg=pa80&dq=rico+carty+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=wu8g5j_yry&sig=n2bxo5ijweqs7icb7znj9vtx8zu&hl=en&ei=hdtntjnze4kklwfsvdwebq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0cbwq6aewazgu#v=onepage&q=rico%20carty%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''designated hitter born 25 years ago'', by bruce markusen, baseball digest, july 1998, vol. 57, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref> while with the cubs, he had a personality clash with their star third baseman, [[ron santo]], forcing the team to trade carty to the [[1973 oakland athletics season|oakland athletics]] one month later.<ref name=rico carty trades and transactions at baseball almanac/><ref name=''designated hitter born 25 years ago''/> with a combined .229 batting average for the three teams, carty was released by the athletics in december {{by|1973}} and, it seemed as if his career might be over.<ref name=rico carty at baseball reference/>

dyer>{{cite web|url=http://bioproj.sabr.org/bioproj.cfm?a=v&v=l&bid=1913&pid=3930|title=the baseball biography project: duffy dyer|author=ulrey, adam |publisher=society for american baseball research|accessdate=10 november 2010}}</ref> he was drafted by the mets in the [[1966 major league baseball draft]] and backed up [[jerry grote]] as a member of the [[1969 new york mets season|1969 miracle mets]] team that went on to win the [[1969 world series|world series]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thebaseballcube.com/draft/1966/round-1-2.shtml |title=1966 june secondary draft round 1 |publisher=thebaseballcube.com |accessdate=10 november 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/nym/1969.shtml |title=1969 new york mets batting, pitching, & fielding series |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=10 november 2010 }}</ref> dyer caught most of the mets games in [[1972 new york mets season|1972]], as grote battled injuries.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/nym/1972.shtml |title=1972 new york mets season |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=10 november 2010 }}</ref> in 94 games, he posted career-highs with 8 [[home run]]s and 36 [[runs batted in]].<ref name=duffy dyer/> he also led national league catchers in [[double play]]s and in baserunners [[caught stealing]], finished second in [[assist (baseball)|assists]] and, third in [[fielding percentage]].<ref name=duffy dyer/> in [[1973 new york mets season|1973]], dyer was part of the mets team that staged another miraculous season when they came from last place on august 30 to win the [[national league eastern division]] [[pennant (sports)|pennant]].<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ui4daaaambaj&pg=pa20&dq=pennant+races+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=w_lqtniffysclgfx4ocbdq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0cc0q6aewaq#v=onepage&q=pennant%20races%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=six greatest pennant races of the last 50 years |author=vass, george |publisher=books.google.com |date=september 1991 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=3 november 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web in october [[1974 in baseball|1974]], dyer was traded to the pirates for [[gene clines]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-almanac.com/players/trades.php?p=dyerdu01 |title=duffy dyer trades and transactions |publisher=baseball almanac |accessdate=10 november 2010 }}</ref> he backed up [[manny sanguillen]] and helped the pirates win the [[1975 pittsburgh pirates season|1975]] [[national league eastern division]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/pit/1975.shtml |title=1975 pittsburgh pirates batting, pitching, & fielding statistics |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=10 november 2010 }}</ref> dyer was the pirates catcher on august 9, [[1976 pittsburgh pirates season|1976]], when [[john candelaria]] [[pitcher|pitched]] a [[no hitter]] against the [[1976 los angeles dodgers season|los angeles dodgers]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/pit/pit197608090.shtml |title=august 9, 1976 dodgers-pirates box score |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=10 november 2010 }}</ref> in [[1977 pittsburgh pirates season|1977]] the pirates traded away sanguillen, and dyer shared catching duties with [[ed ott]] in a [[platoon system]]. dyer led national league catchers in 1977 with a .996 [[fielding percentage]], committing only two [[error (baseball)|errors]] in 93 games.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa86&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=fielding leaders |publisher=books.google.com |date=july 2001 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=24 october 2010 }}</ref>

later in his career, davis improved on defense. during his great offensive seasons in 1983 and 1984, defense was somewhat of a challenge for him; in 1983 alone, he had 13 [[error (baseball)|errors]] and 21 [[passed ball]]s.<ref name=jody davis at baseball reference/> however, by [[1985 chicago cubs season|1985]] with the help of coach and former catcher, [[johnny oates]], he had his defensive problems under control; his passed balls decreased, as did his errors.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=qjqdaaaambaj&pg=pa20&dq=jody+davis+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=3ts8tittjcwalaf8y5gudq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0ccsq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=jody%20davis%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=jody davis of the cubs: catcher with a mission |author=mitchell, fred |publisher=books.google.com |date=june 1987 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=18 october 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/d/davisjo02.shtml#standard_fielding |title=jody davis fielding statistics |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=18 october 2010 }}</ref> in [[1986 chicago cubs season|1986]] he led national league catchers in [[putouts]], [[assist (baseball)|assists]] and baserunners [[caught stealing]] and, finished second to [[bob brenly]] in [[fielding percentage]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1986-fielding-leaders.shtml |title=1986 national league fielding leaders |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=18 october 2010 }}</ref> his defensive improvement resulted in his first and only [[gold glove award]] and, earned him his second [[1986 major league baseball all-star game|all-star game]] appearance.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/gold_glove_nl.shtml#1986 |title=1986 gold glove award winners |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=18 october 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/nls/nls198607150.shtml |title=1986 all-star game |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=18 october 2010 }}</ref>

* [http://books.google.com/books?id=qjqdaaaambaj&pg=pa20&dq=jody+davis+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=3ts8tittjcwalaf8y5gudq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0ccsq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=jody%20davis%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''jody davis of the cubs: catcher with a mission'', baseball digest, june 1987]

|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/d/davisjo02.shtml#standard_fielding |title=jody davis fielding statistics |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=18 october 2010 }}</ref> in [[1986 chicago cubs season|1986]] he led national league catchers in [[putouts]], [[assist (baseball)|assists]] and baserunners [[caught stealing]] and, finished second to [[bob brenly]] in [[fielding percentage]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1986-fielding-leaders.shtml |title=1986 national league fielding leaders |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=18 october 2010 }}</ref> when davis broke the 100 assists barrier in {{by|1986}}, he joined [[johnny bench]], [[jim sundberg]], [[gary carter]] and [[tony pea]] as the only catchers to have more than 100 assists in a season since the end of the second world war.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leaders/a_c_leagues.shtml |title=yearly league leaders & records for assists as catchers |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=5 january 2011 }}</ref> his defensive improvement resulted in his first and only [[gold glove award]] and, earned him his second [[1986 major league baseball all-star game|all-star game]] appearance.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/gold_glove_nl.shtml#1986 |title=1986 gold glove award winners |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=18 october 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/nls/nls198607150.shtml |title=1986 all-star game |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=18 october 2010 }}</ref>

later in his career, davis improved on defense. during his great offensive seasons in 1983 and 1984, defense was somewhat of a challenge for him; in 1983 alone, he had 13 [[error (baseball)|errors]] and 21 [[passed ball]]s.<ref name=jody davis at baseball reference/> however, by [[1985 chicago cubs season|1985]] with the help of [[coach (baseball)|coach]] and former catcher, [[johnny oates]], he had his defensive problems under control; his passed balls decreased, as did his errors.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=qjqdaaaambaj&pg=pa20&dq=jody+davis+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=3ts8tittjcwalaf8y5gudq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0ccsq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=jody%20davis%20baseball%20digest&f=false in [[1940 detroit tigers season|1940]], york was converted into a [[first baseman]], leaving tebbetts in sole possession of the catcher's position.<ref>{{cite news |title=york to first base |agency=associated press |work=lawrence journal-world |page=6 |date=27 january 1940 |accessdate=29 june 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=idndaaaaibaj&sjid=xvonaaaaibaj&pg=3520,253948&dq=birdie+tebbetts&hl=en}}</ref> he responded by posting a .296 [[batting average]] as the tigers defeated the [[1940 cleveland indians season|cleveland indians]] and the [[1940 new york yankees season|new york yankees]] in a tight pennant race to clinch the american league title.<ref name=birdie tebbetts at baseball reference/> tebbetts was held hitless in the [[1940 world series]] as the tigers lost to the [[1940 cincinnati reds season|cincinnati reds]] in a seven-game series.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1940_ws.shtml |title=1940 world series |publisher=baseball-reference.com |accessdate=28 june 2011}}</ref> he once again led american league catchers in assists and in baserunners caught stealing.<ref name=birdie tebbetts at baseball reference/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/al/1940-fielding-leaders.shtml |title=1940 american league fielding leaders |publisher=baseball-reference.com |accessdate=28 june 2011}}</ref> in september, tebbetts had been charged with assault and battery during a game in cleveland when a basket of tomatoes was dropped on him by a cleveland fan.<ref>{{cite news |title=detroit catcher sued for attack on cleveland fan |agency=associated press |work=the evening independent |page=12 |date=30 september 1940 |accessdate=28 june 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=7efpaaaaibaj&sjid=rfqdaaaaibaj&pg=5747,5756661&dq=birdie+tebbetts&hl=en}}</ref> as police held the fan, tebbetts rushed up and struck him. the charges were later dismissed.<ref>{{cite news |title=dismissed |agency=associated press |work=the telegraph-herald |page= |date=26 january 1941 |accessdate=28 june 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=e3bfaaaaibaj&sjid=hbwmaaaaibaj&pg=5129,5411327&dq=birdie+tebbetts&hl=en}}</ref> he developed a reputation for antagonizing opposing players, constantly hectoring them in an effort to have them make mistakes and give his team an advantage.<ref name=backstop: a history of the catcher and a sabermetric ranking of 50 all-time greats/><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=hi4daaaambaj&pg=pa59&dq=birdie+tebbetts+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=nkiuttxjeoro0qh8-7s0dg&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0ceqq6aewbw#v=onepage&q=birdie%20tebbetts%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=i'd rather catch |author=tebbetts, birdie |publisher=books.google.com |date=october 1949 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=6 july 2011 }}</ref>

* [http://books.google.com/books?id=hi4daaaambaj&pg=pa57&dq=birdie+tebbetts+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=6dsutvdwn4a20agi35yzdg&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0ceqq6aewbw#v=onepage&q=birdie%20tebbetts%20baseball%20digest&f=false i'd rather catch] by birdie tebbetts, baseball digest, october 1949

in a 15 year career, tenace played in 1555 [[games played|games]], accumulating 1060 [[hit (baseball)|hits]] in 4390 [[at bats]] for a .241 career batting average along with 201 home runs, 674 runs batted in and an [[on base percentage]] of .388.<ref name=gene tenace at baseball reference/> he not only caught nearly 900 games, but also played [[first baseman|first base]] over 600 times.<ref name=gene tenace at baseball reference/> tenace ended his career with a .986 [[fielding percentage]] as a catcher and a .993 fielding percentage as a first baseman.<ref name=gene tenace at baseball reference/> he reached 20 home runs in five of his seven seasons as a regular, with a high of 29 in {{by|1975}}.<ref name=gene tenace at baseball reference/> after becoming an everyday player in [[1973 oakland athletics season|1973]], he did not have an on-base average below .370 until his final year; his obp was above .400 five times and over .390 (about 60 points above the league average) an additional three times, ending his career with an impressive .388 on base percentage.<ref name=gene tenace at baseball reference/> six times he drew more than 100 bases on balls, and he led his league twice.<ref name=gene tenace at baseball reference/> he set the american league record for having the lowest batting average while leading the league in walks in {{by|1974}} when he posted a .211 batting average with a league-leading 110 walks.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=mdidaaaambaj&pg=pa14&lpg=pa14&dq=gene+tenace+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=fmaefqfzhi&sig=3nvejkoqm1h3bntsr9481mvdh7o&hl=en&ei=dkwqtmrdg9guswabkeg6da&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&sqi=2&ved=0cbuq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=gene%20tenace%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=lowest batting average while leading the league in walks |publisher=books.google.com |date=november 1988 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=4 october 2010 }}</ref> in {{by|1977}}, he had a .415 on base percentage while posting a .233 batting average, the second lowest batting average with a .400 on base percentage in major league history.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=gs4daaaambaj&pg=pa15&lpg=pa15&dq=gene+tenace+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=4fxz-pycae&sig=ymov8idjoeaydp0yqcgwjnd6bco&hl=en&ei=v0yqtnljfik0lqe3uo2kdq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0cdaq6aewcdgk#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=lowest batting average with .400 on base percentage |publisher=books.google.com |date=june 2004 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=4 october 2010 }}</ref> less than half of his career trips to first base came via base hits, reaching 1,075 times through walks (984) and being [[hit by pitch|hit by pitches]] (91) as opposed to only 1,060 hits.

his obp was above .400 five times and over .390 (about 60 points above the league average) an additional three times, ending his career with an impressive .388 on base percentage.<ref name=gene tenace at baseball reference/> six times he drew more than 100 bases on balls, and he led his league twice.<ref name=gene tenace at baseball reference/> he set the american league record for having the lowest batting average while leading the league in walks in {{by|1974}} when he posted a .211 batting average with a league-leading 110 walks.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=mdidaaaambaj&pg=pa14&lpg=pa14&dq=gene+tenace+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=fmaefqfzhi&sig=3nvejkoqm1h3bntsr9481mvdh7o&hl=en&ei=dkwqtmrdg9guswabkeg6da&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&sqi=2&ved=0cbuq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=gene%20tenace%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=lowest batting average while leading the league in walks |publisher=books.google.com |date=november 1988 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=4 october 2010 }}</ref> in {{by|1977}}, he had a .415 on base percentage while posting a .233 batting average, the second lowest batting average with a .400 on base percentage in major league history.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=gs4daaaambaj&pg=pa15&lpg=pa15&dq=gene+tenace+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=4fxz-pycae&sig=ymov8idjoeaydp0yqcgwjnd6bco&hl=en&ei=v0yqtnljfik0lqe3uo2kdq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0cdaq6aewcdgk#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=lowest batting average with .400 on base percentage |publisher=books.google.com |date=june 2004 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=4 october 2010 }}</ref> less than half of his career trips to first base came via base hits, reaching 1,075 times through walks (984) and being [[hit by pitch]]es (91) as opposed to only 1,060 hits.

named manager of the last-place braves after the 1912 season, stallings raised boston to fifth place in the nl in his first season, 1913, but the braves were sunk at the bottom of the eight-team league and 11 games from the frontrunning [[san francisco giants|new york giants]] on july 15, 1914 when they began their meteoric rise.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=as0daaaambaj&pg=pa84&dq=hank+gowdy+baseball+digest&cd=3#v=onepage&q=hank%20gowdy%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''how losing an exhibition sparked miracle braves'', by joseph m. overfield, baseball digest, may 1961, vol. 20, no. 4, issn 0005-609x]</ref> with stallings expertly handling a roster of light hitters (boston hit only .251 as a team) and relying on pitchers [[dick rudolph]] and [[seattle bill james|bill james]] (who each won 26 games), the braves won 52 of their final 66 contests to overtake the other seven national league teams and finish 10 games in front of the second-place giants.<ref>[http://www.thisgreatgame.com/1914.html the 1914 boston braves at www.thisgreatgame.com]</ref> they then defeated the heavily favored [[1914 philadelphia athletics season|philadelphia athletics]] in four straight games to earn the nickname miracle braves.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1914_ws.shtml 1914 world series at baseball reference]</ref><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=2c4daaaambaj&pg=pa30&lpg=pa30&dq=1914+boston+braves+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=nygtwm4v81&sig=elgkgxnpkd-omqyqvyosk_54sku&hl=en&ei=z9lltjumcyp58aah6luy&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0ccuq6aewbq#v=onepage&q&f=false ''down to the wire; six greatest stretch runs for the pennant'' by george vass, baseball digest, sep 2001, vol. 60, no. 9, issn 0005-609x]</ref>

'''benito santiago rivera''' (born march 9, 1965 in [[ponce, puerto rico]]) is a puerto rican former [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] player.<ref name=benito santiago statistics>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/s/santibe01.shtml |title=benito santiago statistics |publisher=baseball-reference.com |accessdate=19 october 2011}}</ref> he played for twenty seasons as a [[catcher]] in [[major league baseball]] from {{by|1986}} to {{by|2005}}, most notably for the [[san diego padres]].<ref name=benito santiago statistics/> in the late 1980s and early 1990s, santiago was considered the premier catcher in the [[national league]].<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=pcsdaaaambaj&pg=pa24&dq=benito+santiago+baseball+digest&hl=en#v=onepage&q=benito%20santiago%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=here's an all-overpaid team of major leaguers |author=vass, george |publisher=books.google.com |date=june 1995 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=19 october 2011 }}</ref>

while santiago initially made an impression with his offensive statistics, he soon became known for his defensive prowess, most notably for his strong throwing arm.<ref name=mavbe they ought to call him 'shotgun' santiago>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=sjqdaaaambaj&pg=pa41&dq=benito+santiago+baseball+digest&hl=en#v=onepage&q=benito%20santiago%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=mavbe they ought to call him 'shotgun' santiago |author=reinman, t.r. |publisher=books.google.com |date=december 1988 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=19 october 2011 }}</ref> santiago was known for his ability to throw out would be [[stolen base|base stealers]] from a kneeling position.<ref name=mavbe they ought to call him 'shotgun' santiago/> in [[1988 san diego padres season|1988]], he led national league catchers in [[assist (baseball)|assists]] and in baserunners [[caught stealing]] with a 45% average when the league average was 30%.<ref name=mavbe they ought to call him 'shotgun' santiago/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1988-fielding-leaders.shtml |title=1988 national league fielding leaders |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=19 october 2011 }}</ref> although he still led the league's catchers with 12 errors, it was an improvement over the 22 he had committed the previous season. santiago was awarded the first of three consecutive [[gold glove award]]s in {{by|1988}}.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/gold_glove_nl.shtml#1988 |title=1988 national league gold glove award winners |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=19 october 2011 }}</ref> santiago also claimed his second succesive silver slugger award as the padres improved to finish in third place in the [[national league west|national league western division]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/silver_slugger_nl.shtml#1988 |title=1988 silver slugger award winners |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=19 october 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1988.shtml |title=1988 national league team statistics and standings |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=19 october 2011 }}</ref>

in [[2003 san francisco giants season|2003]], the 38 year old santiago continued to perform well, hitting fifth in the [[batting order (baseball)|batting order]] behind [[barry bonds]], he appeared in 108 games while posting a .279 batting average with 56 runs batted in.<ref name=benito santiago statistics/><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=lysdaaaambaj&pg=pa52&dq=benito+santiago+baseball+digest&hl=en#v=onepage&q=benito%20santiago%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=armed behind the plate |author=peters, nick |publisher=books.google.com |date=september 2003 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=19 october 2011 }}</ref>

it has often been pointed out that three of the 1947 series' prominent figures, gionfriddo, lavagetto and bevens, finished their playing careers in this series. gionfriddo, in fact, did not play in game 7, and his famous catch of dimaggio's drive was his only put-out in this game. so gionfriddo's famous catch was his final put-out in his major league career.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=2tedaaaambaj&pg=pa70&lpg=pa70&dq=al+gionfriddo+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=dnd4vgoaqp&sig=sdbm9rvlkbvaku0dpgxohf648re&hl=en&ei=ljnmsoocoomxtge8tyhpaq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1#v=onepage&q=al%20gionfriddo%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''gionfriddo recalls his famous catch'' by dave distel, baseball digest, february 1973, vol. 32, no. 2, issn 0005-609x]</ref>

* [http://books.google.com/books?id=2tedaaaambaj&pg=pa70&lpg=pa70&dq=al+gionfriddo+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=dnd4vgoaqp&sig=sdbm9rvlkbvaku0dpgxohf648re&hl=en&ei=ljnmsoocoomxtge8tyhpaq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1#v=onepage&q=al%20gionfriddo%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''gionfriddo recalls his famous catch'' in baseball digest, february 1973]

following his playing retirement, desautels managed the [[williamsport tigers]] of the [[eastern league (baseball)|eastern league]] for three years from {{by|1947}} to {{by|1949}}.<ref name=the baseball biography project: gene desautels/> he then managed the class-a [[flint arrows]], a tigers [[farm team]].<ref name=gene desautels minor league manager record at baseball reference>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/minors/player.cgi?id=desaut001eug#standard_managing gene desautels minor league manager record at baseball reference]</ref> in {{by|1951}}, he managed the double a [[little rock travelers]] to their first [[southern association]] [[pennant (sports)|pennant]] in nine years.<ref name=the baseball biography project: gene desautels/> desautels moved on to manage the [[indianapolis indians]] in {{by|1952}}, and the [[triple-a (baseball)|triple-a]] [[sacramento solons]] from {{by|1953}} to {{by|1954}}.<ref name=gene desautels minor league manager record at baseball reference/> later in life, he served as a special counselor for flint, michigan high schools.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=kdmdaaaambaj&pg=pa58&lpg=pa58&dq=gene+desautels+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=3iecuzc-r-&sig=rnuvqy26hdroctpjxx3ia41d7dm&hl=en&ei=ahxgtomjh4x6lwff0ryxbq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0cbyq6aewaq#v=onepage&q=gene%20desautels%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''whatever became of...?'', by bob duvall, baseball digest, february 1970, vol. 29, no. 2, issn 0005-609x]</ref> he was inducted into the holy cross athletics hall of fame in 1981.<ref>[http://goholycross.cstv.com/hallfame/holy-hallfame.html holy cross athletics hall of fame]</ref>

thompson ended the season with career highs in batting average (.312), [[double (baseball)|doubles]] (30), home runs (19) and [[runs batted in]] (65).<ref name=robby thompson statistics/> although thompson was one of the best fielding second basemen in the national league, he was often overlooked in post-season awards because his playing career coincided with that of [[baseball hall of fame]] second baseman [[ryne sandberg]].<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=1yodaaaambaj&pg=pa36&dq=robby+thompson+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=vchxtcyddy2gtwfu4_judg&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0cc8q6aewag#v=onepage&q=robby%20thompson%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=middle infielders discuss techniques of 'turning two' |author=cunningham, bob |publisher=books.google.com |date=july 1995 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=5 march 2011 }}</ref> by {{by|1993}}, sandberg was past his prime and thompson finally received recognition when he won the [[gold glove award]] for fielding excellence and the [[silver slugger award]], which is awarded annually to the best [[batting (baseball)|offensive]] player at each [[baseball positions|position]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/gold_glove_nl.shtml#1993 |title=1993 gold glove award winners |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=3 march 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/silver_slugger_nl.shtml#1993 |title=1993 silver slugger award winners |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=3 march 2011 }}</ref> he was rewarded by the giants in november when he signed a three-year contract for $12 million, making him the second-highest paid second baseman in baseball after ryne sandberg.<ref>{{cite news |title=giants sign robby thompson |agency=associated press |work=lodi news-sentinel |page=15 |date=15 november 1993 |accessdate=3 march 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=6jqzaaaaibaj&sjid=utihaaaaibaj&pg=2537,1732736&dq=robby+thompson&hl=en}}</ref>

in an eleven-year major league career thompson played in 1,304 [[games played|games]], accumulating 1,187 [[hit (baseball)|hits]] in 4,612 [[at bats]] for a .257 career batting average along with 119 home runs, 458 [[runs batted in]] and a .329 [[on base percentage]].<ref name=robby thompson statistics/> he led the national league in triples in 1989 with 11 and he finished his career with a .983 [[fielding percentage]].<ref name=robby thompson statistics/> thompson led national league second basemen in double plays for three consecutive seasons from {{by|1990}} to {{by|1992}}.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=xiodaaaambaj&pg=pa46&dq=robby+thompson+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=vchxtcyddy2gtwfu4_judg&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0cccq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=robby%20thompson%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=in '93, robby thompson came of age as a clutch hitter |author=stone, larry |publisher=books.google.com |date=december 1993 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=5 march 2011 }}</ref> he [[hit for the cycle]] in a game on april 22, 1991.<ref>{{cite news |title=thompson hits for cycle; giants still lose 7-5 |agency=associated press |work=the albany herald |page=3 |date=23 april 1991 |accessdate=3 march 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ec9daaaaibaj&sjid=vk0maaaaibaj&pg=1012,3631392&dq=robby+thompson&hl=en}}</ref>

'''dennis dale denny mclain''' (born 29 march 1944) is an [[united states|american]] former professional [[baseball]] player.<ref name=denny mclain statistics>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/m/mclaide01.shtml |title=denny mclain statistics |publisher=baseball-reference.com |accessdate=22 december 2011}}</ref> he played as a [[pitcher]] in [[major league baseball]] for ten seasons, most notably for the [[detroit tigers]]. in 1968, mclain became the last [[pitcher]] in major league baseball to [[win (baseball)|win]] 30 or more games during a season (316) a feat accomplished by only thirteen players in the 20th century.<ref name=from the big time to the big house>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/classic/biography/s/mclain_denny.html |title=from the big time to the big house |author=acocella, nick|publisher=espn.go.com |accessdate=24 december 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com.sa/books?id=btqdaaaambaj&pg=pa8&dq=baseball+digest+30-game+winners&hl=en&sa=x&ei=bld7tq-fitcimqxwqpc6ag&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%2030-game%20winners&f=false |title=30-game winners since 1900 |author=|publisher=|date=october 1988 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=28 december 2011 }}</ref>

mclain was brash and outspoken, sometimes creating controversy by criticizing teammates and fans with little provocation.<ref name=the baseball biography project: denny mclain>{{cite web|url=http://bioproj.sabr.org/bioproj.cfm?a=v&v=l&bid=2308&pid=9345|title=the baseball biography project: denny mclain|last=armour|first=mark|publisher=society for american baseball research|accessdate=20 december 2011}}</ref> his stellar performance at the beginning of his professional baseball career was a marked contrast to his personal life, where he became associated with organized crime and was eventually convicted on charges of embezzlement and served time in prison.<ref name=the baseball biography project: denny mclain/><ref name=fallen star: the downfall of former pitcher denny mclain>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com.sa/books?id=2codaaaambaj&lpg=pa68&dq=baseball%20digest%20denny%20mclain&pg=pa68#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20denny%20mclain&f=false |title=fallen star: the downfall of former pitcher denny mclain |author=thomashoff, craig |publisher=|date=march 2002 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=23 december 2011 }}</ref>

in [[1967 detroit tigers season|1967]], the tigers hired former major league pitcher, [[johnny sain]], as their pitching coach.<ref name=jim northrup recalls his playing days with tigers>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com.sa/books?id=_isdaaaambaj&lpg=pa64&dq=baseball%20digest%20johnny%20sain%20denny%20mclain&pg=pa64#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=jim northrup recalls his playing days with tigers |author=sargent, jim |publisher=|date=february 2004 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=24 december 2011 }}</ref> sain helped develop mclain's pitching skills and taught him the psychology of pitching.<ref name=jim northrup recalls his playing days with tigers/><ref name=1968: year of the pitcher>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisgreatgame.com/1968.html |title=1968: year of the pitcher |publisher=thisgreatgame.com |accessdate=25 december 2011}}</ref> the 1967 season was a memorable one due to the tight four-way pennant race between the tigers, the [[1967 boston red sox season|boston red sox]], the [[1967 minnesota twins season|minnesota twins]] and the [[1967 chicago white sox season|chicago white sox]].<ref name=the baseball biography project: denny mclain/> mclain had an off year, finishing with a 1716 record and a 3.79 earned run average and was winless after 29 august.<ref name=denny mclain statistics/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/gl.cgi?id=mclaide01&t=p&year=1967 |title=1967 denny mclain pitching log |publisher=baseball-reference.com |accessdate=22 december 2011}}</ref> on 18 september, mclain reported that he had severely injured two toes on his left foot, saying that he had stubbed them after his foot had fallen asleep.<ref name=the baseball biography project: denny mclain/> going into the final game of the season against the [[1967 california angels season|california angels]], the tigers needed a victory to force a one-game playoff with the red sox for the american league pennant.<ref name=the baseball biography project: denny mclain/> mclain pitched ineffectively in the final game and the tigers lost to finish the season one game behind the red sox.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/al/1967.shtml |title=1967 american league team statistics and standings |publisher=baseball-reference.com |accessdate=22 december 2011}}</ref>

since mclain's 31 win season, only two other pitchers have approached the 30-game milestone ([[steve carlton]] won 27 games in 1972 and [[bob welch (baseball)|bob welch]] also with 27 victories in 1990.<ref name=will majors ever produce another 30-game winner?>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com.sa/books?id=iysdaaaambaj&pg=pa70&dq=baseball+digest+denny+mclain&hl=en&sa=x&ei=b8h0tpf4h-jzmaxj2kmpag&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20denny%20mclain&f=false |title=will majors ever produce another 30-game winner? |author=niedzielka, amy |publisher=|date=august 1993 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=23 december 2011 }}</ref> with major league baseball moving from the four-man pitching rotation of mclain's era to five-man rotations, and with the increased reliance on relief pitchers, some observers opine that there may not be another 30-game winner as the game is played today.<ref name=1968: year of the pitcher/><ref name=will majors ever produce another 30-game winner?/>

'''dennis dale denny mclain''' (born march 29, 1944) is an [[united states|american]] former professional [[baseball]] player.<ref name=denny mclain statistics>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/m/mclaide01.shtml |title=denny mclain statistics |publisher=baseball-reference.com |accessdate=december 22, 2011}}</ref> he played as a [[pitcher]] in [[major league baseball]] for ten seasons, most notably for the [[detroit tigers]]. in 1968, mclain became the last [[pitcher]] in major league baseball to [[win (baseball)|win]] 30 or more games during a season (316) a feat accomplished by only eleven players in the 20th century.<ref name=from the big time to the big house>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/classic/biography/s/mclain_denny.html |title=from the big time to the big house |author=acocella, nick|publisher=espn.go.com |accessdate=december 24, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com.sa/books?id=btqdaaaambaj&pg=pa8&dq=baseball+digest+30-game+winners&hl=en&sa=x&ei=bld7tq-fitcimqxwqpc6ag&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%2030-game%20winners&f=false |title=30-game winners since 1900 |author=|publisher=|date=october 1988 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=december 28, 2011 }}</ref>

mclain was brash and outspoken, sometimes creating controversy by criticizing teammates and fans with little provocation.<ref name=the baseball biography project: denny mclain>{{cite web|url=http://bioproj.sabr.org/bioproj.cfm?a=v&v=l&bid=2308&pid=9345|title=the baseball biography project: denny mclain|last=armour|first=mark|publisher=society for american baseball research|accessdate=december 20, 2011}}</ref> his stellar performance at the beginning of his professional baseball career was a marked contrast to his personal life, where he became associated with organized crime and was eventually convicted on charges of embezzlement and served time in prison.<ref name=the baseball biography project: denny mclain/><ref name=fallen star: the downfall of former pitcher denny mclain>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com.sa/books?id=2codaaaambaj&lpg=pa68&dq=baseball%20digest%20denny%20mclain&pg=pa68#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20denny%20mclain&f=false |title=fallen star: the downfall of former pitcher denny mclain |author=thomashoff, craig |publisher=|date=march 2002 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=december 23, 2011 }}</ref>

this is sometimes referred to as the most lopsided trade ever in baseball.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/page2/s/list/baseball/worst/deadlinedeals.html|accessdate=2009-09-19|publisher=espn.com|author=page 2 staff|title=worst baseball deadline trades}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=scsdaaaambaj&lpg=pa31&ots=ofyvcfjeku&dq=aaron%20robinson%20baseball%20digest&pg=pa32#v=onepage&q=aaron%20robinson%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=these were the ten most lopsided player trades |author=gold, eddie |publisher=books.google.com |date=august 1996 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=19 april 2011 }}</ref>

this is sometimes referred to as the most lopsided trade ever in baseball.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/page2/s/list/baseball/worst/deadlinedeals.html|accessdate=2009-09-19|publisher=espn.com|author=page 2 staff|title=worst baseball deadline trades}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=scsdaaaambaj&lpg=pa31&ots=ofyvcfjeku&dq=aaron%20robinson%20baseball%20digest&pg=pa32#v=onepage&q=aaron%20robinson%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=these were the ten most lopsided player trades |author=gold, eddie |publisher=books.google.com |date=august 1996 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=19 april 2011 }}</ref>

this is sometimes referred to as the most lopsided trade in baseball history.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/page2/s/list/baseball/worst/deadlinedeals.html|accessdate=2009-09-19|publisher=espn.com|author=page 2 staff|title=worst baseball deadline trades}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=scsdaaaambaj&lpg=pa31&ots=ofyvcfjeku&dq=aaron%20robinson%20baseball%20digest&pg=pa32#v=onepage&q=aaron%20robinson%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=these were the ten most lopsided player trades |author=gold, eddie |publisher=books.google.com |date=august 1996 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=19 april 2011 }}</ref>

masi is best known for a [[pick off]] play attempted by [[1948 cleveland indians season|cleveland indians]] [[pitcher]] [[bob feller]] and [[shortstop]] [[lou boudreau]] in the [[1948 world series]].<ref name=the baseball biography project: phil masi/><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=zjqdaaaambaj&pg=pa50&dq=phil+masi+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=rwc8s7trd5ha9as1oyz1bw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0cdaq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=phil%20masi%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''major league baseball in the 1940s'', by art ahrens, baseball digest, february 1978, vol. 37, no. 2, issn 0005-609x]</ref><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=etmdaaaambaj&pg=pa22&dq=phil+masi+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=rwc8s7trd5ha9as1oyz1bw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0cdoq6aewag#v=onepage&q&f=false ''memorable world series controversies'', by george vass, baseball digest, october 1972, vol. 31, no. 10, issn 0005-609x]</ref> in the bottom of the eighth [[inning]] of game one, masi [[pinch runner|pinch-ran]] for catcher [[bill salkeld]]. [[mike mccormick (outfielder)|mike mccormick]] hit a [[sacrifice bunt]] to advance masi to [[second base]]. feller [[intentional walk|intentionally walked]] [[eddie stanky]], who was replaced by [[sibby sisti]]. feller then tried to pick masi off of second base. [[lou boudreau]] appeared to tag masi [[out (baseball)|out]], but [[umpire (baseball)|umpire]] bill stewart called him [[safe (baseball)|safe]]. [[tommy holmes]] then [[single (baseball)|singled]] masi home with the only [[run (baseball)|run]] of the game to give the braves a 1-0 victory.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/bsn/bsn194810060.shtml 1948 world series game 1 box score at baseball reference]</ref> although this gave the braves a 1-0 lead in games, the indians bounced back to win the world series in six games.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1948_ws.shtml 1948 world series at baseball reference]</ref>

in a 14-season career, masi posted a .264 [[batting average]] with 47 [[home run]]s and 417 [[run batted in|rbi]] in 1229 [[games played]].<ref name=phil masi at baseball reference/> masi's best season was [[1947 boston braves season|1947]], when he batted .304, with 9 home runs, 50 rbi and 22 [[double (baseball)|doubles]].<ref name=phil masi at baseball reference/> he made four consecutive [[mlb all-star game|all-star game]] appearances between 1945-48.<ref name=phil masi at baseball reference/> masi led national league catchers with a .989 [[fielding percentage]] in 1947, and led all american league catchers in 1950 with a .996 fielding percentage, committing only two [[error (baseball)|errors]] in 114 games.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa86&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, july 2001, p.86, vol. 60, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref> over his career, he committed only 72 [[error (baseball)|errors]] in 4,257 [[total chances|chances]] for a career .982 fielding percentage. a fast running [[catcher]], he collected 45 [[stolen base]]s in his career and was often used in [[pinch runner|pinch-running]] duties.

* [http://books.google.com/books?id=zjqdaaaambaj&pg=pa50&dq=phil+masi+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=rwc8s7trd5ha9as1oyz1bw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0cdaq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=phil%20masi%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''major league baseball in the 1940s'', by art ahrens, baseball digest, february 1978]

'''philip samuel masi''' (january 6, 1916{{endash}} march 29, 1990) was an [[united states|american]] [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] player.<ref name=phil masi statistics>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/m/masiph01.shtml?redir |title=phil masi statistics |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=12 march 2011 }}</ref> from {{by|1939}} though {{by|1952}}, he played in [[major league baseball]] as a [[catcher]] for the [[atlanta braves|boston braves]] (19391949), [[pittsburgh pirates]] (1949) and [[chicago white sox]] (19501952).<ref name=phil masi statistics/> although he was known for being one of the best defensive catchers of his era, masi was best known for a controversial play that occurred during the [[1948 world series]] between the boston braves and the cleveland indians.<ref name=the baseball biography project: phil masi>{{cite web|url=http://bioproj.sabr.org/bioproj.cfm?a=v&v=l&bid=1452&pid=8926|title=the baseball biography project: phil masi|last=mcmurray|first=john|publisher=society for american baseball research|accessdate=7 april 2010}}</ref><ref name=major league baseball in the 1940s>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=zjqdaaaambaj&pg=pa50&dq=phil+masi+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=rwc8s7trd5ha9as1oyz1bw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0cdaq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=phil%20masi%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=major league baseball in the 1940s |author=ahrens, art |publisher=books.google.com |date=february 1978 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=12 march 2011 }}</ref>

it was in the first game of the [[1948 world series]] held at [[braves field]] against the favored [[1948 cleveland indians season|cleveland indians]] that masi would become embroiled in a controversy that secured his place in baseball history.<ref name=major league baseball in the 1940s/><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=etmdaaaambaj&pg=pa22&dq=phil+masi+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=rwc8s7trd5ha9as1oyz1bw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0cdoq6aewag#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=memorable world series controversies |author=vass, george |publisher=books.google.com |date=october 1972 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=12 march 2011 }}</ref> braves pitcher johnny sain and indians pitcher, [[bob feller]] were engaged in a scoreless pitchers' duel when the braves came to bat in the bottom of the eighth [[inning]]. feller [[base on balls|walked]] braves catcher [[bill salkeld]] to open the inning. braves manager, [[billy southworth]] then substituted the slow-footed salkeld with masi, who entered the game as a [[pinch runner]]. [[mike mccormick (outfielder)|mike mccormick]] followed by hitting a [[sacrifice bunt]], advancing masi to [[second base]]. feller issued an [[intentional walk]] to [[eddie stanky]], who was replaced by [[sibby sisti]]. feller then made a [[pick off]] attempt of masi at second base. indians' shortstop, [[lou boudreau]], appeared to tag masi [[out (baseball)|out]], but [[umpire (baseball)|umpire]] bill stewart called him [[safe (baseball)|safe]].<ref name=the baseball biography project: phil masi/> [[tommy holmes]] proceeded to hit a [[single (baseball)|single]] that allowed masi to score the only [[run (baseball)|run]] of the game, giving the braves a 1-0 victory.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/bsn/bsn194810060.shtml |title=1948 world series game 1 box score |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=12 march 2011 }}</ref> the umpire's controversial ruling touched off heated debates among the media and fans, especially after [[associated press]] photographs of the play were published.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ozidaaaambaj&lpg=pa86&dq=phil%20masi%20baseball%20digest&pg=pa84#v=onepage&q=phil%20masi%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=pickoff play caused a storm in 1948 series |author=lebovitz, hal |publisher=books.google.com |date=october 1971 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=14 march 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=putout dispute still rages; was masi safe or not? |agency=associate press |work=prescott evening courier |page=5 |date=7 october 1948 |accessdate=13 march 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=zgalaaaaibaj&sjid=b1adaaaaibaj&pg=6286,1656034&dq=phil+masi&hl=en}}</ref> although the victory gave the braves a 1-0 lead in games, the indians bounced back to win the world series in six games.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1948_ws.shtml |title=1948 world series |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=12 march 2011 }}</ref>

* [http://books.google.com/books?id=zjqdaaaambaj&pg=pa50&dq=phil+masi+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=rwc8s7trd5ha9as1oyz1bw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0cdaq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=phil%20masi%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''major league baseball in the 1940s'', by art ahrens, baseball digest, february 1978]
