[[mike mccormick (outfielder)|mike mccormick]] followed by hitting a [[sacrifice bunt]], advancing masi to [[second base]]. feller issued an [[intentional walk]] to [[eddie stanky]], who was replaced by [[sibby sisti]]. feller then made a [[pick off]] attempt of masi at second base. indians' shortstop, [[lou boudreau]], appeared to tag masi [[out (baseball)|out]], but [[umpire (baseball)|umpire]] bill stewart called him [[safe (baseball)|safe]].<ref name=the baseball biography project: phil masi/> [[tommy holmes]] proceeded to hit a [[single (baseball)|single]] that allowed masi to score the only [[run (baseball)|run]] of the game, giving the braves a 1-0 victory.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/bsn/bsn194810060.shtml |title=1948 world series game 1 box score |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=12 march 2011 }}</ref> the umpire's controversial ruling touched off heated debates among the media and fans, especially after [[associated press]] photographs of the play were published.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ozidaaaambaj&lpg=pa86&dq=phil%20masi%20baseball%20digest&pg=pa84#v=onepage&q=phil%20masi%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=pickoff play caused a storm in 1948 series |author=lebovitz, hal |publisher=books.google.com |date=october 1971 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=14 march 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=putout dispute still rages; was masi safe or not? |agency=associate press |work=prescott evening courier |page=5 |date=7 october 1948 |accessdate=13 march 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=zgalaaaaibaj&sjid=b1adaaaaibaj&pg=6286,1656034&dq=phil+masi&hl=en}}</ref> although the victory gave the braves a 1-0 lead in games, the indians bounced back to win the world series in six games.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1948_ws.shtml |title=1948 world series |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=12 march 2011 }}</ref>

* [http://books.google.com/books?id=zjqdaaaambaj&pg=pa50&dq=phil+masi+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=rwc8s7trd5ha9as1oyz1bw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0cdaq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=phil%20masi%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''major league baseball in the 1940s'', by art ahrens, baseball digest, february 1978]

'''philip samuel masi''' (january 6, 1916{{spaced ndash}}march 29, 1990) was an [[united states|american]] professional [[baseball]] player.<ref name=phil masi statistics>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/m/masiph01.shtml?redir |title=phil masi statistics |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=12 march 2011 }}</ref> from {{by|1939}} though {{by|1952}}, he played in [[major league baseball]] as a [[catcher]] for the [[atlanta braves|boston braves]] (19391949), [[pittsburgh pirates]] (1949) and [[chicago white sox]] (19501952).<ref name=phil masi statistics/> although he was known for being one of the best defensive catchers of his era, masi was best known for a controversial play that occurred during the [[1948 world series]] between the boston braves and the cleveland indians.<ref name=the baseball biography project: phil masi>{{cite web|url=http://bioproj.sabr.org/bioproj.cfm?a=v&v=l&bid=1452&pid=8926|title=the baseball biography project: phil masi|last=mcmurray|first=john|publisher=society for american baseball research|accessdate=7 april 2010}}</ref><ref name=major league baseball in the 1940s>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=zjqdaaaambaj&pg=pa50&dq=phil+masi+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=rwc8s7trd5ha9as1oyz1bw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0cdaq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=phil%20masi%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=major league baseball in the 1940s |author=ahrens, art |publisher=books.google.com |date=february 1978 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=12 march 2011 }}</ref>

it was in the first game of the [[1948 world series]] held at [[braves field]] against the favored [[1948 cleveland indians season|cleveland indians]] that masi would become embroiled in a controversy that secured his place in baseball history.<ref name=major league baseball in the 1940s/><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=etmdaaaambaj&pg=pa22&dq=phil+masi+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=rwc8s7trd5ha9as1oyz1bw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0cdoq6aewag#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=memorable world series controversies |author=vass, george |publisher=books.google.com |date=october 1972 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=12 march 2011 }}</ref> braves pitcher johnny sain and indians pitcher, [[bob feller]] were engaged in a scoreless pitchers' duel when the braves came to bat in the bottom of the eighth [[inning]]. feller [[base on balls|walked]] braves catcher [[bill salkeld]] to open the inning. braves manager, [[billy southworth]] then substituted the slow-footed salkeld with masi, who entered the game as a [[pinch runner]]. [[mike mccormick (outfielder)|mike mccormick]] followed by hitting a [[sacrifice bunt]], advancing masi to [[second base]]. feller issued an [[intentional walk]] to [[eddie stanky]], who was replaced by [[sibby sisti]]. feller then made a [[pick off]] attempt of masi at second base. indians' shortstop, [[lou boudreau]], appeared to tag masi [[out (baseball)|out]], but [[umpire (baseball)|umpire]] bill stewart called him [[safe (baseball)|safe]].<ref name=the baseball biography project: phil masi/> [[tommy holmes]] proceeded to hit a [[single (baseball)|single]] that allowed masi to score the only [[run (baseball)|run]] of the game, giving the braves a 1-0 victory.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/bsn/bsn194810060.shtml |title=1948 world series game 1 box score |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=12 march 2011 }}</ref> the umpire's controversial ruling touched off heated debates among the media and fans, especially after [[associated press]] photographs of the play were published.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ozidaaaambaj&lpg=pa86&dq=phil%20masi%20baseball%20digest&pg=pa84#v=onepage&q=phil%20masi%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=pickoff play caused a storm in 1948 series |author=lebovitz, hal |publisher=books.google.com |date=october 1971 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=14 march 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=putout dispute still rages; was masi safe or not? |agency=associate press |work=prescott evening courier |page=5 |date=7 october 1948 |accessdate=13 march 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=zgalaaaaibaj&sjid=b1adaaaaibaj&pg=6286,1656034&dq=phil+masi&hl=en}}</ref> although the victory gave the braves a 1-0 lead in games, the indians bounced back to win the world series in six games.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1948_ws.shtml |title=1948 world series |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=12 march 2011 }}</ref>

* [http://books.google.com/books?id=zjqdaaaambaj&pg=pa50&dq=phil+masi+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=rwc8s7trd5ha9as1oyz1bw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0cdaq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=phil%20masi%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''major league baseball in the 1940s'', by art ahrens, baseball digest, february 1978]

[[1967 boston red sox season|1967]] was the season of the [[the impossible dream (1967)|impossible dream]] for the red sox (referring to the hit song from the musical play ''[[man of la mancha]]''), who rebounded from a ninth-place finish a year before to win the american league pennant (their first since {{by|1946}}) on the last day of the season.<ref name=1967 american league team statistics and standings at baseball reference>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/al/1967.shtml 1967 american league team statistics and standings at baseball reference]</ref> with the red sox battling as part of a four-team pennant race, yastrzemski hit .513 (23 hits in 44 at bats) with five home runs and 16 runs batted in over the last two weeks of the season, and finished a mere one game ahead of the [[detroit tigers]] and [[minnesota twins]].<ref name=1967 american league team statistics and standings at baseball reference/><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=tcsdaaaambaj&pg=pa66&dq=yastrzemski+baseball+digest&cd=2#v=onepage&q=yastrzemski%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''triple crown season in '67 marked high point for yaz'', by dan shaughnessy, baseball digest, august 1992, vol. 51, no. 8, issn 0005-609x]</ref> the red sox lost the [[1967 world series|world series]] four games to three to the [[st. louis cardinals]], losing three times to [[bob gibson]].<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1967_ws.shtml 1967 world series at baseball reference]</ref> in that season, yastrzemski also won the [[hickok belt]] as top professional athlete of the year and ''[[sports illustrated]]'' magazine's [[sportsman of the year]] award.

on may 19, [[1976 boston red sox season|1976]], yastrzemski hit three home runs against the detroit tigers at [[tiger stadium (detroit)|tiger stadium]].<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/det/det197605190.shtml may 19, 1976 red sox-tigers box score at baseball reference]</ref> he then went to [[yankee stadium]] and hit two more, tying the major league record of five home runs in two consecutive games.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=zdqdaaaambaj&pg=pa18&dq=carl+yastrzemski+baseball+digest&cd=1#v=onepage&q=carl%20yastrzemski%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''yastrzemski recalls his most memorable games'', by peter gammons, baseball digest, september 1981,vol. 40, no. 9, issn 0005-609x]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/nya/nya197605200.shtml may 20, 1976 red sox-yankees box score at baseball reference]</ref>

*[http://books.google.com/books?id=zdqdaaaambaj&pg=pa18&dq=carl+yastrzemski+baseball+digest&cd=1#v=onepage&q=carl%20yastrzemski%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''yastrzemski recalls his most memorable games''], by peter gammons, baseball digest, september 1981,vol. 40, no. 9, issn 0005-609x

[[1967 boston red sox season|1967]] was the season of the [[the impossible dream (1967)|impossible dream]] for the red sox (referring to the hit song from the musical play ''[[man of la mancha]]''), who rebounded from a ninth-place finish a year before to win the american league pennant (their first since {{by|1946}}) on the last day of the season.<ref name=1967 american league team statistics and standings at baseball reference>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/al/1967.shtml 1967 american league team statistics and standings at baseball reference]</ref> with the red sox battling as part of a four-team pennant race, yastrzemski hit .513 (23 hits in 44 at-bats) with five home runs and 16 runs batted in over the last two weeks of the season, and finished a mere one game ahead of the [[detroit tigers]] and [[minnesota twins]].<ref name=1967 american league team statistics and standings at baseball reference/><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=tcsdaaaambaj&pg=pa66&dq=yastrzemski+baseball+digest&cd=2#v=onepage&q=yastrzemski%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''triple crown season in '67 marked high point for yaz'', by dan shaughnessy, baseball digest, august 1992, vol. 51, no. 8, issn 0005-609x]</ref> the red sox went into the final two games of the season trailing the twins by 1 game and leading the tigers by 1/2 game. the red sox final two games were against minnesota with the pennant and home run title (and hence, the triple crown) on the line. in the saturday game, yaz went 3 for 4 with a home run and 4 rbi. klllebrew also homered, but the red sox won, 6-4. thus, the teams went into the final game tied for 1st place, and yaz and killebrew were tied with 44 home runs apiece. in the final game, neither player homered, but yaz went 4 for 4 with 2 rbi in the red sox 5-3 win. so in the two games with the pennant on the line, yastrzemski was 7 for 8 with 6 rbi

tettleton started the season in rochester but was soon called back to the major leagues where he shared catching duties with [[terry kennedy]] in [[1988 baltimore orioles season|1988]] and, improved his batting average significantly to a .261.<ref name=mickey tettleton statistics/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/bal/1988.shtml |title=1988 baltimore orioles |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=9 march 2011 }}</ref> [[1989 baltimore orioles season|1989]] was a breakout year for tettleton as he started the season hitting 13 home runs in april and may, setting a new major league record for catchers.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=bdqdaaaambaj&pg=pa63&dq=mickey+tettleton+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=brv2taaubs2gtweuv9mkbg&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0cccq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=mickey%20tettleton%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=mickey tettleton plays big role in orioles' revival |author=capezzuto, tom |publisher=books.google.com |date=september 1989 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=9 march 2011 }}</ref> he hit 20 home runs by midseason, earning him a place as a reserve player for the [[american league]] team in the [[1989 major league baseball all-star game|1989 all-star game]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/gl.cgi?id=tettlmi01&t=b&year=1989 |title=1989 mickey tettleton batting log |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=9 march 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/als/als198907110.shtml |title=1989 all-star game |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=9 march 2011 }}</ref> in august, tettleton had to undergo surgery to remove a cyst from his left knee and, missed almost one month.<ref>{{cite news |title=tettleton to miss at least 3 weeks |agency=associated press |work=the milwaukee sentinel |page=3 |date=8 august 1989 |accessdate=9 march 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=tytqaaaaibaj&sjid=yxieaaaaibaj&pg=7019,2499468&dq=mickey+tettleton&hl=en}}</ref> he finished the season with a .258 batting average, 26 home runs, 65 runs batted in and an impressive .369 [[on base percentage]], helping the orioles improve from last place in the [[american league east]] in 1988 to second place in 1989, two games behind the [[1989 toronto blue jays season|toronto blue jays]].<ref name=mickey tettleton statistics/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/al/1989.shtml |title=1989 american league standings |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=9 march 2011 }}</ref> tettleton's hitting performance earned him the {{by|1989}} american league [[silver slugger award]] which is awarded annually to the best [[batting (baseball)|offensive]] player at each [[baseball positions|position]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/silver_slugger_al.shtml#1989 |title=1989 silver slugger award winners |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=9 march 2011 }}</ref>

|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/gl.cgi?id=tettlmi01&t=b&year=1989 |title=1989 mickey tettleton batting log |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=9 march 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/als/als198907110.shtml |title=1989 all-star game |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=9 march 2011 }}</ref> in august, tettleton had to undergo surgery to remove a cyst from his left knee and, missed almost one month.<ref>{{cite news |title=tettleton to miss at least 3 weeks |agency=associated press |work=the milwaukee sentinel |page=3 |date=8 august 1989 |accessdate=9 march 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=tytqaaaaibaj&sjid=yxieaaaaibaj&pg=7019,2499468&dq=mickey+tettleton&hl=en}}</ref> he finished the season with a .258 batting average, 26 home runs, 65 runs batted in and an impressive .369 [[on base percentage]], helping the orioles improve from last place in the [[american league east]] in 1988 to second place in 1989, two games behind the [[1989 toronto blue jays season|toronto blue jays]].<ref name=mickey tettleton statistics/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/al/1989.shtml |title=1989 american league standings |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=9 march 2011 }}</ref> tettleton's hitting performance earned him the {{by|1989}} american league [[silver slugger award]] which is awarded annually to the best [[batting (baseball)|offensive]] player at each [[baseball positions|position]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/silver_slugger_al.shtml#1989 |title=1989 silver slugger award winners |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=9 march 2011 }}</ref>

'''juan antonio marichal snchez''' (born october 20, 1937 in laguna verde, [[dominican republic]]<ref name=juan marichal at baseball reference>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/m/maricju01.shtml juan marichal at baseball reference]</ref>) is a former [[right-handed]] [[pitcher]] in [[major league baseball]].<ref name=juan marichal at baseball reference/> playing for the [[san francisco giants]] most of his career, marichal was known for his high leg kick, pinpoint control and intimidation tactics, which included aiming pitches directly at the opposing batters' helmets.{{citation needed|date=january 2010}} marichal also played for the [[boston red sox]] and [[los angeles dodgers]] for the final two seasons of his career.<ref name=juan marichal at baseball reference/> although he won more games than any other pitcher during the 1960s, he appeared in only one [[world series]] game and he was often overshadowed by [[sandy koufax]] and [[bob gibson]] in post-season awards.<ref name=juan marichal: he was winningest pitcher of '60s>[http://books.google.com/books?id=ziodaaaambaj&pg=pa74&dq=juan+marichal+baseball+digest&cd=1#v=onepage&q=juan%20marichal%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''juan marichal: he was winningest pitcher of '60s'', by john lowe, baseball digest, august 1998, vol. 57, no. 8, issn 0005-609x]</ref><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=dzidaaaambaj&pg=pa31&dq=juan+marichal+baseball+digest&cd=2#v=onepage&q=juan%20marichal%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''juan marichal-a man in many shadows'', by michael r. lauletta, baseball digest, june 1970, vol. 29, no. 6, issn 0005-609x]</ref> marichal was inducted into the [[baseball hall of fame]] in [[baseball hall of fame balloting, 1983|1983]].<ref>[http://baseballhall.org/hof/marichal-juan juan marichal at the baseball hall of fame]</ref>

at age 21, may was a member of the [[1971 pittsburgh pirates season|pirates]] team that won the [[1971 world series]].<ref name=milt may at baseball reference/> in the seventh inning of game four of that series, his [[pinch-hitter|pinch-hit]] single drove in [[bob robertson]] with the winning run in a 4-3 pirate victory.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/pit/pit197110130.shtml 1971 world series game 4 box score at baseball reference]</ref> tragedy struck the pirates in late [[1972 in baseball|1972]], when [[outfielder]] [[roberto clemente]] died in a plane crash. may was slated to replace clemente in the pirates' lineup in [[1973 pittsburgh pirates season|1973]], with catcher [[manny sanguilln]] moving to right field.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=gzidaaaambaj&pg=pa46&lpg=pa46&dq=manny+sanguillen+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=mixudaysxo&sig=7eq4qpxvqh_pqugjcrx9xqdlst8&hl=en&ei=stiptku5eyp6lwecqiciba&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0cb8q6aewaw#v=onepage&q=manny%20sanguillen%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''manny sanguillen...out from clemente's shadow'', by bob lenoir, baseball digest, july 1975, vol. 34, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref> however the experiment ended by july when it was determined that sanguillen could not adjust to playing in the outfield and may was back on the pirates' bench.<ref name=milt may at br bull pen>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/bullpen/milt_may milt may at br bull pen]</ref>

after the 1973 season, may was traded to the [[houston astros]] for [[jerry reuss]].<ref name=milt may trades and transactions at baseball almanac/> he became the astros starting catcher, replacing veteran [[johnny edwards (baseball)|johnny edwards]].<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/hou/1974.shtml 1974 houston astros season at baseball reference]</ref> he led national league catchers with a .993 [[fielding percentage]] in [[1974 houston astros season|1974]].<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa86&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, july 2001, vol. 60, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref> may led all national league catchers in {{by|1975}} with 70 [[assist (baseball)|assists]] and 47 baserunners [[caught stealing]].<ref name=milt may at baseball reference/> he was also charged with 18 [[passed ball]]s in 1975 for the astros, who had [[knuckleball]]er [[joe niekro]] on their staff.<ref name=milt may at br bull pen/> on may 4, [[1975 houston astros season|1975]], may drove in [[bob watson]] for major league baseball's one millionth run.<ref name=topkin/>

the indians won the pennant despite a horrific incident at the [[polo grounds]] on august 16. yankees pitcher [[carl mays]], another of several ex-red sox players who had come the yankees' way, used a submarine (underhand) pitching style. he threw one up and in on cleveland shortstop [[ray chapman]], who tended to crowd the plate and apparently never saw the ball coming. chapman suffered a severe skull fracture, and died the following morning.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=miwdaaaambaj&pg=pa9&lpg=pa9&dq=chapman+mays+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=n_rjrvpk_q&sig=xks6butxlmmuhyw5wnoo6slgrk4&hl=en&ei=hrrvs4hsks2ptgeild2ebg&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0cagq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=chapman%20mays%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''my pitch that killed chapman was a strike!'' by phyllis propert, baseball digest, july 1957, vol. 16, no. 6, issn 0005-609x]</ref> mays was absolved of any wrongdoing, but the incident would haunt him for the rest of his life. meanwhile, the indians rallied around the memory of their shortstop, and won the season.

in an 11 year career, westrum played in 919 [[games played|games]], accumulating 503 [[hit (baseball)|hits]] in 2322 [[at bats]] for a .217 career batting average along with 96 home runs, 315 runs batted in, and a .356 [[on base percentage]].<ref name=wes westrum at baseball reference/> he ended his career with a .985 fielding percentage.<ref name=wes westrum at baseball reference/> in the 1950 season, he committed only one [[error (baseball)|error]] in 139 [[games played]], and had 21 [[double play]]s, the 11th highest season total for a catcher.<ref name=''turn back the clock, former catcher wes westrum recalls career with giants''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=aywdaaaambaj&pg=pa84&dq=wes+westrum+baseball+digest&cd=1#v=onepage&q=wes%20westrum%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''turn back the clock, former catcher wes westrum recalls career with giants'', by bob mayer, baseball digest, november 2001, vol. 60, no. 11, issn 0005-609x]</ref><ref>[http://members.tripod.com/bb_catchers/catchers/fieldsea.htm catchers double plays at the encyclopedia of catchers]</ref> his 1950 fielding percentage of .999 stood as a national league record for catchers, until it was surpassed by [[charles johnson (baseball, born 1971)|charles johnson]] in {{by|1997}}.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leaders/fielding_perc_c_season.shtml single-season fielding percentage leaders at baseball reference]</ref> westrum made the national league [[major league baseball all-star game|all-star]] teams in [[1952 major league baseball all-star game|1952]] and [[1953 major league baseball all-star game|1953]].<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/nls/nls195207080.shtml 1952 all-star game at baseball reference]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/nls/nls195307140.shtml 1953 all-star game at baseball reference]</ref> over his career he threw out .47% of the [[baserunning|base runners]] who tried [[stolen base|steal]] a base on him, ranking him 9th on the all-time list.<ref>[http://members.tripod.com/bb_catchers/catchers/8cfldcspct.htm catchers caught stealing at the encyclopedia of catchers]</ref> westrum played more games as a catcher than any other player in giants history (902).<ref>[http://members.tripod.com/bb_catchers/catchers/mostgame.htm most games caught for team at the encyclopedia of catchers]</ref>

in an 11 year career, westrum played in 919 [[games played|games]], accumulating 503 [[hit (baseball)|hits]] in 2322 [[at bats]] for a .217 career batting average along with 96 home runs, 315 runs batted in, and a .356 [[on base percentage]].<ref name=wes westrum at baseball reference/> he ended his career with a .985 fielding percentage.<ref name=wes westrum at baseball reference/> in the 1950 season, he committed only one [[error (baseball)|error]] in 139 [[games played]], and had 21 [[double play]]s, the 11th highest season total for a catcher.<ref name=''turn back the clock, former catcher wes westrum recalls career with giants''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=aywdaaaambaj&pg=pa84&dq=wes+westrum+baseball+digest&cd=1#v=onepage&q=wes%20westrum%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''turn back the clock, former catcher wes westrum recalls career with giants'', by bob mayer, baseball digest, november 2001, vol. 60, no. 11, issn 0005-609x]</ref><ref>[http://members.tripod.com/bb_catchers/catchers/fieldsea.htm catchers double plays at the encyclopedia of catchers]</ref>

many believe that this shift was first employed against ted williams in the 1940s, as thought up by then-[[cleveland indians|indians]] [[manager (baseball)|manager]] [[lou boudreau]]. however, it was first used against [[cy williams]] in the 1920s.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=zcodaaaambaj&pg=pa41&dq=eddie+yost+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=eh3gtouch4lhbqs36dsp&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0cdiq6aewajgk#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=20th century all-overlooked stars |author=vass, george |publisher=books.google.com |date=august 1999 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=27 may 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=4i0daaaambaj&pg=pa30&dq=ken+williams+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=i8lgtjnfbjyg4qa7zododw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0ceiq6aewbg#v=onepage&q=ken%20williams%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=baseball's forgotten stars |author=vass, george |publisher=books.google.com |date=july 2004 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=27 may 2012 }}</ref>

a contender for greatest upset of all time, the miracle braves were in last place on july 4, then roared on to win the [[national league]] pennant by {{frac|10|1|2}} games and sweep the stunned athletics.<ref>[http://www.thisgreatgame.com/1914.html the 1914 boston braves at www.thisgreatgame.com]</ref><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=as0daaaambaj&pg=pa84&dq=hank+gowdy+baseball+digest&cd=3#v=onepage&q=hank%20gowdy%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''how losing an exhibition sparked miracle braves'', by joseph m. overfield, baseball digest, may 1961, vol. 20, no. 4, issn 0005-609x]</ref> the braves' relatively unknown starting trio of pitchers, with a combined career record of 285245, outperformed the athletics vaunted rotation (929654) in all four games.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=2c4daaaambaj&pg=pa30&lpg=pa30&dq=1914+boston+braves+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=nygtwm4v81&sig=elgkgxnpkd-omqyqvyosk_54sku&hl=en&ei=z9lltjumcyp58aah6luy&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0ccuq6aewbq#v=onepage&q&f=false ''down to the wire; six greatest stretch runs for the pennant'' by george vass, baseball digest, sep 2001, vol. 60, no. 9, issn 0005-609x]</ref> [[hank gowdy]] hit .545 (6 of 11) with five extra-base hits and also drew five walks for boston in the series and was the difference maker in games 1 and 3.

next [[johnny bench]].<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=4zedaaaambaj&pg=pa4&lpg=pa5&dq=manny+sanguillen+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=cyx-9cnbrb&sig=zmjjun_zwjd1o5tddo47_dedd4e&hl=en&ei=jngptn-gj8oqlaffwqmpaw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0ccmq6aewbtge#v=onepage&q&f=false |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=-pdkaaaaibaj&sjid=siinaaaaibaj&pg=5193,2250469&dq=barry+foote&hl=en}}</ref> he made his major league debut with the expos on september 14, [[1973 montreal expos season|1973]] at the age of 21.<ref name=barry foote at baseball reference/> foote was highly regarded as a [[rookie]] by then-expos manager [[gene mauch]], who called him, the next [[johnny bench]].<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=4zedaaaambaj&pg=pa4&lpg=pa5&dq=manny+sanguillen+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=cyx-9cnbrb&sig=zmjjun_zwjd1o5tddo47_dedd4e&hl=en&ei=jngptn-gj8oqlaffwqmpaw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0ccmq6aewbtge#v=onepage&q&f=false |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=3jedaaaambaj&pg=pa71&dq=baseball+digest+november+1974&hl=en&ei=if00tndnkog88gb-1nwjaw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0cc0q6aewaa#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20november%201974&f=false born in [[staten island, new york]], majeski came out of the [[boston braves (baseball)|boston braves]] [[farm system]], making his major league debut with the team in [[1939 boston bees season|1939]], when they were known as the boston bees.<ref name=hank majeski at baseball reference/><ref name=''majestic majeski''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=ytidaaaambaj&pg=pa43&lpg=pa43&dq=hank+majeski+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=abeyv1xth8&sig=bcmyyspvkw4uzqnnhl4jgr4aknm&hl=en&ei=yolxtmthnml38aad97wzcw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0ccqq6aewbq#v=onepage&q=hank%20majeski%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''majestic majeski'', by ed rumill, baseball digest, july 1948, vol. 7, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref> he appeared in 109 games in {{by|1939}} but, then spent [[1940 boston bees season|1940]] shuttling between the bees and the [[minor league baseball|minor league]] [[newark bears (19261949)|newark bears]], a new york yankees farm team.<ref name=''majestic majeski''/> majeski was purchased by the new york yankees in [[1941 new york yankees season|1941]], and he continued to play for newark until he joined the [[united states coast guard]] in {{by|1943}}.<ref name=''majestic majeski''/> after being discharged at the end of world war ii, he rejoined the yankees for the [[1946 new york yankees season|1946]] season, appearing in only eight games before being purchased by [[connie mack (baseball)|connie mack's]] philadelphia athletics in june [[1946 philadelphia athletics season|1946]].<ref name=''majestic majeski''/>

* [http://books.google.com/books?id=ytidaaaambaj&pg=pa43&lpg=pa43&dq=hank+majeski+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=abeyv0xpab&sig=wdk2s-6mb2vurtyvv9dsbbjqeo4&hl=en&ei=5cbxtobnfct48abkoahacg&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0cceq6aewba#v=onepage&q=hank%20majeski%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''majestic majeski'', by ed rumill, baseball digest, july 1948]

majeski's contract was purchased by the [[boston braves (baseball)|boston braves]], then known as the boston bees and, he made his major league debut with the team on may 17, [[1939 boston bees season|1939]] at the age of 22.<ref name=hank majeski at baseball reference/><ref name=majestic majeski>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ytidaaaambaj&pg=pa43&lpg=pa43&dq=hank+majeski+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=abeyv1xth8&sig=bcmyyspvkw4uzqnnhl4jgr4aknm&hl=en&ei=yolxtmthnml38aad97wzcw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0ccqq6aewbq#v=onepage&q=hank%20majeski%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=majestic majeski |author=rumill, ed |publisher=books.google.com |date=july 1948 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=24 april 2011 }}</ref> during his rookie season, bees' manager [[casey stengel]] converted him into a third baseman.<ref name=majestic majeski/> majeski began the season hitting above .300 for the first half of the season before a mid-season [[slump (sports)|slump]] saw his average dip to .238 but, he recovered to finish the year with a .272 average along with 7 [[home run]]s and 54 [[runs batted in]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/gl.cgi?id=majesha01&t=b&year=1939 |title=1939 hank majeski batting log |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=24 april 2011 }}</ref>

originally called the [[lou boudreau|boudreau]] or williams shift, the strategy is often associated with [[ted williams]], but it was actually first employed against [[cy williams]] during the 1920s.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=zcodaaaambaj&pg=pa41&dq=eddie+yost+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=eh3gtouch4lhbqs36dsp&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0cdiq6aewajgk#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=20th century all-overlooked stars |author=vass, george |publisher=books.google.com |date=august 1999 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=24 april 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=4i0daaaambaj&pg=pa30&dq=ken+williams+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=i8lgtjnfbjyg4qa7zododw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0ceiq6aewbg#v=onepage&q=ken%20williams%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=baseball's forgotten stars |author=vass, george |publisher=books.google.com |date=july 2004 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=24 april 2012 }}</ref> it was later used against ted williams during the [[1946 world series]] between the [[red sox]] and the [[st. louis cardinals|cardinals]] as a defensive gimmick by st. louis manager [[eddie dyer]] to psych out and hopefully contain boston slugger williams. it was devised by cleveland indians manager lou boudreau on a blackboard between games of a doubleheader in july 1946 to halt williams' hot hitting. i always considered the boudreau shift a psychological, rather than a tactical victory, wrote lou boudreau in his book, ''player-manager''. the shift has been employed since then to thwart extreme pull hitters (mostly lefties), such as [[barry bonds]], [[ryan howard]], [[jason giambi]], [[david ortiz]] and also [[mark teixeira]]

originally called the [[lou boudreau|boudreau]] or williams shift, the strategy is often associated with [[ted williams]], but it was actually first employed against [[cy williams]] during the 1920s.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=zcodaaaambaj&pg=pa41&dq=eddie+yost+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=eh3gtouch4lhbqs36dsp&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0cdiq6aewajgk#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=20th century all-overlooked stars |author=vass, george |publisher=books.google.com |date=august 1999 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=24 april 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=4i0daaaambaj&pg=pa30&dq=ken+williams+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=i8lgtjnfbjyg4qa7zododw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0ceiq6aewbg#v=onepage&q=ken%20williams%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=baseball's forgotten stars |author=vass, george |publisher=books.google.com |date=july 2004 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=24 april 2012 }}</ref> it was later used against ted williams during the [[1946 world series]] between the [[red sox]] and the [[st. louis cardinals|cardinals]] as a defensive gimmick by st. louis manager [[eddie dyer]] to psych out and hopefully contain boston slugger williams. it was devised by cleveland indians manager lou boudreau on a blackboard between games of a doubleheader in july 1946 to halt williams' hot hitting. i always considered the boudreau shift a psychological, rather than a tactical victory, wrote lou boudreau in his book, ''player-manager''. the shift has been employed since then to thwart extreme pull hitters (mostly lefties), such as [[barry bonds]], [[ryan howard]], [[jason giambi]], [[david ortiz]] and also [[mark teixeira]]

'''delbert rice jr.''' (october 27, 1922 – january 26, 1983) was a [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] [[catcher]], [[coach (baseball)|coach]] and [[manager (baseball)|manager]] in [[major league baseball]].<ref name=del rice at baseball reference>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/r/ricede01.shtml del rice at baseball reference]</ref> he was known as one of the better defensive catchers of his era.<ref name=''rice-card's daily dish''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=8didaaaambaj&pg=pa45&dq=del+rice+baseball+digest&cd=1#v=onepage&q=del%20rice%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''rice-card's daily dish'', by ellis veech, baseball digest, august 1952, issn 0005-609x]</ref>

rice played in the major leagues for 17 years (1945-61), appearing in 1,309 games with a .237 [[batting average]] along with 79 [[home run]]s and a career .987 fielding percentage.<ref name=del rice at baseball reference/> he was selected as a reserve in the [[1953 major league baseball all-star game|1953 all-star game]].<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/nls/nls195307140.shtml 1953 all-star game at baseball reference]</ref> rice was known for his strong defensive skills, leading national league catchers in [[fielding percentage]] in [[1948 st. louis cardinals season|1948]] and [[1949 st. louis cardinals season|1949]], and tieing for the lead in [[double play]]s in 1949, [[1950 st. louis cardinals season|1950]] and [[1951 st. louis cardinals season|1951]].<ref name=''rice-card's daily dish''/><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa86&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, july 2001, p.86, vol. 60, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref> he also had a career in the [[national basketball league (united states)|national basketball league]], playing four seasons for the [[rochester royals]] from 1946 until 1950, when [[fred saigh]], the cardinals owner, asked him to concentrate on baseball.<ref name=''rice-card's daily dish''/><ref>[http://www.sportsecyclopedia.com/nba/rochester/rochroyals.html rochester royals at www.sportsecyclopedia.com]</ref>

'''delbert rice jr.''' (october 27, 1922 – january 26, 1983) was an [[united states|american]] [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] player, [[coach (baseball)|coach]] and [[manager (baseball)|manager]].<ref name=del rice at baseball reference>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/r/ricede01.shtml |title=del rice at baseball reference |publisher=baseball-reference.com |accessdate=15 october 2011}}</ref> he played for 17 seasons as a [[catcher]] in [[major league baseball]] from {{by|1945}} to {{by|1961}}, most notably for the [[st. louis cardinals]]. although rice was a relatively weak hitter, he sustained a lengthy career in the major leagues due to his valuable defensive abilities.<ref name=''rice-card's daily dish''>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=8didaaaambaj&pg=pa45&dq=del+rice+baseball+digest&cd=1#v=onepage&q=del%20rice%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=rice-card's daily dish |author=veech, ellis |publisher=|date=august 1952 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=15 october 2011 }}</ref>

in a seventeen-year major league career, rice played in 1,309 [[games played|games]], accumulating 908 [[hit (baseball)|hits]] in 3,826 [[at bats]] for a .237 career batting average along with 79 home runs, 441 runs batted in and an [[on base percentage]] of .312.<ref name=del rice at baseball reference/> he ended his career with a .987 [[fielding percentage]].<ref name=del rice at baseball reference/> rice was known for his strong defensive skills, leading national league catchers in fielding percentage in {{by|1948}} and {{by|1949}}, and tying for the lead in [[double play]]s in 1949, {{by|1950}} and {{by|1951}}.<ref name=''rice-card's daily dish''/><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa86&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=fielding leaders |author= |publisher=|date=july 2001 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=16 october 2011 }}</ref>

in a seventeen-year major league career, rice played in 1,309 [[games played|games]], accumulating 908 [[hit (baseball)|hits]] in 3,826 [[at bats]] for a .237 career batting average along with 79 home runs, 441 runs batted in and an [[on base percentage]] of .312.<ref name=del rice at baseball reference/> he ended his career with a .987 [[fielding percentage]].<ref name=del rice at baseball reference/> rice was known for his strong defensive skills, leading national league catchers in fielding percentage in 1948 and 1949, and tying for the lead in [[double play]]s in 1949, 1950 and 1951.<ref name=''rice-card's daily dish''/><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa86&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=fielding leaders |author= |publisher=|date=july 2001 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=16 october 2011 }}</ref>

oates began managing in baseball in 1982 when he guided the [[new york yankees]]' double-a [[nashville sounds]] to win the [[southern league (baseball)|southern league]] title.<ref name=johnny oates minor league managerial record>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/minors/player.cgi?id=oates-001joh#standard_managing::none |title=johnny oates minor league managerial record |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=november 24, 2010 }}</ref> from [[1984 chicago cubs season|1984]] to [[1987 chicago cubs season|1987]], he worked as a coach for the [[chicago cubs]] and was credited with developing [[jody davis (baseball)|jody davis]] into a [[gold glove award]] winning catcher.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=qjqdaaaambaj&pg=pa20&dq=jody+davis+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=3ts8tittjcwalaf8y5gudq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0ccsq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=jody%20davis%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=jody davis of the cubs: catcher with a mission |author=mitchell, fred |publisher=google books |date=june 1987 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=october 18, 2010 }}</ref> he rejoined the orioles organization at their [[rochester red wings|rochester aaa affiliate]] in 1988.<ref name=johnny oates minor league managerial record/> the following year, he was promoted to the majors where he worked as first base coach under [[frank robinson]], and in [[1991 baltimore orioles season|1991]], after robinson started 1324, oates was promoted to the manager of the orioles.<ref>{{cite news |title=orioles fire robinson; oates is replacement |agency=associated press |work=the southeast missourian |page=1 |date=may 24, 1991 |accessdate=november 24, 2010 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=z8qfaaaaibaj&sjid=ltgeaaaaibaj&pg=3191,3219487&dq=johnny+oates&hl=en}}</ref> in his first full season with the team, oates led the orioles to an 8973 record and then to an 8577 record in [[1993 baltimore orioles season|1993]], which helped him to win [[the sporting news manager of the year award|''the sporting news'' manager of the year award]].<ref name=johnny oates managerial record>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/managers/oatesjo01.shtml |title=johnny oates managerial record |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=november 24, 2010 }}</ref><ref name=johnny oates awards>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-almanac.com/players/awards.php?p=oatesjo01 |title=johnny oates awards |publisher=baseball almanac |accessdate=november 24, 2010 }}</ref> however, following the strike-shortened [[1994 baltimore orioles season|1994 season]], oates was dismissed by new owner [[peter angelos]].<ref>{{cite news |title=impatient orioles give johnny oates the heave-ho |agency=associated press |work=gettysburg times |page=1 |date=september 27, 1994 |accessdate=november 24, 2010 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=realaaaaibaj&sjid=lp0faaaaibaj&pg=6144,3242614&dq=johnny+oates&hl=en}}</ref>

in a 7 year career, schmidt played in 454 [[games played|games]], accumulating 317 [[hit (baseball)|hits]] in 1305 [[at bats]] for a .243 career batting average along with 39 [[home run]]s and 150 [[runs batted in]].<ref name=bob schmidt at baseball reference/> schmidt led the [[american league]] in [[fielding percentage]] in {{by|1962}} while playing for the washington senators.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/al/1962-fielding-leaders.shtml 1962 american league fielding leaders at baseball reference]</ref> he had a career fielding percentage of .988.<ref name=bob schmidt at baseball reference/> he holds the major league record for most [[putout]]s in an [[extra inning]] game with 22, set on june 22, {{by|1958}}.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=ry4daaaambaj&pg=pa15&dq=bob+schmidt+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=d_qdtopneswblgfytemjdq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0cdiq6aewag#v=onepage&q=bob%20schmidt%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, september 1990, vol. 49, no. 9, issn 0005-609x]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/phi/phi195806221.shtml june 22, 1958 giants-phillies box score at baseball digest]</ref>

cochrane compiled a .320 batting average while hitting 119 home runs over a 13 year playing career.<ref name=mickey cochrane at baseball reference/> his .320 batting average was the highest career vander meer's performance earned him the role as the starting pitcher for the [[national league]] team in the [[1938 major league baseball all-star game|1938 all-star game]] held at cincinnati's [[crosley field]].<ref name=vander meer and gomez slated to start all-star game today>{{cite news |title=vander meer and gomez slated to start all-star game today |agency=associated press |work=the meriden record |page=4 |date=6 july 1938 |accessdate=7 june 2012 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=aohhaaaaibaj&sjid=sf8maaaaibaj&pg=3296,1136756&dq=johnny+vander+meer&hl=en}}</ref> the [[american league]] team, having won four of the previous five all-star games were favored to win the game, but vander meer pitched three scoreless innings and allowed only one hit, as the national league went on to win by a score of 4-1.<ref name=vander meer and gomez slated to start all-star game today/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/nls/nls193807060.shtml |title=1938 all-star game |publisher=baseball-reference.com |accessdate=8 june 2012}}</ref> he ended the season with a record of 15 wins against 10 losses and a 3.12 [[earned run average]] for the fourth place reds. he might have won more games, but spent nearly a month in the hospital being treated for boils late in the season.<ref name=johnny vander meer recalls his consecutive no-hitters>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com.sa/books?id=pzmdaaaambaj&lpg=pa63&dq=johnny%20vander%20meer%20baseball%20digest&pg=pa63#v=onepage&q=johnny%20vander%20meer%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=johnny vander meer recalls his consecutive no-hitters |author=langford, walter m. |publisher=|date=june 1985 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=9 june 2012 }}</ref>

in [[1941 cincinnati reds season|1941]], vander meer's performance improved somewhat with a 16-12 record and six [[shutout]]s while leading the league with 202 [[strikeout]]s. on june 6, 1941 in a game against philadelphia, he allowed only one hit.<ref>{{cite news |title=vander meer wins one-hitter |agency=associated press |work=eugene register guard |page=6 |date=8 june 1941 |accessdate=8 june 2012 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=hk9waaaaibaj&sjid=pogdaaaaibaj&pg=6248,2454789&dq=johnny+vander+meer+one+hitter&hl=en}}</ref> vander meer later recalled that the only hit in the game could have been ruled an [[error (baseball)|error]], as shortstop [[eddie joost]] fielded the [[ground ball]], then dropped it before throwing to first base.<ref name=johnny vander meer recalls his double no-hitters>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com.sa/books?id=ozidaaaambaj&lpg=pa68&dq=johnny%20vander%20meer%20baseball%20digest&pg=pa68#v=onepage&q=johnny%20vander%20meer%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=johnny vander meer recalls his double no-hitters |author=levitt, ed |publisher=|date=october 1971 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=9 june 2012 }}</ref> he earned his third all-star selection in the [[1942 major league baseball all-star game|1942 all-star game]], and once again threw three scoreless innings in a 3-1 loss to the american league.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/nls/nls194207060.shtml |title=1942 all-star game |publisher=baseball-reference.com |accessdate=8 june 2012}}</ref> he finished the [[1942 cincinnati reds season|1942]] season with a career-high 18 wins against 12 losses and once again led the league in strikeouts. he posted a 15-16 record in [[1943 cincinnati reds season|1943]] for the second place reds and led the league in strikeouts for a third consecutive year. on march 3, 1944, vander meer joined the [[united states navy]] and was stationed at [[sampson air force base|sampson naval training station]] in new york where he would play for the navy baseball team.<ref name=remembering johnny vander meer>{{cite web|url=http://baseballinwartime.blogspot.com/2010/02/remembering-johnny-vander-meer.html |title=remembering johnny vander meer |publisher=baseballinwartime.blogspot.com |accessdate=8 june 2012}}</ref> he was discharged from the navy in december 1945, having lost two years of his major league career to his military service,<ref>{{cite news |title=navy is to discharge johnny vander meer |agency=associated press |work=the milwaukee journal |page=2 |date=19 december 1945 |accessdate=8 june 2012 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=7kuaaaaaibaj&sjid=mcmeaaaaibaj&pg=6644,1996712&dq=johnny+vander+meer+navy&hl=en}}</ref> but vander meer claimed that his extensive military play made him less wild as a pitcher, which his record partially supports.<ref name=bullock2004>{{cite book | title=playing for their nation: baseball and the american military during world war ii | publisher=university of nebraska press | author=bullock, steven r. | pages=107-108 | year=2004 | isbn=0-8032-1337-9}}</ref>

born and raised in [[jamesburg, new jersey]], hayes was nicknamed '''blimp''', even though he was listed at 6'0 and 185 [[pound (mass)|lbs]].<ref name=frankie hayes in baseball digest>[http://books.google.com/books?id=eisdaaaambaj&pg=pa6&dq=frankie+hayes+baseball+digest&cd=1#v=onepage&q=frankie%20hayes%20baseball%20digest&f=false frankie hayes in baseball digest, january 1996, vol. 55, no. 1, issn 0005-609x]</ref> he began his major league career on september 21, [[1933 philadelphia athletics season|1933]] at the age of 18, making him the youngest player in the league at the time.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/al/1933-other-leaders.shtml 1933 american league awards, all-stars and other leaders at baseball reference]</ref> he would go hitless in five [[at bat]]s that season.<ref name=frankie hayes at baseball reference/> hayes appeared in 92 games in [[1934 philadelphia athletics season|1934]] as a reserve catcher backing up [[charlie berry]], before being sent to the [[minor league baseball|minor leagues]] to play for the [[buffalo bisons]] in the {{by|1935}} season.

in may [[1945 cleveland indians season|1945]], the athletics traded hayes to the cleveland indians for [[buddy rosar]], another light-hitting catcher with solid defensive skills.<ref name=frankie hayes trades and transactions at baseball almanac/> he led all american league catchers in {{by|1945}} with 145 games played and a .988 [[fielding percentage]].<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa86&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, july 2001, p.86, vol. 60, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref> he was selected to be a reserve catcher for the american league in the [[1945 major league baseball all-star game|1945 all-star game]] however, the game was cancelled due to wartime restrictions.

in a 14 year career, hayes played in 1364 [[games played|games]], accumulating 1164 [[hit (baseball)|hits]] in 4493 [[at bats]] for a .259 career batting average along with 119 home runs and 585 [[runs batted in]].<ref name=frankie hayes at baseball reference/> he ended his career with a .977 fielding percentage.<ref name=frankie hayes at baseball reference/> he compiled 30 career stolen bases along with 213 doubles and 32 [[triple (baseball)|triples]].<ref name=frankie hayes at baseball reference/> during his career, he was named to six [[major league baseball all-star game|all-star teams]].<ref name=frankie hayes at baseball reference/> he led the american league three times in [[total chances]] per game, twice each in [[putout]]s, [[double play]]s, and once each in [[assist (baseball)|assists]] and fielding percentage as a catcher.<ref name=frankie hayes at the baseball library/> when he caught 155 games in 1944, he set a still-standing american league record for games played in a season as catcher.<ref name=frankie hayes at the baseball library/><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=cdqdaaaambaj&pg=pa10&dq=frankie+hayes+baseball+digest&cd=3#v=onepage&q=frankie%20hayes%20baseball%20digest&f=false frankie hayes in baseball digest, august 1978, vol. 37, no. 8, issn 0005-609x]</ref> his record of 312 consecutive games caught remains unbroken. hayes' 29 double plays in 1945 is the second-highest season total ever for a catcher, behind [[steve o'neill]]'s record of 36, set in [[1916 in baseball|1916]].<ref name=frankie hayes at the baseball library/><ref>[http://members.tripod.com/bb_catchers/catchers/double.htm catchers' double play records at the encyclopedia of baseball catchers]</ref>

|agency=associated press |work=times daily |page=4 |date=21 april 1992 |accessdate=31 january 2012 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=_e4eaaaaibaj&sjid=v8ceaaaaibaj&pg=5328,3135351&dq=frankie+hayes+catcher&hl=en}}</ref> in september {{by|1934}}, hayes joined a group of american baseball players led by connie mack in a [[barnstorm (sports)|barnstorming]] tour of japan when charlie berry, who had originally been selected to go, was struck with appendicitis.<ref name=frankie hayes new york times obituary/> among the baseball players who joined hayes in japan were such names as [[babe ruth]], [[lou gehrig]], [[jimmy foxx]] and [[charlie gehringer]].<ref name=frankie hayes new york times obituary/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://philadelphiaathletics.org/history/1934.html |title=baseball's 1934 all star tour of japan |publisher=philadelphiaathletics.org |accessdate=2 february 2012}}</ref> he was sent to the [[minor league baseball|minor leagues]] in {{by|1935}} where he played for the [[buffalo bisons]] and the [[albany senators (minor league baseball)|albany senators]] of the [[international league]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/minors/player.cgi?id=hayes-003fra |title=frankie hayes minor league statistics |publisher=baseball-reference.com |accessdate=31 january 2012}}</ref>

although hayes was rated as one of the top catchers in major league baseball, he had a reputation for being temperamental and, this may have played a role in mack's decision to trade him to the [[cleveland indians]] for catcher [[buddy rosar]] in may [[1945 cleveland indians season|1945]].<ref>{{cite news |title=major league stardom value tumbles as chisox get frank hayes for $7500 |agency= |work=reading eagle |page=15 |date=21 july 1946 |accessdate=2 february 2012 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=x4u1aaaaibaj&sjid=qz0faaaaibaj&pg=5753,1674278&dq=frankie+hayes+catcher&hl=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=mack gets rosar for frank hayes |agency=associated press |work=the milwaukee journal |page=6 |date=30 may 1945 |accessdate=2 february 2012 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ns8aaaaaibaj&sjid=8iqeaaaaibaj&pg=3572,5679192&dq=frankie+hayes+catcher&hl=en}}</ref> contemporary news reports expressed astonishment over the trade, as hayes was considered one of the best catchers in the league while rosar was refusing to play for the indians due to a salary dispute.<ref>{{cite news |title=plenty of guesses but no answers why mr. mack trades frank hayes |agency= |work=the windsor daily star |page=3 |date=30 may 1945 |accessdate=2 february 2012 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=gsq_aaaaibaj&sjid=d1amaaaaibaj&pg=2758,5236155&dq=frankie+hayes+catcher&hl=en}}</ref> hayes immediately assumed the starting catcher's role for the indians, leading american league catchers with 145 games played and a .988 [[fielding percentage]].<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa86&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, july 2001, p.86, vol. 60, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref> he was selected to be a reserve catcher for the american league in the [[1945 major league baseball all-star game|1945 all-star game]] however, the game was cancelled due to wartime travel restrictions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-almanac.com/asgbox/yr1945as.shtml |title=1945 all-star game |publisher=baseball almanac |accessdate=2 february 2012}}</ref>

in a fourteen-year career, hayes played in 1,364 [[games played|games]], accumulating 1,164 [[hit (baseball)|hits]] in 4,493 [[at bats]] for a .259 career batting average along with 119 home runs, 585 [[runs batted in]] and a .343 on base percentage.<ref name=frankie hayes at baseball reference/> he ended his career with a .977 fielding percentage.<ref name=frankie hayes at baseball reference/> he compiled 30 career stolen bases along with 213 doubles and 32 [[triple (baseball)|triples]].<ref name=frankie hayes at baseball reference/> during his career, he was named to six [[major league baseball all-star game|all-star teams]].<ref name=frankie hayes at baseball reference/> he led the american league three times in [[total chances]] per game, twice each in [[putout]]s, [[double play]]s, and once each in [[assist (baseball)|assists]] and fielding percentage as a catcher.<ref name=frankie hayes at the baseball library/> when he caught 155 games in 1944, he set a still-standing american league record for games played in a season as catcher.<ref name=frankie hayes at the baseball library/><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=cdqdaaaambaj&pg=pa10&dq=frankie+hayes+baseball+digest&cd=3#v=onepage&q=frankie%20hayes%20baseball%20digest&f=false frankie hayes in baseball digest, august 1978, vol. 37, no. 8, issn 0005-609x]</ref> his accomplishment of 312 consecutive games caught remains an unbroken major league record. hayes' 29 double plays in 1945 is the second-highest season total ever for a catcher, behind [[steve o'neill]]'s record of 36, set in [[1916 in baseball|1916]].<ref name=frankie hayes at the baseball library/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://members.tripod.com/bb_catchers/catchers/double.htm |title=catchers' double play records |publisher=the encyclopedia of baseball catchers |accessdate=31 january 2012}}</ref>

'''ralston burdett hemsley''' (june 24, 1907  july 31, 1972) was a [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] [[catcher]]. born in [[syracuse, ohio]], he played 19 seasons in [[major league baseball]]. he was nicknamed rollicking rollie.<ref name=''rollie hemsley left his imprint on baseball''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=1jedaaaambaj&pg=pa81&dq=rollie+hemsley+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=hx27s9rueyw69qsu_qibca&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0cdaq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=rollie%20hemsley%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''rollie hemsley left his imprint on baseball'', by hal lebovitz, baseball digest, november 1972, vol. 31, no. 11, issn 0005-609x]</ref>

hemsley became the starting catcher for the browns in the [[1934 st. louis browns season|1934]] season, and his best years were with the [[baltimore orioles|st. louis browns]] in 1934 and [[1935 st. louis browns season|1935]], when he hit .309 and .290 respectively. he also hit 7 [[triple (baseball)|triple]]s both years, a career high. his effort in 1935 also earned him his first spot on the [[major league baseball all-star game|all-star]] team, as well as 9th place in [[major league baseball most valuable player award|mvp]] voting.<ref name=br/> he played well for two more seasons for the browns, but a batting average of .222 in [[1937 st. louis browns season|1937]], as well as a suspension for violation of team rules on july 2, 1937,<ref name=bl/> led to a trade on february 10, [[1938 cleveland indians season|1938]]. hemsley was traded to the [[cleveland indians]] for ed cole, [[roy hughes (baseball)|roy hughes]], and [[billy sullivan, jr.]] on the recommendation of [[bob feller]], who had been impressed with hemsley's catching skills.<ref name=''rollie hemsley left his imprint on baseball''/><ref name=br/> he spent the 1938 season backing up [[frankie pytlak]] but, became known as feller's personal catcher.<ref>{{cite news |title=catching feud may speed up indian's drive |agency=united press |work=the sunday morning star |page=26 |date=16 april 1939 |accessdate=9 november 2010 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=x84maaaaibaj&sjid=bwigaaaaibaj&pg=3804,1960044&dq=pytlak+hemsley&hl=en}}</ref> hemsley became the starter in [[1939 cleveland indians season|1939]] after pytlak went down with an injury, and played well enough to earn his third all-star bid. on opening day of the [[1940 cleveland indians season|1940]] season, hemsley caught feller's [[no-hitter]], becoming the only catcher to catch an opening day no-hit game.<ref name=bl/> he also drove in the only run of the game with a triple.<ref>[http://www.retrosheet.org/boxesetc/1940/b04160cha1940.htm april 16, 1940 indians-white sox box score at retrosheet]</ref> his consistency in the 1940 season saw him lead the american league catchers with a .994 [[fielding percentage]], and led to a couple mvp votes as well as his fourth all-star appearance.<ref name=br/><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa86&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, july 2001, p.86, vol. 60, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref>

hogan batted .300 with five home runs and 45 rbi in the [[1929 new york giants (mlb) season|1929]] season as the giants dropped to third place in the final standings.<ref name=baseballref/> he helped guide the giants pitching staff to the lowest team [[earned run average]] in the league.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1929.shtml#teams_standard_pitching::7 |title=1929 national league team statistics and standings |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=16 march 2012 }}</ref> [[1930 new york giants (mlb) season|1930]] marked hogan's best season offensively. his performance was aided by the introduction of a lively ball wound with special australian wool, resulting in a league batting average that was above .300 for the only time in baseball history.<ref name=hack wilson belted homers, hecklers with equal gusto>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/?id=3jadaaaambaj&pg=pa78&dq=hack+wilson+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=hack%20wilson%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=hack wilson belted homers, hecklers with equal gusto |author=holway, john |publisher=books.google.com |date=june 1996 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=28 february 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-almanac.com/hitting/hibavg4.shtml |title=league by league totals for batting average |publisher=baseball almanac |accessdate=1 march 2011 }}</ref> hogan finished the season with a .339 average, 13 home runs, and 75 runs batted in, as the giants once again finished in third place.<ref name=baseballref/>

hogan batted .300 with five home runs and 45 rbi in the [[1929 new york giants (mlb) season|1929]] season as the giants dropped to third place in the final standings.<ref name=baseballref/> he helped guide the giants pitching staff to the lowest team [[earned run average]] in the league.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1929.shtml#teams_standard_pitching::7 |title=1929 national league team statistics and standings |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=16 march 2012 }}</ref> [[1930 new york giants (mlb) season|1930]] marked hogan's best season offensively. his performance was aided by the introduction of a lively ball wound with special australian wool, resulting in a league batting average that was above .300 for the only time in baseball history.<ref name=hack wilson belted homers, hecklers with equal gusto>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/?id=3jadaaaambaj&pg=pa78&dq=hack+wilson+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=hack%20wilson%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=hack wilson belted homers, hecklers with equal gusto |author=holway, john |publisher=books.google.com |date=june 1996 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=28 february 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-almanac.com/hitting/hibavg4.shtml |title=league by league totals for batting average |publisher=baseball almanac |accessdate=1 march 2011 }}</ref> hogan finished the season with a .339 average, 13 home runs, and 75 runs batted in, as the giants once again finished in third place.<ref name=baseballref/>

in [[1927 cleveland indians season|1927]], sewell had a breakout year, hitting for a career-high .294 batting average with 27 [[double (baseball)|doubles]], 53 [[runs batted in]], and scored 52 [[run (baseball)|runs]].<ref name=luke sewell statistics/> sewell questioned [[babe ruth]]'s integrity in a game on june 11, {{by|1927}}. he demanded that [[umpire (baseball)|umpires]] check ruth's bat after he clouted two straight home runs off [[garland buckeye]].<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=wjmdaaaambaj&pg=pa73&dq=luke+sewell+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=9yy1tcjrd4gtgqfcjigycw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0ccyq6aewatgk#v=onepage&q=luke%20sewell%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=the babe's phantom 155th game |author=simons, herbert |publisher=books.google.com |date=january 1971 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=18 january 2011 }}</ref> although he led the league's catchers with 20 [[error (baseball)|errors]], he also led the league with 119 assists and 71 baserunners [[caught stealing]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/al/1927-fielding-leaders.shtml |title=1927 american league fielding leaders |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=18 january 2011 }}</ref> despite the fact that the indians finished the season in sixth place, sewell ranked ninth in voting for the {{by|1927}} american league [[major league baseball most valuable player award|most valuable player award]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1927.shtml#almvp |title=1927 american league most valuable player award ballot |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=18 january 2011 }}</ref> in [[1928 cleveland indians season|1928]], he once again led the league's catchers with 117 assists and 60 baserunners caught stealing and ranked twelfth in voting for the {{by|1928}} american league most valuable player award.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/al/1928-fielding-leaders.shtml |title=1928 american league fielding leaders |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=18 january 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1928.shtml#almvp |title=1928 american league most valuable player award ballot |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=18 january 2011 }}</ref>

|publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=18 january 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1928.shtml#almvp |title=1928 american league most valuable player award ballot |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=18 january 2011 }}</ref>

in [[1927 cleveland indians season|1927]], sewell had a breakout year, hitting for a career-high .294 batting average with 27 [[double (baseball)|doubles]], 53 [[runs batted in]], and scored 52 [[run (baseball)|runs]].<ref name=luke sewell statistics/> sewell questioned [[babe ruth]]'s integrity in a game on june 11, {{by|1927}}. he demanded that [[umpire (baseball)|umpires]] check ruth's bat after he clouted two straight home runs off [[garland buckeye]].<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=wjmdaaaambaj&pg=pa73&dq=luke+sewell+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=9yy1tcjrd4gtgqfcjigycw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0ccyq6aewatgk#v=onepage&q=luke%20sewell%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=the babe's phantom 155th game |author=simons, herbert |publisher=books.google.com |date=january 1971 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=18 january 2011 }}</ref> although he led the league's catchers with 20 [[error (baseball)|errors]], he also led the league with 119 assists and 71 baserunners [[caught stealing]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/al/1927-fielding-leaders.shtml |title=1927 american league fielding leaders |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=18 january 2011 }}</ref> despite the fact that the indians finished the season in sixth place, sewell ranked ninth in voting for the {{by|1927}} american league [[major league baseball most valuable player award|most valuable player award]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1927.shtml#almvp |title=1927 american league most valuable player award ballot |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=18 january 2011 }}</ref> in [[1928 cleveland indians season|1928]], he once again led the league's catchers with 117 assists and 60 baserunners caught stealing and ranked twelfth in voting for the {{by|1928}} american league most valuable player award.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/al/1928-fielding-leaders.shtml |title=1928 american league fielding leaders |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=18 january 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1928.shtml#almvp |title=1928 american league most valuable player award ballot |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=18 january 2011 }}</ref>

born in [[los angeles, california]], battey was contracted as an amateur [[free agent]] by the chicago white sox in [[1952 chicago white sox season|1952]]. from [[1955 chicago white sox season|1955]] to [[1959 chicago white sox season|1959]], he served as the white sox reserve catcher, backing up and learning from [[sherm lollar]].<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=jlydaaaambaj&pg=pa13&dq=earl+battey+baseball+digest&cd=1#v=onepage&q=earl%20battey%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''battey up!'', by charles dexter, baseball digest, june 1961, vol. 20, no. 5, issn 0005-609x]</ref> he reached the [[1959 world series|world series]] with the white sox in 1959, but he didn't play in the series.<ref name=''where are they now?''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=etqdaaaambaj&pg=pa71&dq=earl+battey+baseball+digest&cd=2#v=onepage&q=&f=false ''where are they now?'', by randy schultz, baseball digest, june 1989, vol. 48, no. 6, issn 0005-609x]</ref> in april [[1960 washington senators season|1960]], battey was traded to the washington senators one year prior to the team's move to minnesota, where they were renamed the twins.<ref>[http://www.baseball-almanac.com/players/trades.php?p=batteea01 earl battey trades and transactions at baseball almanac]</ref> after the trade, battey developed into an extremely capable defensive catcher, leading the american league in [[assist (baseball)|assists]] and [[putout]]s for four consecutive years from 1960 to [[1963 minnesota twins season|1963]].<ref name=earl battey at cooloftheevening.com>[http://cooloftheevening.com/earl_battey.htm earl battey at cooloftheevening.com]</ref> battey appears to have been one of the first major league players to wear an earflap on his batting helmet in [[1961 minnesota twins season|1961]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.uniwatchblog.com/2010/02/02/theres-no-service-like-wire-service-vol-3/ |title=  theres no service like wire service, vol. 3|author=paul lukas|date=2010-02-02|work=uni watch blog|publisher= |accessdate=2010-02-02}}</ref> he ended 1961 with a .302 [[batting average]], sixth best in the american league.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/al/1961-batting-leaders.shtml 1961 american league batting leaders at baseball reference]</ref> battey was the twins catcher on august 26, [[1962 minnesota twins season|1962]], when pitcher [[jack kralick]] threw a [[no-hitter]].<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/min/min196208260.shtml august 26, 1962 athletics-twins box score at baseball reference]</ref> also in 1962, he was selected as the starting catcher for the american league in the [[major league baseball all-star game|all-star game]], and set a record for major league catchers by [[pick off|picking off]] 15 [[baserunning|base runners]].<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/als/als196207100.shtml 1962 all-star game at baseball reference]</ref><ref>[http://members.tripod.com/bb_catchers/catchers/pickoff-leaders.htm pick-off leaders at the encyclopedia of baseball catchers]</ref>

born in [[los angeles, california]], battey attended [[jordan high school (los angeles, california)|jordan high school]] in the watts neighborhood of los angeles.<ref name=battey up!>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=jlydaaaambaj&pg=pa13&dq=earl+battey+baseball+digest&cd=1#v=onepage&q=earl%20battey%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=battey up! |author=dexter, charles |publisher=|date=june 1961 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=22 june 2011 }}</ref> he was signed as an amateur [[free agent]] by the chicago white sox prior to the [[1953 chicago white sox season|1953]] season.<ref name=earl battey at baseball reference/> battey was assigned to the [[colorado springs sky sox]] in the single-a [[western league (defunct minor league)|western league]] where he began his baseball career by hitting only a .158 [[batting average]] in 26 games.<ref name=earl battey minor league statistics>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/minors/player.cgi?id=battey001ear |title=earl battey minor league statistics |publisher=baseball-reference.com |accessdate=22 june 2011 }}</ref> the white sox demoted him to the [[waterloo white hawks]] in the b-level [[illinois-indiana-iowa league]] and battey responded with a .292 average and 11 [[home run]]s in 129 games.<ref name=earl battey minor league statistics/> in {{by|1955}}, battey was promoted to the [[minor league baseball|triple-a]] [[charleston senators]] in the [[american association (20th century)|american association]] where, he hit for a .269 batting average along with 8 home runs and 71 runs batted in.<ref name=earl battey minor league statistics/> his performance earned him a promotion to the major leagues where he made his debut with the white sox on september 10, [[1955 chicago white sox season|1955]] at the age of 20.<ref name=earl battey at baseball reference/>

in [[1914 boston braves season|1914]], whaling was a member of the braves team that went from last place to first place in two months, becoming the first team to win a [[pennant (sports)|pennant]] after being in last place on the fourth of july.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=as0daaaambaj&pg=pa84&dq=hank+gowdy+baseball+digest&cd=3#v=onepage&q=hank%20gowdy%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''how losing an exhibition sparked miracle braves'', by joseph m. overfield, baseball digest, may 1961, vol. 20, no. 4, issn 0005-609x]</ref> while serving as the backup to starting catcher [[hank gowdy]], whaling hit .206 in 60 games and led national league catchers in baserunners [[caught stealing]] percentage with 54.5%.<ref name=bert whaling at baseball reference/><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1914-fielding-leaders.shtml 1914 national league fielding leaders at baseball reference]</ref> the braves went on to sweep [[connie mack (baseball)|connie mack's]] heavily-favored athletics in four games in the [[1914 world series]], although whaling never got a chance to play in the series.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1914_ws.shtml 1914 world series at baseball-reference]</ref> the team became known as the miracle braves and remain one of the most storied comeback teams in baseball history.

whaling began his professional baseball career at the age of 20 with the [[portland beavers]] in {{by|1908}}.<ref name=bert whaling minor league statistics>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/minors/player.cgi?id=whalin001alb |title=bert whaling minor league statistics |publisher=baseball-reference.com |accessdate=10 july 2011}}</ref> he then played for the [[seattle giants]] from {{by|1909}} to {{by|1911}}.<ref name=bert whaling minor league statistics/> in august 1911, he was signed by the [[cleveland naps]] of the [[american league]] but, didn't play at the major league level.<ref>{{cite news |title=louie litschi to be given another chance by new york |agency= |work=reading eagle |page=13 |date=27 august 1911 |accessdate=11 july 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=9byraaaaibaj&sjid=apwfaaaaibaj&pg=3652,5933655&dq=bert+whaling&hl=en}}</ref> in april {{by|1912}}, whaling was released by the naps and returned to play for the seattle giants where, he posted a .264 [[batting average]] and hit 10 [[home run]]s.<ref name=bert whaling minor league statistics/><ref>{{cite news |title=naps release bert whaling |agency= |work=the milwaukee journal |page=15 |date=24 april 1912 |accessdate=11 july 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=1ymwaaaaibaj&sjid=ysaeaaaaibaj&pg=4411,3487003&dq=bert+whaling&hl=en}}</ref> whaling's defensive skills were made evident as he threw out 188 baserunners attempting to steal a base during the 1912 season.<ref name=boston signs crack players>{{cite news |title=boston signs crack players |agency= |work=the meriden daily journal |page=8 |date=24 october 1912 |accessdate=10 july 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=bptiaaaaibaj&sjid=-wenaaaaibaj&pg=4973,3683616&dq=bert+whaling&hl=en}}</ref> during the [[deadball era]], catchers played a huge defensive role, given the large number of [[bunt (baseball)|bunt]]s and [[stolen base]] attempts, as well as the difficulty of handling the [[spitball]] pitchers who dominated pitching staffs.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=9s0daaaambaj&pg=pa26&dq=baseball+digest+defensive+catchers#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20defensive%20catchers&f=false |title=for catchers, the name of the game is defense |author=vass, george |publisher=books.google.com |date=may 2005 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=12 july 2011 }}</ref> a newspaper report in 1912 called whaling the best catcher to have ever played in the [[northwestern league (1905-1917)|northwestern league]].<ref>{{cite news |title=northwestern's batting honors of 1912 to meek while james is king of pitchers |agency= |work=the spokesman-review |page=8 |date=6 october 1912 |accessdate=10 july 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=vefvaaaaibaj&sjid=zeadaaaaibaj&pg=6719,6596787&dq=bert+whaling&hl=en}}</ref>

before the [[1914 boston braves season|1914]] season began, rariden left the braves to join the [[federal league]] leaving whaling as their main catcher with [[hank gowdy]] as his back up.<ref
