spokesman-review |page=8 |date=6 october 1912 |accessdate=10 july 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=vefvaaaaibaj&sjid=zeadaaaaibaj&pg=6719,6596787&dq=bert+whaling&hl=en}}</ref>

before the [[1914 boston braves season|1914]] season began, rariden left the braves to join the [[federal league]] leaving whaling as their main catcher with [[hank gowdy]] as his back up.<ref name=the new bill james historical baseball abstract>{{citation |first=bill | last=james |year=2001 |title=the new bill james historical baseball abstract |publisher =the free press |isbn=0-684-80697-5 |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=3usbqum8hsac&pg=pa418&dq=bert+whaling&hl=en&ei=b5ietscjhcorgqfx1ltbaw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0cdaq6aewajgk#v=onepage&q=bert%20whaling&f=false |quote=}}</ref> when whaling failed to provide much offense, braves manager, [[george stallings]] gave gowdy the starting catcher's job.<ref name=the new bill james historical baseball abstract/> the braves had been in last place in the [[national league]] on july 4 before going on an extended winning streak.<ref name=how losing an exhibition sparked miracle braves>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=as0daaaambaj&pg=pa84&dq=hank+gowdy+baseball+digest&cd=3#v=onepage&q=hank%20gowdy%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=how losing an exhibition sparked miracle braves |author=overfield, joseph |publisher=books.google.com |date=may 1961 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=10 july 2011 }}</ref> the team went from last place to first place within a two-month period, becoming the first team to win a [[pennant (sports)|pennant]] after being in last place on the fourth of july.<ref name=how losing an exhibition sparked miracle braves/> whaling hit .206 in 60 games as gowdy's back up and led national league catchers in baserunners [[caught stealing]] percentage with 54.5%.<ref name=bert whaling at baseball reference/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1914-fielding-leaders.shtml |title=1914 national league fielding leaders |publisher=baseball-reference.com |accessdate=10 july 2011}}</ref> the braves went on to sweep [[connie mack (baseball)|connie mack's]] heavily favored [[1914 philadelphia athletics season|philadelphia athletics]] in four games in the [[1914 world series]], although whaling never got a chance to play in the series.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1914_ws.shtml |title=1914 world series |publisher=baseball-reference.com |accessdate=10 july 2011}}</ref> the team became known as the miracle braves and remain one of the most storied comeback teams in baseball history.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisgreatgame.com/1914.html |title=the miracle braves |publisher=thisgreatgame.com |accessdate=10 july 2011}}</ref>

daz was a member of the [[1983 philadelphia phillies season|1983]] phillies team that became known as ''the wheeze kids'', due to the average age of the team being over thirty.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/mag1120630/index.htm |title=in philadelphia, they're the wheeze kids |author=wulf, steve |publisher=books.google.com |date=14 march 1983 |work=sports illustrated |accessdate=6 march 2011 }}</ref> the moniker was a whimsical reference to the [[whiz kids (baseball)|whiz kids]] phillies team that won the national league pennant in [[1950 philadelphia phillies season|1950]]. in a game against the [[1983 new york mets season|new york mets]] on april 13, [[1983 philadelphia phillies season|1983]], daz performed a feat that has only been accomplished by 11 other players in the history of major league baseball.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=xyodaaaambaj&pg=pa12&dq=bo+diaz+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=1mtztacrf9g2tge1oax_dg&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0cemq6aewbg#v=onepage&q=bo%20diaz%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=grand slams that have decided games in the bottom of the ninth inning |author= |publisher=books.google.com |date=september 1996 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=6 march 2011 }}</ref> the phillies were trailing by a score of 9 to 6 and with two [[out (baseball)|outs]] in the ninth [[inning (baseball)|inning]], when daz hit a [[grand slam (baseball)|grand slam home run]] off [[neil allen]] to win the game for the phillies by a score of 10 to 9.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/phi/phi198304130.shtml |title=april 13, 1983 mets-phillies box score |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=6 march 2011 }}</ref> on september 23, daz was the phillies catcher when steve carlton won the 300th game of his career.<ref>{{cite news |title=stoic carlton participates in excitement of no. 300 |agency=associated press |work=gadsden times |page=7 |date=25 september 1983 |accessdate=7 march 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=tp8faaaaibaj&sjid=dtyeaaaaibaj&pg=2636,4539451&dq=steve+carlton&hl=en}}</ref> with the phillies leading the game by a score of 3 to 2 in the fifth inning, daz sealed the victory with a two-run [[single (baseball)|single]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/sln/sln198309230.shtml |title=september 23, 1983 phillies-cardinals box score |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=7 march 2011 }}</ref>

in [[1984 philadelphia phillies season|1984]], daz went on the [[disabled list]] twice due to knee problems and played in only 27 games.<ref name=bo diaz statistics/> after the season ended, he underwent two knee surgeries to restore his mobility.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=pzmdaaaambaj&pg=pa33&dq=bo+diaz+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=1mtztacrf9g2tge1oax_dg&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0cdsq6aewba#v=onepage&q=bo%20diaz%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=comebacks by injured stars could determine '85 races |author=vass, george |publisher=books.google.com |date=june 1985 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=6 march 2011 }}</ref> daz broke his right wrist at the beginning of the [[1985 philadelphia phillies season|1985]] season and was on the disabled list for a month and a half.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/gl.cgi?id=diazbo01&t=b&year=1985 |title=1985 bo diaz batting log |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=7 march 2011 }}</ref> during his absence, his replacement, [[ozzie virgil, jr.|ozzie virgil]] hit above the .300 mark, relegating daz to the backup catcher's role upon his return.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/gl.cgi?id=virgioz02&t=b&year=1985 |title=1985 ozzie virgil batting log |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=7 march 2011 }}</ref> on august 8, 1985, the phillies traded daz to the cincinnati reds.<ref name=bo diaz trades and transactions/>

in 12 seasons he played in 962 games and had 2,840 at bats, 347 runs, 820 hits, 152 doubles, 32 triples, 29 home runs, 388 rbi, 30 stolen bases, 240 walks, .289 batting average, .346 on-base percentage, .395 slugging percentage, 1,123 total bases and 39 sacrifice hits.<ref name=billy sullivan jr. at baseball reference/> sullivan led national league catchers in [[1938 st. louis browns season|1938]] with a .990 [[fielding percentage]].<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa86&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, july 2001, p.86, vol. 60, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref> his father, [[billy sullivan (baseball)|billy sullivan]], was also a major league catcher.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/s/sullibi03.shtml billy sullivan at baseball reference]</ref>

wynegar was [[batting average|batting]] .294 with six home runs and 37 [[runs batted in]] at the {{by|1976}} all-star break to be named to the [[american league]] [[1976 major league baseball all-star game|all-star team]] his rookie season.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=acwdaaaambaj&pg=pa70&dq=butch+wynegar+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=sagdtml_och68abvmexbdq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0ccuq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=butch%20wynegar%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''butch wynegar enjoyed a meteoric rise to the majors'' by barry sparks, baseball digest, july 1996, vol. 55, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref> he drew a walk in his only at-bat, and became the youngest player at the time to appear in an all-star game (20 years, 212 days).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/nls/nls197607130.shtml|title=1976 all-star game|publisher=baseball-reference.com|date=1976-07-13}}</ref> for the season, wynegar had 650 [[putouts]], second in the league behind [[jim sundberg]], and batted .260 with ten home runs and 69 rbis to finished second in the [[1976 minnesota twins season|1976]] american league [[major league baseball rookie of the year award|rookie of the year]] balloting to [[mark fidrych]], and was named the [[the sporting news rookie of the year award|''the sporting news'' rookie of the year]].<ref name=the ballplayers>{{cite book |author=charlton, james; shatzkin, mike; holtje, stephen |title=the ballplayers: baseball's ultimate biographical reference |publisher=arbor house/william morrow |location=new york |year=1990 |isbn=0-87795-984-6 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate= |page=1207}}</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1976.shtml#alroy 1976 american league rookie of the year voting results at baseball reference]</ref>

wynegar was [[batting average|batting]] .294 with six home runs and 37 [[runs batted in]] at the {{by|1976}} all-star break to be named to the [[american league]] [[1976 major league baseball all-star game|all-star team]] his rookie season.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=acwdaaaambaj&pg=pa70&dq=butch+wynegar+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=sagdtml_och68abvmexbdq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0ccuq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=butch%20wynegar%20baseball%20digest&f=false|title=butch wynegar enjoyed a meteoric rise to the majors|author=barry sparks|date=july 1996|publisher=baseball digest vol. 55, no. 7 0005-609x}}</ref> he drew a walk in his only at-bat, and became the youngest player at the time to appear in an all-star game (20 years, 212 days).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/nls/nls197607130.shtml|title=1976 all-star game|publisher=baseball-reference.com|date=1976-07-13}}</ref> for the season, wynegar had 650 [[putouts]], second in the league behind [[jim sundberg]], and batted .260 with ten home runs and 69 rbis to finished second in the {{by|1976}} [[american league]] [[major league baseball rookie of the year award|rookie of the year]] balloting to [[mark fidrych]], and was named the [[the sporting news rookie of the year award|''the sporting news'' rookie of the year]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1976.shtml#alroy|title=baseball awards voting for 1976|publisher=baseball-reference.com}}</ref>

wynegar was [[batting average|batting]] .294 with six home runs and 37 [[runs batted in]] at the 1976 all-star break to be named to the [[american league]] [[1976 major league baseball all-star game|all-star team]] his rookie season.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=acwdaaaambaj&pg=pa70&dq=butch+wynegar+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=sagdtml_och68abvmexbdq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0ccuq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=butch%20wynegar%20baseball%20digest&f=false|title=butch wynegar enjoyed a meteoric rise to the majors|author=barry sparks|date=july 1996|publisher=baseball digest vol. 55, no. 7 0005-609x}}</ref> he drew a walk in his only at-bat, and became the youngest player at the time to appear in an all-star game (20 years, 212 days).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/nls/nls197607130.shtml|title=1976 all-star game|publisher=baseball-reference.com|date=1976-07-13}}</ref> for the season, wynegar had 650 [[putout]]s, second in the league behind [[jim sundberg]], and batted .260 with ten home runs and 69 rbis to finished second in the 1976 [[american league]] [[major league baseball rookie of the year award|rookie of the year]] balloting to [[mark fidrych]], and was named the [[the sporting news rookie of the year award|''the sporting news'' rookie of the year]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1976.shtml#alroy|title=baseball awards voting for 1976|publisher=baseball-reference.com}}</ref>

wynegar proved to be adept both behind the plate and batting.  his first major league home run was a game-winner off [[catfish hunter]] on april 18, 1976. <ref>http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/nya/nya197604180.shtml</ref>  wynegar was [[batting average|batting]] .294 with six home runs and 37 [[runs batted in]] at the 1976 all-star break to be named to the [[american league]] [[1976 major league baseball all-star game|all-star team]] his rookie season.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=acwdaaaambaj&pg=pa70&dq=butch+wynegar+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=sagdtml_och68abvmexbdq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0ccuq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=butch%20wynegar%20baseball%20digest&f=false|title=butch wynegar enjoyed a meteoric rise to the majors|author=barry sparks|date=july 1996|publisher=baseball digest vol. 55, no. 7 0005-609x}}</ref> he drew a walk in his only at-bat, and became the youngest player at the time to appear in an all-star game (20 years, 212 days).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/nls/nls197607130.shtml|title=1976 all-star game|publisher=baseball-reference.com|date=1976-07-13}}</ref> for the season, wynegar had 650 [[putout]]s, second in the league behind [[jim sundberg]], and batted .260 with ten home runs and 69 rbis to finished second in the 1976 [[american league]] [[major league baseball rookie of the year award|rookie of the year]] balloting to [[mark fidrych]], and was named the [[the sporting news rookie of the year award|''the sporting news'' rookie of the year]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1976.shtml#alroy|title=baseball awards voting for 1976|publisher=baseball-reference.com}}</ref>

torre followed in his brother [[frank torre|frank's]] footsteps and joined the milwaukee braves in [[1960 milwaukee braves season|1960]] as a backup for veteran catcher [[del crandall]]. he finished second to [[billy williams (left fielder)|billy williams]] in the {{by|1961}} [[major league baseball rookie of the year award|rookie of the year]] voting, and became a reliable player on a veteran braves team that included [[hank aaron]] and [[eddie mathews]].<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1961.shtml#nl_rookie_of_the_year_voting 1965 national league rookie of the year voting results at baseball reference]</ref> he was primarily a [[catcher]], but also spent significant time as a [[first baseman]]. in [[1965 milwaukee braves season|1965]], torre won a [[list of nl gold glove winners at catcher|gold glove]] as a catcher, and led national league catchers in [[fielding percentage]] in  he won a world series in 1964. .<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/gold_glove_nl.shtml#1965 national league gold glove award winners at baseball reference]</ref><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa86&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, july 2001, vol. 60, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref> in an article for the ''st. petersburg independent'' that year, [[beat generation]] author [[jack kerouac]] called torre the best catcher since [[roy campanella]].<ref>{{cite book|last=kerouac|first=jack|title=good blonde & others|publisher=grey fox press|year=1993|page=134}}</ref> after moving to atlanta, he hit .315 in [[1966 atlanta braves season|1966]].

torre followed in his brother [[frank torre|frank's]] footsteps when he was signed by the milwaukee braves as an amateur [[free agent]] in [[1960 milwaukee braves season|1960]].<ref name=joe torre statistics/> in his first season in the [[minor league baseball|minor leagues]] with the class a [[eau claire braves]], he won the {{by|1960}} [[northern league (baseball, 1902-71)|northern league]] batting championship with a .344 [[batting average]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/minors/player.cgi?id=torre-001jos |title=joe torre minor league statistics |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=8 january 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/minors/leader.cgi?type=bat&id=13148 |title=1960 northern league batting leaders |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=8 january 2011 }}</ref> torre made his major league debut late in the season on september 21, 1960.<ref name=joe torre statistics/> he was assigned to the triple a [[louisville colonels (minor league baseball)|louisville colonels]] for the {{by|1961}} season where, the braves had planned to groom him as the eventual successor to their [[major league baseball all-star game|all-star]] catcher, [[del crandall]].<ref name=best young catcher!>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ws0daaaambaj&lpg=pa19&dq=joe%20torre%20baseball%20digest&pg=pa19#v=onepage&q=joe%20torre%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=best young catcher! |author=walfoort, cleon |publisher=books.google.com |date=december 1961 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=8 january 2011 }}</ref> however, those plans were changed when crandall injured his throwing arm in may [[1961 milwaukee braves season|1961]], forcing the braves to promote torre to the major leagues with just over a year of minor league experience.<ref name=best young catcher!/> torre rose to the occasion, hitting for a .278 batting average with 21 [[double (baseball)|doubles]] and 10 [[home run]]s.<ref name=joe torre statistics/> he finished the season ranked second to [[billy williams (left fielder)|billy williams]] in the {{by|1961}} [[national league]] [[major league baseball rookie of the year award|rookie of the year]] voting.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1961.shtml#nl_rookie_of_the_year_voting |title=1961 national league rookie of the year voting results |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=8 january 2011 }}</ref>

the cardinals made simmons their full-time catcher in [[1971 st. louis cardinals season|1971]], leaving torre to concentrate on playing at third base. freed from the mentally challenging, strength-sapping job of catching, torre had a career-season offensively.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=odmdaaaambaj&lpg=pa4&dq=joe%20torre%20baseball%20digest&pg=pa4#v=onepage&q=joe%20torre%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=warm up tosses |author=kuenster, john |publisher=books.google.com |date=december 1971 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=9 january 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=my0daaaambaj&pg=pa6&dq=joe+torre+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=e0kptdsoicwclgfv5z3gaq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0cdsq6aewbg#v=onepage&q=joe%20torre%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=un-covering the past |author= |publisher=books.google.com |date=december 2000 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=9 january 2011 }}</ref> he was hitting for a .359 batting average at mid-season and was voted to be the starting third baseman for the national league in the [[1971 major league baseball all-star game|1971 all-star game]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/gl.cgi?id=torrejo01&t=b&year=1971 |title=1971 joe torre batting log |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=9 january 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/als/als197107130.shtml |title=1971 all-star game |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=9 january 2011 }}</ref> torre won the national league [[list of major league baseball batting champions|batting championship]], hitting .363 and led the league with 137 [[runs batted in]], enroute to winning the {{by|1971}} national league [[major league baseball most valuable player award|most valuable player]] award.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1971-batting-leaders.shtml |title=1971 national league batting leaders |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=9 january 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1971.shtml#nl_mvp_voting |title=1971 national league most valuable player award voting |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=9 january 2011 }}</ref> adapting to a new defensive position proved to be a challenge as torre led the league's third basemen with 21 [[error (baseball)|errors]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1971-fielding-leaders.shtml |title=1971 national league fielding leaders |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=10 january 2011 }}</ref> in december, he was awarded the 1971 [[hutch award]], given annually to the player who best exemplifies the fighting spirit and competitive desire of [[fred hutchinson]].<ref>{{cite news |title=hutch award to joe torre |agency=associated press |work=st. joseph news-press |page=5 |date=16 december 1971 |accessdate=10 january 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ne1haaaaibaj&sjid=9hqnaaaaibaj&pg=1172,4215591&dq=joe+torre&hl=en}}</ref>

with the mets in {{by|1975}}, torre became the third player in major league history, and first in the national league, to hit into four [[double play]]s in one game.<ref>{{cite news |title=joe torre sets record as double play victim |agency=associated press |work=the bulletin |page= |date=21 july 1975 |accessdate=10 january 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=jmzyaaaaibaj&sjid=8vcdaaaaibaj&pg=3439,5803978&dq=joe+torre&hl=en}}</ref> when torre's batting average fell to .247 in [[1975 new york mets season|1975]], it appeared his best years might be behind him however, his average rebounded 59 points in [[1976 new york mets season|1976]] to finish the year with a .306 batting average.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=otmdaaaambaj&pg=pa22&dq=joe+torre+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=ffeptbfio4p7lwfruqwraq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0ceyq6aewctgk#v=onepage&q=joe%20torre%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=biggest batting gainers and losers in '76 |author=pickard, chuck |publisher=books.google.com |date=february 1977 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=9 january 2011 }}</ref> in may [[1977 new york mets season|1977]], the mets fired manager [[joe frazier (baseball)|joe frazier]] and named torre as their [[player-manager]].<ref>{{cite news |title=torre replaces frazier as mets' manager |agency=united press international |work=the milwaukee sentinel |page=1 |date=1 june 1977 |accessdate=9 january 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=7wgwaaaaibaj&sjid=3heeaaaaibaj&pg=3386,82404&dq=joe+torre&hl=en}}</ref> because he believed he could not do the job properly while still playing, he decided to retire at age 37, but did serve 18 days as a player-manager (only having 2 at-bats), becoming the second of three players in the 1970s to take on both roles ([[frank robinson]], in the two previous seasons with the [[cleveland indians]], and [[don kessinger]], in {{by|1979}} with the [[chicago white sox]], were the others).<ref>{{cite news |title=fly ball to right ends joe torre's playing career |agency=associated press |work=st. joseph gazette |page=2 |date=21 june 1977 |accessdate=9 january 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ixndaaaaibaj&sjid=dlonaaaaibaj&pg=1124,4071132&dq=joe+torre&hl=en}}</ref>

web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/gl.cgi?id=torrejo01&t=b&year=1971|title=1971 joe torre batting log|publisher=baseball reference|accessdate=9 january 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/als/als197107130.shtml|title=1971 all-star game|publisher=baseball reference|accessdate=9 january 2011 }}</ref> torre won the national league [[list of major league baseball batting champions|batting championship]], hitting .363 and led the league with 137 [[runs batted in]], en route to winning the {{by|1971}} national league [[major league baseball most valuable player award|most valuable player]] award.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1971-batting-leaders.shtml|title=1971 national league batting leaders|publisher=baseball reference|accessdate=9 january 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1971.shtml#nl_mvp_voting|title=1971 national league most valuable player award voting|publisher=baseball reference|accessdate=9 january 2011 }}</ref> adapting to a new defensive position proved to be a challenge as torre led the league's third basemen with 21 [[error (baseball)|errors]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1971-fielding-leaders.shtml|title=1971 national league fielding leaders|publisher=baseball reference|accessdate=10 january 2011 }}</ref> in december, he was awarded the 1971 [[hutch award]], given annually to the player who best exemplifies the fighting spirit and competitive desire of [[fred hutchinson]].<ref>{{cite news|title=hutch award to joe torre|agency=associated press|work=st. joseph news-press|page=5|date=16 december 1971|accessdate=10 january 2011|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ne1haaaaibaj&sjid=9hqnaaaaibaj&pg=1172,4215591&dq=joe+torre&hl=en}}</ref>

with the mets in {{mlby|1975}}, torre became the third player in major league history, and first in the national league, to hit into four [[double play]]s in one game.<ref>{{cite news|title=joe torre sets record as double play victim|agency=associated press|work=the bulletin|page=|date=21 july 1975|accessdate=10 january 2011|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=jmzyaaaaibaj&sjid=8vcdaaaaibaj&pg=3439,5803978&dq=joe+torre&hl=en}}</ref> [[felix milln]] singled in all four of his at-bats hitting ahead of torre, and at a post-game press conference, torre joked about his own performance by saying i'd like to thank felix millan for making this possible.  when torre's batting average fell to .247 in [[1975 new york mets season|1975]], it appeared his best years might be behind him. however, his average rebounded 59 points in [[1976 new york mets season|1976]], and he finished the year with a .306 batting average.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=otmdaaaambaj&pg=pa22&dq=joe+torre+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=ffeptbfio4p7lwfruqwraq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0ceyq6aewctgk#v=onepage&q=joe%20torre%20baseball%20digest&f=false|title=biggest batting gainers and losers in '76|author=pickard, chuck|publisher=books.google.com|date=february 1977|work=baseball digest|accessdate=9 january 2011 }}</ref> in may [[1977 new york mets season|1977]], the mets fired manager [[joe frazier (baseball)|joe frazier]] and named torre as their [[player-manager]].<ref>{{cite news|title=torre replaces frazier as mets' manager|agency=united press international|work=the milwaukee sentinel|page=1|date=1 june 1977|accessdate=9 january 2011|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=7wgwaaaaibaj&sjid=3heeaaaaibaj&pg=3386,82404&dq=joe+torre&hl=en}}</ref> because he believed he could not do the job properly while still playing, he decided to retire at age 37. he did serve 18 days as a player-manager (only having 2 at-bats), becoming the second of three players in the 1970s to take on both roles ([[frank robinson]], in the two previous seasons with the [[cleveland indians]], and [[don kessinger]], in {{by|1979}} with the [[chicago white sox]], were the others).<ref>{{cite news|title=fly ball to right ends joe torre's playing career|agency=associated press|work=st. joseph gazette|page=2|date=21 june 1977|accessdate=9 january 2011|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ixndaaaaibaj&sjid=dlonaaaaibaj&pg=1124,4071132&dq=joe+torre&hl=en}}</ref>

ennis was born to george and agnes ennis in the [[crescentville, philadelphia|crescentville]] section{{citation needed|date=april 2011}} of [[philadelphia, pennsylvania]].  he played baseball and football at olney high school and was mentioned as an all-state [[fullback (gridiron football)|fullback]].  philadelphia phillies scout [[jocko collins]] came to watch one of ennis's high school classmates pitch.  when ennis hit two long home runs, collins tried to recruit him but ennis was hesitant, worried that he was not ready, and unsure that he wanted to pursue a baseball career.  in august 1942, ennis finally signed with collins to play with the phillies' [[canadian-american league]] team, but the league suspended operation for [[world war ii]].  ennis signed with collins again in march 1943 and hit .348 with 19 home runs and 16 [[triple (baseball)|triple]]s for the phillies' [[trenton, new jersey]] [[interstate league]] team.  in september 1943, philadelphia wanted to call ennis to the major leagues, but he went into the [[united states navy]] instead.  ennis saw military action in the pacific theater and also toured with a baseball team that included [[billy herman]], [[johnny vander meer]] and [[schoolboy rowe]].<ref name=bbdigest1948>[http://books.google.com/books?id=_s0daaaambaj&lpg=pp1&dq=baseball%20digest%201948&pg=pa21#v=onepage&q&f=false baseball digest], 1948, by russ davis.</ref> he joined the usn on september 29, 1943 and was assigned to sampson naval training station, new york where he graduated as a signalman from a school at sampson and then posted to the hawaiian sea frontier. he was included on the navy's western pac tour of many pacific islands in 19441945. his naval rank was petty officer third class. most of his service was on the island of guam after the winter tour.{{citation needed|date=april 2011}}

ennis was born to george and agnes ennis in the [[crescentville, philadelphia|crescentville]] section{{citation needed|date=april 2011}} of [[philadelphia, pennsylvania]].  he played baseball and football at olney high school and was mentioned as an all-state [[fullback (gridiron football)|fullback]].  philadelphia phillies scout [[jocko collins]] came to watch one of ennis's high school classmates pitch.  when ennis hit two long home runs, collins tried to recruit him but ennis was hesitant, worried that he was not ready, and unsure that he wanted to pursue a baseball career.  in august 1942, ennis finally signed with collins to play with the phillies' [[canadian-american league]] team, but the league suspended operation for [[world war ii]].  ennis signed with collins again in march 1943 and hit .348 with 19 home runs and 16 [[triple (baseball)|triple]]s for the phillies' [[trenton, new jersey]] [[interstate league]] team.  in september 1943, philadelphia wanted to call ennis to the major leagues, but he went into the [[united states navy]] instead.  ennis saw military action in the pacific theater and also toured with a baseball team that included [[billy herman]], [[johnny vander meer]] and [[schoolboy rowe]].<ref name=bbdigest1948>[http://books.google.com/books?id=_s0daaaambaj&lpg=pp1&dq=baseball%20digest%201948&pg=pa21#v=onepage&q&f=false baseball digest], 1948, by russ davis.</ref> he joined the usn on september 29, 1943 and was assigned to sampson naval training station, new york where he graduated as a signalman from a school at sampson and then posted to the hawaiian sea frontier. when the navy learned that ennis was associated with the philadelphia phillies,they assumed he was a major leaguer and invited him to fill one of the vacancies while in honolulu. he was included on the navy's western pac tour of many pacific islands in 19441945. ennis looked very good at the plate in the few exhibition games which immediately preceded the tours. his slugging prompted dan topping, new owner of the new york yankees and a fellow serviceman at pearl to offer him $25,000 to sign with the yanks. the phillies had only paid del $50 to sign. his naval rank was petty officer third class. most of his service was on the island of guam after the winter tour. playing with and against major leaguers on the tours was equivalent of a minor league apprenticeship for ennis. after the tours he was assigned to a fleet recreation billet at gab gab beach on guam and stayed on the island for one year and did not make it back to the states as soon as some of the others because he did not have enough points built up. he finally returned stateside through san diego on the uss wakefield. http://picasaweb.google.com/109127256998453427371/1975_tcma_guam?feat=embedwebsite&gsessionid=zzcu6ff_hr5jn2p7xakmkw#5455158380991053506

a light-[[batting (baseball)|hitting]] defensive specialist, rariden set the major league record for most [[assist (baseball)|assists]] by a catcher in a season with 238 while playing for the [[newark pepper]] of the [[federal league]] in {{by|1915}}.<ref name=single-season leaders & records for assists as catcher at baseball reference>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leaders/a_c_season.shtml single-season leaders & records for assists as catcher at baseball reference]</ref> before rariden's career, most catchers were large, slow-footed players.<ref name=slim catchers replace big men in majors>{{cite news |title=slim catchers replace big men in majors |agency= |work=the pittsburgh gazette times |page=8 |date=6 august 1916 |accessdate=15 january 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=1htiaaaaibaj&sjid=i2gdaaaaibaj&pg=5215,5839392&dq=ray+schalk&hl=en}}</ref> rariden's small size and agility helped him become one of the best catchers in major league baseball.<ref name=slim catchers replace big men in majors/> [[major league baseball|major league]] status was retroactively applied to the federal league in {{by|1968}}. he also had the second highest total with 215 in {{by|1914}}.<ref name=single-season leaders & records for assists as catcher at baseball reference/> in the [[deadball era]] during which rariden played, catchers played a huge defensive role, given the large number of [[bunt (baseball)|bunt]]s and [[stolen base]] attempts, therefore catchers of his era usually accumulated higher assist totals than did those of subsequent eras.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=9s0daaaambaj&pg=pa26&dq=baseball+digest+defensive+catchers#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20defensive%20catchers&f=false |title=for catchers, the name of the game is defense |author=vass, george |publisher=books.google.com |date=may 2005 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=12 july 2011 }}</ref>

the selection of which pitch to use can depend on a wide variety of factors including, but not limited to, the type of hitter who is being faced; whether there are any [[baserunning|base runner]]s; how many outs have been made in the [[inning]]; and the current score. the responsibility for selecting the type of pitch was traditionally made by the [[catcher]] by relaying hand signals to the pitcher, with the pitcher having the option to ask for another selection by nodding his head.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=pc0daaaambaj&pg=pa24&lpg=pa24&dq=catchers+least+appreciated+players+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=7ystjq1cp3&sig=f1gb-phynyvh9lvzehbgnvye9lk&hl=en&ei=raq7tjx2h4p7lwfy-ojsbw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0cciq6aewba#v=onepage&q=catchers%20least%20appreciated%20players%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''catchers are baseball's least appreciated players'', by david andriesen, baseball digest, november 2003, vol. 62, no. 11, issn 0005-609x]</ref> however, current form is to have the [[manager (baseball)|manager]] or a [[coach (baseball)|coach]] relay the pitch selection to the catcher, via secret hand signals to prevent the opposing team from having the advantage of knowing what the next pitch will be. starting pitchers typically throw over 100 pitches per game, while relievers throw fewer.<ref>[http://www.yankeespitches.yolasite.com www.yankeespitches.yolasite.com]</ref>

the responsibility for selecting the type of pitch was traditionally made by the [[catcher]] by relaying hand signals to the pitcher with the fingers, usually 1 finger for fastball and/or the pitchers best pitch , with the pitcher having the option to ask for another selection by shaking his head.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=pc0daaaambaj&pg=pa24&lpg=pa24&dq=catchers+least+appreciated+players+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=7ystjq1cp3&sig=f1gb-phynyvh9lvzehbgnvye9lk&hl=en&ei=raq7tjx2h4p7lwfy-ojsbw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0cciq6aewba#v=onepage&q=catchers%20least%20appreciated%20players%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''catchers are baseball's least appreciated players'', by david andriesen, baseball digest, november 2003, vol. 62, no. 11, issn 0005-609x]</ref> however, current form is to have the [[manager (baseball)|manager]] or a [[coach (baseball)|coach]] relay the pitch selection to the catcher, via secret hand signals to prevent the opposing team from having the advantage of knowing what the next pitch will be. starting pitchers typically throw more pitches than relievers.<ref>[http://www.yankeespitches.yolasite.com www.yankeespitches.yolasite.com]</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=catcher signals|url=http://www.baseball-catcher.com/guide/signals.htm|work=baseball-catcher.com|publisher=baseball-catcher.com}}</ref>

the responsibility for selecting the type of pitch was traditionally made by the [[catcher]] by relaying hand signals to the pitcher with the fingers, usually 1 finger for fastball and/or the pitchers best pitch, with the pitcher having the option to ask for another selection by shaking his head.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=pc0daaaambaj&pg=pa24&lpg=pa24&dq=catchers+least+appreciated+players+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=7ystjq1cp3&sig=f1gb-phynyvh9lvzehbgnvye9lk&hl=en&ei=raq7tjx2h4p7lwfy-ojsbw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0cciq6aewba#v=onepage&q=catchers%20least%20appreciated%20players%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=catchers are baseball's least appreciated players |author=andriesen, david |publisher=books.google.com |date=november 2003 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=9 march 2012 }}</ref> however, current form is to have the [[manager (baseball)|manager]] or a [[coach (baseball)|coach]] relay the pitch selection to the catcher, via secret hand signals to prevent the opposing team from having the advantage of knowing what the next pitch will be. starting pitchers typically throw more pitches than relievers.<ref>[http://www.yankeespitches.yolasite.com www.yankeespitches.yolasite.com]</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=catcher signals|url=http://www.baseball-catcher.com/guide/signals.htm|work=baseball-catcher.com|publisher=baseball-catcher.com}}</ref>

the responsibility for selecting the type of pitch was traditionally made by the [[catcher]] by relaying hand signals to the pitcher with the fingers, usually 1 finger for fastball and/or the pitcher's best pitch, with the pitcher having the option to ask for another selection by shaking his head.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=pc0daaaambaj&pg=pa24&lpg=pa24&dq=catchers+least+appreciated+players+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=7ystjq1cp3&sig=f1gb-phynyvh9lvzehbgnvye9lk&hl=en&ei=raq7tjx2h4p7lwfy-ojsbw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0cciq6aewba#v=onepage&q=catchers%20least%20appreciated%20players%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=catchers are baseball's least appreciated players |author=andriesen, david |publisher=books.google.com |date=november 2003 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=9 march 2012 }}</ref> however, current form is to have the [[manager (baseball)|manager]] or a [[coach (baseball)|coach]] relay the pitch selection to the catcher, via secret hand signals to prevent the opposing team from having the advantage of knowing what the next pitch will be. starting pitchers typically throw more pitches than relievers.<ref>[http://www.yankeespitches.yolasite.com www.yankeespitches.yolasite.com]</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=catcher signals|url=http://www.baseball-catcher.com/guide/signals.htm|work=baseball-catcher.com|publisher=baseball-catcher.com}}</ref>

wert reached the major leagues in [[1963 in baseball|1963]] and became the tigers' regular [[third baseman]] from [[1964 detroit tigers season|1964]]-[[1970 in baseball|1970]]. though never a strong hitter, wert earned a reputation as one of the best fielding [[third baseman|third basemen]].<ref name=the second best third baseman/> in [[1965 detroit tigers season|1965]], wert played all 162 games for the tigers and led all [[american league]] [[third baseman|third basemen]] with a .976 [[fielding percentage]], marking the only year in the 1960s that a third baseman other than [[brooks robinson]] had led the league in fielding.<ref name=don wert at baseball reference/><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa86&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, july 2001, p.86, vol. 60, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref> he also led the team with 159 hits, had a .341 [[on base percentage]] fueled by a career-high 73 [[base on balls|walks]], and even showed some power with hit 12 [[home run]]s.<ref name=don wert at baseball reference/> with his performance in [[1965 in baseball|1965]], wert was selected for the first annual tiger of the year by the detroit chapter of the [[baseball writers association of america]], and also finished no. 10 in the [[american league]] [[major league baseball most valuable player award|most valuable player]] voting.<ref name=tiger of the year award at baseball almanac/><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1965.shtml#almvp 1965 american league most valuable player award voting results at baseball reference]</ref> wert had his best season as a batter in [[1966 detroit tigers season|1966]], when he  had a .268 [[batting average]], .342 [[on base percentage]], 20 [[double (baseball)|doubles]], 11 [[home run]]s, and 70 [[rbi]]s.<ref name=don wert at baseball reference/>

freehan attended the [[university of michigan]], where he set an all-time [[big ten conference]] batting mark of .585 in 1961 and also played [[college football|football]].<ref>[http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/mag1010445/index.htm sports illustrated, july 27, 1997]</ref> he signed with his hometown tigers in [[1961 in baseball|1961]] for a $100,000 bonus, which his father withheld until he graduated in 1966, and broke in briefly with 4 games at the end of the season before returning to the minors in 1962.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=8ssdaaaambaj&pg=pa58&lpg=pa58&dq=bill+freehan+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=2gdknkfoig&sig=qpyltdvnwprmepq78mlly4__f94&hl=en&ei=udxqsok7ay2xtgefjm2dba&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0cbsq6aewbw#v=onepage&q=bill%20freehan%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''bill freehan: a key member of the 1968 champion tigers'', by jim sargent, baseball digest, jun 2000, vol. 59, no. 6, issn 0005-609x]</ref> in [[1963 detroit tigers season|1963]] he arrived in the majors to stay, working with former catcher [[rick ferrell]] on his defense and splitting catching duties with [[gus triandos]], who was traded following the season. the [[1964 detroit tigers season|1964]] campaign gave indications of what was to come; he [[batting average|batted]] .300 to finish sixth in the al, along with 18 home runs and 80 [[run batted in|runs batted in]].<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/al/1964-batting-leaders.shtml 1964 american league batting leaders at baseball reference]</ref> he also earned the first of ten consecutive all-star selections, and placed seventh in the mvp balloting.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1964.shtml#almvp 1964 american league most valuable player voting results at baseball reference]</ref> in [[1965 detroit tigers season|1965]] he led the al in putouts for the first of six times, and received his first of his five consecutive gold gloves. in [[1966 detroit tigers season|1966]] he again led the league in putouts, and also led in fielding average for the first of three times.

*[http://books.google.com/books?id=8ssdaaaambaj&pg=pa58&lpg=pa58&dq=bill+freehan+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=2gdknkfoig&sig=qpyltdvnwprmepq78mlly4__f94&hl=en&ei=udxqsok7ay2xtgefjm2dba&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0cbsq6aewbw#v=onepage&q=bill%20freehan%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''bill freehan: a key member of the 1968 champion tigers'', by jim sargent, baseball digest, jun 2000]

freehan attended the [[university of michigan]], where he set an all-time [[big ten conference]] batting mark of .585 in 1961 and also played [[college football|football]].<ref>[http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/mag1010445/index.htm sports illustrated, july 27, 1997]</ref> he signed with his hometown tigers in [[1961 in baseball|1961]] for a $100,000 bonus, which his father withheld until he graduated in 1966, and broke in briefly with 4 games at the end of the season before returning to the minors in 1962.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=8ssdaaaambaj&pg=pa58&lpg=pa58&dq=bill+freehan+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=2gdknkfoig&sig=qpyltdvnwprmepq78mlly4__f94&hl=en&ei=udxqsok7ay2xtgefjm2dba&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0cbsq6aewbw#v=onepage&q=bill%20freehan%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''bill freehan: a key member of the 1968 champion tigers'', by jim sargent, baseball digest, jun 2000, vol. 59, no. 6, issn 0005-609x]</ref> in [[1963 detroit tigers season|1963]] he arrived in the majors to stay, working with former catcher [[rick ferrell]] on his defense and splitting catching duties with [[gus triandos]], who was traded following the season. the [[1964 detroit tigers season|1964]] campaign gave indications of what was to come; he [[batting average|batted]] .300 to finish sixth in the american league, along with 18 home runs and 80 [[run batted in|runs batted in]].<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/al/1964-batting-leaders.shtml 1964 american league batting leaders at baseball reference]</ref> he also earned the first of ten consecutive all-star selections, and placed seventh in the [[major league baseball most valuable player award|most valuable player award]] balloting.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1964.shtml#almvp 1964 american league most valuable player voting results at baseball reference]</ref> in [[1965 detroit tigers season|1965]] he led the american league in [[putout]]s for the first of six times, and received his first of his five consecutive gold gloves. in [[1966 detroit tigers season|1966]] he again led the league in putouts, and also led in [[fielding percentage]] for the first of four times.

in his 12-year career, freehan played in 1774 [[games played|games]] with 1591 [[hit (baseball)|hits]] in 6073 [[at bats]] for a .262 batting average along with 241 [[double (baseball)|doubles]], 200 [[home run]]s, 758 [[runs batted in|rbi]], and a .340 [[on base percentage]].<ref name=bill freehan at baseball reference/> in addition to his home runs and total bases, his .412 slugging average and totals of 1591 hits, 706 [[run (baseball)|runs]] and 476 [[extra base hit]]s all put him among the top five american league catchers to that time. his batting totals are particularly remarkable in light of the fact that offense was at a low throughout the sport during his career, with a decided advantage toward [[pitcher]]s. freehan led all american league catchers in fielding percentage four times (1965, 1966, 1970, 1973).<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa86&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, july 2001, p.86, vol. 60, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref> he also ranked sixth in american league history with 114 times being hit by a pitch. he was named an [[major league baseball all-star game|all-star]] in each of the eleven seasons in which he caught at least 75 games. his 11 all-star game appearances are the most by any eligible player who is not in the [[baseball hall of fame]]. freehan caught more games as a catcher than any other player in tigers' team history and, he ranked ninth in major league history in games caught (1581) at the end of his career.<ref>[http://members.tripod.com/bb_catchers/catchers/mostgame.htm most games caught for team at the encyclopedia of baseball catchers]</ref>

*[http://books.google.com/books?id=8ssdaaaambaj&pg=pa58&lpg=pa58&dq=bill+freehan+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=2gdknkfoig&sig=qpyltdvnwprmepq78mlly4__f94&hl=en&ei=udxqsok7ay2xtgefjm2dba&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0cbsq6aewbw#v=onepage&q=bill%20freehan%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''bill freehan: a key member of the 1968 champion tigers'', by jim sargent, baseball digest, jun 2000]

he batted .300 to finish sixth in the american league (al), along with 18 home runs and 80 [[run batted in|runs batted in]].<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/al/1964-batting-leaders.shtml 1964 american league batting leaders at baseball reference]</ref> he also earned the first of ten consecutive all-star selections, and placed seventh in the [[major league baseball most valuable player award|most valuable player award]] balloting.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1964.shtml#almvp 1964 american league most valuable player voting results at baseball reference]</ref> in [[1965 detroit tigers season|1965]] he led the al in [[putout]]s for the first of six times, and received his first of his five consecutive gold gloves. in [[1966 detroit tigers season|1966]] he again led the league in putouts, and also led in [[fielding percentage]] for the first of four times.

in his 15-year career, freehan played in 1,774 [[games played|games]] with 1,591 [[hit (baseball)|hits]] in 6,073 [[at bat]]s for a .262 batting average along with 241 [[double (baseball)|doubles]], 200 [[home run]]s, 758 [[runs batted in|rbi]], and a .340 [[on base percentage]].<ref name=bill freehan at baseball reference/> in addition to his home runs and total bases, his .412 slugging average and totals of 1,591 hits, 706 [[run (baseball)|runs]] and 476 [[extra base hit]]s all put him among the top five al catchers to that time. his batting totals are particularly remarkable in light of the fact that offense was at a low throughout the sport during his career, with a decided advantage toward [[pitcher]]s. freehan led all al catchers in fielding percentage four times (1965, 1966, 1970, 1973).<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa86&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, july 2001, p.86, vol. 60, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref> he also ranked sixth in american league history with 114 times being hit by a pitch. freehan caught more games than any other player in tigers' team history.<ref>[http://members.tripod.com/bb_catchers/catchers/mostgame.htm most games caught for team at the encyclopedia of baseball catchers]</ref>

*[http://books.google.com/books?id=8ssdaaaambaj&pg=pa58&lpg=pa58&dq=bill+freehan+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=2gdknkfoig&sig=qpyltdvnwprmepq78mlly4__f94&hl=en&ei=udxqsok7ay2xtgefjm2dba&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0cbsq6aewbw#v=onepage&q=bill%20freehan%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''bill freehan: a key member of the 1968 champion tigers'', by jim sargent, baseball digest, jun 2000]

in 1969, the league split into two divisions,<ref>{{cite book|last=koppett|first=leonard|coauthors=koppett, dave|title=koppett's concise history of major league baseball|publisher=carroll & graf|date=2004|page=300|isbn=0786712864|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=cjrbvkgashcc&pg=pa300&dq=major+league+baseball+split+divisions&ei=nuvds93papdynrv4yfsm&cd=1#v=onepage&q=major%20league%20baseball%20split%20divisions&f=false}}</ref> and the teams with the best records in each division played one another in the nlcs to determine the pennant winner. the format of the nlcs was changed from a [[best-of-five playoff|best-of-five]] to a [[best-of-seven playoff|best-of-seven format]] for the 1985 postseason.<ref>{{cite journal|title=league championship series results|journal=baseball digest|publisher=lakeside|volume=60|issue=10|page=74|issn=0005-609x|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=2ssdaaaambaj&pg=pa74&dq=baseball+digest+national+league+championship+series+1969&ei=iezds9wnjahkm_nm3jqn&cd=3#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20national%20league%20championship%20series%201969&f=false}}</ref> in 1995, an additional playoff series was added when major league baseball restructured the two divisions in each league into three.<ref name=realign>{{cite web|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=6-ytaaaaibaj&sjid=3gceaaaaibaj&pg=6390,4161911&dq=phillies+mets+rivalry&hl=en|title=pirates agree to move to new division|date=september 16, 1993|work=ocala star-banner|accessdate=october 15, 2009}}</ref> {{as of|2010}}, the winners of the [[national league east|eastern]], [[national league central|central]], and [[national league west|western divisions]], as well as one [[wild card (sports)|wild card team]], play in the [[national league division series]], a best-of-five playoff to determine the opponents who will play for the pennant.<ref>{{cite book|last=formosa|first=dan|coauthors=hamburger, paul|title=baseball field guide: an in-depth illustrated guide to the complete rules of baseball|publisher=thunder's mouth press|date=2006|pages=2425|isbn=1560257008|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ca_ppp9fvbsc&pg=pa24&dq=major+league+baseball+postseason&ei=mehds-28jzx6nywtidgn&cd=4#v=onepage&q=major%20league%20baseball%20postseason&f=false}}</ref>

the senators faced [[john mcgraw]]'s heavily-favored [[1924 new york giants season|new york giants]] in the [[1924 world series]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1924_ws.shtml |title=1924 world series |publisher=baseball-reference.com |accessdate=29 april 2012}}</ref> the two teams traded wins back and forth until the series reached the seventh and deciding game. the senators trailed the giants 3 to 1 in the eighth inning of game 7, when bucky harris hit a routine ground ball to third which hit a pebble and took a bad hop over giants third baseman [[freddie lindstrom]]. two runners scored on the play, tying the score at three.<ref name=1924 world series game 7 box score at baseball reference>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/ws1/ws1192410100.shtml |title=1924 world series game 7 box score |publisher=baseball-reference.com |accessdate=29 april 2012}}</ref> an aging walter johnson then came in to pitch the ninth inning, and held the giants scoreless into extra innings. in the bottom of the twelfth inning with ruel at bat, he hit a high, [[foul ball]] directly over [[home plate]].<ref name=how senators' strategy won for johnson>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=zzidaaaambaj&pg=pa37&dq=muddy+ruel+baseball+digest&cd=1#v=onepage&q=muddy%20ruel%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=how senators' strategy won for johnson |author=ruel, muddy |publisher=|date=october 1964 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=29 april 2012 }}</ref> the giants' catcher, [[hank gowdy]], dropped his protective mask to field the ball but, failing to toss the mask aside, stumbled over it and dropped the ball, thus giving ruel another chance to bat.<ref name=how senators' strategy won for johnson/> on the next [[pitch (baseball)|pitch]], ruel hit a [[double (baseball)|double]] and, then proceeded to score the winning [[run (baseball)|run]] when [[earl mcneely]] hit a [[ground ball]] that took another bad hop over lindstrom's head.<ref name=1924 world series game 7 box score at baseball reference/><ref name=how senators' strategy won for johnson/> it would mark the only [[world series]] triumph for the franchise during their sixty-year tenure in washington.

{{cite web |title=washington senators |url=http://www.baseballlibrary.com/ballplayers/player.php?name=washington_senators |publisher=baseballlibrary.com |accessdate=aug 7, 2009 |postscript= <!--none-->}}</ref> with their hard luck being crucial to the plot of the musical and film ''[[damn yankees (musical)|damn yankees]]''. [[cecil travis]], [[buddy myer]], [[roy sievers]] and [[eddie yost]] were notable senators players whose careers were spent in obscurity due to the team's lack of success.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com.sa/books?id=rdqdaaaambaj&lpg=pa48&dq=spud%20davis%20baseball%20digest&pg=pa46#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=13 most forgotten stars in major league history |author=grosshandler, stan |publisher=books.google.com |date=february 1981 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=may 3, 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/?id=zcodaaaambaj&pg=pa44&dq=eddie+yost+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=20th century all-overlooked stars |author=vass, george |publisher=books.google.com |date=august 1999 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=may 3, 2012 }}</ref> in [[1954 washington senators season|1954]], the senators signed future hall of fame member [[harmon killebrew]]. by [[1959 washington senators season|1959]], he was the senators regular third baseman, leading the league with 42 home runs and earning a starting spot on the [[1959 major league baseball all-star game (first game)|american league all-star team]].

dietz made his major league debut with the giants on june 18, [[1966 san francisco giants season|1966]] at the age of 24.<ref name=dick dietz statistics/> nicknamed ''mule'', he played as the giants backup catcher behind [[tom haller]] in [[1967 san francisco giants season|1967]].<ref name=dick dietz statistics/><ref name=a new image for giants' dick dietz>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com.sa/books?id=qjmdaaaambaj&pg=pa42&dq=baseball+digest+dick+dietz&hl=en&sa=x&ei=vhl2ttzufth3maw54_meag&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20dick%20dietz&f=false |title=a new image for giants' dick dietz |author=twombly, wells |publisher=|date=october 1970 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=24 december 2011 }}</ref> in september, dietz was named to the {{by|1967}} [[topps all-star rookie rosters|topps all-star rookie team]].<ref>{{cite news |title=topps rookie team named |agency=associated press |work=the morning record |page=9 |date=9 september 1967 |accessdate=25 december 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=lcziaaaaibaj&sjid=sganaaaaibaj&pg=5110,940324&dq=dick+dietz+topps&hl=en}}</ref> in february [[1968 san francisco giants season|1968]], the giants were in need of good [[infielder]]s, and with four young catching prospects in their system, including dietz, club president [[chub feeney]] decided to trade haller along with a player to be named later, to the los angeles dodgers for [[ron hunt]] and [[nate oliver]].<ref name=hunt, oliver dealt to san francisco by la for haller>{{cite news |title=hunt, oliver dealt to san francisco by la for haller |agency=associated press |work=tri city herald |page=13 |date=12 february 1968 |accessdate=31 october 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=pwehaaaaibaj&sjid=sycfaaaaibaj&pg=4684,2324095&dq=tom+haller&hl=en}}</ref> dietz shared catching duties with [[jack hiatt]] and [[bob barton]] in [[1968 san francisco giants season|1968]], producing a .272 batting average with 6 home runs and 38 runs batted in.<ref name=dick dietz statistics/>

dietz is remembered for his role in a controversial umpiring decision during the 1968 season.<ref name=dick dietz: 1941-2005>{{cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/chronicle/archive/2005/06/30/spgibdh1lq1.dtl |title=dick dietz: 1941-2005 |publisher=sfgate.com |accessdate=24 december 2011 |first=david |last=bush |date=24 june 2011}}</ref> the giants were facing dodgers' pitcher [[don drysdale]], who was in the midst of a scoreless inning streak that would eventually reach a record-setting 58 and two-thirds innings.<ref name=baseball rules corner>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com.sa/books?id=4i4daaaambaj&pg=pa87&dq=baseball+digest+dick+dietz&hl=en&sa=x&ei=vhl2ttzufth3maw54_meag&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20dick%20dietz&f=false |title=baseball rules corner |author=marazzi, rich |publisher=|date=november 2002 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=24 december 2011 }}</ref> the giants had the bases loaded with no [[out (baseball)|outs]] and dietz at bat.<ref name=baseball rules corner/> dietz was [[hit by pitch|hit by a pitch]], apparently ending drysdale's scoreless innings streak.<ref name=baseball rules corner/> however, home plate [[umpire (baseball)|umpire]] [[harry wendelstedt]], citing a rarely enforced rule, refused to allow dietz to take first base, claiming that dietz did not attempt to avoid being struck by the ball.<ref name=baseball rules corner/> drysdale then retired dietz and the next two batters, keeping his scoreless streak alive.<ref name=baseball rules corner/> dietz was the giants catcher on september 17, 1968, when [[gaylord perry]] pitched a [[no-hitter]] against the [[1968 st. louis cardinals season|st. louis cardinals]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.retrosheet.org/boxesetc/1968/b09170sfn1968.htm |title=september 17, 1968 cardinals-giants box score |publisher=retrosheet.org |accessdate=24 december 2011}}</ref> in [[1969 san francisco giants season|1969]], dietz continued to share the catching duties with hiatt and barton.<ref name=dick dietz statistics/> when the other two players were traded before the start of the [[1970 san francisco giants season|1970]] season, dietz became the giants' regular starting catcher.<ref name=a new image for giants' dick dietz/>

web|url=http://www.retrosheet.org/boxesetc/1968/b09170sfn1968.htm |title=september 17, 1968 cardinals-giants box score |publisher=retrosheet.org |accessdate=december 24, 2011}}</ref> in [[1969 san francisco giants season|1969]], dietz continued to share the catching duties with hiatt and barton.<ref name=dick dietz statistics/> when the other two players were traded before the start of the [[1970 san francisco giants season|1970]] season, dietz became the giants' regular starting catcher.<ref name=a new image for giants' dick dietz/>

in 1969, the league split into two divisions,<ref>{{cite book|last=koppett|first=leonard|coauthors=koppett, dave|title=koppett's concise history of major league baseball|publisher=carroll & graf|year=2004|page=300|isbn=0786712864|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=cjrbvkgashcc&pg=pa300&dq=major+league+baseball+split+divisions&ei=nuvds93papdynrv4yfsm&cd=1#v=onepage&q=major%20league%20baseball%20split%20divisions&f=false}}</ref> and the teams with the best records in each division played one another in the five-game alcs to determine the pennant winner. the format of the alcs was changed from a [[best-of-five playoff|best-of-five]] to a [[best-of-seven playoff|best-of-seven format]] in the 1985 postseason.<ref>{{cite journal|title=league championship series results|journal=baseball digest|publisher=lakeside|volume=60|issue=10|page=74|issn=0005-609x|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=2ssdaaaambaj&pg=pa74&dq=baseball+digest+national+league+championship+series+1969&ei=iezds9wnjahkm_nm3jqn&cd=3#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20national%20league%20championship%20series%201969&f=false}}</ref> in 1995, an additional playoff series was added when major league baseball restructured into three divisions in each league.<ref name=realign>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/al/1995.shtml|title=1995 american league team statistics and standings|work=baseball-reference.com|publisher=sports reference llc|accessdate=january 25, 2010}}</ref> {{as of|2010}}, the winners of the [[american league east|eastern]], [[american league central|central]], and [[american league west|western divisions]], as well as the [[list of american league wild card winners|al wild card winner]], play in the [[american league division series]], a best-of-five playoff to determine the opponents who will play in the alcs.<ref>{{cite book|last=formosa|first=dan|coauthors=hamburger, paul|title=baseball field guide: an in-depth illustrated guide to the complete rules of baseball|publisher=thunder's mouth press|year=2006|pages=2425|isbn=1560257008|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ca_ppp9fvbsc&pg=pa24&dq=major+league+baseball+postseason&ei=mehds-28jzx6nywtidgn&cd=4#v=onepage&q=major%20league%20baseball%20postseason&f=false}}</ref> american league pennant winners have gone on to win the world series 60 times, most recently in 2009.

kiner was born in [[santa rita, new mexico]], and raised in [[alhambra, california]].  he was of [[pennsylvania dutch]] and [[scotch irish]] ancestry.<ref name=bbdigest1948>[http://books.google.com/books?id=_s0daaaambaj&lpg=pp1&dq=baseball%20digest%201948&pg=pa2#v=onepage&q&f=false baseball digest, 1948, by charles j. doyle of the ''pittsburgh sun-telegraph''.]</ref>  kiner served as a u.s. navy pilot during world war ii.<ref>[http://bioproj.sabr.org/bioproj.cfm?a=v&v=a&bid=1066&pid=7516 baseball biography project page on kiner]</ref> kiner made his major league debut on april 12, {{by|1946}} with the [[pittsburgh pirates]].  he finished the season with 23 home runs, but 109 strikeouts.  after the season, the pirates convinced future hall of famer [[hank greenberg]] not to retire.  greenberg gave kiner hours of instruction and, in {{by|1947}}, kiner led the major leagues with 51 home runs while striking out less than 100 times.<ref name=bbdigest1948 /> many of kiner's homers were hit into a shortened left-field and left-center-field porch at [[forbes field]] (originally built for greenberg and known in the press as greenberg gardens); the porch was retained for kiner and redubbed kiner's korner.<ref>{{cite book |title= lost ballparks: a celebration of baseball's legendary fields|last= ritter|first= lawrence|year= 1992|publisher= penguin usa|isbn= 0-1402-3422-5|pages= 6667}}</ref> kiner would later use kiner's korner as the title of his post-game tv show in new york.<ref>[http://www.baseball-almanac.com/quotes/quokiner.shtml ralph kiner quotes]. baseball-almanac.com. retrieved on 2009-01-16.</ref>

kiner was born in [[santa rita, new mexico]], and raised in [[alhambra, california]]. he is of [[pennsylvania dutch]] and [[scotch-irish american|scots-irish]] ancestry.<ref name=bbdigest1948>[http://books.google.com/books?id=_s0daaaambaj&lpg=pp1&dq=baseball%20digest%201948&pg=pa2#v=onepage&q&f=false baseball digest, 1948, by charles j. doyle of the ''pittsburgh sun-telegraph''.]</ref>  kiner served as a u.s. navy pilot during world war ii.<ref>[http://bioproj.sabr.org/bioproj.cfm?a=v&v=a&bid=1066&pid=7516 baseball biography project page on kiner]</ref>

spohrer had his best season offensively in [[1930 boston braves season|1930]] when he posted a .361 [[on base percentage]], a .441 [[slugging percentage]] and led the braves with a .317 batting average in 112 games.<ref name=al spohrer statistics/> that season, a lively ball wound with special australian wool was used by major league baseball, resulting in a league batting average that was above .300 for the only time in baseball history.<ref name=hack wilson belted homers, hecklers with equal gusto>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/?id=3jadaaaambaj&pg=pa78&dq=hack+wilson+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=hack%20wilson%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=hack wilson belted homers, hecklers with equal gusto |author=holway, john |publisher=books.google.com |date=june 1996 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=28 february 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-almanac.com/hitting/hibavg4.shtml |title=league by league totals for batting average |publisher=baseball almanac |accessdate=1 march 2011 }}</ref> in {{by|1931}}, the national league introduced a new, heavier ball to counteract the prodigious offensive statistics of the previous year.<ref>{{cite news |title=national league changes ball to curtail slugging |agency=associated press |work=st. petersburg times |page=2 |date=4 february 1931 |accessdate=1 march 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=sstpaaaaibaj&sjid=2k0daaaaibaj&pg=6893,1920686&dq=hack+wilson&hl=en}}</ref> the raised stitching on the ball allowed pitchers to grip the ball better and throw sharper [[curveball]]s.<ref name=hack wilson belted homers, hecklers with equal gusto/>

in [[1914 boston braves season|1914]], hess was a member of the braves team that went from last place to first place in two months, becoming the first team to win a [[pennant (sports)|pennant]] after being in last place on the fourth of july.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=as0daaaambaj&pg=pa84&dq=hank+gowdy+baseball+digest&cd=3#v=onepage&q=hank%20gowdy%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''how losing an exhibition sparked miracle braves'', by joseph m. overfield, baseball digest, may 1961, vol. 20, no. 4, issn 0005-609x]</ref> he is the [[list of countries with their first major league player|first person born in switzerland to play]] major league baseball.

in [[1914 boston braves season|1914]], hess was a member of the braves team that went from last place to first place in two months, becoming the first team to win a [[pennant (sports)|pennant]] after being in last place on the fourth of july.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=as0daaaambaj&pg=pa84&dq=hank+gowdy+baseball+digest&cd=3#v=onepage&q=hank%20gowdy%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''how losing an exhibition sparked miracle braves'', by joseph m. overfield, baseball digest, may 1961, vol. 20, no. 4, issn 0005-609x]</ref> he is the [[list of countries with their first major league player|first person born in switzerland to play]] major league baseball.

braves pitcher [[johnny sain]] and indians pitcher, [[bob feller]] engaged in a scoreless pitchers' duel when the braves came to bat in the bottom of the eighth [[innings#baseball|inning]]. feller [[base on balls|walked]] braves catcher [[bill salkeld]] to open the inning. braves manager, [[billy southworth]] then substituted the slow-footed salkeld with [[phil masi]], who entered the game as a [[pinch runner]]. [[mike mccormick (outfielder)|mike mccormick]] followed by hitting a [[sacrifice bunt]], advancing masi to [[second base]]. feller issued an [[intentional walk]] to [[eddie stanky]], who was replaced by [[sibby sisti]]. feller then made a [[pick off]] attempt of masi at second base. indians' shortstop, [[lou boudreau]], appeared to tag masi [[out (baseball)|out]], but [[umpire (baseball)|umpire]] bill stewart called him [[safe (baseball)|safe]].<ref name=pickoff play caused a storm in 1948 series>{{cite magazine |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ozidaaaambaj&lpg=pa86&dq=phil%20masi%20baseball%20digest&pg=pa84#v=onepage&q=phil%20masi%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=pickoff play caused a storm in 1948 series |last=lebovitz |first=hal |volume=30 |issue=10 |pages=8486 |date={{#formatdate:october 1971}} |magazine=baseball digest |accessdate={{#formatdate:14 march 2011}} }}</ref> [[tommy holmes]] proceeded to hit a [[single (baseball)|single]] that allowed masi to score the only [[run (baseball)|run]] of the game, giving the braves a 10 victory.<ref name=game1/>

a native of [[charlotte amalie, u.s. virgin islands|charlotte amalie]], [[virgin islands]], hendricks was a superior defensive catcher and a very fine handler of [[pitcher]]s on a usually strong baltimore orioles rotation that included [[mike cuellar]], [[pat dobson]], [[dave mcnally]], [[jim palmer]] and [[tom phoebus]]. he also spent most of his playing for the orioles on teams that went to three consecutive [[world series]] from 1969–71, sharing duties with [[andy etchebarren]]. hendricks led american league catchers in [[fielding percentage]] in [[1969 baltimore orioles season|1969]] and [[1975 baltimore orioles season|1975]].<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa86&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, july 2001, p.86, vol. 60, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref>

mele was the nephew of major league baseball players [[tony cuccinello|tony]] and [[al cuccinello]], but did not play baseball until he attended [[william cullen bryant high school]].  the high school gave up baseball after his freshman year, but mele played with other local baseball teams.  mentored by his uncle tony, mele gained major league attention and worked out with several teams while still in high school.  after high school, mele attended [[new york university]].  in 1940, he broke his leg sliding into third base but, in 1941, he posted a [[batting average]] of .405, and in 1942, he hit .369.  he also excelled as a [[basketball]] player.  nyu basketball [[head coach]] [[howard cann]] called mele one of the finest players he ever coached.  in the summer of 1941, mele also played baseball for the [[burlington, vermont]] team of the [[northern league (baseball, 190271)|northern league]] where he made contact with the [[boston red sox]] and signed a five-figure contract.  but before he could join the sox, he first signed up for the [[united states marine corps]] in 1942 and was called in july 1943.  as part of the [[v-12 navy college training program]], mele played baseball for [[red rolfe]] at [[yale university]].  he was sent to the [[pacific ocean]] where he was able to play baseball with [[joe dimaggio]] and others.  mele led the navy league with a .358 average in 1944.  in 1946, after the marines, mele joined the red sox in [[sarasota, florida]] before being sent to the [[louisville colonels (minor league baseball)|louisville colonels]] and, later, the [[eastern league (baseball)|eastern league]] [[scranton red sox]].  mele won the eastern league [[most valuable player]] award, leading the league in average (.342), [[total bases]] and [[triple (baseball)|triple]]s.  the following year, the [[1947 boston red sox season|boston red sox]] went into spring with uncertainty at the [[right field]] position, but mele won the job with a 5-for-5 performance, and hit .302 for the season.  he also substituted well in [[center field]] when [[dom dimaggio]] was injured.<ref name=digest48>{{cite journal |last1=rumill |first1=ed |year=1948 |title=he hoops it up for the red sox now |journal=[[baseball digest]] |volume=7 |issue=3 |pages=1416 |publisher= |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=_s0daaaambaj&lpg=pp1&dq=baseball%20digest%201948&pg=pa14#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate=27 august 2011}}</ref>

'''lonas edgar bailey, jr.''' (april 15, 1931  march 23, 2007) was an american [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] player who played [[catcher]] in the [[major league baseball|major leagues]] from {{by|1953}} through {{by|1966}}.<ref name=ed bailey at baseball reference>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/b/baileed01.shtml ed bailey at baseball reference]</ref> bailey batted left-handed and threw right-handed. he was born in [[jefferson county, tennessee|strawberry plains, tennessee]]. a five-time [[major league baseball all-star game|all-star]], bailey was one of the top defensive catchers in the [[national league]] in the late 1950s and early 1960s.<ref name=''bailey- next catching great?''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=tswdaaaambaj&pg=pa49&dq=ed+bailey+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=9yautpite4gklwfxxpxada&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0ccgq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=ed%20bailey%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''bailey- next catching great?'', by bob pile, baseball digest, august 1956, vol. 15, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref>

* [http://books.google.com/books?id=tswdaaaambaj&pg=pa49&dq=ed+bailey+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=9yautpite4gklwfxxpxada&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0ccgq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=ed%20bailey%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''bailey- next catching great?'', by bob pile, baseball digest, august 1956]
