born in [[nitro, west virginia]], burdette was signed by the [[new york yankees]] in [[1947 new york yankees season|1947]], and after making two relief appearances for the team in september [[1950 new york yankees season|1950]], he was traded to the braves in august [[1951 boston braves season|1951]] for four-time 20-game winner [[johnny sain]].<ref name=lew burdette trades and transactions at baseball almanac>[http://www.baseball-almanac.com/players/trades.php?p=burdele01 lew burdette trades and transactions at baseball almanac]</ref> along with left-hander [[warren spahn]] and [[bob buhl]], he gave the braves one of the best starting rotations in the majors during the 1950s, [[win (baseball)|winning]] 15 or more games eight times between [[1953 milwaukee braves season|1953]] and [[1961 milwaukee braves season|1961]]. burdette led [[national league]] pitchers in [[earned run average]] in {{by|1956}}.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1956-pitching-leaders.shtml 1956 national league pitching leaders at baseball reference]</ref> when milwaukee won the 1957 world series against the [[1957 new york yankees season|yankees]], burdette became the first pitcher in 37 years to win three [[complete game]]s in a series, and the first since [[christy mathewson]] in [[1905 world series|1905]] to pitch two [[shutout]]s (games 5 and 7).<ref name=lew burdette obituary at the new york times>[http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9b01efdb103ff934a35751c0a9619c8b63 lew burdette obituary at the new york times] february 7, 2007</ref><ref name=''lew burdette: his moment of glory came in '57 series''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=ey4daaaambaj&pg=pa54&dq=lew+burdette+baseball+digest&cd=1#v=onepage&q=lew%20burdette%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''lew burdette: his moment of glory came in '57 series'', by lou chapman, baseball digest, october 1991, vol. 50, no. 10, issn 0005-609x]</ref> in the [[1958 world series|1958 series]], however, the [[1958 new york yankees season|yankees]] defeated burdette twice in three starts.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1958_ws.shtml 1958 world series at baseball reference]</ref> in addition to winning 20 games in {{by|1958}} and tying spahn for the national league lead with 21 victories in {{by|1959}}, burdette won 19 in [[1956 milwaukee braves season|1956]] and [[1960 milwaukee braves season|1960]], 18 in 1961, and 17 in [[1957 milwaukee braves season|1957]].<ref name=lew burdette at baseball reference/><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1959-pitching-leaders.shtml 1959 national league pitching leaders at baseball reference]</ref>

born in [[nitro, west virginia]], burdette was signed by the [[new york yankees]] in [[1947 new york yankees season|1947]], and after making two relief appearances for the team in september [[1950 new york yankees season|1950]], he was traded to the braves in august [[1951 boston braves season|1951]] for four-time 20-game winner [[johnny sain]].<ref name=lew burdette trades and transactions at baseball almanac>[http://www.baseball-almanac.com/players/trades.php?p=burdele01 lew burdette trades and transactions at baseball almanac]</ref> along with left-hander [[warren spahn]] and [[bob buhl]], he gave the braves one of the best starting rotations in the majors during the 1950s, [[win (baseball)|winning]] 15 or more games eight times between [[1953 milwaukee braves season|1953]] and [[1961 milwaukee braves season|1961]]. burdette led [[national league]] pitchers in [[earned run average]] in {{by|1956}}.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1956-pitching-leaders.shtml 1956 national league pitching leaders at baseball reference]</ref> when milwaukee won the 1957 world series against the [[1957 new york yankees season|yankees]], burdette became the first pitcher in 37 years to win three [[complete game]]s in a series, and the first since [[christy mathewson]] in [[1905 world series|1905]] to pitch two [[shutout]]s (games 5 and 7).<ref name=lew burdette obituary at the new york times>[http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9b01efdb103ff934a35751c0a9619c8b63 lew burdette obituary at the new york times] february 7, 2007</ref><ref name=''lew burdette: his moment of glory came in '57 series''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=ey4daaaambaj&pg=pa54&dq=lew+burdette+baseball+digest&cd=1#v=onepage&q=lew%20burdette%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''lew burdette: his moment of glory came in '57 series'', by lou chapman, baseball digest, october 1991, vol. 50, no. 10, issn 0005-609x]</ref> in the [[1958 world series|1958 series]], however, the [[1958 new york yankees season|yankees]] defeated burdette twice in three starts.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1958_ws.shtml 1958 world series at baseball reference]</ref> in addition to winning 20 games in {{by|1958}} and tying spahn for the national league lead with 21 victories in {{by|1959}}, burdette won 19 in [[1956 milwaukee braves season|1956]] and [[1960 milwaukee braves season|1960]], 18 in 1961, and 17 in [[1957 milwaukee braves season|1957]].<ref name=lew burdette at baseball reference/><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/nl/1959-pitching-leaders.shtml 1959 national league pitching leaders at baseball reference]</ref>

}}</ref> in 1892, a professional team in [[hastings, nebraska]] sent a railroad ticket to des moines semiprofessional player, byron mckibbon, but mckibbon backed out and gave the ticket to clarke instead.  clarke impressed the hastings team and he signed his first professional contract.<ref name=bbdigest1948>[http://books.google.com/books?id=_s0daaaambaj&lpg=pp1&dq=baseball%20digest%201948&pg=pa45#v=onepage&q&f=false baseball digest], 1948, by bill bryson of ''[[the des moines register]]''.</ref>  he was in the [[southern league (baseball)|southern league]] at age 21 and played for teams in [[montgomery, alabama]], and [[savannah, georgia]].<ref name=dmreg51 />

from august 25 to 27 at the boston red sox, demeter had game winning hits in all three, leading to a tigers sweep.<ref>{{cite news |title=demeter's hits sink bosox three successive games |work=[[the sporting news]] |last=claflin |first=larry |page=17 |date=12 september 1964}}</ref> in the september 7, 1964 issue of ''[[sports illustrated]]'', demeter was awarded with player of the week honors for his clutch play.<ref name=si>{{cite journal |last1=carry |first1=peter |date=7 september 1964 |title=player of the week |journal=[[sports illustrated]] |volume=21 |issue=10 |pages=124 |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=9dedaaaambaj&lpg=pa28&dq=don%20demeter%20baseball%20digest%201965&pg=pa28#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref>

in january 1965, demeter signed a new contract with the tigers for the amount of $30,000.<ref name=chop/> in late january, he joined manager dressen on an annual press-radio-television tour that went to toledo and outstate michigan.<ref>{{cite news |title=grieving horton renews pledge to reach goal |work=[[the sporting news]] |last=spoelstra |first=watson |page=10 |date=16 january 1965}}</ref> demeter was cited as the tigers most clutch hitter,<ref name=si/><ref>{{cite journal |last1=lewis |first1=allen |year=1965 |month=april |title=why the white sox and reds will win |journal=[[baseball digest]] |publisher=lakeside publishing company |volume=24 |issue=3 |pages=1953 |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=9dedaaaambaj&lpg=pa28&dq=don%20demeter%20baseball%20digest%201965&pg=pa28#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> but demeter still wasn't satisfied with his power output. he trained in oklahoma during the winter, chopping wood and gaining 12 pounds to 202.<ref name=chop/> on february 5 in tulsa, oklahoma, demeter was given the art griggs award given to oklahomans with the most outstanding performance at the major league level. he remarked, i would have to thank [[mickey mantle]] for moving out of the state, [[allie reynolds]] for retiring and [[warren spahn]] for just getting old.<ref>{{cite news |title=rickey speech stirs listeners at tulsa dinner |work=[[the sporting news]] |last=ferguson |first=john |page=16 |date=20 february 1965}}</ref>

from august 25 to 27 at the boston red sox, demeter had game-winning hits in all three, leading to a tigers sweep.<ref>{{cite news |title=demeter's hits sink bosox three successive games |work=[[the sporting news]] |last=claflin |first=larry |page=17 |date=12 september 1964}}</ref> in the september 7, 1964 issue of ''[[sports illustrated]]'', demeter was awarded with player of the week honors for his clutch play.<ref name=si>{{cite journal |last1=carry |first1=peter |date=7 september 1964 |title=player of the week |journal=[[sports illustrated]] |volume=21 |issue=10 |pages=124 |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=9dedaaaambaj&lpg=pa28&dq=don%20demeter%20baseball%20digest%201965&pg=pa28#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref>

this practice is believed to have contributed to chapman's death.  he was struck by a pitch by [[carl mays]] on august 16, 1920, in a game against the [[new york yankees]] at the [[polo grounds]].<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=miwdaaaambaj&pg=pa9&lpg=pa9&dq=chapman+mays+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=n_rjrvpk_q&sig=xks6butxlmmuhyw5wnoo6slgrk4&hl=en&ei=hrrvs4hsks2ptgeild2ebg&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0cagq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=chapman%20mays%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''carl mays: my pitch that killed chapman was a strike!'' by phyllis propert, baseball digest, july 1957, vol. 16, no. 6, issn 0005-609x]</ref> mays threw with a [[submarine (baseball)|submarine]] delivery, and it was the top of the fifth inning, in the late afternoon. eyewitnesses recounted that chapman never moved out of the way of the pitch, presumably unable to see the ball. chapman didn't react at all, said rod nelson of the society of american baseball research. it was at twilight and it froze him.<ref name=usatoday/>  the sound of the ball smashing into chapman's skull was so loud that mays thought it had hit the end of chapman's bat, so he fielded the ball and threw to first base. chapman died twelve hours later in a [[new york city]] hospital, at about 4:30 a.m.<ref>[http://www.nytimes.com/packages/html/sports/year_in_sports/08.17.html ''the death of ray chapman'', the new york times, august 17, 1920]</ref> he was replaced by [[harry lunte]] for the rest of the game.<ref name=boxscore>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/classic/s/quiz/5/21.html|title=classic box score: august 16, 1920|last=caple|first=jim|date=2001-05-21|publisher=espn.com|accessdate=2008-05-09}}</ref>

gibson was a fierce competitor who rarely smiled and was known to throw close, fast [[brushback pitch|inside pitches]] to let batters know who was in charge, similar to his contemporary and fellow hall of famer [[don drysdale]].<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=vzqdaaaambaj&pg=pa38&lpg=pa38&dq=bob+gibson+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=vaai44dxll&sig=yzirjeqkkipmiqxbn2ieqo9p7_g&hl=en&ei=vvtmsvspfcuttgeorntiaq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7#v=onepage&q=bob%20gibson%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''hall of famer defends inside pitches to batter'', by art spander, baseball digest, november 1987, vol. 46, no. 11, issn 0005-609x]</ref> even so, gibson had good control and hit only 102 batters in his career (fewer than drysdale's 154).<ref name=bob gibson at baseball reference>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/g/gibsobo01.shtml bob gibson at baseball reference]</ref> revered by st. louis baseball fans, gibson dominated with his fastball, sharp slider and a slow, looping curveball. he now resides in the [[omaha-council bluffs metropolitan area|omaha suburb]] of [[bellevue, nebraska|bellevue]] with his wife and son, and is a special instructor coach for the [[st. louis cardinals]].

* [http://books.google.com/books?id=vzqdaaaambaj&pg=pa38&lpg=pa38&dq=bob+gibson+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=vaai44dxll&sig=yzirjeqkkipmiqxbn2ieqo9p7_g&hl=en&ei=vvtmsvspfcuttgeorntiaq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7#v=onepage&q=bob%20gibson%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''hall of famer defends inside pitches to batter'', baseball digest, november 1987]

reese's nickname originated in his childhood, as he was a champion [[marbles]] player (a little pee wee is a small marble). reese was born in [[ekron, kentucky|ekron]], [[meade county, kentucky|meade county]], [[kentucky]], and raised there until he was nearly eight years old, when his family moved to [[racial segregation|racially segregated]] [[louisville, kentucky|louisville]].  in high school, reese was so small that he did not play baseball until senior year, at which time he weighed only 120 pounds and played just six games as a second baseman.<ref name=bbdigest1948>[http://books.google.com/books?id=_s0daaaambaj&lpg=pp1&dq=baseball%20digest%201948&pg=pa11#v=onepage&q&f=false baseball digest], 1948, by arthur daley of ''[[the new york times]]''.</ref> he graduated from [[dupont manual high school]] in 1937.{{citation needed|date=april 2011}}  he worked as a cable splicer for the louisville phone company, only playing amateur baseball in a church league.  when his team reached the league championship, the minor league [[louisville colonels (minor league baseball team)|louisville colonels]] allowed them to play the championship game on their field.  reese impressed colonels owner cap neal who signed him to a contract for a $200 bonus.<ref name=bbdigest1948 />

in the 1947-48 off-season, owner [[bill veeck]] signed recent [[st. louis browns]] manager [[muddy ruel]] as a [[coach (baseball)|coach]] to join [[manager (baseball)|manager]]/[[shortstop]] [[lou boudreau]] and coach [[bill mckechnie]] who was also a long-time manager.<ref name=bbdigest1948>[http://books.google.com/books?id=_s0daaaambaj&lpg=pp1&dq=baseball%20digest%201948&pg=pa62#v=onepage&q&f=false baseball digest], 1948, indians collect a brain trust by lyall smith of the ''[[detroit free press]]''.</ref>

in the 1947-48 off-season, owner [[bill veeck]] signed recent [[baltimore orioles|st. louis browns]] [[manager (baseball)|manager]] [[muddy ruel]] as a [[coach (baseball)|coach]] to join [[player-manager]] [[lou boudreau]] and coach [[bill mckechnie]], the latter who was also a long-time manager.<ref name=bbdigest1948>[http://books.google.com/books?id=_s0daaaambaj&lpg=pp1&dq=baseball%20digest%201948&pg=pa62#v=onepage&q&f=false baseball digest], 1948, indians collect a brain trust by lyall smith of the ''[[detroit free press]]''.</ref>

in [[1967 detroit tigers season|1967]], the tigers hired former major league pitcher, [[johnny sain]], as their pitching coach.<ref name=jim northrup recalls his playing days with tigers>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com.sa/books?id=_isdaaaambaj&lpg=pa64&dq=baseball%20digest%20johnny%20sain%20denny%20mclain&pg=pa64#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=jim northrup recalls his playing days with tigers |author=sargent, jim |publisher=|date=february 2004 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=24 december 2011 }}</ref> sain helped develop lolich's pitching skills and taught him the psychology of pitching.<ref name=the baseball biography project: mickey lolich/><ref name=jim northrup recalls his playing days with tigers/> the 1967 season was a memorable one due to the tight four-way pennant race between the tigers, the [[1967 boston red sox season|boston red sox]], the [[1967 minnesota twins season|minnesota twins]] and the [[1967 chicago white sox season|chicago white sox]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisgreatgame.com/1967.html |title=1967: the impossible dream |publisher=thisgreatgame.com |accessdate=25 december 2011}}</ref> the tigers remained in the pennant race until the final day of the season, finishing one game behind the red sox.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/al/1967.shtml |title=1967 american league team statistics and standings |publisher=baseball-reference.com |accessdate=22 december 2011}}</ref> lolich finished the season with a 14-14 record, but led the league with 6 [[shutout]]s.<ref name=mickey lolich statistics/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/al/1967-pitching-leaders.shtml |title=1967 american league pitching leaders |publisher=baseball-reference.com |accessdate=25 december 2011}}</ref>

in [[1967 detroit tigers season|1967]], the tigers hired former major league pitcher [[johnny sain]] as their pitching coach.<ref name=jim northrup recalls his playing days with tigers>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com.sa/books?id=_isdaaaambaj&lpg=pa64&dq=baseball%20digest%20johnny%20sain%20denny%20mclain&pg=pa64#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=jim northrup recalls his playing days with tigers |author=sargent, jim |publisher=|date=february 2004 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=24 december 2011 }}</ref> sain helped develop lolich's pitching skills and taught him psychological aspects of pitching.<ref name=the baseball biography project: mickey lolich/><ref name=jim northrup recalls his playing days with tigers/> the 1967 season was a memorable one for the tight four-way pennant race among the tigers, the [[1967 boston red sox season|boston red sox]], the [[1967 minnesota twins season|minnesota twins]] and the [[1967 chicago white sox season|chicago white sox]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisgreatgame.com/1967.html |title=1967: the impossible dream |publisher=thisgreatgame.com |accessdate=25 december 2011}}</ref> the tigers were in contention until the final day of the season, finishing one game behind the red sox.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/al/1967.shtml |title=1967 american league team statistics and standings |publisher=baseball-reference.com |accessdate=22 december 2011}}</ref> lolich again finished 14-14, but led the league in [[shutout]]s with six.<ref name=mickey lolich statistics/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/al/1967-pitching-leaders.shtml |title=1967 american league pitching leaders |publisher=baseball-reference.com |accessdate=25 december 2011}}</ref>

born in [[mahanoy city, pennsylvania]], dugan went directly from the [[college of the holy cross]] to the major leagues.<ref name=dugan jumps back>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=6bcdaaaambaj&pg=pa25&dq=joe+dugan+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=lf2atykmg4xwgqfwkywbbw&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0cegq6aewca#v=onepage&q=joe%20dugan%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=dugan jumps back |author=pollock, ed |publisher=books.google.com |date=november 1946 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=5 april 2011 }}</ref> he made his major league debut with [[connie mack (baseball)|connie mack's]] philadelphia athletics on july 5, [[1917 philadelphia athletics season|1917]]. dugan struggled as a hitter his first two years, batting only a combined .195, but in [[1919 philadelphia athletics season|1919]] he batted .271, and then the next year hit .322.<ref name=joe dugan statistics/> by {{by|1920}}, dugan was being cited as the best third baseman in the major leagues.<ref>{{cite news |title=dugan ranks as a star player |agency= |work=the norwalk hour |page=11 |date=10 september 1920 |accessdate=6 april 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=kn0vaaaaibaj&sjid=ht0faaaaibaj&pg=3934,5454820&dq=joe+dugan&hl=en}}</ref> he was moved permanently to third base in [[1921 philadelphia athletics season|1921]], and would be a steady .280-.300 hitter as well as a fine defensive third baseman for the rest of his career.

meyer was born in [[knoxville, tennessee]] to william and carrie meyer.  his father was born in [[baden]], [[germany]] and came to the united states at age 16 and operated a [[brewery]].  growing up, billy meyer's neighbor and classmate from grade school was madelon warters, who he eventually married.  meyer played baseball in grade school when his father bought him a catcher's glove to catch his older brother.  his hero was catcher [[johnny kling]].  meyer was a good student until high school when baseball became a primary focus, even resulting in a school suspension.  his father operated a brewery in [[smithton, pennsylvania]] for a time and the younger meyer worked there during vacation.  during [[sophomore]] year of high school, billy meyer was offered $75 per month to play catcher for a [[lakeland, florida]] team, but he was expected to inherit the brewery, so his father resisted the idea.  he went regardless, and played so well that a [[sanford, florida]] team offered him $175 per month to play for them.  he played for other florida teams and finally hit a championship-winning home run for [[gainesville, florida]].  when he returned to tennessee with $250, his father never protested against baseball again.<ref name=bbdigest1948>[http://books.google.com/books?id=_s0daaaambaj&lpg=pp1&dq=baseball%20digest%201948&pg=pa3#v=onepage&q&f=false baseball digest, 1948, by vince johnson from the ''pittsburgh post-gazette''.]</ref>

meyer was born in [[knoxville, tennessee]], to william and carrie meyer.  his father was born in [[baden]], [[germany]], came to the united states at age 16 and operated a [[brewery]].  he eventually married his neighbor and classmate from grade school, madelon warters.  he started playing baseball in grade school when his father bought him a catcher's glove to catch his older brother.  his hero was catcher [[johnny kling]].  he was a good student until high school when baseball became such a primary focus that it even resulted in a school suspension.  his father operated a brewery in [[smithton, pennsylvania]], for a time and the younger meyer worked there during vacation.  during his [[sophomore]] year of high school, billy meyer was offered $75 per month to catch for a [[lakeland, florida]], team, but he was expected to inherit the brewery so his father resisted the idea.  he went regardless, and played so well that a [[sanford, florida]], team offered him $175 per month to play for them.  he caught for other florida teams and finally hit a championship-winning home run for [[gainesville, florida]].  when he returned to tennessee with $250, his father never protested against baseball again.<ref name=bbdigest1948>[http://books.google.com/books?id=_s0daaaambaj&lpg=pp1&dq=baseball%20digest%201948&pg=pa3#v=onepage&q&f=false baseball digest, 1948, by vince johnson from the ''pittsburgh post-gazette''.]</ref>

pagliaroni was contracted by the boston red sox as an amateur [[free agent]] in [[1955 boston red sox season|1955]].<ref name=jim pagliaroni trades and transactions at baseball almanac>[http://www.baseball-almanac.com/players/trades.php?p=pagliji01 jim pagliaroni trades and transactions at baseball almanac]</ref> he was only 17 years old when he made his debut with the red sox that same year.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=ty0daaaambaj&pg=pa13&dq=jim+pagliaroni+baseball+digest&cd=3#v=onepage&q=jim%20pagliaroni%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest august 1997, vol. 56, no. 8, issn 0005-609x]</ref> he then spent the next few years playing in the [[minor league baseball|minor leagues]] before returning to the red sox in [[1960 boston red sox season|1960]], where he played as backup to [[russ nixon]]. by the [[1961 boston red sox season|1961]] season, pagliaroni had taken over as the starting catcher. pagliaroni was the red sox catcher on june 18, 1961, when the team rallied from eight runs down with two [[out (baseball)|outs]] in the ninth [[inning]] to defeat the [[1961 washington senators season|washington senators]].<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/bos/bos196106181.shtml june 18, 1961, senators-red sox box score at baseball reference]</ref> pagliaroni hit a [[grand slam (baseball)|grand slam]] to tie the game.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=ic4daaaambaj&pg=pa12&dq=jim+pagliaroni+baseball+digest&cd=1#v=onepage&q=&f=false baseball digest october 1999, vol. 58, no. 10, issn 0005-609x]</ref>

over his 11-year career, pagliaroni played in 849 [[games played|games]], accumulating 622 [[hit (baseball)|hits]] in 2,465 [[at bats]] for a .252 career [[batting average]], along with 90 home runs, 326 [[runs batted in]] and a career [[fielding percentage]] of .991.<ref name=jim pagliaroni at baseball reference/> he led national league catchers with a .997 fielding percentage in [[1966 pittsburgh pirates season|1966]], committing only two [[error (baseball)|errors]] in 118 games.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa86&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, july 2001, vol. 60, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref> pagliaroni caught two [[no-hitter]]s during his career ([[bill monbouquette]] in 1962, [[catfish hunter]]'s [[perfect game]] in [[1968 oakland athletics season|1968]]).<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/cha/cha196208010.shtml august 1, 1962, white sox-red sox box score at baseball reference]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/oak/oak196805080.shtml may 8, 1968, twins-athletics box score at baseball reference]</ref>

in [[1951 chicago white sox season|1951]], carrasquel broke an american league record by accepting 297 [[total chances|chances]] without an [[error (baseball)|error]] in 53 [[games played]]. his most productive season came in [[1954 chicago white sox season|1954]], when he posted career-highs in [[home run]]s (12), [[run batted in|rbi]] (62), [[hit (baseball)|hits]] (158), [[run (baseball)|runs]] (106), [[extra-base hit|extrabases]] (43), [[base on balls|walks]] (85), and led the league in [[games played]], [[plate appearances]] and double plays while hitting for a .255 batting average.<ref name=chico carrasquel at baseball reference/><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=zswdaaaambaj&pg=pa9&dq=chico+carrasquel+baseball+digest&hl=en&ei=eibys9hblibglqeityckdq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0ccoq6aewaq#v=onepage&q=chico%20carrasquel%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, january 1956, vol. 15, no. 1, issn 0005-609x]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/al/1954-batting-leaders.shtml 1954 american league batting leaders at baseball reference]</ref>

in a 10-season career, carrasquel was a .258 hitter (1199-for-4644) with 55 home runs and 474 rbi in 1325 games, including 568 runs, 172 [[double (baseball)|doubles]], 25 [[triple (baseball)|triples]], 31 [[stolen base]]s, and a .333 [[on-base percentage]].<ref name=chico carrasquel at baseball reference/> a disciplined hitter, he posted a solid 1.052 [[walk-to-strikeout ratio]] (491-to-467).<ref name=chico carrasquel at baseball reference/> carrasquel led the american league in [[assist (baseball)|assists]] in 1951, and he led american league shortstops in [[fielding percentage]] in 1951, 1953 and 1954.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa86&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false baseball digest, july 2001, p.86, vol. 60, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/al/1951-fielding-leaders.shtml 1951 american league fielding leaders at baseball reference]</ref>

during [[spring training]] in [[1954 chicago white sox season|1954]], it was reported that white sox manager [[paul richards (baseball)|paul richards]] was not pleased with carrasquel's lack of effort on the field.<ref>{{cite news |title=white sox hope platoon system will win flag |agency=united press international |work=warsaw times union |page=5 |date=1 april 1954 |accessdate=23 march 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=wfbgaaaaibaj&sjid=xhomaaaaibaj&pg=5921,3148285&dq=chico+carrasquel&hl=en}}</ref> it was a charge that would continue to pursue carrasquel for the remainder of his tenure with the white sox. carrasquel responded with his most productive season in {{by|1954}} when, he was voted to make his third start as the american league shortstop in the [[1954 major league baseball all-star game|1954 all-star game]] and, posted career-highs in [[home run]]s (12), [[run batted in|rbi]] (62), [[hit (baseball)|hits]] (158), [[run (baseball)|runs]] (106), [[extra-base hit]]s (43), [[base on balls|walks]] (85).<ref name=chico carrasquel at baseball reference/> batting as the white sox [[leadoff hitter]], he led the league in [[games played]] and in [[plate appearances]] while hitting for a .255 batting average.<ref name=chico carrasquel at baseball reference/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/als/als195407130.shtml |title=1954 all-star game |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=23 march 2011 }}</ref> defensively, he led the league's shortstops in double plays and in fielding percentage.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=zswdaaaambaj&pg=pa9&dq=chico+carrasquel+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=chico%20carrasquel%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=two right views on chico's squat |author=mcauley, ed |publisher=|date=january 1956 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=26 march 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/al/1954-fielding-leaders.shtml during [[spring training]] in [[1954 chicago white sox season|1954]], it was reported that white sox manager [[paul richards (baseball)|paul richards]] was not pleased with carrasquel's lack of effort on the field.<ref>{{cite news |title=white sox hope platoon system will win flag |agency=united press international |work=warsaw times union |page=5 |date=1 april 1954 |accessdate=23 march 2011 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=wfbgaaaaibaj&sjid=xhomaaaaibaj&pg=5921,3148285&dq=chico+carrasquel&hl=en}}</ref> it was a charge that would continue to pursue carrasquel for the remainder of his tenure with the white sox. carrasquel responded with his most productive season in {{by|1954}} when, he was voted to make his third start as the american league shortstop in the [[1954 major league baseball all-star game|1954 all-star game]] and, posted career-highs in [[home run]]s (12), [[run batted in|rbi]] (62), [[hit (baseball)|hits]] (158), [[run (baseball)|runs]] (106), [[extra-base hit]]s (43), [[base on balls|walks]] (85).<ref name=chico carrasquel at baseball reference/> batting as the white sox [[leadoff hitter]], he led the league in [[games played]] and in [[plate appearances]] while hitting for a .255 batting average.<ref name=chico carrasquel at baseball reference/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/als/als195407130.shtml |title=1954 all-star game |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=23 march 2011 }}</ref> defensively, he led the league's shortstops in double plays and in fielding percentage.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=zswdaaaambaj&pg=pa9&dq=chico+carrasquel+baseball+digest#v=onepage&q=chico%20carrasquel%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=two right views on chico's squat |author=mcauley, ed |publisher=|date=january 1956 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=26 march 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/al/1954-fielding-leaders.shtml |title=1954 american league fielding leaders |publisher=baseball reference |accessdate=26 march 2011 }}</ref>

while sullivan was not a very good hitter, it was his performance as a fielder that garnered him high praise from his peers. [[ty cobb]], hall of fame outfielder of the detroit tigers and former all-time major league leader in stolen bases, once described him as the hardest catcher on which to attempt a steal.<ref>{{citation |first1=ty | last1=cobb |first2=al | last2=stump | year=1961 |title=my life in baseball: the true record |publisher=university of nebraska press |isbn=9780803263598 |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=opsjqb-l9xic&pg=pa171&dq=billy+sullivan+baseball&hl=en&ei=yt7htvpzmuajmqxtycqz&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0cfqq6aewcdgk#v=onepage&q&f=false |quote=}}</ref> sullivan's reputation as a defensive stand out is enhanced because of the era in which he played. in the [[deadball era]], catchers played a huge defensive role, given the large number of [[bunt (baseball)|bunt]]s and stolen base attempts, as well as the difficulty of handling the [[spitball]] pitchers who dominated pitching staffs.<ref name=for catchers, the name of the game is defense>{{cite web |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=9s0daaaambaj&pg=pa26&dq=baseball+digest+defensive+catchers#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20defensive%20catchers&f=false |title=for catchers, the name of the game is defense |author=vass, george |publisher=books.google.com |date=may 2005 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=23 august 2010 }}</ref> he had to catch every type of [[pitch (baseball)|pitch]] imaginable, such as shine balls, spitballs, [[knuckleball]]s, and emory balls.<ref name=for catchers, the name of the game is defense/>

'''michael scott matheny''' (born september 22, 1970) is an american former [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] player and the current [[manager (baseball)|manager]] of the [[st. louis cardinals]].<ref name=mike matheny statistics>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/m/mathemi01.shtml |title=mike matheny statistics |publisher=baseball-reference.com |accessdate=12 january 2012}}</ref> he played in [[major league baseball]] as a [[catcher]] for four different teams during his thirteen year playing career. although matheny wasn't a good hitter, he was considered one of the best defensive catchers of his era, winning four national league [[gold glove awards]].<ref name=for catchers, the name of the game is defense>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=9s0daaaambaj&pg=pa26&dq=baseball+digest+defensive+catchers#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20defensive%20catchers&f=false |title=for catchers, the name of the game is defense |author=vass, george |publisher=|date=may 2005 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=12 january 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/mag1111481/index.htm |title=sports illustrated players' poll: who is the best defensive catcher in the major leagues? |publisher=sportsillustrated.cnn.com |accessdate=3 april 2012}}</ref> he is one of only three catchers in major league history to catch at least 100 games in a single season without committing an [[error (baseball)|error]].<ref name=giants catcher mike matheny announces retirement>{{cite web|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/news/press_releases/press_release.jsp?ymd=20070201&content_id=1792021&vkey=pr_sf&fext=.jsp&c_id=sf |title=giants catcher mike matheny announces retirement |publisher=mlb.com |accessdate=4 april 2012}}</ref>

'''michael scott matheny''' (born september 22, 1970) is an american former [[professional baseball|professional]] [[baseball]] player and the current [[manager (baseball)|manager]] of the [[st. louis cardinals]].<ref name=mike matheny statistics>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/m/mathemi01.shtml |title=mike matheny statistics |publisher=baseball-reference.com |accessdate=12 january 2012}}</ref><ref name=matheny bio>{{cite web |url=http://stlouis.cardinals.mlb.com/team/coach_staff_bio.jsp?c_id=stl&coachorstaffid=118414 |title=managers and coaches: mike matheny |publisher=stlous.cardinals.mlb.com |accessdate=august 17, 2013}}</ref> he played in [[major league baseball]] as a [[catcher]] for four different teams during his thirteen-year playing career. not a prodigious hitter, he was considered one of the best defensive catchers of his era, winning four national league [[gold glove awards]]<ref name=for catchers, the name of the game is defense>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=9s0daaaambaj&pg=pa26&dq=baseball+digest+defensive+catchers#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20defensive%20catchers&f=false |title=for catchers, the name of the game is defense |author=vass, george |publisher=|date=may 2005 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=12 january 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/mag1111481/index.htm |title=sports illustrated players' poll: who is the best defensive catcher in the major leagues? |publisher=sportsillustrated.cnn.com |accessdate=3 april 2012}}</ref> and becoming one of only three major league catchers to catch at least 100 games in a single season without committing an [[error (baseball)|error]].<ref name=giants catcher mike matheny announces retirement>{{cite web|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/news/press_releases/press_release.jsp?ymd=20070201&content_id=1792021&vkey=pr_sf&fext=.jsp&c_id=sf |title=giants catcher mike matheny announces retirement |publisher=mlb.com |accessdate=4 april 2012}}</ref>

dobernic was born in a [[yugoslavia]]n family in [[mount olive, illinois]].  his first organized baseball was for [[rayne, louisiana]] in the [[evangeline baseball league]] in 1937.  for the next four years, he was in the [[chicago white sox]] system including the [[st. paul saints]], [[waterloo hawks (baseball)|waterloo hawks]] and the major league team.  but difficulty controlling his pitches largely kept him out of the major leagues.  during [[world war ii]], he spent three years in the [[united states army air forces]] including [[africa]] and [[italy]].  he returned in the summer of 1945 and pitched for an army team in [[texas]], winning 19 consecutive games despite his continued wild pitching.  [[lee grissom]] and [[burgess whitehead]] suggested changes in his pitching style which helped, and his [[los angeles angels (pcl)|los angeles angels]] [[manager (baseball)|manager]] [[bill sweeney (first baseman)|bill sweeney]] made him a [[relief pitcher]].  in a 1945 game against the [[san francisco seals (baseball)|san francisco seals]], dobernic entered the game with the [[bases loaded]] and none [[out (baseball)|out]] in the 1st [[inning]] and pitched nine innings while allowing no [[hit (baseball)|hit]]s.  in 1947, new angels manager [[bill kelly (first baseman)|bill kelly]] credited dobernic with saving 26 games and said the angels would have finished in the [[second division (baseball)|second division]] rather than winning the [[pacific coast league]] championship.  excluding two poor games, dobernic had a 2.93 [[earned run average]] in 1947.<ref name=bbdigest1948>[http://books.google.com/books?id=_s0daaaambaj&lpg=pp1&dq=baseball%20digest%201948&pg=pa21#v=onepage&q&f=false baseball digest], 1948, by [[dick hyland]] of the ''[[los angeles times]]''.</ref>

in 13 seasons, rosar played in 988 [[games played|games]], with 836 [[hit (baseball)|hits]] for a .261 career [[batting average]], along with 18 [[home run]]s and 367 [[runs batted in]].<ref name=buddy rosar/> despite his relatively low offensive statistics, rosar's defensive skills earned him a place on the american league [[major league baseball all-star game|all-star team]] five times during his career.<ref name=buddy rosar/> he caught two [[no hitter]] games in his career, pitched by [[dick fowler]] in [[1945 philadelphia athletics season|1945]], and [[bill mccahan]] in [[1947 philadelphia athletics season|1947]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://members.tripod.com/bb_catchers/catchers/catchnoh.htm |title=catchers who caught no hitters |publisher=the encyclopedia of baseball catchers |accessdate=9 november 2010 }}</ref> rosar led all american league catchers in fielding percentage four years (1944, 19461948).<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=lssdaaaambaj&pg=pa86&dq=july+2001+fielding+leaders+baseball+digest&cd=4#v=onepage&q=july%202001%20fielding%20leaders%20baseball%20digest&f=false |title=fielding leaders |publisher=books.google.com |date=july 2001 |work=baseball digest |accessdate=9 november 2010 }}</ref> he also led the league three times in assists, twice in baserunners caught stealing and once in caught stealing percentage.<ref name=buddy rosar/> rosar has the best ratio of [[double plays]] to [[error (baseball)|errors]] of any catcher in major league history.<ref>{{cite book | url = http://books.google.com/books?id=muztj4-8n0ec | title = the new bill james historical baseball abstract | first = bill |last = james |publisher = simon and schuster |year = 2003 | isbn = 0-7432-2722-0 }}</ref> rosar holds the 20th century career record for fewest [[passed ball]]s per games caught (0.0300) with only 28 miscues in 934 games as catcher.<ref name=buddy rosar at the encyclopedia of catchers/> at the time of his retirement in [[1951 boston red sox season|1951]], rosar's .992 career fielding percentage was the highest for a catcher in major league history.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://members.tripod.com/bb_catchers/catchers/8cfldfld.htm |title=catchers career fielding percentages |publisher=the encyclopedia of baseball catchers |accessdate=9 november 2010 }}</ref>

in {{mlby|1969}}, santo and [[1969 chicago cubs season|the cubs]] were in first place in the [[national league east]] for 156 days, before going 9-17 in their final 25 games, while the [[1969 new york mets season|new york miracle mets]] went 37-11 in their final 48 games.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=3sodaaaambaj&pg=pa66&dq=baseball+digest+ron+santo#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20ron%20santo&f=false ''ron santo: a hall of fame plaque in his future?'' by bill dray, baseball digest, july 1992, vol. 51, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref> during that season, the cubs sent their entire starting [[infielder|infield]], including santo, to the [[1969 major league baseball all-star game|all-star game]] in [[washington, d.c.]]; he and cubs shortstop [[don kessinger]] started for the national league team.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/als/als196907230.shtml 1969 all-star game at baseball reference]</ref> santo finished the season with a .289 [[batting average]], 29 [[home run]]s and a career-high 123 [[runs batted in]] (rbi), and finished fifth in the national league most valuable player voting.<ref name=ron santo at baseball reference/><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1969.shtml#nlmvp 1969 most valuable player award voting results at baseball reference]</ref>

in 1969, santo and [[1969 chicago cubs season|the cubs]] were in first place in the [[national league east]] for 156 days, before going 8-17 in their final 25 games, while the [[1969 new york mets season|new york miracle mets]] went 37-11 in their final 48 games.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=3sodaaaambaj&pg=pa66&dq=baseball+digest+ron+santo#v=onepage&q=baseball%20digest%20ron%20santo&f=false ''ron santo: a hall of fame plaque in his future?'' by bill dray, baseball digest, july 1992, vol. 51, no. 7, issn 0005-609x]</ref> during that season, the cubs sent their entire starting [[infielder|infield]], including santo, to the [[1969 major league baseball all-star game|all-star game]] in washington, d.c.; he and cubs shortstop [[don kessinger]] started for the national league team.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/als/als196907230.shtml 1969 all-star game at baseball reference]</ref> santo finished the season with a .289 [[batting average]], 29 [[home run]]s and a career-high 123 [[runs batted in]] (rbi), and finished fifth in the national league most valuable player voting.<ref name=ron santo at baseball reference/><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/awards_1969.shtml#nlmvp 1969 most valuable player award voting results at baseball reference]</ref>

he was acquired by the [[los angeles dodgers|brooklyn dodgers]] from the pirates midway through the {{by|1947}} season and he is most famous for his heroic [[catch (baseball)|catch]] of a [[line drive|drive]] off the [[baseball bat|bat]] of the [[new york yankee]]'s [[joe dimaggio]] in game 6 of the [[1947 world series]].<ref name=''gionfriddo recalls his famous catch''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=2tedaaaambaj&pg=pa70&lpg=pa70&dq=al+gionfriddo+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=dnd4vgoaqp&sig=sdbm9rvlkbvaku0dpgxohf648re&hl=en&ei=ljnmsoocoomxtge8tyhpaq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1#v=onepage&q=al%20gionfriddo%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''gionfriddo recalls his famous catch'' by dave distel, baseball digest, february 1973, vol. 32, no. 2, issn 0005-609x]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1947_ws.shtml 1947 world series at baseball reference]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/nya/nya194710050.shtml 1947 world series game 6 at baseball reference]</ref> the dodgers led the yankees 8-5 going into the bottom of the 6th [[inning]] when gionfriddo was brought in as a defensive replacement. [[snuffy stirnweiss]] and [[yogi berra]] were on base when dimaggio drove the ball to the 415 marker. gionfriddo raced across the field and reached over the [[baseball field|fence]] to catch the ball. in one of the most famous images in baseball history, the taciturn dimaggio shook his head and kicked at the dirt in frustration.

* [http://books.google.com/books?id=2tedaaaambaj&pg=pa70&lpg=pa70&dq=al+gionfriddo+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=dnd4vgoaqp&sig=sdbm9rvlkbvaku0dpgxohf648re&hl=en&ei=ljnmsoocoomxtge8tyhpaq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1#v=onepage&q=al%20gionfriddo%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''gionfriddo recalls his famous catch'' in baseball digest, february 1973]

he was acquired by the [[los angeles dodgers|brooklyn dodgers]] from the pirates midway through the {{by|1947}} season, and he is most famous for his heroic [[catch (baseball)|catch]] of a [[line drive|drive]] off the [[baseball bat|bat]] of the [[new york yankee]]'s [[joe dimaggio]] in game 6 of the [[1947 world series]].<ref name=''gionfriddo recalls his famous catch''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=2tedaaaambaj&pg=pa70&lpg=pa70&dq=al+gionfriddo+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=dnd4vgoaqp&sig=sdbm9rvlkbvaku0dpgxohf648re&hl=en&ei=ljnmsoocoomxtge8tyhpaq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1#v=onepage&q=al%20gionfriddo%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''gionfriddo recalls his famous catch'' by dave distel, baseball digest, february 1973, vol. 32, no. 2, issn 0005-609x]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1947_ws.shtml 1947 world series at baseball reference]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/nya/nya194710050.shtml 1947 world series game 6 at baseball reference]</ref> the dodgers led the yankees 8-5 going into the bottom of the 6th [[inning]] when gionfriddo was brought in as a defensive replacement. [[snuffy stirnweiss]] and [[yogi berra]] were on base when dimaggio drove the ball to the 415 marker. gionfriddo raced across the field and reached over the [[baseball field|fence]] to catch the ball. in one of the most famous images in baseball history, the taciturn dimaggio shook his head and kicked at the dirt in frustration.

*[http://books.google.com/books?id=2tedaaaambaj&pg=pa70&lpg=pa70&dq=al+gionfriddo+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=dnd4vgoaqp&sig=sdbm9rvlkbvaku0dpgxohf648re&hl=en&ei=ljnmsoocoomxtge8tyhpaq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1#v=onepage&q=al%20gionfriddo%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''gionfriddo recalls his famous catch''  baseball digest, february 1973]

he was acquired by the [[los angeles dodgers|brooklyn dodgers]] from the pirates midway through the {{by|1947}} season, and he is most famous for his heroic [[catch (baseball)|catch]] of a [[line drive|drive]] off the [[baseball bat|bat]] of the [[new york yankee]]'s [[joe dimaggio]] in game 6 of the [[1947 world series]].<ref name=''gionfriddo recalls his famous catch''>[http://books.google.com/books?id=2tedaaaambaj&pg=pa70&lpg=pa70&dq=al+gionfriddo+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=dnd4vgoaqp&sig=sdbm9rvlkbvaku0dpgxohf648re&hl=en&ei=ljnmsoocoomxtge8tyhpaq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1#v=onepage&q=al%20gionfriddo%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''gionfriddo recalls his famous catch'' by dave distel, baseball digest, february 1973, vol. 32, no. 2, issn 0005-609x]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1947_ws.shtml 1947 world series at baseball reference]</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/nya/nya194710050.shtml 1947 world series game 6 at baseball reference]</ref> the dodgers led the yankees 8-5 going into the bottom of the 6th [[inning]] when gionfriddo was brought in as a defensive replacement. [[snuffy stirnweiss]] and [[yogi berra]] were on base when dimaggio drove the ball to the 415 marker. gionfriddo raced across the field and caught the ball several steps before crashing into the bullpen gate. in one of the most famous images in baseball history, the taciturn dimaggio shook his head and kicked at the dirt in frustration. at the time, there was no instant replay, and gionfriddo was widely believed to have robbed dimaggio of a home run. however, the game film, when developed later, clearly showed gionfriddo catching the ball several steps shy of the wall, and thus actually robbing dimaggio of a double or triple instead of a home run. still photos of the catch contributed to the misconception that it was a potential home run, since the images showed gionfriddo with his glove behind the bullpen gate, and the ball inside the glove. however, these photos were taken several seconds after the play, when gionfriddo's momentum had carried his arm over the gate.<ref>enders, eric. ''the fall classic: the definitive history of the world series''. new york: sterling, 2007.</ref>

*[http://books.google.com/books?id=2tedaaaambaj&pg=pa70&lpg=pa70&dq=al+gionfriddo+baseball+digest&source=bl&ots=dnd4vgoaqp&sig=sdbm9rvlkbvaku0dpgxohf648re&hl=en&ei=ljnmsoocoomxtge8tyhpaq&sa=x&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1#v=onepage&q=al%20gionfriddo%20baseball%20digest&f=false ''gionfriddo recalls his famous catch''  baseball digest, february 1973]

[[snuffy stirnweiss]] and [[yogi berra]] were on base when dimaggio drove the ball to the 415 marker. gionfriddo raced across the field and caught the ball several steps before crashing into the bullpen gate. in one of the most famous images in baseball history, the taciturn dimaggio shook his head and kicked at the dirt in frustration. at the time, there was no instant replay, and gionfriddo was widely believed to have robbed dimaggio of a home run. however, the game film, when developed later, clearly showed gionfriddo catching the ball several steps shy of the wall, and thus actually robbing dimaggio of a double or triple instead of a home run. still photos of the catch contributed to the misconception that it was a potential home run, since the images showed gionfriddo with his glove behind the bullpen gate, and the ball inside the glove. however, these photos were taken several seconds after the play, when gionfriddo's momentum had carried his arm over the gate.<ref>enders, eric. ''the fall classic: the definitive history of the world series''. new york: sterling, 2007.</ref>
